Succession — Will — Execution — Allegation of senility — Whether deceased had the necessary testamentary capacity while executing his will — Who bears burden of proving righteousness of transaction and document propounded to be will of deceased

Succession — Executors — Discharge of — Whether there was due and proper administration of estate — Whether executors were proper persons to look after interests of the estate and beneficiaries as a whole — Whether estate if left in executors' hands would probably be loaded and rendered of little value — Whether executors ought to be discharged

p.text: The deceased was a man of great wealth and possessed various properties both locally and overseas. The paintiffs and the defendants are his children and grandchildren. The action concerns wills purportedly executed by the deceased over his real and personal property in Malaysia, Thailand and US. The plaintiffs propounded three wills dated 24�October 1990 ('1990 wills') as the last will of the deceased. The first, second and third defendants — the latter two being the first defendant's sons — ('the first to third defendants') conceded that the 1990 wills were true wills of the deceased; however, they propounded three wills dated 3 August 1992 ('1992 wills') — purportedly prepared by the third defendant — as the last will of the deceased. The fourth and fifth defendants — a father and adopted daughter team — who claimed that there were no true wills, propounded the intestacy of the deceased. The plaintiffs claimed as well, inter alia, for the return or restitution of substantial properties and including a piece of land ('the Teluk Bahang land') the first to third defendants allegedly extruded and peculated in the last year of the deceased's life and for the removal of the first to third defendants as executors and trustees of the estate. The first to third defendants submitted that all such properties were gifts from the deceased to them. At the trial, the first defendant chose not to give evidence from the witness box. It was argued, inter alia, that the deceased, at the time of the execution of the 1992 wills was senile and thus lacked the necessary testamentary capacity to make a will. It was also submitted that the deceased was coerced and/or unduly influenced to make the gifts and 1992 wills. The deceased was, up to the last few days before his death, staying with the first defendant's family.

Held , pronouncing the force and validity of the last will and testament dated 24 October 1990; ordering the transfer of the Teluk Bahang land to the executors and trustees of the estate, and the return of properties received by the first to third defendants purportedly as gifts from the deceased; and discharging the first and second defendants as executors and trustees of the estate:

There was no evidence at all that the deceased understood that he was signing a transfer of the Teluk Bahang land to the first defendant. The deceased in the position he was — in relation to the first defendant and his family — ought to have been in full view of what he was doing. But there was no evidence at all that care and providence had been taken by the first defendant to ensure that the deceased was put in possession of all material facts and information so as to enable the deceased to decide freely what he wanted to do with the Teluk Bahang land. By keeping silent, the first defendant had actively concealed the material facts and thus committed dishonesty against his siblings if not against the deceased. There was also no evidence to rebut the inference that the first defendant's testimony if given would have been unfavourable to the asserted gift of the Teluk Bahang land (see p 596F-H, I).

The first defendant and his family — who stood in such a relationship that while its continued confidence was necessarily reposed by the deceased and influence possessed by the first defendant and his family — were called upon to act with good faith and they had the burden of proving that the gifts were not brought about by undue influence. And they — who bears the burden of proof of absence of undue influence — failed to show that the transactions were fair and reasonable, that no advantage had been taken of his position and that no information which should have been communicated had been withheld. They failed to dispel bad faith. Undue influence, that proved as well as presumed, was not rebutted (see p 606B-D).

The circumstances attending the execution of the 1992 wills were that suspicious that even if undue influence was not proved, but it was, the court is not satisfied as to the righteousness of the transaction. The third defendant who prepared the wills under which he and his family took their extraordinary bounty and assumed all power failed to substantiate the truth, honesty and righteousness of the 1992 wills. He failed to give clear proof that the deceased knew and approved of that part under which he and his family took their extraordinary benefits. Therefore, 1992 wills purporting to be executed by the deceased have no validity whatsoever and cannot be admitted to probate (see p 616G-I). Moreover, there was non compliance with
s 5
of the Wills Act 1959 resulting in the due execution of the wills not being proved.

All things considered, it must be deduced that the deceased understood and approved the provisions of the 1990 wills. The plaintiffs who propounded the 1990 wills had discharged the burden of showing the righteousness of the transaction and that the document propounded expressed the true last will of the deceased. This means that the 1990 wills are the true last wills of the deceased and can be admitted to probate (see p 628G).

There was no due and proper administration of the estate. Truly, the first to second defendants had disqualified themselves by their conduct from continuing the office. Their neglect of duty or inaccuracy of conduct, their acts or omissions showed a want of proper capacity to execute the duties. Judging by the events from June 1992, it could be fairly said that the estate if left in their hands would probably be loaded and rendered of little value (see p 635D-F).

Si mati adalah seorang yang kaya dan memiliki banyak harta di dalam dan di luar negeri. Plaintif-plaintif dan defendan-defendan adalah anak-anak dan cucu-cucunya. Tindakan ini adalah berkaitan dengan wasiat yang kononnya dilaksanakan oleh si mati atas harta tanah dan harta alihnya di Malaysia, Thailand dan US. Plaintif-plaintif mengemukakan tiga wasiat bertarikh 24 Oktober 1990 ('wasiat 1990') wasiat terakhir si mati. Defendan pertama, kedua dan ketiga — defendan kedua dan ketiga adalah anak-anak lelaki defendan pertama — ('defendan pertama hingga ketiga') bersetuju bahawa wasiat 1990 adalah wasiat sebenar si mati; tetapi, mengemukakan tiga wasiat bertarikh 3 Ogos 1992 ('wasiat 1992') — yang kononnya disediakan oleh defendan ketiga — sebagai wasiat terakhir si mati. Defendan keempat dan kelima — seorang ayah dan anak angkat perempuan — yang menuntut bahawa tidak ada wasiat yang sebenarnya, mengemukakan kematian tak berwasiat si mati. Plaintif-plaintif juga menuntut, antara lain, untuk pengembalian atau restitusi sebahagian besar harta dan termasuk sebidang tanah ('tanah Teluk Bahang') mana defendan pertama hingga ketiga dikatakan telah melesapkan pada tahun terakhir kehidupan si mati dan pembuangan defendan pertama hingga ketiga sebagai wasi-wasi dan pemegang-pemegang amanah harta pusaka itu. Defendan pertama hingga ketiga berhujah bahawa semua harta itu merupakan alang daripada si mati kepada mereka. Pada masa perbicaraan defendan pertama memilih untuk tidak memberi keterangan daripada petak saksi. Adalah dihujahkan, antara lain, bahawa si mati, pada masa pelaksanaan wasiat 1992 adalah nyanyuk dan dengan itu tidak mempunyai keupayaan perwasiatan yang perlu untuk membuat wasiat. Adalah juga dihujahkan bahawa si mati dipaksa dan/atau telah dipengaruh secara tidak wajar untuk membuat alang dan wasiat 1992. Si mati tinggal bersama keluarga defendan pertama hingga beberapa hari sebelum kematiannya.

Diputuskan , mengisytiharkan penguatkuasaan dan kesahan wasiat terakhir bertarikh 24 Oktober 1990; memerintahkan pindahmilik tanah Teluk Bahang kepada wasi-wasi dan pemegang-pemegang amanah harta pusaka, dan pengembalian harta-harta yang kononnya diterima oleh defendan pertama hingga ketiga sebagai alang daripada si mati; dan melepaskan defendan pertama dan kedua sebagai wasi-wasi dan pemegang-pemegang amanah harta pusaka:

Tidak ada bukti langsung bahawa si mati faham yang dia menandatangani pindahmilik tanah Teluk Bahang kepada defendan pertama. Si mati dalam keadaannya yang demikian — berhubung dengan defendan pertama dan keluarganya — sepatutnya mengetahui sepenuhnya tentang apa yang dilakukannya. Tetapi tidak ada bukti langsung bahawa defendan pertama telah mengambil perhatian untuk memastikan bahawa si mati mengetahui semua fakta-fakta dan maklumat yang material supaya si mati dapat membuat keputusan dengan bebas apa yang dia hendak buat dengan tanah di Teluk Bahang. Dengan berdiam diri, defendan pertama telah dengan aktifnya menyembunyikan fakta-fakta material dan dengan itu melakukan ketidakjujuran terhadap adik-beradiknya jikapun tidak terhadap si mati. Juga tiada bukti untuk mematahkan inferens bahawa testimoni defendan pertama jika diberikan tidak akan berpihak kepada tuntutan alang tanah Teluk Bahang (lihat ms 596F-H,).

Defendan pertama dan keluarganya — yang mana hubungan membuatkan si mati menaruh keyakinan yang berterusan dan pengaruh defendan pertama dan keluarganya — adalah perlu bertindak dengan suci hati dan mereka mempunyai beban membukti bahawa alang itu tidak datang daripada pengaruh tidak wajar. Dan mereka — yang menanggung beban membukti ketiadaan pengaruh tidak wajar — gagal untuk menunjukkan bahawa transaksi itu adalah adil dan munasabah, bahawa tiada kesempatan telah diambil daripada kedudukannya dan bahawa tiada maklumat yang sepatutnya dikomunikasikan telah disembunyikan. Mereka gagal untuk menghilangkan niat jahat. Pengaruh tidak wajar, yang dibuktikan dan juga dianggap, tidak dipatahkan (lihat ms 606B-D).

Keadaan-keadaan semasa pelaksanaan wasiat 1992 penuh dengan syak wasangka dan jikapun pengaruh tidak wajar tidak dibuktikan, tetapi ianya telah dibuktikan, mahkamah tidak berpuas hati tentang sama ada transaksi itu betul atau tidak. Defendan ketiga yang menyediakan wasiat itu di mana dia dan keluarganya mengambil ganjaran yang luar biasa dan mengambil semua kuasa gagal untuk menunjukkan kebenaran, kejujuran dan betul atau tidaknya wasiat 1992 itu. Beliau gagal untuk memberi bukti yang jelas bahawa si mati tahu dan meluluskan apa yang dia dan keluarganya ambil manfaat yang luar biasa. Oleh itu, wasiat 1992 yang kononnya dilaksanakan oleh si mati tidak mempunyai kesahan apa pun dan tidak boleh diterima kepada probet lihat ms 616G-I).Tambahan pula, terdapat ketidakpatuhan kepada
s 5
Akta Wasiat 1959 yang menyebabkan pelaksanaan wasiat itu tidak dibuktikan.

Semua perkara-perkara ini dipertimbangkan, adalah mesti disimpulkan bahawa si mati faham dan meluluskan peruntukan-peruntukan wasiat 1990. Plaintif-plaintif yang mengemukakan wasiat 1990 telah melepaskan beban untuk menunjukkan bahawa transaksi itu adalah betul dan bahawa dokumen yang dikemukakan menyatakan wasiat akhir si mati yang sebenar. Ini bermakna bahawa wasiat 1990 adalah wasiat terakhir si mati yang sebenar dan boleh diterima kepada probet (lihat ms 628G).

Tidak ada pengurusan yang betul berkenaan dengan harta pusaka itu. Sebenarnya, pertama dan kedua telah hilang kelayakan mereka kerana tindak-tanduk mereka daripada terus menguruskan urusan itu. Kecuaian terhadap tugas atau tindakan yang tidak tepat, tindakan atau peninggalan mereka menunjukkan keperluan keupayaan yang sewajarnya untuk melaksanakan tugas-tugas itu. Menghakimi daripada peristiwa-peristiwa daripada bulan Jun 1992, boleh dikatakan secara adil bahawa harta pusaka itu jika dibiarkan di bawah urusan mereka mungkin akan dimuslihatkan dan mempunyai nilai yang sedikit (lihat ms 635D-F).]
[ Editorial note : The first to third defendants, and the fourth and fifth defendants, have respectively filed an appeal to the Court of Appeal.]

case:constituents.case:constituent: John Khoo , Ng Poh Tatt , S Theivanthiran and Richard Huang (Ismail Khoo & Associates) for the plaintiffs.
KH Koh , Raymond Ooi ( Raymond Ooi ), Lim Choo Hooi ( J Tan & CH Lim ) and Foo Say Keow ( Murad & Foo ) for the first to third defendants.
JA Yeoh ( Shearn Delamore & Co ) for the fourth and fifth defendants.

p.text: This has been a trial of some proportions. Sixty seven days were invested recording and hearing evidence and submissions. A catalogue of facts were asserted, a host of issues was raised, literally thousands of folios of documents were produced (see bundles of documents marked PB1, PB2, PB3 and PB4 by the plaintiff, DB1[A]-DB1[F] by the first to third defendants and DB2[A] and DB2[B] by the fourth and fifth defendants) and more than 750�pp of typed notes were recorded. Yet, these proceedings would have been longer even still if not for the agreement of the parties, thankfully, to dispense with all formal proof (save where expressly required, and there were few) of all documents in the bundles of documents and to agree to certain facts (see bundle of all agreed facts).

It has to do with a family dispute on the last will or intestacy, and related issues, of Khaw Bian Cheng (the deceased), the progenitor of the plaintiffs and defendants, and the considerable fortune he left or should have left. The disputes, claims and related issues will be related in the course of this grounds. However, to set the scene,

claiming that the three wills dated 3 August 1992 were forged by the first, second and third defendants and or procured by fraud and undue influence, the plaintiffs propounded three wills dated 24�October 1990 ('1990 wills') as the last will of the deceased,
denying any forgery, the first, second and third defendants propounded three wills dated 3 August 1992 ('1992 wills') as the last will of the deceased, whilst,
the fourth and fifth defendants, claiming there are no true wills, propounded the intestacy of the deceased.

The plaintiffs claimed as well for the return or restitution of substantial sums, several cars, jewellery and a piece of land that the first to third defendants allegedly extruded and peculated in the last year of the deceased's life, for the removal of the first, second and third defendants as executors and trustees and for the forfeiture of their beneficial interests under the 1990 or 1992 wills.

Eclectic, the evidence ranged from the genealogy and early years, the properties in Malaysia, Thailand and the United States ('US'), the character and lifestyle, the children and grandchildren, the trials and tribulations with progeny, the bequests, the many 'wills and codicils', the 'settlements and gifts' and dealings of the deceased.

Twenty three witnesses testified at the trial; 12 were summoned by the plaintiffs, eight by the first to third defendants and three by the fourth and fifth defendants. Trial commenced on 22 October 1996 and ended on 25�March 1998.

Testifying for the plaintiffs were Khaw Cheng Bok (PW5), Khaw Cheng Liat PW9), Hamid Merican (PW1 — a businessman/estate agent and friend of the family), Dr Abdul Gafoor (PW2 — an orthopaedic surgeon), Teoh Say Bee (PW3 — an employee of the deceased for 50�years), Teh Beng Tatt (PW4 — the deceased's accounts clerk for 12 years), Dr�Tan Chee Khuan (PW6 — a consultant psychiatrist at Lam Wah Ee Hospital, Penang — 'LWE Hospital'), Dr Francis Tan Seow Kee (PW7 — a consultant physician at LWE Hospital), Teoh Seng Chye (PW8 — the Deputy Branch Manager of Bank Bumiputra (M) Bhd Pulau Tikus Branch — 'BBMB'), Chew Cheng Leong (PW10 — the manager of Arthur Andersen & Co of Kuala Lumpur), Nik Saghir bin Nik Ismail (PW11 — a senior partner of Messrs Nik Saghir & Ismail, Advocates & Solicitors of Kuala Lumpur) and Ghazi bin Ishak (PW12 — a senior partner of Messrs�Ghazi & Lim, Advocates & Solicitors of Penang and a witness to the 1990 wills).

Testifying for the first to third defendants were Howard Khaw Teik Chong (DW4), Richard Khaw Teik Ewe (DW5), Lim Cheng Chuan (DW1 — a senior lawyer and a witness to the 1992 wills), Yeoh Keat Chye (DW2 — the driver of the deceased), Tan Beng Hin (DW3 — a broker), Lim Bock Eng DW6 — Khaw Cheng Poon's wife), ML Isdakorn Kasemsri (DW7 — a lawyer from Bangkok, Thailand) and Cho Choo Meng (DW8 — a chartered accountant and director of Price Waterhouse, Penang). Notably absent from the witness-box was Cheng Poon.

The witnesses for the fourth and fifth defendants were Khaw Cheng Hum, Prateep Pattana-Amorn (DW9 — a lawyer from Songkla, Thailand) and Putian a/l Boncham (DW10 — the interpreter of the court who interpreted DW9's testimony from Thai to English).

It is appropriate, since it has to do with the deceased, to begin with a short narrative of the deceased. The deceased, known also as Bian Cheng Naranong, born in Penang in 1905, was the only son of Khaw Joo Chie (also known as Joo Chie Naranong) and Lim Swee Eam. He was the only grandson of Khaw Sim Bee (also known as Sim Bee Naranong) and a great grandson of Khaw Soo Cheang, the founding patriarch of the Khaws of Penang and the Naranongs of Thailand. Khaw Soo Cheang, a veritable taipan of the south seas, was an adventurer/entrepreneur extraordinaire . He came to Penang, 1822, a destitute from South China, but soon built an immense business empire spanning 19th century Penang and Siam (as Thailand was called). Khaw Soo Cheang enjoyed the patronage of the Royal House of Siam and had close ties with the aristocracy of Siam. His sons, Sim Bee was the youngest and arguably the most able, were also men of remarkable gift and enterprise. They fanned out, like the sons of Mayer Amshel of Frankfurt known better by their sobriquet 'Rothschild', and built on their father's empire. In their heyday, they were even governors of many of the southern Thai provinces. Like the Rothschilds before them, they too were bestowed titles of nobility and were members of the (Thai) aristocracy. Indeed, that comparison is apt, as the story of the Khaws/Naranongs of the founding patriarch and his sons was similarly one of wealth and power. Unfortunately, the following generations failed to produce a Khaw/Naranong of the stature of the patriarch or his sons (for further reading on the Khaws/Naranongs, see Family and State, The Formation of a Sino-Thai Tin-Mining Dynasty 1797-1932 by Jennifer CW Cushman).

The Khaws in this action belong to the Sim Bee branch of the Khaw/Naranong family of Penang and Thailand. Not much is known about Joo Chie, the only son of Sim Bee. Presumably, Joo Chie inherited Sim Bee's wealth and the deceased in turn inherited Joo Chie's inherited wealth.

All parties agreed that the deceased was an educated man fluent in the English language. A on vivant who lived off his inheritance, his marriage to Ooi Geen Peen, his only wife, blessed him with five sons (Cheng Hum [fourth defendant], Cheng Bok [first plaintiff], Cheng Poon [first defendant], Cheng Liat [second plaintiff] and Cheng Been [who is mentally unsound]) and two daughters (Liang Imm [third plaintiff] and Beng Imm [the deceased]). Described variously as uxorious:

… henpecked, a martinet, strict with his children, parsimonious, careful with money, as good as his word, charitable and generous, the deceased educated and supported his children (except Cheng Hum and Liang Imm) and most of his children's children. He provided them Bannuities and allowances until his last day, on 10 April 1993, at 88, at Mount Elizabeth Hospital, Singapore. The deceased was the sole beneficiary of his wife who died in 1988.

The mise en scene will be complete with the children and grandchildren of the deceased. Liang Imm, the eldest child, was raised by her paternal grandparents. She is the residuary beneficiary of the estate of Lim Swee Eam (Joo Chie's wife and Liang Imm's paternal grandmother). Susie Yeoh Kooi Huah (fourth plaintiff) and Betsy Yeoh Kooi Sim (fifth plaintiff) are Liang Imm's children.

Cheng Hum, the eldest son, lives as he did off his inheritance from his paternal grandparents and some properties from the deceased. Raised by paternal grandparents, he only lived with his parents for five years, when his parents were living with his grandparents. Grace Khaw (fifth defendant) is Cheng Hum's only (adopted).

Cheng Bok, the second son, retired at 52 as the Chief Health Inspector of the Johore Bahru City Council. He lived, until five, with his paternal grandparents. Thereafter, he lived with his parents at 20 Pykett Avenue (Pykett Avenue). At 25, he left for Australia to pursue his studies. He entered public service in 1963. He retired in 1982. He lived his adult life, most of it, in Johore Bahru. Between 1963 to 1972, he was not allowed into Pykett Avenue. He was financially assisted, as were his children, by the deceased. Teik Lim (sixth plaintiff), Gim Hong (seventh plaintiff) and Teik Chye (eighth plaintiff) are Cheng Bok's children. Cheng Poon, the third son, depended entirely on the deceased. He lived his entire life, now, at Pykett Avenue with his two sons, Richard Khaw Teik Ewe (second defendant) and Howard Khaw Teik Chong (third defendant), and daughter, Gim Chuan. Richard and Howard were supported and educated at the expense of the deceased. Cheng Poon's wife, Bok Eng, lived away from the family for ten years. After the demise of the deceased's wife with whom she had disagreement, she moved back to Pykett Avenue. Between 1988 to 1993, Cheng Poon, Bok Eng (from 1990/1992), Richard, Howard and Gim Chuan were the only Khaws (and Cheng Been) living with the deceased.

Cheng Liat, the fourth son, had worked as a factory manager. He retired in 1985 at age 52. He lived, until age 15, with his parents. Thence, he was dispatched to the United Kingdom where he lived for ten years. On 19 September 1990, he was adjudged a bankrupt; on 29 July 1997, the receiving order was annulled. Teik Hock, Teik Ghim, Serena Khaw and Desmond Khaw (9th to 12th plaintiffs) are Cheng Liat's children. Sally Khaw is Cheng Liat's first wife. Cheng Been, the fifth son, is mentally unsound. He is supported by a trust set up by the deceased. Beng Imm, a lawyer, died in 1969.

Evidently, three generations of Khaws of the Sim Bee branch lived for many and many a year off the inherited wealth of the deceased. Yet, the deceased left, leaving a clue of the wealth he inherited, substantial properties in Penang (see P19), Thailand (see PB1[21–27]) and US (see schedule to the 'US will dated 3 August 1992'— P2C). However, on the day he died, in stark contrast to his immovable properties, the deceased left a paltry RM26,926.88, relatively speaking, in his account.
It is timely to elaborate on the 'wills' that the plaintiffs, and the first to third defendants propounded.

All plaintiffs, through Cheng Bok, propounded three wills dated 24�October 1990 ('1990 wills') as the last will of the deceased. Cheng Poon, Cheng Bok, Richard and Teik Lim (Cheng Poon as the governing trustee) are the executors and trustees in all 1990 wills. The first will dated 24 October 1990 ('1990 Malaysian will') relates to the real and personal property of the deceased in Malaysia; the plaintiffs and defendants (except Grace) are named as the beneficiaries. The second will dated 24 October 1990 ('1990 Thai will') relates to the real and personal property of the deceased in Thailand; Cheng Poon, Cheng Bok, Cheng Liat and Bian Naranong Trust Fund are named as the beneficiaries. The third will dated 24 October 1990 ('1990 US will') relates to the real and personal property of the deceased in the US; Cheng Poon, Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat are named as the beneficiaries. The witnesses to the 1990 wills were Ghazi Ishak and Hamid.

The first, second and third defendants conceded that the 1990 wills were true wills of the deceased; however, they propounded three wills dated 3 August 1992 ('1992 wills') as the last will of the deceased. Cheng Bok, Cheng Poon and his sons (Cheng Poon as the governing trustee) are the executors and trustees in all 1992 wills. The first will dated 3 August 1992 ('1992 Malaysian will') relates to the real and personal property of the deceased in Malaysia; the plaintiff and defendants (except Grace) are named as the beneficiaries. The second will dated 3 August 1992 ('1992 Thai will') relates to the real and personal property of the deceased in Thailand; Cheng Poon, Cheng Bok, Cheng Liat and Bian Cheng Naranong Trust Fund are named as the beneficiaries. The third will dated 3 August 1992 ('1992 US will') relates to the real and personal property of the deceased in the US; Cheng Poon, Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat are named as the beneficiaries. The witnesses to the 1992 wills were Lim Cheng Chuan and Dr Abdul Gafoor. It has already been said that the fourth and fifth defendants propounded the intestacy of the deceased. Nevertheless, all parties agreed that the 1990 wills, and similarly of the 1992 wills, was a single instrument and that the partition of the 1990 or 1992 wills into several instruments (the Malaysian, Thai and US chapters) should not be a ground or reason to invalidate the 1990 and or 1992 wills.

Going by the evidence, a few days after the burial of the deceased, Lim Cheng Chuan (DW1) read the 1992 wills to the Khaws present at Pykett Avenue. The following proceedings erupted in quick succession.

On 2 December 1993, vide Penang High Court 32-159-93, Cheng Bok, Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard, the executors and trustees in the 1992 Malaysian will, petitioned for probate of the estate of the deceased in Malaysia. On 30 June 1995, Abdul Hamid J directed that O 72 of the
Rules of the High Court 1980
shall apply to 32-159-93. Hence, at the stage of submissions before this court, all parties agreed that the outcome of the instant proceedings shall be binding on 32-159-93.
On 6 September 1994, all 13 plaintiffs instituted action (Penang High Court 22-271-94) against Cheng Poon, and Howard for the following relief:

an injunction restraining Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard 'from applying for and taking out any probate or administration with connection with the estate of the deceased in Malaysia, Thailand or America';
an order removing Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard as executors and trustees of the estate of the deceased;
an account by Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard of the lands and estate of the deceased.
On 31 March 1995, Cheng Bok instituted 22-63-95 against Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard for the following reliefs:
a declaration that the wills of the deceased dated 2 August 1992 concerning his assets in Malaysia, Thailand and America are invalid;
a declaration that the wills of the deceased dated 24 October 1990 concerning his assets in Malaysia, Thailand and America are valid wills;

a declaration that Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard had infringed the 1990 wills and or the 1992 wills and all rights and/or interest of Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard in the estate of the deceased are forfeited; and
a declaration that Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard are not qualified to be executors of the deceased.
The following orders were made in 22-63-95:

on 23 May 1995, on Cheng Bok's application, TS Nathan J granted an ex parte injunction restraining Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard from 'leasing, charging selling disposing or dealing with the assets of the deceased pending the disposal of 22-63-95'; on 30 May 1995, TS Nathan J granted an inter partes injunction upon similar terms;
on 19 September 1995, on Cheng Bok's application, TS Nathan J appointed Amanah Raya Bhd ('Amanah') as the receivers and managers of the assets and liabilities of the estate of the deceased;
on 8 April 1996, Nathan J ordered the consolidation of 22-271-95 and 22-63-95;
on 26 September 1996, on Cheng Hum and Grace Khaw's application (encl 87), this court granted leave to Cheng Hum and Grace Khaw to be added as the fourth and fifth defendants;
on 22 October 1996, this court directed that the consolidated action (22-271-95 and 22-63-95) be intituled as appearing in the first page of the instant judgment; and,
leave for the amendments to the instant pleadings.
(Note: there was and there is no appeal against any of the aforesaid orders.)
On 6 December 1995, Bok commenced action (Penang High Court 22-299-95), on behalf of the estate, against Cheng Poon and Richard for the following orders:
a declaration that cars purchased in the names of Cheng Poon and Richard are held by them for the deceased;
a declaration that the transfer of lands known as Holding Nos 6767 and 678, Mukim 2, Daerah Barat Daya, Penang ('the Teluk Bahang land') by the deceased to the Cheng Poon is invalid;
a declaration that the Teluk Bahang land is held for the deceased;
an account of moneys from the disposal of the said cars;
an account of all moneys in the joint account of the deceased and Cheng Poon;

an account of all moneys transferred from the deceased's account to Cheng Poon's account and/or Cheng Poon's account with his wife and/or members of his family or withdrawn from the deceased's account for their benefit;
an order compelling Cheng Poon to return all moneys taken out which cannot be justified with valid documents;
an order compelling Cheng Poon to return monies amounting to RM826,000 to Cheng Bok and RM866,000 to Cheng Liat;
injunctions against dealing with the cars and the Teluk Bahang land;
general damages;
exemplary damages; and
interest and costs.

About a year before any one of the above proceedings were instituted, Cheng Bok, Cheng Liat, Richard (all on 20 October 1993) and Howard (on 1 December 1993) executed An Agreement of the Beneficiaries of the will of Khaw Bian Cheng for Independent Administration and for Administration without Bond (see DB1[1–2]). By their solicitors' letter dated 6 April 1994, Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat notified one Charles Lebeau that they were immediately withdrawing their consent under the Agreement of the Beneficiaries of the will Of Khaw Bian Cheng for Independent Administration and for Administration without Bond . Nonetheless, Howard petitioned the Superior Court for the State of Arizona (vide Petition No P 24426), on 25�July 1994, for probate of the 1992 US will and for his appointment as personal representative of the deceased's estate in Arizona; on 16�September 1994, Howard was appointed the personal representative of the deceased's estate in Arizona. On 18 October 1994, the 1992 US will was 'admitted to Formal Probate' by the Superior Court for the State of Arizona (see DB1[82]). On 27 January 1995, Howard was appointed 'ancillary' personal representative of the Florida estate of the deceased (see DB1[82]).

With regard to the Thai estate, the deceased died possessed of numerous landed properties in Kantang, Thailand; specifically, the deceased held 146/147 properties in his own name or through a Thai corporate — Bian Cheng, Wife, Relatives and Friends Ltd — in which he held 10,000 of a total of 12,000 shares.

Trial of the consolidated action (22-271-95 and 22-63-95) intituled 22-63-95 commenced on 22 October 1996. After trial commenced, Cheng�Bok applied, on 14 December 1996 vide 22-299-95 (encl 4), for 22-299--95 to be consolidated with the consolidated action (22-271-95 and 22-63-95). There were no objections from the parties in 22-299-95 or the parties in the consolidated action (22-271-95 and 22-63-95) to that consolidation. Felicitously, through their counsel, Cheng Bok, Cheng Poon and Richard, the immediate parties in 22-299-95, agreed with regard to proof of the claim and defence in 22-299-95 to rely on the evidence adduced in the instant trial from 22 October 1996. Accordingly,�it�was ordered on 6 May 1997, with the consent of all parties, that 22-299-95 be consolidated with the consolidated action (22-271-95 and 22-63-95) and that all consolidated causes and matters be tried at the same time, that is, in the instant trial.

The litigants are divided, albeit consanguity, into three fractious camps. All 13 plaintiffs, through Cheng Bok, propounded the 1990 wills and impugned the 1992 wills. They sought: (i) an injunction restraining Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard 'from applying for and taking out any probate or administration (with) connection with the estate of the deceased in Malaysia, Thailand or America', (ii) an order removing Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard as executors and trustees of the estate of the deceased, (iii) an account from Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard of the lands and estate of the deceased, (iv) a declaration that Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard infringed the 1990 wills and or the 1992 wills and that all rights and/or interest of Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard in the estate of the deceased are forfeited, and, (v) a further declaration that Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard are not qualified to be executors of the deceased.

Cheng Bok also sought, on behalf of the estate, (vi) a declaration that all cars purchased in the names of Cheng Poon and Richard were held by them for the deceased, (vii) a declaration that the transfer of lands known as Holding Nos 676 and 678, Mukim 2, Daerah Barat Daya, Penang ('the Teluk Bahang land') by the deceased to the Cheng Poon is invalid, viii)�a�declaration that the Teluk Bahang land was held for the deceased, (ix) Cheng Poon and Richard's account of the monies received from their disposal of the said cars, (x) Cheng Poon and Richard's account of all monies in the joint account of Cheng Poon and the deceased, (xi) Cheng Poon and Richard's account of all monies transferred from the deceased to Cheng Poon's account and/or to Cheng Poon's account with his wife and/or the members of his family and or withdrawn from the deceased's account for their benefit, (xii) an order that Cheng Poon do return all monies which could be justified with valid documents, (xiii) an order that Cheng Poon do 'return' RM826,000 to Cheng Bok and RM866,000 to Cheng Liat, (xiv) injunctions restraining Cheng Poon and Richard from dealing with the cars and the Teluk Bahang land, (xv) general damages, (xvi) exemplary damages, and, (xvii) interest and costs.

Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard, the 'real defendants', propounded the 1992 wills as the last will of the deceased. They denied the charges of misdeeds and pleaded that the said cars, monies and Teluk Bahang land were gifts from the deceased.

The last camp, Cheng Hum and Grace Khaw, propounded the intestacy of the deceased. They asserted, in pleading and in Cheng Hum's oral testimony, that the deceased, after the demise of his wife in 1988, was not of a sound disposing mind, and that the 1990 and 1992 wills were not true wills of the deceased.
As imparted, or was it forewarned, more than 750 pp of typed notes were recorded. Perhaps, the key to follow that copious body of evidence should be a brief outline of the salient evidence.

After the death of his wife, the deceased who had prior wills, executed a deed of settlement dated 2 March 1989 ('1989 deed') — [DB1(A)(89-94)]. That 1989 deed was not implemented; apparently, Cheng Liat complained that the 1989 deed favoured Cheng Poon but and was not fair to him and Cheng Bok and that the deceased was advised that the 1989 deed favoured Cheng Poon. About a year later, on 2 March 1990, at E & O Hotel, Penang, the deceased executed a codicil prepared by Nik Saghir. In the same year, on 24 October 1990, the deceased executed the 1990 wills. In June 1991, the deceased sold the Batu Ferringhi land for RM7,501,032; apparently, individual sums of RM866,000 was promised to Cheng Poon, Bok and Cheng Liat. In June 1992, the deceased received the balance purchase price (RM6.3m) from the sale of the Batu Ferringhi land; RM866,000 was paid to Cheng Poon. However, Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat were not given their shares; they were given deeds dated the 24 July 1992 ('the 24 July 1992 deeds') in lieu of their respective RM866,000. Meanwhile, between June to July 1992, the said RM6.3m had been disbursed, mostly to Cheng Poon and his family. On 13 July 1992, the deceased who suffered a stroke was admitted to LWE�Hospital. On 17 July 1992, the deceased was discharged from LWE�Hospital. On 3�August 1992, at Pykett Avenue, according to the proponents of the 1992 wills, the deceased executed the 1992 wills and transferred the Teluk Bahang land to Cheng Poon.

With regard to the 1992 wills, it was said that Lim, Dr Gafoor and Howard at the very least were present when the 1992 wills were signed; both attesting witnesses (Lim and Dr Gafoor) testified that they, present at the same time, witnessed the deceased signing his will/s, at Pykett Avenue on 3 August 1992. Those wills were not bound. Both attesting witnesses testified that they subscribed the wills signed by the deceased on 3 August 1992 in the presence of the deceased and in the presence of each other. Lim identified the 1992 wills as the wills he subscribed on 3 August 1992. Dr Gafoor was less categorical — 'the loose sheets that I signed on 3 August 1992 appear to be those (in the 1992 wills)'. Both attesting witnesses identified their signatures on the 1992 wills. Howard testified that the deceased amended the 1990 wills and he prepared the 1992 wills (there were no carbon or other duplicate copies) according to the amendments made to the 1990 wills. According to Lim, he took possession of the 1992 wills, duly signed and subscribed, that is, three documents in all, when he left Pykett Avenue on 3 August 1992. In examination-in-chief, Lim testified most unequivocally that the 1992 wills had not left him; he testified that the 1992 wills were always in his office, under lock and key.

Beng Tatt testified, however, that Richard instructed him, on 12 August 1992, to collect some documents from Lim for the deceased and Dr Gafoor's signatures, and that Lim handed him loose sheets of documents for the deceased and Dr Gafoor's signatures. According to Beng Tatt, the deceased signed those loose sheets at Pykett Avenue and Dr Gafoor signed those loose sheets at his clinic. In both cases, Beng Tatt testified, the deceased and Dr Gafoor signed those loose sheets in his presence and of no other.

Beng Tatt further testified that Lim handed him a stack of documents at Pykett Avenue on 26 August 1992, for the deceased and Dr Gafoor's signatures. The deceased signed that stack of documents in his and Lim's presence. Lim instructed him, after the deceased signed that stack of documents, to take that stack of documents to Dr Gafoor for his signature. On 28 August 1992, as Dr Gafoor was on holiday, he returned that stack of documents to Lim. On 4 September 1992, Lim again handed him that stack of documents; Lim instructed him to have those documents signed by Dr Gafoor. On 4 September 1992, Dr Gafoor signed that stack of documents at his clinic. And the testimony of Dr Gafoor was that Beng Tatt handed him, on 12 August 1992 and 14 September 1992, loose sheets of a will with the signatures of the deceased and Lim and that he signed those loose sheets and affixed his rubber stamp without the presence of the deceased or Lim. Dr Gafoor testified that the 1992 wills, because of the 'amendments', were not the wills he subscribed on 3 August 1992.

Lim Cheng Chuan denied however that he handed loose sheets of the 1992 wills to Beng Tatt or that he instructed Beng Tatt to have loose sheets signed by the deceased and Dr Gafoor. He maintained that the 1992 wills were always in his possession. He denied all knowledge of the execution of loose sheets of the 1992 wills after 3 August 1992. However, he admitted that he handed the 1992 wills to Beng Tatt and instructed Beng Tatt to have the 1992 wills affixed with Dr Gafoor's rubber stamp.

In the course of this grounds, there will be a detailed discussion and more of the evidence on the 1992 wills. However, it should be promptly pointed out that a second 1992 Thai will dated 3 August 1992 (D2D), whereas there should be none, was produced during the trial, and that second 1992 Thai will was vehemently denied and disavowed by Lim who only admitted it was bearing his signature when he was confronted by the production of the second 1992 Thai will.

With regard to the 1990 wills, there was no challenge, unlike the 1992 wills, that those wills were not executed in manner prescribed by the
Wills Act 1959
. Both subscribers (Ghazi Ishak and Hamid) testified that they, present at the same time, witnessed the deceased signing his will/s in the chambers of Messrs Presgrave & Mathews, Advocates and Solicitors of Penang on 24 October 1990, and that they subscribed the wills signed by the deceased on 24 October 1990 in the presence of the deceased and in the presence of each other. Both Ghazi Ishak and Hamid identified the 1990 wills as the wills they subscribed on 24 October 1990.

Essentially, the 'expert' evidence on the mental/medical state of the deceased rest on the testimony of Dr Tan Chee Khuan ('Dr Tan') and Dr�Francis Tan Seow Kee ('Dr Francis'). Dr Tan testified that he assessed the mental state of the deceased on 16 March 1990, 24 October 1990, 24�July 1992, 3 August 1992, 27 January 1993 (the dates are pertinent) and that on all five occasions he found the deceased to be of 'sound disposing mind'. Dr Tan also testified that Cheng Been is suffering from chronic schizophrenia.

Dr Francis testified that the deceased was referred to him, on 12 July 1992, by a general medical practitioner who advised that the deceased had suffered series of seizures. He narrowed the cause to three possible causes: (i) a mild stroke, (ii) the medication the deceased was taking, and, (iii) the blood chemistry of the deceased. The deceased, admitted on 12 July 1992, was discharged from LWE Hospital on 17 July 1992. There was a lacuna infarct on the left side of the brain of the deceased. There were periods, at LWE Hospital, when the deceased was slightly confused. The deceased requested, on 17 July 1992, to be discharged. The condition of the deceased, he saw him next, on 22 July 1992, was stable. The deceased was clear and lucid on 22 July 1992.

emph.emph: Hamid Merican, Teoh Say Bee and Teh Bent Tatt

p.text: The other witnesses, apart from kin, who testified on the mental/medical condition of the deceased were Hamid, Say Bee and Beng Tatt.

Md Hamid Merican bin Abdul Kader Merican, 50, a businessman and an estate agent, testified that he had known the deceased for more than 30 years. 'I was assisting him in his financial matters and in the management of his properties. I regard myself as his personal friend … I�was acquainted with his financial matters. The deceased consulted me from time to time.'

Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard lived with the deceased. Until 1988, Bok Eng was not living at Pykett Avenue. The deceased's wife told him that Bok Eng was not a good woman and was not allowed into Pykett Avenue.

The deceased asked him if the 1989 deed would give his entire estate/property to Cheng Poon. He advised the deceased to take legal advice; he recommended Saghir Md Noor. In Singapore, the deceased, Cheng Bok, Cheng Poon and Cheng Liat discussed the 1989 deed. The sons were arguing for the division of their father's properties. The deceased was present when his sons came to their agreement.

Further to that meeting in Singapore, he, the deceased and Lim met at Nik Saghir's office. The 1989 deed was discussed. Nik Saghir confirmed that Cheng Poon would have the entire estate. The deceased instructed Nik Saghir to prepare a will or codicil.

Sometime in 1990, he was with the deceased at the E & O Hotel, Penang. Nik Saghir, Cheng Bok, Poon and Cheng Liat were also present. Nik Saghir handed a draft will or codicil to the deceased. He heard that the said will/codicil would give equal shares to Cheng Bok, Cheng Poon and Cheng Liat, except that Cheng Poon would have a 40% share of a property in Thailand while the other two sons would have a 30% share each. The three sons were appointed executors and trustees with Cheng Poon as the governing trustee. The deceased executed that codicil in the presence of Nik Saghir and Lim. When the codicil was signed, he was not in the room.
On 24 October 1990, at Messrs Presgrave & Mathews of Penang, the deceased executed the 1990 wills in the presence of Ghazi Ishak and himself.

In July 1992, he visited the deceased at LWE Hospital. The deceased could not recognize him. He greeted the deceased, but the deceased did not respond. One evening, whilst the deceased was still in LWE hospital, Richard, Howard and a lady paid him a visit. Richard or Howard asked, 'can you do something about the wills?' He replied, 'Please don't touch it'. After the deceased was discharged from LWE Hospital, En Ismail — Nik Saghir's partner — informed him that someone was asking for a copy of the March 1990 will/codicil and for one other document.

He paid three visits to the deceased after he (the deceased) was discharged. On the first visit, he was told that the deceased was sleeping. On the second visit, he was told that the deceased was in the toilet. On the third visit, he saw the deceased holding a set of English newspapers. He greeted the deceased, but he (the deceased) did not respond. He said, 'Uncle, I am going back'. The deceased did not respond.

From what he knew, from years of contact, the deceased was very careful with money. He (the deceased) would only spend if there was reason. Several times the deceased said that he was having a cash problem and that he wanted to dispose off his properties or obtain a loan. It was impossible that the deceased would spend RM5m within a period of five months.

Sometime in 1986, the deceased's wife told him that she would give Cheng Bok, Cheng Poon and Cheng Liat each 15% of the sales proceeds from the sale of her lands — Lots 92, 93, 110, Mukim 17, Batu Ferringhi, Penang ('the Batu Ferringhi land'). The deceased told him that he (the deceased) would carry out her wish. The deceased sold the Batu Ferringhi land and gave RM1m to Cheng Poon.

Two days before the deceased died, he telephoned Pykett Avenue. Cheng Poon informed him that the deceased was unconscious. He could hear Bok Eng's voice in the background telling Cheng Poon not to tell him the state of the deceased.

The deceased had several cars in the names of Cheng Poon and Richard. The deceased told him that Cheng Poon and Richard were holding the cars for Cheng Bok, Cheng Liat and Cheng Poon. The deceased informed him that Cheng Hum was bypassed as his mother Lim Swee Eam) had given Cheng Hum substantial properties and that Cheng Hum had no issue.

He attended the deceased's funeral. A lorry arrived with the body of the deceased in a coffin. The coffin was not taken into the house or house compound. The deceased's wife had a grand funeral. For many days, her body was lying in state in the house. In the case of the deceased, the lorry with the coffin departed for the cemetery after a few hours outside the house. The funeral for the deceased was rather bare.

Under cross-examination by Mr Koh, Hamid testified that he knew the deceased well. A few years before the death of the deceased, he traveled with the deceased to Kuala Lumpur, Singapore, Thailand and London. From 7 June 1990 to 13 June 1990, he was in Bangkok with the deceased. On 21 June 1990, he was in the United Kingdom. After he arrived, he met the deceased.
Sometimes, the deceased discussed his finances with him. He helped the deceased to obtain an overdraft of RM1.5m from the BBMB; the Teluk Bahang land was charged as security.

The deceased had more properties than the five properties in PB1(77). The deceased had plans to develop Pykett Avenue. He (the deceased) contemplating a hotel on Pykett Avenue. Despite attempts, he could not contact the architect — Dayabina Architect Sdn Bhd — to prepare the proposed development plans.

Hamid said he was not aware of the 24 July 1992 deeds. However, did convey the deceased's message to Cheng Liat that a sum of RM900,000 (thereabout) was due to him (Cheng Liat) from the sale of the Batu Ferringhi land and that the deceased intended to defer payment and pay him (Cheng Liat) interests instead.

row.entry: I put it to you … Richard and Howard never came to your house and asked you to do something to the will.
They came and asked me to do something to the will. I told them not to touch the will.

p.text: The deceased was careful with his money. However, a few months before he died, after receiving the sale proceeds from the Batu Ferringhi land, a lot of monies left his (the deceased) account.

After the deceased was discharged from the LWE hospital, he received a note that someone from the deceased's office telephoned and asked for a copy of the deceased's (1990) wills. He delivered a copy of the 1990 wills to Pykett Avenue. The deceased was upstairs reading newspapers. He greeted the deceased, but the deceased did not respond.

Once, after his third visit, he telephoned Pykett Avenue. Cheng Poon told him that the deceased was unconscious in Singapore. In the background, was a woman's voice saying in Hokkien, 'not to inform him'.

The deceased was a careful man. The deceased kept his accounts accurately. From April 1992, he was not seeing the deceased frequently; the deceased seldom called and he was seeing him less frequently.

row.entry: I put it to you … you were friendly with the deceased up till July 1992.
That is your version. It is not true.

p.text: Hamid said that he would not know if the deceased, after July 1992, was unhappy with him. 'I remember that I met the deceased in July/August 1992 in the airport lounge. The deceased was returning from China. I said hello to him. I remember that the deceased said to me in April 1992 that he would pay interest to the first and second plaintiffs.'

row.entry: I put it to you that it was in June 1992.
I can't recall, it could be April or June.

p.text: The Batu Ferringhi land was sold for RM7,501,032. He calculated the RM866,000 paid to Cheng Poon. In April or June 1992, the deceased said to him that he had no money to pay 45% of the Batu Ferringhi sale proceeds to his three sons. Tan Beng Seng or Tang Beng Brothers secured the buyer for the Batu Ferringhi land. He was informed that they were paid a commission. He was paid a 2% seller's commission.
Under cross-examination by Mr Yeoh, Hamid testified that the deceased was very close to his wife. He (the deceased) was very upset by her death; his health declined but it recovered.

He enjoyed the trust and confidence of the deceased; the deceased turned to him for advice on financial matters and on his relationship with his sons; the deceased consulted him on his wills and assets. He was not involved in the preparation of the 1989 deed. After it was executed, the deceased told him that he (the deceased) had instructed Lim, sometime before Christmas 1989, to transfer his assets to the trust under the 1989 deed. The deceased asked him and he (Hamid) expressed his opinion that the 1989 deed would give the entire estate to Cheng Poon. He advised the deceased to take legal advice. The deceased was so upset by the 1989 deed that he chased Cheng Poon, Cheng Poon 'celaka', out of the house. Beng Tatt was present. He (Hamid) pacified the deceased. After a few days, the deceased and Cheng Poon reconciled.

Sometime after the trip to Singapore in 1989, Cheng Liat was ordered out from the house. The deceased told him that Cheng Poon had said to him (the deceased) that Cheng Liat was poisoning the cup he (the deceased) was using to take his medicine. He advised the deceased to verify the facts and to make up with Cheng Liat. But they the deceased and Cheng Liat) did not reconcile.

There were two trips to Singapore. Both meetings at Singapore were initiated by the deceased. Cheng Liat and Cheng Poon followed the deceased to Singapore. The deceased summoned Cheng Bok who was then in Johore Bahru to Singapore. The three sons discussed the 1989 deed. Cheng Liat said to Cheng Bok that Cheng Poon was swallowing the whole estate and that they (Cheng Liat and Cheng Bok) 'will get telor'. Cheng Bok scolded Cheng Liat and asked for the document. The deceased who was in his own room when his sons were arguing did not know of his sons' argument.

Sometime in early January 1990, the deceased, Lim, Nik Saghir and himself met at Nik Saghir's office. Cheng Liat, Cheng Bok and Cheng Poon remained outside. The 1989 deed was the only document that was discussed. Lim briefed Nik Saghir. He (Hamid) did not say anything. Nik Saghir confirmed that the 1989 deed would give the entire estate to Cheng Poon. The deceased instructed Nik Saghir to prepare a new will or codicil. The three sons did not ask him of the outcome of that meeting with Nik Saghir.

Sometime in March 1990, there was a meeting at E & O Hotel, Penang, to prepare a will or codicil. Present were Nik Saghir, the deceased, Lim and himself. When he was in the room, a will or codicil was discussed. Later, Lim informed him that the deceased had executed a codicil or will. He (Hamid) had not seen the documents executed at E & O Hotel.

He accompanied the deceased to Dr Tan Chee Khuan's clinic on three or four occasions. Say Bee or Beng Tatt arranged those visits. Sometimes, Cheng Poon, Say Bee or Beng Tatt were also present. Dr Tan Chee Khuan certified that the deceased was of sound mind.

On 24 October 1990, he witnessed the execution of the 1990 wills. The deceased instructed him to prepare the 1990 wills. No one else instructed him on the preparation of the 1990 wills. He forwarded the draft 1990 wills to Ghazi Ishak for perusal. Ghazi Ishak read and explained the draft 1990 wills, when the deceased called upon him, to the deceased. The deceased asked him to witness the 1990 will. On 24 October 1990, the deceased executed three wills in their Ghazi Ishak and Hamid) presence. He (Hamid) had no knowledge that the deceased had called upon Dr Tan on 24 October 1990.

row.entry: I put it to you … En Ghazi never read the 24 October 1990 wills to the deceased when it was executed.

p.text: Hamid said that the 1990 wills were not in accord with the three sons' agreement in Singapore. After the 1990 wills were executed, Ghazi Ishak gave a copy of each of the 1990 wills to the deceased.

The deceased was a careful and sound man when he executed the 1990 wills. He (the deceased) perused the 1990 wills. The deceased told him that he (the deceased) was leaving out Cheng Hum as Lim Swee Eam had given him (Cheng Hum) substantial properties. The deceased also told him that Lim Swee Eam had given sufficient properties to Liang Imm. He did not know why Liang Imm was given 17% in Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd while Cheng Hum was not.
Except for the 1990 wills, the deceased paid him for his services. He secured an overdraft of RM1.5m from BBMB for the deceased. He received RM21,000 or RM25,000 as his fees.

By an agreement dated 12 December 1987, the deceased and Cheng Hum sold a portion of the land they jointly owned — Holdings 10, 11(1),�12 Mukim 14, NE District, Penang. Cheng Hum made some payments to Cheng Poon or Cheng Liat, but he was not sure if the deceased had insisted on those payments. He was not aware that Cheng Hum was reluctant to sell that land. The deceased wanted to sell those properties as he (the deceased) wanted that money. Cheng Liat and Cheng Poon did not push for that sale. He could not recall whether he and Cheng Liat were at Cheng Hum's house to collect Cheng Hum's cheque for RM80,000; but he did not receive a share of that RM80,000.

row.entry: Would you say that the deceased was a strict and careful man when he executed the 24 October 1990 wills?
The deceased was a strict and careful man.

p.text: Cheng Hum and the deceased instructed him to prepare 2(A)(13). He did not know that the deceased had threatened, unless Cheng Hum executed DB2(A)(13), to disown Cheng Hum or that Cheng Hum signed DB2(A)(13) at the insistence of the deceased and Cheng Poon. He received RM21,000 (not RM70,000) as his commission from Cheng Hum. He was informed that sale was aborted. He believed that more than the 10% deposit was refunded to the purchaser. He did not know if Cheng Hum had asked the deceased for assistance to refund the deposit. He did not refund the commission paid to him.

When the 1990 wills were being prepared, he reminded the deceased of his (the deceased) previous codicils or wills. He (Hamid) asked for a copy of the will/codicil prepared by Nik Saghir. The deceased said that it was with Lim, but he made no attempt to obtain a copy of that will/codicil from Lim.

In re-examination, Hamid testified that the deceased asked him to go to America to secure a purchaser for the Benson land. In July 1992, the deceased was absent-minded; at times he had a vivid memory while at times, he had lapses of memory. After July 1992, the mind of the deceased was not stable. As such, he visited the deceased less frequently. Even prior to July 1992, the mind of the deceased was already not stable.

During the meeting at Nik Saghir's office, Lim explained the provisions of the 1989 deed to Nik Saghir, the deceased and himself. The deceased discussed the 1990 wills with him on a number of occasions.

After the sale of the Ayer Itam land was aborted, he was not aware of any further dispute. When the deceased executed the 1990 wills, he was strict, careful and of sound mind. He had never seen the will/codicil Nik Saghir prepared.

In further re-examination, Hamid testified that in April 1990 the deceased gave him a copy of Tri-Am International Inc's offer of US$1.6m for the Benson land — D12. The deceased rejected that offer but instructed him to secure a sale for more than US$2m. Cheng Poon was aware of that offer from Tri-Am International Inc.

The deceased purchased a Rolls Royce and registered it in Cheng Poon's name. Richard who arranged the purchase told him that he received a commission from the seller. Several times, Cheng Poon instructed him to prepare a transfer of the Teluk Bahang land to himself (Cheng Poon). He did not do so.

Under further cross-examination by Mr Koh, Hamid testified that he could know if the true value of the Benson land was US$1.6m. In June 1990, in relation to the Benson land, he and Cheng Poon flew from London to the States. The deceased remained in London with a woman and Cheng Liat. He visited the Benson land with Cheng Poon. Richard received RM135,000 as commission from the purchase of the Rolls Royce.

row.entry: I put it to you... Cheng Poon did not instruct you to transfer the Teluk Bahang land to himself.
I maintain … Cheng Poon instructed me to transfer the Teluk Bahang land to himself ….

p.text: He tried to sell the Teluk Bahang land for the deceased. He negotiated with a prospective purchaser.

row.entry: I put it to you … the defendants were trying to discharge the Teluk Bahang land from BBMB and that Cheng Poon did not ask you to arrange the transfer of the said land to himself.'
I do not agree. Cheng Poon asked me to transfer the land onto himself.

I put it to you … you refused to hand to Cheng Poon whatever documents pertaining to the tentative sale of the Teluk Bahang land and Howard had to call En Ismail of Nik Saghir to try and obtain from En Ismail the documents relating to the tentative sale.
Yes, I can agree that Howard contacted the said Ismail to obtain the proposed documents.

p.text: Under further cross-examination by Mr Yeoh, Hamid testified that he did not know why the deceased did not accompany him to visit the Benson land. It was the idea of the deceased to sell the Benson land and that he and Cheng Poon should go to the States.

Teoh Say Bee, 68, testified that he had worked for the deceased for 50 years. He is presently employed by the estate of the deceased. His duty was to collect rents from the properties of the deceased, purchase the personal things of the deceased and read letters to the deceased. The deceased dictated and he typed the replies. 'For some 30 years, I was reading letters to the deceased and writing his replies. In one week there would be about three to four letters to be read to the deceased and three to four letters to reply.'

The wife of the deceased died in 1988. In 1990, the deceased was healthy; he was reading the deceased's letters to the deceased and writing his replies. In 1991, he was still reading the deceased's letters to the deceased and the deceased was still replying his letters. In 1992, roughly from January, the deceased was not registering the letters read to him and not instructing him to reply his letters.

Prior to the death of the wife of the deceased, and for ten years, Bok Eng was not living at Pykett Avenue. During that time, Cheng Poon and her children stayed on at Pykett Avenue. Bok Eng and the wife of the deceased were not on good terms. After the demise of the wife of the deceased, Eng moved back to Pykett Avenue.

In July 1992, Bok Eng informed him that the deceased was admitted to LWE Hospital. He was instructed to take care of the deceased. He stayed at the LWE Hospital for about five to six days. On the first day, the deceased woke up at about 11am. 'His body was still … something like in fits. It was happening once every half an hour. He could not speak to me.' During those five to six days, he was constantly with the deceased; he slept in the deceased's room. On the second day, the deceased was hallucinating — the deceased said that a lot of people were walking in a picture on the wall. The deceased asked how much was his driver's salary and whether his driver had a house. The deceased said he wanted to give a big house and RM5,000 to his driver. The deceased said he wanted to give him (Say Bee) and Beng Tatt RM5m each.

Before the deceased was admitted to LWE Hospital, he was urinating blood. After the deceased was discharged, he could not express himself. The deceased was forgetful. 'For example, he would ask for roast chicken and when I gave him roast chicken, he would say he wanted chicken chops. He would ask for 'kuih' and when I gave him 'kuih' he would say that he wanted 'kuih talam'. The deceased could not dress himself. He had to dress and undress the deceased.

After the deceased was discharged from LWE Hospital, he was not reading; he was starring at the newspapers. The deceased could not understand what was read to him. The deceased would not respond. The deceased, during the 50 years that he worked for him, was a frugal and careful man. After he was discharged in July 1992, the deceased gave money to whoever asked of him.

Prior to 1992, the deceased signed the rental receipts. After January 1992, the deceased was still signing the rental receipts but his signatures, sometimes, were incomplete. After January 1992, the signatures of the deceased were full of mistakes. He had to rewrite the receipts. He did not know if the deceased was aware he was signing rental receipts but he informed the deceased he was signing rental receipts. When he presented rental receipts for signature, the deceased signed without question. In a month, the deceased had to sign 40 rental receipts. There would be five to six mistakes in those 40 receipts.

In the afternoon, on 3 August 1992, he was at Penang Hill. The deceased had asked him to be at his bungalow (Fairmount). The deceased reached the bungalow at 7pm; two Thai ladies in their 20's were accompanying the deceased. The driver was there. four persons carried the deceased in a sedan chair to the bungalow. The deceased, when he reached the bungalow, physically normal but was quiet. When he was healthy, the deceased visited his bungalow about two to three times a year.

In the morning of 3 August 1992, the deceased was in the house; later, he was not in the house. He did not know where the deceased went and with whom. At the bungalow, he asked the deceased what he wanted to eat. The deceased said, 'curry and bread'. He had no further conversation with the deceased. On the night of 3 August 1992, one of those two Thai ladies passed the night in the deceased's room. Those two Thai ladies, Cheng Poon procured them, were supporting the deceased as he was moving about the bungalow. The next morning, at 10am the entire party descended from Penang Hill. Bok Eng operates a stained glass factory — 'Glashaus' — at Pykett Avenue.

Under cross-examination by Mr Koh, Say Bee testified that he kept records of the rentals collected and the daily expenses. Other than letters, did not read other documents to the deceased. 'Before his death, the deceased practised on a piece of paper before he signed a document. Before that he was normal.' After the deceased was discharged from the LWE Hospital, he (Say Bee) received a bonus. The deceased was senile.
In 1993, he accompanied the deceased to temples, dentists and tailors. The deceased said to him that he wanted to go to those places. In 1993, the deceased asked him to buy lottery tickets.

Under cross-examination by Mr Yeoh, Say Bee testified that the deceased was very close to his wife. However, he did not know if the deceased consulted his wife on family matters. Before 1988, the deceased was fine; the deceased had palpitation of the heart; the deceased was only hospitalised for medical check-ups. The deceased was very sad when his wife passed away. After two or three months, 'he was normal again. He was looking happy. He was healthy.'

Before her death, the wife of the deceased ran the household whilst the deceased instructed him on financial matters. After her death, Cheng Poon was giving instructions on financial matters of the deceased as Cheng Poon was close to the deceased.

For 30 years, he read the deceased's letters to the deceased. The deceased could read but he wanted him (Say Bee) to read to him. There were occasions when the deceased would read his letters. Beginning the end of 1991, the deceased was forgetful and could not express himself. In 1992, the deceased seem not to be registering what he had read to him; sometimes, the deceased would ask what he had read to him.

row.entry: Upon what basis... you are so sure it was December 1991?
I just know it was December 1991.

p.text: In re-examination, Say Bee testified that the deceased, when he accompanied him to temples, dentists and tailors, did not talk much. During those trips, the deceased was quite forgetful. At the temple, he had to ask the deceased if he wanted joss-sticks. Before 1992, the deceased would ask him for joss-sticks. In 1992, the deceased would be sitting quietly if he did not prompt him to pray. At the end of 1991, he noticed that the deceased was getting more and more forgetful. In 1992, on many occasions, the deceased asked for masseur service. In 1992, he did not see the deceased reading his letters. In 1992, when he read the deceased's letters to the deceased, the deceased would be quiet. In 1991, he read all letters to the deceased. The deceased was not reading on his own. In 1991, sometimes the deceased would dictate his replies, but sometimes he would not.

Under further cross-examination by Mr Koh, Say Bee testified that the deceased said to him the matters set out in para 3 of B1(B)(17 — that the Teluk Bahang was intended for Cheng Bok, Cheng Liat and Cheng Poon. 'That was said to me whilst I was with the deceased in Singapore in 1993. He was still senile but that was what he said to me.'

row.entry: I have to put it to you that para 3 of B1(B)(17) never happened.
I disagree. He did say to me such things. The deceased also told me the subject in B1(B)(17) para 4.
Since the deceased said all that to you he was of sound mind?
I don't agree he was of sound mind but he said that to me.
I put it to you that B1(B)(17) para 4 never happened as he did borrow money in his own name even after he was more than 80 years old.
He did tell me the things in B1(B)(17) para 4.
I put it to you … the deceased would not have discussed those matters with you.
He did say all those things to me.

p.text: Teh Beng Tatt, 44, a clerk of the estate of the deceased and of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd, testified that he started working for the deceased as a book keeper and finance clerk in December 1979.
The deceased was angry with Cheng Poon as the 1989 deed would give all his property to Cheng Poon. The deceased did not want that deed.

In July 1992, after he was discharged, the deceased became very quiet and his memory became worse — he could not remember things well. Sometimes, he could not continue with his signature of his cheques. In July and August 1992, the deceased's memory was very bad.

On 1 August 1992, when he reached home, he was informed that someone from his office telephoned and asked him to be at the office at 6.30pm. At 6.30pm, at Pykett Avenue, the deceased was having his dinner. He waited in the office. Saying he wanted to see if Hamid was in the will, Howard asked him for the safe keys. He told Howard that he must wait for the deceased. Richard brought the deceased to the office and Howard asked the deceased to instruct him to hand over the safe keys. The deceased was quiet — just starring at him. Howard took the safe keys from him and opened the safe. He (Beng Tatt) took out an envelope with the words, 'last will of Datuk Khaw Bian Cheng dated 24 October 1990'. Howard took that envelope and proceeded upstairs with Richard. He followed them. Howard opened the envelope and read the wills. Howard said to Richard that there were mistakes and that the wills must be redone. Howard did not mention the mistakes. He (Beng Tatt) left without the safe keys.

In the morning of 3 August 1992, Bok Eng told him that 'they have made arrangements for Lim and Dr Gafoor's presence in the house and that an appointment has been made with one Dr Tan'. He was instructed to escort Lim and Dr Gafoor upstairs when they arrived.

At 2.30 pm, one Patricia Lim who was in the house told him that Howard requested her to type some documents. Patricia asked for his help. He told her, he did not know how to use a notebook computer. He did not want to help as he had no wish to involve himself in the preparation of the documents she was typing. After the documents were ready, he got to know that Patricia was preparing the will of the deceased.

On 3 August 1992, he saw the execution of wills at Pykett Avenue. Present were Lim, Dr Gafoor, Cheng Poon and Howard. Lim arrived at 4pm. Dr Gafoor arrived shortly thereafter. Say Bee was away, at Penang Hill. Lim, Dr Gafoor and the deceased were seated at a long table. Cheng Poon was present. Richard appeared on and off. The wills were not signed at 4pm. They waited for half an hour. Howard brought in documents in loose sheet form from his room. Howard gave those documents to Lim. 'First round, the third defendant brought in more than ten sheets. Then from subsequent rounds, he brought in five to six sheets in each round. Howard made about five to six trips. After each trip, Howard waited for a while in his room. Each time he handed the documents to Lim.'

He was very close to the deceased when the deceased signed those documents. He turned the pages for him. 'It was not true that Lim read and explained the wills to the deceased. It was not read (nor) explained to the deceased.' Howard was commuting between the living room and his room. After depositing the last batch of documents, Howard stationed himself at the table. The execution of documents commenced at about 4.30pm and ended around 6pm. Beng Tatt said that the 1992 wills appeared to be the documents signed on 3 August 1992. The deceased was quiet throughout the execution of documents. He did not leave the deceased.

Whilst waiting for Dr Gafoor and Lim, the deceased wanted to go to Penang Hill. It appeared that the deceased was in a hurry to go there. Immediately after signing the documents, the deceased left for Penang Hill. Lim took possession of the documents.

On 12 August 1992, Richard told him that Lim had asked him to collect some documents for the deceased and Dr Gafoor's signatures. At Lim's office, handed him some loose sheets of documents and said that some documents signed on 3 August 1992 had mistakes. Lim asked him to take those loose sheets to the deceased and Dr Gafoor for their signatures. He was not asked to obtain Dr Gafoor's' rubber stamp. He took those loose sheets. The deceased signed those loose sheets; he was the only other person present. He had explained to the deceased that Lim needed the deceased's signature on those loose sheets as the previous documents had mistakes. 'The deceased did not say anything. He just signed.'

Next, he presented those loose sheets to Dr Gafoor who signed on all those loose sheets. He was the only other person present. He had explained to Dr Gafoor that those loose sheets were from Lim who had explained that the earlier documents had mistakes and that he (Dr Gafoor) was required to sign those loose sheets. The next day, he handed those loose documents to Richard. Beng Tatt said, he could recognize only one of those loose sheets he collected on 12 August 1992.

On 26 August 1992, Lim came to his office with further documents, 1cm thick, for the signature of the deceased. Lim explained to the deceased that the earlier wills were wrong and needed to be redone. The deceased did not respond; he signed those documents in the presence of Lim. Then, Lim instructed him to take those documents to Dr Gafoor for his signature. On 28 August 1992, at Dr Gafoor's clinic with those documents, he was informed that Dr Gafoor was on vacation. He returned those documents to Lim.

On 4 September 1992, Lim came to his office and gave him the same documents Lim had given on 26 August 1992. Lim asked him to have those documents signed by Dr Gafoor. He kept that stack of documents in his cabinet. Richard had a set of keys to his cabinet. On 14 September 1992, he brought that stack of documents to Dr Gafoor's clinic. Dr Gafoor signed those documents. 'Only the two of us were present'. He had explained to Dr Gafoor that those documents needed his signature and that he (Beng Tatt) was instructed by Lim. He handed those signed documents to Richard; Howard had instructed him that all important documents executed by the deceased must be inspected by Cheng Poon and family.

He kept the accounts of the deceased from 1979 until the death of the deceased. He had custody of the deceased's cheques. Before 1992, each time the deceased wanted a cheque, the deceased would ask him to bring him a cheque. Only after the deceased inspected the cheque would the deceased sign the cheque. For recurrent expenditure, he would prepare the cheques without prior instructions. Nonetheless, the deceased would question the payments. 'That was the routine up and until the end of 1991. From my experience it was difficult to get the deceased to sign a cheque. He had many questions to ask before he would sign a cheque. The deceased was not easy (nor) free with his money. He was concerned about his cash flow.' Before 1992, none of the first to third defendants instructed him (Beng Tatt) on the preparation of the deceased's cheques.

Sometime in May to July 1992, the first to third defendants were instructing him on the preparation of the deceased's cheques — big amount were involved. Each time he consulted the deceased, but each time, one of the first to third defendants would follow him to the deceased's room. 'Then they would ask the deceased for money. The deceased kept quiet. The (first, or third) defendants then asked him to prepare the cheque and he would prepare the cheque. The deceased then signed the cheque.' Before 1992, the deceased only instructed him to prepare cheques of a few thousand for Cheng Poon and Richard. From 1992, amounts requested to be drawn by Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard were very large — all more than RM100,000, and for a few hundred thousand ringgit. The deceased did not ask any questions. He signed the cheques. He did not and does not think that the deceased knew what he was signing. In June 1992, more than RM2m were signed to Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard. In all his years working for the deceased, he had not seen such large withdrawals within such a short period from the deceased's accounts. In December 1992, the deceased's account had less than RM10,000.

Cheng Poon never worked in his life. Richard, as Managing Director of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd, was drawing RM2,500 a month. Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd is not an active company; it has only a piece of land — Pykett Avenue. Howard was not working in Penang.

Beng Tatt thus explained the accounts found in the bundles: He prepared the accounts — PB1(127-143). PB1(127-130) the Thai accounts. PB1(132) was the 'ancestral worship' account. PB1(133-135) was the summary of the accounts of the deceased from January 1993 to 10�April 1993. PB1(136-138) was the account in continuation of PB1(133-135), from 10 April 1993 to 31 March 95. PB1(139-142) was the US accounts. He prepared the Malaysian accounts. He did not prepare the Thai or US accounts. He prepared the US accounts from details given orally by Howard.

In the month of June 1992, deceased wrongly signed eight cheques — P6(1-8). Sometimes, the deceased tested out his signature on a piece of paper. Sometimes, when the deceased could not sign, he would suggest to the deceased to sign on the following day. Cheng Poon insisted that the deceased sign the cheques 'there and then'. Cheng Poon said, it was his father's money and he (Beng Tatt) should not interfere but listen to him as he would be his future employer. He (Beng Tatt) was afraid of Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard as he could be sacked if he did not listen to them. 'It was stressful working for the (first to third) defendants. It was stressful as the first to third defendants were giving instructions'.
After the institution of the present proceedings, Howard asked him to sign a statutory declaration, but he refused as the statements in the statutory declaration were not true.

Other than the sums withdrawn in PB1(150) — a bank statement of the deceased's account — three other sums (RM316,133.06, RM133,294.02 and RM130,420.55) were withdrawn from other accounts. [see PB1(155)]. But not all withdrawals were taken by Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard. Some were towards monthly expenses.

On 10 April 1993, the deceased had RM26,927.88 in Malaysia. From the details provided by Howard, the US estate, on 31 May 1995, had a deficit account — USD13,187.82 owing to Howard. As for the Thai accounts, the amount standing to the credit of the estate on 31 March 1993, according to the accounts faxed to him — PB1(129-130) — was Baht174,649.01. On 31 March 1995, the estate in Malaysia had a deficit of RM172,666.31. Richard instructed him to send USD37,021.44 from the Malaysian to the US estate.

Beng Tatt explained that PB1(129) was the key-in copy from the information extracted from a facsimile copy. In the facsimile copy, the item stated as 'testamentary expenses' in PB1(129) was stated as 'funeral' expenses. Howard instructed him to amend it to testamentary expenses. The Malaysian account never received Baht234,450. The Malaysian estate spent RM39,802.56 on the funeral of the deceased.

In November 1993, Richard appointed him to work for Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd, company without any active business or income. Richard advanced his salary. Glashaus Sdn Bhd is a company owned by Bok Eng and Quah Bah Bah. Sometime in 1994, Glashaus Sdn Bhd started paying rent to Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd.
