Richard instructed him to type (i) PB3(1) — an application by Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd to the receiver and manager of the estate for a RM190,000 advance; and (ii)�PB1(158) — the instructions of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd to Tan Chiew Hun to obtain a purchaser for Pykett Avenue at the price of RM16,215,760.

The deceased had a BMW 735IL (a car he paid in full) in the name of Richard. The deceased owned a Rolls-Royce in the name of Cheng Poon. The deceased used Cheng Poon's name as he the deceased was old and could not obtain a loan. He witnessed the will of the deceased dated 27�December 87 — DB1(B)(3-5).

Under cross-examination by Mr Koh, Beng Tatt testified that the deceased had more properties than those listed in the 1989 deed. In the afternoon, on 3 August 1992, he saw Richard at Pykett Avenue. Richard was there for a while. After that, he did not see Richard.

He prepared the accounts of the deceased for submission to the Inland Revenue. He also prepared the accounts of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd. He had custody of the personal cheques of the deceased. The deceased had a personal safe in a cabinet. The deceased was a careful man. Prior to 1 August 1992, he (Beng Tatt) was keeping the safe keys. The deceased entrusted that key to him after he worked for five to six years for the deceased. 'The deceased trusted me,' Beng Tatt said.

row.entry: I put it to you … the deceased kept all safe keys.
Not true. I had one set.
I put it to you … the deceased's set was the only set.

p.text: Prior to him handing the safe keys to Howard, each time the safe was opened the deceased was present.

On 3 August 1992, (i) the deceased did not have any documents in front of him, (ii) he did not serve drinks to Dr Gafoor and Lim, (iii) there was not much conversation, and, (iv) Cheng Poon, the deceased, Dr�Gafoor and Lim were together from 4.30pm to 6pm; Howard was also present although he was moving in and out of his room. After the arrival of Dr�Gafoor and Lim, the deceased asked him to stay on; he stayed on.

row.entry: It was Lim Cheng Chuan who asked you to see Dr Gafoor about some documents. It was on 12 August 1992.
Yes, Lim Cheng Chuan gave me some documents and he asked me to get it signed by the deceased and after that by Dr�Gafoor.�…
Do you remember the deceased asking Howard to make some changes to the documents, that is on 3 August 1992?
I did not hear such from the deceased.
The third defendant brought out three sets of documents from his room?.
He took out loose sheets. It was not bound together. He passed it to Lim Cheng Chuan. I could see it was in loose sheet form.

p.text: He had not seen the 24 July 1992 deeds. Sums of RM866,000 were promised to Cheng Bok, Cheng Poon and Cheng Liat from the sale of the Batu Ferringhi land. That land was sold in June/July 1991. The deceased agreed to give 45% to Cheng Bok, Cheng Poon and Cheng Liat. The documents he gave Richard were the wills dated 3 August 1992. He did not refer to the deceased as Howard had instructed him to refer only to the first to third defendants. He could not refer to the deceased as the deceased was not well. But he reported to the deceased that the 1992 wills were handed to Richard.

The deceased was not a quiet man. He liked to talk. He (the deceased) to talk to him. He liked to talk about his grandfather (Sim Bee). After discharge from the hospital, the deceased was a quiet man.
He did not prepare the letter dated 8 July 1991 from the deceased to Tan Peng Seng. He had not seen the letter dated 9 July 1991 from Lim to the deceased.
From July to December 1992, a few million ringgit was withdrawn from the deceased's account. Each time a large sum was withdrawn, he informed the deceased.

In July 1992, after the deceased was discharged, he received a bonus. He did not think the deceased knew what he was giving. When the deceased sold the Batu Ferringhi land, he gave a bonus to Say Bee and himself. The deceased insisted on the second bonus.

row.entry: Since the deceased insisted on giving you a bonus, then he was not senile.

Usually he would only give a bonus for each land sale. But that was the second bonus. First bonus he gave a 12 months' bonus but on the second occasion he gave 15 months' bonus. I cannot explain the second bonus.

p.text: Cheng Poon instructed him to prepare PB2(5) — the deceased's instructions to his trustees with regard to the RM826,000 to Cheng Bok and RM866,000 to Cheng Liat. The deceased had no money to pay Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat. Cheng Bok read PB2(5). When the deceased signed PB2(5), he (the deceased) was a bit senile.

row.entry: I put it to you … when the deceased signed PB2(5) the deceased was not senile.
He was already not well. He was not that senile, just that when you tell him anything he would not understand. Anything you tell him he would keep quiet.

p.text: In 1992, the deceased instructed him to pay interest to Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat. Cheng Poon suggested the payment of interests when the deceased could not pay Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat.

The deceased gave a mandate to Cheng Poon to draw on account CA�1540021212. Cheng Poon instructed the cheque 00129790 for RM1,436,781.57 for the redemption of the Teluk Bahang land; Cheng Poon instructed the early settlement of the overdraft account. When he informed the deceased of that cheque, the deceased just stared at him. 'I don't think he understood me.' The deceased signed that cheque.

The deceased instructed him to prepare the cheques for the second bonus to Say Bee and himself. Beng Tatt did not agree that the deceased in July 1992 was not senile. 'He just instructed, "write, write, write". He did not explain himself. He mentioned the amount.'

Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard instructed him to prepare the cheque for RM866,000 to Cheng Poon. He presented that cheque to the deceased for signature. The deceased signed that cheque. 'The deceased did not know what he was signing. I believe … from February 1992 the deceased was not aware of what he was paying out. From February 1992, when he explained cheque payments to the deceased, 'mostly he would stare at me.' He was instructed to prepare the following cheques: RM866,00 to Cheng Poon, RM197,000 to Cheng Poon, RM225,000 to Howard, RM225,000 to Bok Eng, RM225,000 to Cheng Poon, RM512,063.70 to Cheng Poon, RM182,000 to Howard, RM39,000 to Howard, RM31,000 to Gim Chuan, RM31,000 to Howard, RM100,000 to Gim Chuan, RM100,000 to Howard. He said to the deceased that the reasons for those payments were that of Cheng Poon and Howard. He did not explain the latter payments as Cheng Poon and Howard had explained those payments in his presence. 'I did not believe even then that the deceased understood the explanation given.'

Beng Tatt denied that he prepared DB1(E)(129) — the acknowledgement of Tan Peng Hin and Tan Peng Seng of their receipt of RM187,500 and RM375,000 respectively, with regard to the sale of the Batu Ferringhi land, from the deceased. Howard explained to the deceased the payment of RM100,000 to Gim Guan.

row.entry: I put it to you … the RM100,000 was for (Gim Chuan) living expenses in the US.
I put it to you … you objected, as it could not be justified.
If Gim Chuan would come and she would testify that she explained to me the purpose of the RM100,000, would you say that she would be lying?

p.text: On 1 July 1992, Cheng Bok instructed him to prepare two payments — RM11,027 and RM8,000 — to himself. Cheng Bok said that he had explained the payments to his father. He informed the deceased of what Cheng Bok had said and the reason for those two payments. The deceased did not understand him.

On 27 July 1992, the deceased called him to write a cheque of RM5,000 to one Ong San Huah. On 1 August 1992, the deceased instructed him to pay RM40 for a Justice of the Peace tie. The deceased also instructed him to pay RM480 to one 'KS'. The deceased said, 'give me RM480'. There was a standing instruction to pay a yearly sum of 200 English pounds to Sally Khaw.

Cheng Poon instructed him to circle certain figures in PB4(6) and charge those sums to the estate. He circled those figures Cheng Poon said should be charged to the estate — see PB4(6-10). Later, Richard took out some of the circled items; the estate did not pay those items Richard had taken out.
He saw Patricia Lim. When he refused to help, she and Howard, not Richard, went upstairs.

row.entry: I put it to you … what you testified about Lim Cheng Chuan coming on 26 August 1992 with loose sheets for the deceased's signature is a lie.
I put it to you … on 25 August 1992 the deceased was in Thailand.
I saw him on 26 August 1992. I cannot explain why the deceased's passport shows that the deceased was not in the country on 26 August 1992.
I put it to you … you are lying about the deceased not knowing about the cheques and the payments and what you said (had) transpired on 3 August 1992.
I am not lying, possibly I may have mixed up the dates.

p.text: After the institution of these proceedings, Howard asked him what was happening. He said to Howard what he said in court. Howard asked if he (Beng Tatt) was certain of the dates. He (Beng Tatt) replied he was. He told Howard that he recorded the dates.

row.entry: I put it to you … you were preparing to come to court and lie.

p.text: Under Mr Yeoh's cross-examination, Beng Tatt testified that the health of the deceased before his wife passed away was good. But the deceased complained of palpitations. He could not remember whether the deceased was ever hospitalised before his wife passed away. 'After the deceased's wife passed away, the deceased's health was all right. He was very sad that his wife passed away.'

During working hours, he would know if the children of the deceased were visiting. 'Cheng Bok visited his father maybe three or four times in a year'. Cheng Liat was a frequent visitor, until he was barred from Pykett Avenue. Cheng Hum and Liang Imm were also frequent visitors.

He could not recall the deceased having taken an overseas trip whilst his wife was alive. After his wife passed away, the deceased made several overseas trips — to London, to the States and China as he could recall. Cheng Poon arranged those trips.

He and Cheng Poon were present when the deceased said he did not want the 1989 deed. Hamid explained the 1989 deed to the deceased. He (Beng Tatt) was not clear whether the deceased ordered Cheng Poon out of the house, but he and Hamid were present when the deceased scolded Cheng Poon. He was at the E & O Hotel when the deceased had one of his meetings with his sons and Nik Saghir. He and Say Bee accompanied the deceased. He was outside the meeting room. He attested the will dated 27�December 1987. When the deceased signed the will dated 27 December 1987, he and Goh Eng Kee were present.

The deceased instructed and he prepared the monthly maintenance of RM1,400 each to Cheng Hum, Cheng Bok, and Cheng Liat. The deceased shouldered as well education/other expenses — RM1,000 to Cheng Hum, RM1,000 to Cheng Liat and RM5,000 to Cheng Bok. After the sale of the Ayer Itam land, the deceased terminated the monthly payments to Cheng Hum. The monthly payments to Cheng Liat and Cheng Bok were stopped when interests on the RM826,000 and RM866,000 were paid to them.

The deceased instructed and he typed the letter barring Cheng Liat from Pykett Avenue — DB1(B)(9). Cheng Poon who was present did not say anything to him (Beng Tatt). He gave that letter to the deceased. He did not type DB2(A)(9).

In re-examination, Beng Tatt testified that after he handed the safe keys to Howard, he did not know of the whereabouts of the (1990) wills. After 1 August 1992, whenever the safe was opened, he was not required.

DB1(D)(347-349) was his hand written calculation of the amount of money in the deceased's account; Howard asked for that computation. He (Beng Tatt) took into account some of the payments that should be made; the payments RM1,026,000 (a rough estimate) to Cheng Bok, RM105,000 (for a van) and RM866,000 to Cheng Liat were never paid.

Beng Tatt clarified that he said the deceased was not well as the deceased was forgetful, could not sign properly, and could not understand what was said to him. Beng Tatt said, he would not know whether the 1992 wills were ever handed to the deceased. From February 1992, the deceased would not comprehend the reason for the cheque he was signing. Before February 1992, even for small amounts, the deceased would ask the reason for each cheque. Before February 1992, he could not recall the deceased having paid large sums, as in PB1(E)(129) to strangers, or to the family. Before 1992, he (Beng Tatt) would know the reason of the deceased's payments.

Cheng Poon took RM140,000 from the deceased account and deducted the expenses in PB4(6-10)(the circled items) he charged to the deceased. That RM140,000 was paid into Cheng Poon's account — see PB1(147). The deceased was giving to Cheng Poon an occasional RM1,000 to RM3,000. 'When Cheng Poon asked from his father, the deceased would give him. I recorded it in the accounts.' Bok Eng, Richard, Howard and Gim Chuan were each receiving RM50 a week from the deceased. That was also recorded.

'Although I may have been mistaken about the date 26 August 1992, I was not lying about the events. That all had taken place. Maybe the date I said as 26 August 1992 was 25 August 1992. It was approximately 26�August 1992.'

Beng Tatt said that the suggestion that he was preparing himself to lie in court was and is not true. 'Personally, I have nothing against the first and third defendants. They have treated me well. Richard has also invited me to work for Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd. There was and is no reason for me to lie in court. I was summoned to court. I am here to tell the truth.'

In further examination, Beng Tatt testified that the calculation in DB1(D)(348) took into consideration payments intended for Cheng Liat and Cheng Bok. He could not remember the figures in DB1(D)(349). The deceased was very happy when he saw the offer for his Benson land. The deceased asked him to show the offer to Cheng Poon and to call Hamid to the office. The deceased told Hamid to sell the Benson land for more than US$2m. Cheng Poon was present. The deceased who was afraid that Cheng Bok would sell his (Cheng Bok) house (124 Jalan Dato' Sulaiman, Johore Bahru) instructed him to keep the title deed. After the deceased passed away, he returned the title deed to Cheng Bok.
Under further cross-examination by Mr Koh, Beng Tatt said that DB1(D)(347-349) was personally instructed by Howard.

row.entry: I put it to you … Howard did not instruct you.
Isn't DB1(D)(354-355) a full record of the RM140,000 taken by Cheng Poon?.
The figures in DB1(D)(354-355) were not audited, but it was an account of how the RM140,000 was spent by Cheng Poon.

p.text: RM38,274 was transferred to the BBMB. RM16,484 was paid to Cheng Bok. The expenses in DB1(D)(354-355) were not recorded in the estate account; only the RM140,000 taken by Cheng Poon was recorded. Whilst the deceased was alive, he prepared and kept the accounts of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd. Richard appointed him to work for Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd at a monthly salary of RM650. After the appointment of the receiver and manager, Bok Eng asked him to leave Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd as there was no further work for him.

row.entry: I put it to you … you were told not to come to Pykett Avenue because files were being stolen.
I was not told. I was only given the reason of the appointment of the receiver and manager.
The first to third defendant, they always treat you well?
They have always been treating me well. There is no grudge between us.

p.text: The litigants who testified, and all testified in the English language, were Cheng Bok, Cheng Liat, Richard, Howard and Cheng Hum.

Cheng Bok testified that he was not in Pykett Avenue when the 1992 wills were signed. He was not aware that the deceased, in August 1992, would be signing wills. The 1990 wills were signed in October 1990. He was present when the deceased signed a set of wills in March 1990. About five or six days after the burial of the deceased, read the 1992 wills, at Pykett Avenue, to him, Cheng Poon, Richard, Howard, Say Bee, Beng Tatt and Bok Eng. Only then, he got to know of the 1992 wills.

He visited the deceased every two to three months. Each time, he stayed for two to three days. Cheng Poon disliked him staying too long. Whilst his mother was alive, he made more frequent visits to Pykett Avenue. When the deceased was admitted to the LWE Hospital in July 1992, he was in Thailand. He came back, on 17 July 1992, and visited the deceased at the hospital; the deceased was quiet and did not respond to him. After the deceased was discharged, he visited the deceased at Pykett Avenue; he stayed in the same room as the deceased.

He was given to understand that the deceased was warded for six weeks in Singapore in 1993. He was not aware that the deceased was warded. He was told, each time he telephoned Pykett Avenue, by Say Bee or Beng Tatt, that the deceased was holidaying in Kuala Lumpur. Say Bee and Beng Tatt informed him that Cheng Poon had instructed them to inform him so. Sometime later, Say Bee or Richard told him that the deceased was in a coma in Singapore. He rushed to Singapore with his children. When he saw the deceased, the deceased was in a coma in the intensive care unit. The following day, the deceased passed away. He was shocked that Cheng Poon and Richard had not informed him that the deceased was warded in Singapore. He would have visited the deceased much earlier if he had been informed. He believed his other brothers and sister were also not informed. They were kept in the dark.

When his father died, he was in Singapore. He felt that the body should be taken back to Penang for funeral rites and for relatives and friends to pay their respects. Cheng Poon, Bok Eng, Richard and Howard overruled him. Instead, the deceased's body was lying in a cheap funeral parlour for four days; the deceased's body was lying on a board from 9 am to 6pm. Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard were not at the funeral parlour. Only he was present with his second son. In the evening, after the coffin arrived, he asked Howard to be photographed with the body of the deceased. Howard declined; he would not be near the body. Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard did not mourn. Cheng Poon was 'euphoric'; he bought two diamond studded watches and showed off the watches at the funeral parlour. The deceased's body was taken back to Penang in a lorry. He had proposed to Cheng Poon to fly the body to Penang. But Cheng Poon said it was 'dead meat'. No one accompanied the body as it was taken to Penang. He was very sad that the remains of the deceased were so treated.

The deceased, a Buddhist and a Taoist who believed in proper funerals and proper rites, careful with money. He could not remember the deceased having given large sums, before 1992, to his children. The deceased, well behaved and disciplined, would not give money easily to his children. The deceased was strict with him. In 1957, when the deceased purchased a Holden car for him, the deceased mortgaged his (Cheng Bok) house and would not pay him the rents received. In 1967, when the deceased gave him RM60,000, the deceased made him transfer three houses in Kulim to the deceased. Although he was more charitable as he got older, the deceased was still careful with his money. The deceased cared for his reputation; he honoured his obligations and his word. His mother agreed to give Chim, Cheng Liat and Cheng Poon, each 15% of the sale proceeds that would be received from the sale of the Batu Ferringhi land. The sale was concluded. But he did not receive his 15% share; he only received some interests on his share (RM826,000).

In 1988, the deceased had a disagreement with Cheng Poon. He had to separate them. Both, apparently, were after the same woman. Sometime in 1990, the deceased informed him that the deceased had appointed Teik Lim, Cheng Poon, Cheng Poon's son and Cheng Bok as the trustees of his wills. The deceased informed him that the 1990 wills prohibited any challenge to the 1990 wills.

Both the 1990 and 1992 wills stipulated a limit of RM40,000 to be spent on the deceased's funeral. Cheng Poon spent RM63,000 on the funeral. When Lim informed him that the 1992 wills provided for the distribution of the estate 30 years after the death of the deceased, he knew the 1992 wills were not wills of the deceased. The deceased was not inconsiderate to his children; however, his children, 30 years after his demise, would also be dead. There was an instance when the deceased intended that Pykett Avenue should not be sold within 10 years from the date of his death. He, Cheng Liat and Cheng Poon pleaded to the deceased that their deaths were approaching. The deceased relented and stipulated five years instead of ten in the 1990 wills. The deceased could not have provided for the distribution of his estate 30 years after his death.

He asked Dr Gafoor, in January 1994, of the events on 3 August 1992. Dr Gafoor told him that he (Dr Gafoor) was asked to go to Pykett Avenue. Dr Gafoor thought that the deceased was ill. Dr Gafoor said that he was surprised he was asked to witness the execution of wills. Dr Gafoor told him that Beng Tatt handed him, sometime around 12 August 1992, loose documents, purportedly from the 1992 wills, for his signature. Dr �Gafoor also told him that Beng Tatt handed him, on or about 14 September 1992, further loose sheets of documents for his signature. Having heard Dr�Gafoor, he suspected that the 1992 wills were bad and defective.

Sometime in March 1993, with Cheng Liat, he went to the office of Lim. Lim who appeared nervous did not want to speak to them. He asked Lim whether he prepared the 1992 wills. Lim replied that the 1992 wills were prepared by Howard. Lim told him that he (Lim) thought he was to prepare the 1992 wills; instead, he was asked to witness the 1992 wills. When he (Cheng Bok) found out the truth about the 1992 wills, he withdrew his consent given to Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard for their administration of the Thai, Malaysian and US estates. He applied to the Thai manager for the name of the solicitor who prepared PB2 (49-60). He received no reply. Subsequently, in Penang, he met the Thai manager who gave him the name and address of the solicitor who prepared the petition for administration of the Thai estate. He instructed his solicitors to write PB1(86, 88-101). When Richard and Howard petitioned the US courts for administration, they had received his demand. Despite the injunction of the High Court, Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard sold a condominium in Florida and 100 acres of land in Arizona. He had given them notice not to proceed with the sale. Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard refused to hand the sale proceeds to the receiver and manager of the estate of the deceased.

On the proposed development of Pykett Avenue, there was a Memorandum of Understanding ('MOU') between the trustees in the 1992 wills and Gloria Bay Sdn Bhd. He signed that MOU as he was told that condominiums on Pykett Avenue would bring income to the estate. However, that MOU was not finalised; Richard withdrew at the very last minute; Richard and Howard destroyed the MOU. He saw them burning the MOU at Pykett Avenue. He had not instigated Howard to burn the MOU. Howard burned the MOU as his request for an undertable payment — RM500,000 and a Mercedes Benz sports car — was turned down.

The accounting entries — PB1(151) — related to monies payable to him and Cheng Liat (RM826,000 and RM866,000). However, Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard pestered and pressurised the deceased into utilising the funds, approximately RM1.7m, to redeem the Teluk Bahang land and to transfer the Teluk Bahang land to Cheng Poon, on 3�August 1992. The deceased did not sign the transfer of the Telok Bahang land to Cheng Poon; the deceased did not know what he was doing.

In 1991, the deceased was well. In 1992, the deceased was not his usual self. Sometimes, he would not answer. He believed the mental health of the deceased was failing. In 1992, after discharge from the hospital, the deceased was starring for hours and not turning the newspapers in his hands. The deceased's conduct was strange; sometimes, throughout an entire dinner, he would not say a single word. The deceased was not able to feed himself.

Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard never worked in their lives. They could not have purchased all the properties in their names. All cars were purchased by the deceased; Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard merely held them for the deceased. Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard 'looted and plundered'. 'Once they sense the blood, they came … like sharks'. His mother had jewellery, about RM2m worth, antiques and expensive crockery. Cheng Poon and his wife kept that jewellery, antiques and expensive crockery. All personal property of their parents are retained by Cheng Poon. Cheng Poon has not surrendered any of that property to the receiver and manager of the estate.

All other children of the deceased were angry but hapless as Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard 'looted and plundered'. They were scared of Cheng Poon who was in a position to influence the deceased into cutting them off from the deceased's will. When Cheng Hum failed to visit the deceased, Cheng Poon instigated the deceased into terminating Cheng Hum's allowance that was paid for the past 60 years. Cheng Hum's house was confiscated at Cheng Poon's instigation. Cheng Liat was refused entry to Pykett Avenue after Cheng Poon poisoned the mind of the deceased.

Since the death of the deceased, he had been back to Pykett Avenue on two or three occasions. Prior to the withdrawal of his consent for the application for probate, he could enter Pykett Avenue. After he withdrew his consent, Cheng Poon became unfriendly. He had only been back to Pykett Avenue on one occasion; Cheng Poon and his wife refused to open the door for him. He had to sleep in Cheng Liat's house. Since that day, he chanced upon with Cheng Poon. He told Cheng Poon that the 1992 wills 'do not look right'. He said to Cheng Poon that someone must have tampered, altered and or changed the 1992 wills. Cheng Poon who denied knowledge was nervous; his face was green and pale. He was shaking as he was talking. Cheng Poon said that Richard and Howard were the culprits and he had nothing to do with it. He asked Cheng Poon why he had not stopped them. Cheng Poon just kept quiet. He also met Cheng Poon, on another occasion, in the KOMTAR building. He enquired on the properties of the estate. Cheng Poon told him that his side (Cheng Poon) was in control and if he (Cheng Bok) wanted to challenge him (Cheng Poon), he (Cheng Bok) would have to challenge him in America. Cheng Poon told him that his side (Cheng Poon) would get all the property of the estate in Thailand, US and Penang and that if he (Cheng Bok) wanted his money 'to come to America'.

He told Yeoh Keat Chye (DW2) that Cheng Poon apart from forging the 1992 wills had taken the Telok Bahang land and the deceased's cars. He told Yeoh Keat Chye that any settlement could be discussed if the Telok Bahang land, cars and his money were returned. Yeoh Keat Chye said that he (Yeoh) would convey his message to Cheng Poon.

Cheng Bok said that he and Cheng Liat, under the 1990 or 1992 wills, held the majority interest. Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard, tampering with the 1990 wills, had disobeyed the 1990 wills. By the 1992 wills, Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard enhanced their benefits and gained control of the estate.

In both the 1990 and 1992 wills, Cheng Hum was only given RM20,000 as Cheng Hum had inherited, even whilst the deceased was alive, seven shophouses at Dato Kramat Road from their paternal grandfather (Joo Chie), seven acres of land behind the Kek Lok Si temple from their paternal grandmother (Lim Swee Eam), a bungalow from the deceased and 'a free meal ticket for the last 65 years'. 'Cheng Hum was amply provided for.'

Cheng Bok proclaimed that he is ready, willing and able to perform his duties as a trustee. He testified that he is a Buddhist and a Taoist. He did not think that Cheng Poon has any religion. Cheng Bok doubted whether Cheng Poon would carry out the religious duties under the wills. He said that none of the deceased's children are allowed into Pykett Avenue to pay their respects to the ancestral tablets at the ancestral hall. Cheng Bok further declared that he would look after the welfare of Cheng Been and carry out the wishes of the deceased.

Under cross-examination by Mr Koh, Cheng Bok denied that Mr�John Khoo had asked Cheng Poon to sign the MOU. He also denied that John Khoo had suggested to Cheng Poon to execute the MOU and that he (John Khoo) would hold the MOU and not release it to Gloria Bay. He denied that Richard said that he (Richard) was afraid Cheng Poon would sign the MOU and hand it to John Khoo. He further denied it was then that he (Cheng Bok) suggested to Richard to burn the MOU. He maintained that he received PB1(49-64) [which is identical to DB1A(133-148)] from Lim and he gave PB1(49-64) to Richard. Cheng Bok agreed that the MOU was not finalised as one signatory was missing. He denied that the MOU was burned at his instigation, that he decided on the funeral arrangements or that he recommended the funeral parlour.

The deceased was furious when he discovered that the 1989 deed [DB1(A)(89-94)] was entirely in Cheng Poon's favour; the deceased ordered Cheng Poon out of the house. Thereafter, Cheng Liat became the deceased's favourite son, for about six months. Then, Cheng Poon poisoned the mind of the deceased who then refused Cheng Liat entry into Pykett Avenue. Thereafter, Cheng Poon became the favourite son. For 10 years, he was not allowed into Pykett Avenue. The deceased gave him RM20,000 to marry a third time. The deceased chose the bride for him. When the deceased entered LWE Hospital, he was on his honeymoon. The deceased paid him interest on his RM826,000. In 1992, the deceased was senile. The deceased did not know what he was doing; everything was done without his consent. In 1992, after the deceased left the hospital, the deceased was not himself. Most of the time, even before the deceased entered the LWE Hospital, the deceased could not answer. The deceased could not have signed those voluminous (1992). The 1992 wills were not read to the deceased. The deceased could not have understood the 1992 wills. The deceased was mentally blind. Cheng Bok denied that the deceased did not want to see him as he was always asking for money. He only asked for small sums. As for the RM826,000, he was only asking what was agreed by his mother. Cheng Bok denied he was disliked by the deceased who he said was a forgiving man. Cheng Bok agreed that he did not visit Pykett Avenue as the mood after he commenced his proceedings was hostile. He disagreed that Richard and Howard were the deceased's favourite grandsons. His son was the favourite grandson. However, Cheng Bok agreed that Cheng Poon was the deceased's favourite son.

Under cross-examination by Mr Yeoh, Cheng Bok testified as follows. Before 1988, he frequently visited his parents. After his mother passed away, his visits to Pykett Avenue were much less frequent. The deceased was very close to his wife. He was dependent on her and he consulted her on all family affairs. Before 1988, the deceased, although complaining of pain arthritis on his hands and swelling on his feet — was quite a healthy man. In 1987, the deceased and his wife were hospitalised at the Mount Elizabeth Hospital, Singapore. The deceased was hospitalised for the usual complaints. His mother was hospitalised because her red blood count was low. His father and mother who loved each other very much were hospitalised together as they needed each other's company. They were quiet inseparable. The deceased was gravely affected by the death of his wife; but after a few months, he became his old self.

Cheng Bok agreed that the deceased was closer to the children who lived with him. Cheng Hum was not close to the deceased. Cheng Liat, before 1988, was quite close to the deceased. Before his mother passed away, he was also quite close to the deceased. After his mother passed away, his relationship remained the same with the deceased. He was one of the deceased's favourite sons.

Until after January 1992, he did not notice any deterioration in the mental health of the deceased. Before that, even after his mother passed away, he did not notice anything wrong with the mental health of the deceased.

Hamid was the financial advisor and an old friend of the deceased. Hamid was also a long time friend of Cheng Poon; he was closer to Cheng Poon than him. Hamid always advised the deceased to be fair to all his children. He was informed that Hamid had advised the deceased not to withdraw RM1.7m to redeem the Teluk Bahang land as that money was to pay him and Cheng Liat.

Cheng Bok denied all knowledge of the 1989 deed until after the death of the deceased. He denied any close relationship with Cheng Liat. Cheng Liat did not inform him of the happenings in Pykett Avenue.

In 1990, in a hotel in Singapore, there was a meeting between the deceased, Cheng Liat, Cheng Poon, Hamid and himself to discuss the will of the deceased. He was asked to attend that meeting. The deceased agreed to the equal division of his property between Cheng Liat, Cheng Poon and himself. Cheng Bok denied he, Cheng Liat or Cheng Poon had arranged that meeting for the deceased to agree to the division of his property. Cheng Bok agreed that at that meeting, Cheng Poon, Cheng Liat and himself agreed to an equal division of the estate. Cheng Bok said he was not sure whether the deceased was present when they, the three brothers, reached their agreement. He did not ask the deceased about his (the deceased) prior wills. few days after that meeting, he was called to the office of Nik Saghir. Cheng Poon, Cheng Liat and Hamid were also at Nik Saghir's office. There, he was informed that the will of the deceased would be prepared. He denied that he was present when the deceased instructed Messrs Nik Saghir; the three sons waited outside Nik Saghir's room. The will was not signed in Nik Saghir's office. About a week or two after that meeting at Nik Saghir's office, Lim, Nik Saghir, Cheng Liat, Cheng Poon and himself met at the E & O Hotel, Penang. The deceased signed some documents in a room. He was not present when the deceased signed the wills that Nik Saghir prepared. He had not and has not seen that document. Towards the end of 1990 or beginning of 1991, he got to know from the deceased of the 1990 wills. He knew then that the deceased had executed an earlier will at the E & O Hotel. He thought the deceased was referring to the E & O will. He was and still is in the dark on the circumstances leading to the execution of the 1990 wills.

After the 1992 wills were read, he took possession of the 1990 wills lying in the deceased's bedroom. He played no part in the preparation of the 1990 wills. The deceased who never discussed the 1990 wills mentioned that he (the deceased) has a secret weapon in his will. He believed that cl�12 of the 1990 wills was that secret weapon. The deceased incorporated a deterrent clause to prevent future dispute, after he (the deceased) found out that the 1989 deed was not in accord with his wishes. He believed that Cheng Hum, although the eldest son, was only given RM20,000 as Cheng Hum was amply provided for, as Cheng Hum and his wife had refused to attend to the ancestral tablets and as the deceased despised Cheng Hum's 'allergy to work'. The deceased said, Cheng Hum was selfish, had not visited him when he was sick and had not cared for him when he needed attention. But the deceased still loved Cheng Hum as a son. Cheng Bok disagreed Cheng Hum was excluded because it was not the deceased's true will. In 1990, the deceased was not easily susceptible to influence or instigation.

Cheng Bok admitted that he inherited six houses, as joint tenant with the deceased, from his paternal grandfather. In 1967, in exchange for RM60,000, he surrendered those houses to the deceased. Cheng Hum inherited seven shophouses, as joint tenant with the deceased, from their paternal grandfather. Lim Swee Eam bequeathed RM14,000 to Cheng Hum. Liang Imm inherited much more from their paternal grandmother.
In re-examination, Cheng Bok clarified that the deceased was depressed by the death of his wife for three to six months. After that, new found freedom, his father forgot about the death of his wife.

Under further cross-examination by Mr Koh, Cheng Bok alleged that the deceased, in 1992, was merely following Cheng Poon's directives; for that reason, it was easy for Cheng Poon, Howard and Richard to plunder RM3.2m from the deceased. He found the 1990 wills (PB1, PB2 and PB3) in the condition before the court, that is, in a red comb bound bundle.

Cheng Liat, who said that he adopted the testimony of Cheng Bok, testified as follows. In 1988, his mother told him that she would be giving Cheng Bok, Cheng Poon and him each 15% of the sale proceeds from the sale of her Batu Ferringhi land.

He read the 1989 deed. He pointed out to the deceased that Cheng Bok and himself would not have anything. The deceased asked him to get Lim's explanation. He waited until Cheng Poon was in Thailand. Lim confirmed to the deceased that Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat, under the 1989 deed, would not have anything. The deceased arranged with Hamid for a second opinion. Cheng Bok, Cheng Poon, Lim, the deceased, Hamid and himself were at the office of Messrs Nik Saghir. Nik Saghir gave his opinion and advice to the deceased; the brothers remained outside Nik Saghir's chambers. He was informed that the deceased instructed Nik Saghir to prepare some documents. On one occasion, after that meeting with Nik Saghir, the deceased was very angry with Cheng Poon. The deceased hurled profanity, something he had not done before, at Cheng Poon. The deceased called Cheng Poon a wicked and vicious son and ordered Cheng Poon out of the house.
Prior to that meeting at Nik Saghir's office, the three brothers and the deceased were in Singapore. He told Cheng Bok that he and Cheng Bok, under the 1989 deed, would not have anything.

In March 1990, after that meeting at the office of Nik Saghir, the three brothers, Lim, Hamid and Nik Saghir met at the E & O Hotel. The deceased, Lim and Nik Saghir had a meeting in a room. The brothers remained outside. He believed that the deceased was executing a will. In March 1990, the deceased was of strong will. His children could not broach the subject of his will. The deceased resented that subject as he believed that he was yet not dying. He dared not speak to the deceased on that subject.

The deceased was a strict but good man. He was very careful with money. Many a time, the deceased threatened him, because of his (Cheng Liat) Christian faith, to cut him from his will. But the deceased did not do so. The deceased was domineering and wanted his ways. The deceased who never worked in his life was accustomed to others yielding to him. The deceased would not tolerate any argument. The deceased was very close to his mother who spoiled the deceased. But he was never unfaithful to her. The deceased was a charitable person. In 1975, the deceased generously returned the deposit, when it could be forfeited, to a purchaser. For 20 years, the deceased was donating to old folks' homes and to the blind. The deceased loved all his children. Cheng Poon was not loved more than the other sons. The deceased said that he disliked those who do not work. The deceased did not give money easily to his children. Many a time, his requests for money were turned down. The deceased was tight fisted with his children.

He was not aware, in October 1990, that the deceased had executed a will. After the death of the deceased, he got to know of the 1990 wills. In 1991, the deceased was still well but fickle and easily influenced by those around him. In 1990, after the deceased accused him of poisoning his drinking water, he was ordered to stay away from Pykett Avenue. Whilst the deceased was alive, he made several attempts to enter Pykett Avenue; but Cheng Poon shooed him away. Cheng Liat believed that the deceased, when he ordered him out of Pykett Avenue, was senile as the deceased showed no emotion whatsoever as he was being shooed away. He was sad that he was pushed out of Pykett Avenue.

He was informed and therefore not aware, in July 1992, that the deceased was hospitalised. He was not aware, in 1993, that the deceased was hospitalised in Singapore. He was told, each time he telephoned Pykett Avenue, Say Bee or Beng Tatt, that the deceased was in Kuala Lumpur. He was told of the deceased's death a day after the deceased had passed away. He did not know why he was not told that the deceased was hospitalised in Singapore.

He suspected, when he learned from Dr Gafoor of the circumstances of the execution of the 1992 wills, that the 1992 wills were invalid. He found out, from Lim, that Lim believed he (Lim) was asked to go to Pykett Avenue to prepare a will. However, Lim was only asked to witness a will. Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard threatened that they would dispose off the assets of the estate and leave Malaysia, leaving him nothing.

Cheng Liat further testified that he is staying in Cheng Been's house. Richard and Teik Lim are the trustees of Cheng Been's estate. Richard threatened to evict him from Cheng Been's house. He had no money to pay the rent that Richard demanded. The deceased had allowed him to stay at Cheng Been's house. Cheng Liat said he would pay the arrears of rent from his beneficial interest in the estate.

Under cross-examination by Mr Koh, Cheng Liat admitted that he was adjudged a bankrupt on 19 September 1990. He received interests on his RM866,000. The deceased paid him interests as the deceased could not pay his share of the proceeds received from the sale of the Batu Ferringhi land. Hamid told him that Cheng Poon used his money to redeem the Teluk Bahang land and to pay for luxury cars.

On the MOU with Gloria Bay, Cheng Liat testified that he saw the MOU burning. He denied that he suggested the destruction of the MOU or that he commenced action 22-271-94 because one Sonny Ho was not given the right to develop Pykett Avenue.

Cheng Liat admitted that he took a loan of RM14,000 from the estate on 24 December 1993. He also admitted that he received a loan of RM15,000 from Bok Eng. Bok Eng released the loan of RM15,000 in three instalments; throwing the last instalment (RM5,000) the air, she asked him to pick it up. Cheng Poon photographed him as he was picking up that money. Cheng Liat maintained that Cheng Poon was not the deceased's favourite son. The deceased loved all his children.
In 1990, for two months, he was in London with the deceased. Cheng Poon told him that the deceased stopped him, within a week of his return to Penang, from going to Pykett Avenue.

Under cross-examination by Mr Yeoh, Cheng Liat testified as follows. In 1988, mother, suffering from diabetes, was in and out of the hospital. He came back to Penang from Kuala Lumpur in 1988. By then he had retired. In Penang, he was always in his parents' house. He kept that routine until about three months after his mother's death when the deceased had other company. Sometime in 1989, he pointed out to the deceased that the 1989 deed would leave him and Cheng Bok 'with a nought'. The deceased was not clear of its specific provisions. He did not say to the deceased that Cheng Hum was not provided under the 1989 deed as the deceased had consistently said that Cheng Hum had been amply provided for. For the same reason, he did not say to the deceased that Liang Imm was also not provided for in the 1989 deed. Cheng Poon was in Thailand when he spoke to the deceased. He had waited for Cheng Poon to be away from Pykett Avenue. Whilst Cheng Poon was in Thailand, Lim explained the 1989 deed to the deceased. The deceased wanted a second opinion. He did not know that the deceased asked Hamid to get a second opinion.

The three brothers met in Singapore as some of them were accompanying the deceased. The three brothers agreed that they would share equally the estate of the deceased. Cheng Hum who was not invited was not present. Liang Imm was also not invited. Cheng Bok refused to believe the 1989 deed would leave them (Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat) with nothing. He, Cheng Bok and Cheng Poon accompanied the deceased to Nik Saghir's office. The three brothers were not at Nik Saghir's office to watch over the deceased and each other and they were not at the E & O Hotel to check on each other.

In 1991, the deceased was a healthy man. He was fair and not easily swayed or influenced. He was very close to his 'secretary', a Thai girl in her twenties who was the deceased's companion. Between beginning of 1990 to about mid-1991, she was living in Pykett Avenue. The deceased was influenced by that Thai girl. Those around the deceased — Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard — could influence the deceased. He and Cheng Bok did not have any influence over the deceased.

He was only aware of the deceased's letter DB1(B)(9) restraining him from Pykett Avenue after the death of the deceased. DB1(B)(9) was written because Cheng Poon and the Thai girl had poisoned the deceased's mind that he (Cheng Liat) was poisoning the deceased's drinking water. He (Cheng Liat) did not believe that the deceased would have written DB1(B)(9). The deceased never said to him that he was not permitted to enter Pykett Avenue. He did not think that the deceased was capable of accusing him of poisoning the deceased's drinking water.

Prior to the instant proceedings, had no knowledge of the will dated 27 December 1987. After the death of the deceased, he got to know of the 1990 wills. Initially, he did not know that Hamid arranged the execution of the 1990 wills. About four or five months after the death of the deceased, after reading the 1990 wills, he got to know that Hamid was a witness. From Hamid, he got to know that Hamid arranged the execution of the 1990 wills.

Cheng Liat disagreed with Mr Yeoh's suggestion that Hamid arranged the execution of the 1990 wills at the behest of the three sons. He did not inherit any property from his mother but he got a small inheritance from his paternal grandmother — an undivided share in a piece of land that has not been distributed to him. Whilst he was working, did not receive an allowance from the deceased. After retiring and whilst in Penang, he was receiving a monthly allowance of RM500, from the beginning of 1989 until July 1992 when he received interest on his RM866,000.

His trip to London with the deceased was after the meeting at the E�&�O Hotel. Hamid, Cheng Poon and the Thai girl were also on that trip. Cheng Poon and Hamid flew from London to the US to conclude a sale of the deceased's properties in the US.

In 1990, the deceased was still strong in will, but Cheng Poon had influence over the deceased. Cheng Poon and his sons were instrumental in forging the 1989 deed. After he explained the 1989 deed, the deceased was angry. He did not know whether the deceased understood the effect of the 1989 deed prior to his explanation. If he had accompanied the deceased to hospitals, it was on occasions when the deceased consulted his doctors and when he was asked to. He did not know that the deceased was seeing his doctor, on 10 March 1990, for certification on the soundness of his mind.

Cheng Liat admitted he received a cheque for RM80,000. But that cheque, he said, was given to him by Cheng Hum who had just sold his Ayer Itam lands. He did not know that Cheng Hum paid out RM130,000 at the insistence of the deceased. He disagreed that Cheng Poon influenced the deceased or secured Hamid to influence the deceased into signing the 1990 wills. Cheng Liat said that from what he knew, Cheng Poon did not know of the 1990 wills until Cheng Poon opened the deceased's safe. Hamid told him that no one knew of the 1990 wills. He did not know of the execution of the 1990 wills. He denied that they (Cheng Poon, Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat) had struck a bargain and that he instituted the action because Cheng Poon had broken his word on the 1990 wills.

In re-examination, Cheng Liat clarified that the RM15,000 was not a loan from Bok Eng but his share from the sale of Lot 44 Bandar Jelutong. Under further cross-examination by Mr Koh, Cheng Liat said that he could have received both RM14,000 and a further RM15,000.

Richard, a young man of 34, testified that he is the Managing Director of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd. and the eldest grandson of the deceased. Howard is his younger brother. Between 1984 to May 1990, he was studying overseas. In May 1990, he graduated with a degree in finance from the University of Houston. On 23 January 1992, he was made the Managing Director of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd. The deceased appointed him a trustee of Cheng Been and 'Poh Guat Keong', a private temple.

The deceased was a strict man. He maintained a distance from his children and employees. However, the deceased was more open with his grandchildren. The deceased was a man of his word. For a short duration, between 1984 to 1986, Teik Lim and Gim Hong also stayed at Pykett Avenue. The deceased preferred his grandchildren to look after him. The deceased was short sighted. In June 1992, the deceased donated RM100,000 to the Chinese Recreation Club Building Fund. Liang Imm's husband was then the President of the club. Joo Chie or Sim Bee donated to the original building fund. The deceased had plans to develop Pykett Avenue. The assets of the deceased's wife were disclosed in the deceased's application for administration. Everyone had access to Pykett Avenue. During the day, the gate and house were not locked. Cheng Bok had access to the house. In 1993, Cheng Bok stayed for 16 days in Pykett Avenue. He could give a list of the things in Pykett Avenue on 10 April 1993 and a list of the personal belongings of the deceased.

In June 1992, he did not instruct Beng Tatt to prepare cheques for large sums to be signed by the deceased. It was not true that he, his father and Howard instructed Beng Tatt, between May to July 1992, to prepare cheques for large sums. In 1991, the deceased was desperate for cash; he wanted cash to travel, to spend and primarily to settle his overdraft. The deceased instructed Hamid to obtain buyers for his properties, including the Teluk Bahang land.

He was receiving a weekly allowance of RM50. Whilst studying overseas, he was receiving US1,000. Upon his return, in 1990, he was receiving a weekly allowance of RM50. Whilst the deceased was alive, he was not receiving any salary as the Managing Director of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd, nor having a job.

Between 3 August 1992 to 7 August 1992, he was not in Penang. On 3 August 1992, was staying at the Kuala Lumpur Hilton. He came back on 7 August 1992. He had no idea that the deceased was signing a will. On 1 August 1992, he was in Penang. Howard did not say to him that he (Howard) was preparing wills. Dr Gafoor and Beng Tatt were mistaken; on 3 August 1992, he was not in Pykett Avenue. Beng Tatt informed him, a few days after 7 August 1992, when he was at Pykett Avenue, that the 1992 wills had been returned with Dr Gafoor's rubber stamp. Saying it was late, Beng Tatt suggested the deposit of the 1992 wills in the safe. That was the first time he got to know of the 1992 wills. He did not see the 1992 wills. He only got to see the 1992 wills when Lim read the 1992 wills.

Sometime in January 1994, Cheng Bok brought a copy of the second Thai will (D11) to Pykett Avenue. Waving D11, Cheng Bok said to him that he (Cheng Bok) had proof that the 1992 wills were not proper. Cheng Bok threw D11 on the table. The pencil marks on D11 were present when he received D11.

Only the deceased had a set of keys to the safe. Beng Tatt was wrong when he said that he (Richard) had a set of keys. Sometimes, the deceased would ask him (Richard) to open the safe. When Beng Tatt wanted to deposit the 1992 wills in the safe, they saw the deceased. The deceased handed him the safe keys. He opened the safe and Beng Tatt deposited an envelope in the safe. He locked the safe and returned the keys to the deceased. That was the last he saw of that envelope. He never touched that envelope. He never open the safe by himself. He would only open it in Beng Tatt's presence. The deceased would not give the safe keys to Beng Tatt. It was not true that Howard and him took the safe keys from Beng Tatt. There were valuables in the safe — cash, jewellery, stocks and shares.

The deceased sold his wife's jewellery. The deceased handed the jewellery to his mother to sell for him. The deceased disliked jewellery and never wore rings or watches. His passion was cars. Sometime in early 1992, the deceased purchased a Rolls-Royce, registered it in his father's name and gave the Rolls-Royce to his father. After the purchase of the Rolls-D Royce, the deceased asked his father to transfer a Mercedes 380 SEL to his father. He did not arrange the purchase of the Rolls-Royce and did not receive a sales commission. Sometime in 1990/1991, the deceased purchased a BMW (CU8) and registered it in his name.

Beng Tatt was protective of the deceased's accounts. The office was Say Bee and Beng Tatt's domain. They answered to the deceased. After the death of the deceased, Beng Tatt continued to keep the accounts and Say Bee continued to collect rent for the estate. Beng Tatt had the accounts under lock and key. He (Richard) was never given a set of keys.

It was not true that he and Howard asked Hamid to do something to the 1990 wills. Hamid visited the deceased after the deceased was discharged from the LWE Hospital. On the first occasion, on the instructions of the deceased, he told Hamid that the deceased was sleeping. On another occasion, the deceased told him to tell Hamid he was in the toilet. On the third occasion, Hamid walked directly to the deceased. The deceased was reading his newspapers. Hamid greeted the deceased. The deceased did not respond. The deceased was still upset with Hamid for failing to introduce an architect to prepare the development plans for Pykett Avenue. The deceased waited three days in Kuala Lumpur for the architect. That was before the deceased was admitted to the LWE Hospital. Because the sale of the Teluk Bahang land was not concluded, Hamid is taking it out on him, his father and brother.

He was in Singapore when the deceased was treated in Singapore. Before the deceased passed away, the deceased was in a coma for 24 hours. A day before the deceased passed away, his father withdrew RM140,000 from the deceased's account.
The deceased was angry that Cheng Bok had charged the land he (the deceased) purchased for Cheng Bok. After the death of the deceased, Cheng Bok had not been Aback to Pykett Avenue, even for prayers.

Between April to December 1993, the estate advanced RM10,000 and his mother advanced RM15,000 to Cheng Liat. He advanced RM6,000 to Cheng Been and RM10,000 to Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd. He made those advances after the death of the deceased. Cheng Bok, his father, Howard and himself, as trustees of the estate, opened an account at the Standard Chartered Bank; a sum of RM130,000 was deposited. A sum of RM40,000 was owing to the Standard Chartered Bank. His fixed deposits pledged as security had been uplifted by the bank. The RM140,000 his father took had been accounted for. The balance, (RM38,274) had been transferred to the trustees' account. Cheng Bok's testimony that he had not signed any of the cheques in that trustees' account was not true.

Tendering the original MOUs with Gloria Bay — 29(A and B) — Richard testified that Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat instigated Howard to burn the MOUs. Cheng Liat said that all their problems would be solved if the MOUs were handed to Ismail Khoo & Co. Cheng Liat wanted to give the development of Pykett Avenue to Gloria Bay Sdn Bhd. He (Richard) did not want to proceed with that MOU as it was not in the best interests of the estate. Several parties, including one Tan Chiew Hun, invited him to sell Pykett Avenue. In 1994, Gloria Bay, supported by Teik Lim's declaration, caveated Pykett Avenue.

Sometime in 1994, Bok withdrew his consent for the grant of administration of the estate of the deceased in Thailand. At that time, they had not applied for probate in Malaysia. He proceeded with the application for probate of the Thai estate, as the position of the estate in Thailand was precarious. With regard to the US estate, Howard was the sole administrator.

Bian Cheng Naranong, Wife, Relatives and Friends Ltd (Thai company) is the owner of the properties listed in the 1992 Thai will. He is one of the directors. The other directors were his father, the Thai manager and Cheng Liat. The shareholders are those named in the 1992 Thai will. He is presently in charge of the company. The trustees (of the 1992 wills) passed a resolution to pay him a salary of RM2,500 per month. He did not agree with Cheng Bok's suggestion to sell the Thai properties en bloc; that would be against the will and would not fetch a good price.

He did not dictate the letter/instruction dated 11 February 1993 — PB2(5). He took legal advice and was advised not to entertain the respective claims of Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat for the said RM826,000 and RM866,000. He told Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat to apply to court. He believed those payments must be made in accordance with the terms of the settlement dated 24 July 1992.

He lived his life with the deceased. The deceased did not give him any land. The deceased gave a property in America — known as Marion Oaks — to Teik Lim. He is one of the eight or ten trustees of the Poh Guat Keong Temple. Teik Lim is a trustee. He did not know why the deceased gave a property in America to Teik Lim.

Richard's testimony, under cross-examination by Mr Khoo, was as follows. Apart from being a trustee for Cheng Been, a trustee of the estate and a managing director of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd, he has no other job. Apart from the RM50 weekly allowance from the deceased, he had no other income. He had RM20,000 in his account. He was 21 when his mother left Pykett Avenue in 1984; he was not raised by servants. Until the death of the deceased, he had his meals with the deceased. In 1990, 1991 and 1992, he was in the house most of the time. In 1992, after prostate surgery, the deceased was urinating blood. He had no knowledge that the deceased was suffering from Parkinson's disease. The deceased complained of palpitation. Other than in July 1992, and when the deceased was at LWE Hospital and suffering a loss of memory, the deceased was not senile. The deceased was normal. He did not see the deceased having seizures in 1992. He visited the deceased at LWE Hospital. The deceased was disorientated; sometimes, the deceased would be talking but he could not make out what the deceased was saying. The deceased, when he was discharged in July 1992, was weak and had to be supported.

On the night of 1 August 1992, he did not see Beng Tatt. The safe was not opened. He did not know why the deceased had not asked him to amend his wills. He had no knowledge of the amendments to the 1990 wills. On 3 August 1992, he was having a business meeting in Kuala Lumpur. He was not informed that the deceased had executed a will on 3�August 1992. He got to know of the 1992 wills when Beng Tatt asked him to get the safe keys. He was surprised that a will had been executed. His father did not inform him of the 1992 wills. He might have spoken to his father on the 1992 wills but he could not remember if it was spoken in detail. His father did not say to him who prepared the 1992 wills. He could not remember when he found out that Howard prepared the 1992 wills. He did not prepare 2D — the second 1992 Thai will. He did not amend the 1992 wills for Dr Gafoor's signature. He had access to Howard's room and use of Howard's laptop computer.

His mother purchased an apartment in Singapore. The price was S$450,000 to S$460,000. It was partly financed. He knew, in July 1992, that his family was receiving large sums of money from the deceased. The deceased left RM14,000 The deceased spent all the RM7m he received from the sale of the Batu Ferringhi land. In June and July 1992, his family received more than RM3.2m from the deceased. On 31 March 1995, consolidating the account of the estate in Thailand and the account of the Thai company, the deceased had RM174,649.01; he could not provide the Thai accounts as at the date of death of the deceased. He did not know he had to provide such an account. Money from Thailand was sent by the Thai manager who approved the payments. He forwarded US$6,000 from the Malaysian estate to the US estate. After the death of the deceased, the Thai manager who was his sailing partner and a family friend visited him several times. After the appointment of the receiver and manager, the Thai manager only visited him once.

For the past four years, he had not shown the accounts of the Thai company to any of the plaintiffs. Letters were sent to the plaintiffs to attend the Annual General Meetings of the Thai company. From April 1996, as managing director of the Thai company, he was receiving Baht40,000 per month. It was not approved by the company. He had not informed the plaintiffs of the Baht40,000 he was 'taking'. He knew he had to have the approval of the company. From 1993 to 1995, he did claim expenses from the Thai company, although he claimed, in 1996, for a few thousand dollars expenses. He took the Baht40,000 from the company.

There is an ancestral house, in Kantang,, Thailand, the house of Khaw Sim Bee, that belonged to the deceased. During his lifetime, the deceased converted it into a museum. The deceased had no movable property nor bank account in Thailand. It was not true that the deceased had a lot of money in Thailand. Despite the appointment of the receiver and manager, he remained as the managing director to maintain the Malaysian and Thai companies. He had not held any meetings in Thailand. He just continued to collect rent and to pay the staff. The Thai manager, director, got his salary from the estate in Thailand. The Thai manager resigned in April 1996. When the deceased passed away, the Thai manager brought money with him from Thailand to Singapore.

In 1994, he could not stop the petition for administration in Thailand as the situation in 1994 was not different from 1993. The lands in Thailand were yet in a precarious situation. Richard agreed that the plaintiffs applied, in 22-271-94, to restrain his application for probate in Thailand. He agreed that the first to third defendants had not disclosed, in 22-271-94, that the petition for probate in Thailand was yet proceeding. He agreed that the Kantang Provincial Court, in January 1995, had turned down the first to third defendants' petition for probate. He did not inform the other beneficiaries of the decision of the Kantang Provincial Court as he and the other beneficiaries were not on speaking terms. He did not inform the other beneficiaries of the first to third defendants' appeal against the decision of the Kantang Provincial Court. Despite objections, the first to third defendants proceeded with their petition and appeal, as they believed it was in the interest of the estate. The first to third defendants wanted to save the Thai properties for all beneficiaries. The properties in Thailand, because of Thai laws (on the inheritance of Thai properties by non-Thai beneficiaries), were in a precarious position. The Thai court was informed of Cheng Bok's objection. The first to third defendants did not inform the Thai court of the plaintiffs' actions in Malaysia. He did not see it fit, at any time, to inform the Thai courts of the plaintiffs' actions in Malaysia or to disclose to the Malaysian courts of the petition in Thailand. He has not renounced the Thai probate. He denied that he attempted to dispose off Pykett Avenue and then leave Malaysia. He said that Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd had no intention of selling Pykett Avenue. He did not inform the plaintiffs of the tenancy agreement with Glashaus Sdn Bhd. Even during the lifetime of the deceased, Glashaus was using Pykett Avenue. The plaintiffs complained that Glashaus was using Pykett Avenue free of rent; he suggested to Glashaus to pay rentals. A cook, driver and maid are employed by the estate. The deceased's wills provided so. They were former employees of the deceased and he continued their employment. They are not working for Glashaus.

The deceased was in Singapore for six weeks; he was treated at the Singapore General Hospital. The plaintiffs were not informed that the deceased was in Singapore as the deceased had instructed that they should not be informed. In February 1993, at LWE Hospital, the deceased was diagnosed as suffering from an advanced stage of cancer of the prostate. The deceased, aware in February 1993 that he was suffering from cancer, decided to seek treatment at the Singapore General Hospital; he was given radiotherapy treatment. The deceased was well in Singapore. Only in the last few days, was the deceased not well.

The deceased was a very unforgiving man. It did not strike him (Richard) as strange that the deceased would not want his children and other grandchildren by his side even as he was nearing his death. He denied he and his family kept the other members of the Khaw family away from the deceased as they were afraid that the others would raise the issue of the wills of the deceased.

His family disposed off their cars, although after suit 22-299-95 was filed, to raise money; it was not to avoid the recovery action. He agreed that he sold the BMW, in early 1994, after he received PB1(96) — Cheng Bok's solicitors' letter to Richard enquiring, inter alia, whether the BMW was the property of the estate — but before 22-299-95 was instituted. The Toyota Estima, purchased in 1991, was sold in 1994, as his family could not afford the instalments; his mother paid the instalments after the deceased passed away. The Ladybird, purchased with his father's own funds, had been sold. The Porsche, purchased in September 1992, is still with the family; the deceased paid the down payment (RM50,000) whilst his father paid the balance (RM180,000). Howard purchased a Mercedes SL with the RM350,000 given him by the deceased.

He agreed that the deceased intended that Lot 44 Bandar Jelutong and the two houses on it should be for the benefit of the Poh Guat Keong Temple. On one occasion, with Howard, he met Douglas Newman; they discussed the US properties. They discussed the Malaysian position with Lebeau as they had received the plaintiff's notice. He did not respond to DB1A (190) — Cheng Bok's letter dated 22 December 1993 on the MOU — but he spoke to Cheng Bok in Singapore.

Richard testified that he was aware that the 'Koe Guan Kong Lim' trust set up by an ancestor was about to be wound up and that its assets would be distributed to all surviving descendants with the generation name 'Cheng' and 'Teik'. However, he could not remember whether he had claimed his interest from the 'Koe Guan Kong Lim' trust. He did not know the value or quantity of jewellery in the deceased's safe. Rental from Thai properties was about Baht150,000 per month.

Richard's testimony, under Mr Yeoh's cross-examination, was as follows. The deceased was more fond of his grandchildren and talked more to them than his children. His sister, and also Gim Hong when she was in Penang, took care of his grandmother. There were maids and servants, but most of the time only granddaughters attended to her. Towards the later stages of her life, a maid was constantly with her. He and Howard attended to her on isolated occasions. The deceased was physically active and more independent and did not require constant attention. He found the deceased, when he was home between 1984 to 1990, to be healthy. When his grandmother was hospitalised, the deceased was also admitted with her. Richard believed that the deceased was admitted for a 'sympathetic' and not 'real illness'; the doctors found nothing wrong with him. It was like a holiday for the deceased. He was aware that the deceased, before admission to LWE Hospital, was suffering from palpitation and an enlarged prostate. He was not aware of the medication given to the deceased or that the deceased was suffering from Parkinson's disease. In 1989, the deceased could walk unaided. But he (the deceased) preferred to hold on to someone.

He was in the house when the deceased asked Hamid to sell his properties, including the Ayer Itam land that he jointly owned with Cheng Hum. Hamid informed the deceased that Cheng Hum had no wish to sell the Ayer Itam land at the offer price of RM4psf, Cheng Hum believed the value was about to rise to RM20psf. The deceased remarked that he could not wait for the price to rise to RM20psf, and the deceased suggested that Cheng Hum should buy up his interest, if the value would rise to RM20 psf.

Richard denied that his family, rather than the deceased, could not wait for the land value to rise. In 1991 to 1992, the deceased was desperate for cash to buy cars and to meet his expenses and overdraft. Richard said that he had no idea of the state of the deceased's overdraft. He explained that he testified that the deceased, in 1990, wanted to enjoy his money as the deceased was traveling a lot, eating out and entertaining. He did not hear from the deceased that he (the deceased) was desperate for money. He supposed it was so as the deceased had asked Hamid to sell his assets.

He was not in a position to know the amount of his grandmother's jewellery. Shortly after his grandmother's death, the deceased sold some of that jewellery. He did not know why the deceased sold some of that jewellery. The deceased asked his mother, in 1989 or 1990, to sell that jewellery. He did not know why the deceased asked his mother, but no one else, to sell his wife's jewellery. 'Perhaps (she) was there.' Richard did not agree that the deceased had not asked his mother to sell the jewellery. Richard denied he invented the sale of his grandmother's jewellery as his family could not account for the jewellery in the house.
Richard related that the deceased asked his mother, just before his grandmother passed away, to visit his grandmother, as the deceased wanted them to reconcile.

Richard testified that the deceased always had 'a string of cars'. 'The deceased would have, at the very least, three cars at any point in time'. The deceased always had a beautiful sedan and other cars for his daily use. In 1988, the deceased had a Mercedes Benz E280 and a Mercedes Benz 380. 'The deceased purchased the Rolls-Royce in 1991 or early 1992.' The Mercedes Benz transferred to Cheng Bok was purchased in 1988 or 1989. His father purchased a Nissan Fairlady sports car in July 1992. The Porsche was purchased in September 1992. 'The deceased continued to have a passion for cars until death.' 'The deceased loved sitting in the Rolls-Royce.'

row.entry: How could he indulge in his passion … when (it was) not registered in his name?.
He need not have to have the cars registered in his name to enjoy it.

p.text: In 1991 and 1992, the deceased had prostate surgery. The deceased had seizures when he was admitted to LWE Hospital in July 1992. After he was discharged, the deceased maintained his passion for cars and traveled to China and the US. Shortly before he died, the deceased planned to travel to Europe to buy the latest Mercedes 600.

He knew of the 1990 wills in late 1990 or early 1991. Hamid mentioned those wills to him. Richard denied that he and Howard propositioned Hamid 'to do something about the 1990 wills'. Richard testified that Hamid testified he and Richard propositioned Hamid to do something about the 1990 wills as the sale of the Teluk Bahang land was aborted, in June 1992, and Hamid is trying to get back on the first to third defendants.

His first sight of the 1990 wills could have been after his grandfather had passed away. Richard denied that Hamid delivered a copy of the 1990 wills, shortly after the deceased was discharged from the LWE Hospital, to Pykett Avenue. Beng Tatt did not go directly to the deceased for the safe keys, as Beng Tatt might have already asked the deceased, and the deceased could have asked Beng Tatt, normally the case, to look for him; the deceased would not trouble himself to come down and open the safe for Beng Tatt. Richard denied he took the safe keys from Beng Tatt. Richard said, he was surprised to find, when he was back on 7 August 1992, that his grandfather had made a fresh will.

Lim who read the 1992 wills, a few days after the burial, Cheng Bok, Cheng Liat and the first to third defendants, was instructed, after the 1992 wills were read, by all those present to prepare the application for probate. His uncles were especially anxious to rush the application for probate.

The deceased and his father, as the directors, appointed him the Managing Director of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd. Whilst the deceased was alive, he was not given and he did not ask for a salary. His salary from Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd was only paid for a few months. The directors of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd are his father and himself. The deceased had 1,999,999 shares in Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd. The remaining one share is held by his father. The deceased did not transfer nor allot any shares in Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd to his other children or grandchildren.

In April 1994, after the resignation of the Thai manager, he took charge of the Thai company. He signed the tax return for 1995 for the Thai company. The Thai manager signed the tax returns for 1993 and 1994. The Thai manager consulted him before he signed those tax returns. He had instructed the Thai manager to maintain the estate in Thailand. The directors of the Thai company were the deceased, his father, Cheng Liat, the Thai manager and himself. The 13 shareholders are those in D31(1-4). The present directors are his father, Howard, himself, his sister, Cheng Liat and the Thai manager. There was no meeting to appoint those additional directors. His father appointed his sister and Howard as additional directors. He did not inform the other beneficiaries of the appointment of the additional directors.

Richard offered no answer when he was asked, 'so, your family did as it pleased'. Richard testified that he gave an account of the rentals received from the Thai estate to the receiver and manager. All 146 (land) titles of the Thai properties are with the Thai manager. He (Richard) would hand over all those 146 titles to the receiver and manager. All those 146 properties, Richard declared, not been sold, charged or pledged. They are intact.

In re-examination, Richard clarified as follows. The deceased had palpitation of the stomach. RM26,927.88 was an accounting figure after deducting the overdraft. The deceased had more than RM250,000 cash. PB1(135) was the balance sheet on the cash position at the date of death of the deceased. PB1(138) was the balance sheet on the cash position as at 31 March 1995. The estate's cash position, between 10 April 1993 to 31 May 1995, was down by approximately RM100,000; there was more expenditure than income. The deceased instructed the Thai manager, about a week or two before he passed away, to bring Baht230,000 to Singapore. The deceased wanted money for his expenses. The Thai manager brought that money a day after the the deceased passed away.

Richard further clarified his family received RM2.7m and not RM3.2m, in the months of June and July 1992. Of that RM2.7m, RM512,063.70 was to settle the overdraft owing by the deceased and his father to the BBMB, Georgetown. The advance of US6,000, from Thailand to the US estate, was made by the Thai manager. The Malaysian estate advanced US$37,021.44 to the US estate; Cheng Bok also signed the cheque for the Malaysian advance. He did not inform the beneficiaries of the application for probate in Thailand as he believed they would sabotage the application so as to put the entire Thai estate in jeopardy, as they would prefer to 'stop everything than to secure the position of the (Thai) estate'. He informed the Kantang Provincial Court that Cheng Bok had withdrawn his consent. Glashaus was paying, even before the execution of the tenancy agreement, a monthly rental of RM1,000. Richard explained that the deceased was an unforgiving man as he remembered the deceased saying to Cheng Bok that he (the deceased) might have forgiven but he has not forgotten. He was present when Cheng Bok came back to Pykett Avenue, after years of absence, and prostrated himself before the deceased and asked for forgiveness. The deceased had arranged a Thai bride for Cheng Bok but Cheng Bok ran away with someone else. Thereafter, Cheng Bok was away from Pykett Avenue for ten years. Cheng Bok had asked for his � share of the rent received from premises 165-173A Jalan Dato Keramat. The deceased had refused to pay Cheng Bok's half share. When their differences were resolved, the deceased paid Cheng Bok. The deceased bought over Cheng Bok's half interest. Howard bought a Mercedes with part of the RM350,000 that the deceased had given Howard. The deceased was happy that he was driven in the US in the Mercedes by Howard. The deceased was only urinating blood after the prostate operation. The deceased said that it was due to the operation. The bleeding which had stopped started again at about the time that cancer was diagnosed. The deceased recovered very quickly, after he was discharged from LWE Hospital.

Howard's evidence in chief may be paraphrased as follows. Between 1989 to1992, he was a student in the US. Between 5 June 1992 to 5�August 1992, during the term holidays, he was in Malaysia. Whilst he was home, the deceased suffered a seizure on 12 July 1992 and executed the 1992 wills.

He and Richard were very close to the deceased. The deceased was the focal point of his family. The deceased provided his family financially and emotionally. He regarded the deceased highly. The deceased, who found ease communicating with him, had a particular liking for him.

After dinner, 1 August 1992, the deceased communicated to him that he (the deceased) wanted him (Howard) to retype his wills. Before that, he was not aware of the will of the deceased. The deceased made corrections on the 1990 wills and told him (Howard) to follow his the deceased) corrections. The deceased handed him the corrected 1990 wills — one set of the Thai, Malaysian and US wills — whilst they were upstairs, along the corridor. He could not recall whether the corrections were made on the originals or copies of the 1990 wills. The deceased told him that he (the deceased) wanted the retyped wills on the following day.

That evening, he (Howard) read the 1990 wills for the first time. He started to retype the wills on 2 August 1992. Close to dinner time, he finished his task. In the evening (2 August 1992), he returned the corrected 1990 wills and handed the retyped wills to the deceased. Each retyped will was held together with a paper clip.

His friend, Lim, who visited him on 2 August 1992, arrived at about dinner time. By then, he had already retyped the wills. Patricia had nothing to do with the preparation of the wills.
