It was not true he asked Beng Tatt for the safe keys or that he took those keys from Beng Tatt, on 1 August 1992. He never saw nor spoke to Beng Tatt in the evening of 1�August 1992. He (Howard) had nothing to do with the safe in the house.

He was instructed to remain in the house on 3 August 1992. He waited for the deceased's instructions. Late in the morning, the deceased said to him that he (the deceased) wanted him (Howard) to accompany him (the deceased) to the hospital. Together with his parents, He accompanied the deceased to the LWE Hospital. He was present when Dr�Tan Chee Khuan examined the deceased. He believed his father was also in the consultation room. They returned home for lunch. After lunch, the deceased read his newspapers and had an afternoon nap.

Around 4pm, Lim and Dr Gafoor came to the house. First to arrive was Lim. He was then in his room, upstairs. Hearing voices and steps on the stairs, he came out and saw Lim being accompanied by Beng Tatt. The deceased walked out from his room. Then both the deceased and Lim walked to the main table. They sat down. He did not sit down with them. Beng Tatt proceeded downstairs, to wait for Dr Gafoor.

Placed neatly on the table were the wills he gave the deceased on 2�August 1992. The wills looked to be in the same condition as he had given it. He did not know who placed those wills on the table. Dr Gafoor arrived about 10 to 15 minutes after Lim. Beng Tatt accompanied Dr�Gafoor upstairs. Dr Gafoor took his seat at the main table. Beng Tatt was standing at the top of the stairs. He (Howard) did not join the meeting. He adjourned to his room. He had no idea who arranged the meeting. The deceased instructed Beng Tatt to ask a servant to serve drinks to Dr Gafoor and Lim. Beng Tatt proceeded downstairs.

Lim, reading the wills, pointed out to the deceased that there was one trustee too many. The deceased instructed him (Howard) to correct the wills, deleting Teik Lim as a trustee. He collected the three sets of wills and proceeded to his room to make the corrections. He replaced the top page. He brought out the 1992 Thai will ([D2B) held together with a paper clip. At that moment, his father was around, signing some documents.

He first amended the Thai will. After that, he returned to his room and corrected the next will. Lim read aloud the 1992 Thai will. The deceased held the 1992 Thai will. He (Howard) only prepared one Thai, one Malaysian and one US will. No duplicates or copies were prepared.

He placed the 1992 Thai will on the table. He stood about 15 feet away. Lim proceeded to read aloud the 1992 Thai will. The 1992 Thai will was then handed to the deceased who read it himself. The deceased signed somewhere towards the end of the page. The 1992 Thai will was stapled when it was signed. After the deceased signed the attestation page — D2B(9) — Lim signed and handed D2B(9) to the deceased. He (Howard) then returned to his room to correct the next will. He brought out the next will, duly corrected; at the table, stapled that will and placed it on the table. Then, Lim proceeded to read that will. He then returned to his room to correct the third will. He brought out the third will, duly corrected, and left it on the table. He saw the deceased, Lim and Dr Gafoor signing the next two wills. He (Howard) prepared all of the 1992 wills. All of the 1992 wills were stapled when it was signed. He stapled those 1992 wills. He did not see the particular pages of the Malaysian and US wills that the deceased, Lim and Dr Gafoor were signing. On 3 August 1992, the deceased was his usual self. He saw Lim and Dr Gafoor signing the other pages of the 1992 Thai will. He believed the attestation page — D2B(9) — was the first page that was signed. As for the signatures on the other pages, the deceased signed a page, and then the subscribers signed that page and handed that page to the deceased. After that, the deceased signed the next page and then the subscribers signed that page and handed that page to the deceased, and so on. The same procedure — the deceased signing a page and then the subscribers signing that page and then handing that page to the deceased — was replicated in the execution of the other two wills.

The persons in the upstairs hall, from the moment both Lim and Dr�Gafoor had arrived until completion of the execution of the 1992 wills, were the deceased, Lim, Dr Gafoor and himself. His father, signing some documents, was only there for a short while. Beng Tatt was there fleetingly; he stood at the top of the stairs and was asked to bring a stapler upstairs. Lim and Dr Gafoor left at about 6pm. As Lim and Dr Gafoor were leaving, he heard Lim reminding Dr Gafoor that he (Lim) would be sending the 1992 wills to Dr Gafoor for Dr Gafoor's rubber stamp.

Richard left for Kuala Lumpur on 3 August 1992. He (Howard) left for the US on 5 August 1992. He did not prepare the second Thai will — 2D. On 4 September 1992, he was not in Malaysia. He had not taken Beng Tatt's cabinet keys and he did not have a set of keys to the cabinet that Beng Tatt opened. Howard denied he had ever instructed Beng Tatt to hand all important documents to his father and Richard for inspection. He denied he instructed Beng Tatt on the figures in DB1D(347-348) — handwritten notes on the RM826,000 and RM866,000 payable to Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat from the sale of the Batu Ferringhi land. He and Richard had not propositioned Hamid to change the 1990 wills. There was no such visit to Hamid. He denied he asked Beng Tatt, after 22-63-95 had been instituted, to sign a false declaration.

In June 1992 or thereabout, he received RM352,000 from the deceased. A significant part was for his schooling fund. The rest was for a car. The schooling fund, so long as he could finish his education, was not for any specific period. He endorsed a cheque for RM225,000 that the deceased gave him. He endorsed the cheque but the sum was paid to Tan Beng Hin. After he endorsed the cheque, the deceased took the cheque from him. Each time he needed money, he approached the deceased. The deceased approved and instructed all payments made to him. He did not instruct the payments in his favour. He denied he threatened Cheng Bok that his family would leave nothing to Cheng Bok. He denied he invited Cheng Bok to sue him in the US. He did not threaten Cheng Liat that the first to third defendants would dispose off all the estate property. Cheng Bok never asked him to be photographed with the body of the deceased. He was not consulted on the funeral arrangements.

The MOU with Gloria Bay, when it was burned, was not signed by all parties. The first MOU was aborted and his father refused to sign the second MOU. Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat told him to burn the MOU. Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat insisted that the MOU be burned as John Khoo was harassing his father for the execution of the MOU by all parties. He turned down Sunny Ho's offer of a car to him for the completion of the MOU. It was not true that he burned the MOU because his request for RM500,000 and a Mercedes sports car was turned down.

In June or July 1992, he asked En Ismail of Messrs Nik Saghir for a copy of the agreement on the (proposed) sale of the Teluk Bahang land. He did not ask for a copy of the codicil/will signed in early 1990.

He is not gainfully employed as he has to finish his studies. He has temporarily stopped his studies. He was pursuing a degree in marketing and business administration at Parloma College, San Diego, California.

In Arizona and Florida, he was granted probate of the US estate. He retained the services of an attorney — Douglas Newman. He notified all interested parties that he was petitioning for probate in the US. Cheng Bok first consented and then withdrew his consent. One hundred acres of land in Benson, Arizona were sold to pay taxes. Approval for the sale was obtained on 19 April 1995. On 9 May 1995, he sold the Racquet Club condominium in Arizona. On 31 May 1995, the US court approved the sale of the condominium. On 25 May 1995, he received the injunction of the plaintiffs. He instructed Douglas Newman not to proceed with the sale. Despite his objection, Douglas Newman who advised that the estate could be sued concluded the sale.

All required parties agreed to his appointment as trustee of the deceased in the US. He engaged an accountant, Gary Hockman, to assist him. A sum of US$62,278.05, was paid on 30 August 1995 to the Inland Revenue Service. From the sale of the condominium, US$24,154.80 was paid directly to the Inland Revenue Service. DB1(F)(29) is a correct account of the properties in the US. The Benson land, purchased for US$100,000 and valued at US$110,000, was sold for US$125,000. He commissioned a valuation of the property before it was sold. After expenses, net sum of US$107,478.76 was received from the sale of the Benson land. The Racquet Club condominium was sold for US$58,000. Arthur Anderson wrote to him, on 13 March 1996, for a detail account of the US estate. It was the only communication he received from Arthur Anderson. He directed Arthur Anderson to Douglas Newman.

Under cross-examination by Mr Khoo, Howard testified that he was the favourite grandson of the deceased. Beginning June 1992, he was receiving large sums from the deceased. He received all sums stated in PB1(326-333). Between 17 June 92 to 29 June 1992, he received cheques totaling RM576,000 from the deceased; but he did not receive the said RM225,000. Before then, he was only receiving RM50 a week.

In 1992, he was a student at the Parloma College. To date, he has not got sufficient points to graduate. Shortly after the death of the deceased, he stopped his studies. Howard denied he came back, in May 1992, to ensure his control of the estate and that he would be a trustee. He was home every six months. At home, he was often in the deceased's room. He did not see the deceased having delusions. The maid woke him up on the first night that the deceased was having a seizure. That was the only time he saw the deceased having a seizure. After he was discharged, in July 1992, the deceased needed physical assistance; but he was maintaining normal hours for a man of his age.

The deceased amended each set of the 1990 wills. He (Howard) read the 1990 wills on 1 August 1992. On that day, he got to know and he was happy that he was not a trustee under the 1990 wills. However, he saw his name in the amended 1990 wills. It was not true that he decided to change the 1990 wills — including himself as a trustee. It was incorrect that the deceased was senile or that he (Howard) had opportunity to change the deceased's wills. It was incorrect, that he, after receiving RM579,000, was emboldened.

row.entry: In 1990, deceased made a will before a prominent lawyer. Was it not odd that you prepared the 1992 wills?
I was the closest to him.

p.text: Richard is now occupying the deceased's room. After it was returned to the deceased, he had not seen the amendments to the 1990 wills. Richard did not prepare the 1990 wills. When he left Malaysia on 5 August 92, he was not aware of the second 1992 Thai will. He had no idea as to who prepared the second Thai will. It was the beginning of 1994 that he got to know of the second 1992 Thai will. He did not investigate as no one was propounding the second 1992 Thai will. He only saw a copy (P11) of the second Thai will.

Howard did not agree (the evidence of Dr Gafoor) that the 1990 wills were signed in loose sheet form, that it was not read to the deceased or that there was no mention of amendments. As far as he was aware, the deceased made no mistakes in his signatures. He was not asked to amend p 9 (attestation page) of the 1992 Thai will. Howard disagreed with Lim's testimony that the 1992 Thai wills were tampered. 'It was not tampered.' In 22-271-95, he affirmed an affidavit dated 13 April 1995.

He was not aware of Keatseangslip's letter of 24 April 1990 — P12(1) — a proposal to the deceased on the exchange of the Benson land priced at US$1.6m for a retail center at Tucson, Arizona priced at US$2.95m, subject to the deceased's payment of the difference of US$1.35m. His father who was aware of the sale of the Benson land never mentioned P12(1) to him. He was not told of that letter. He told his father that the Benson land was sold for US$125,000. Howard denied he sold the Benson land to lay his hands on the sale proceeds.

He received US$43,021.44 from the Malaysia and Thai estates. PB1(141) was the account he provided the Malaysian estate. He took US$11,500 as salary. He could account for the US$237,000, approximately, in the US account, received from the sale of the Benson land and condominium and from the Malaysian and Thai estates.

Howard said, he has no plans at the moment to emigrate to the States. He retained attorneys in the US to assist him in his plans to migrate to the States. He denied he charged his legal expenses to the estate. His mother's legal expenses in the States were not settled by the estate. He could not recall however whether Richard's legal expenses in the States were settled by the estate. It was not true that he planned, knowing his uncles had no means of following him, to dispose as much of the estate property as possible and run to the States.

After the death of the deceased, he consulted attorneys in the States to draft a private trust between his father, Richard and himself. That trust provided that his father's properties would devolve to Richard and himself. It was not true that Richard and himself had total control of their father.

He told his uncles, when they approached him for the RM826,000 and RM866,000, that they would have to apply to court to determine if the RM826,000 and RM866,000 were due to them. He had not asked Beng Tatt to change one item — 'funeral' to 'testamentary' expenses — in the Thai accounts.

He was yet not appointed the representative of the US estate when he received Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat's notice of withdrawal of consent to his appointment. He received Cheng Bok's notice — PB1(84, 86) — of withdrawal of consent to his application for probate in Thailand before he was appointed administrator. During the proceedings, but not in the petition, he informed the US courts of Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat's notice of withdrawal of consent. He took heed of his uncles' protests, but he was advised to proceed with the petition in the States. 'Yes, my US attorney advised the petition to be halted. The proceedings were halted when the letter were received. Subsequently I received probate.' He has not renounced the probate granted him in Thailand and in the States. Douglas Newman was not his alter ego.

He applied to the US courts for administration of the estate of Ooi Geen Peen in the States. He did inform the other beneficiaries. On 10 May 1995, he was appointed the administrator of the estate of Ooi Geen Peen. Ooi Geen Peen had no independent assets. Her properties were owned jointly with the deceased. When he disclosed the assets of the deceased in the States, he also disclosed the assets of Ooi Geen Peen. He had not mortgaged any of the deceased's properties in the States. When he received PB19(84 and 86), he had not obtained probate in Thailand. He did not stop the petition. On 25 January 1995, the Kantang Provincial Court refused the petition for probate. He did not inform the plaintiffs. On 1�September 1995, the decision of the Kantang Court, on appeal, was reversed. He proceeded with the petition in Thailand as he believed it was in the interest of the estate.

row.entry: The excuse in the States was to pay taxes. What is the excuse for the petition, despite the protests of the plaintiffs, to proceed in Thailand?

p.text: The Rolls Royce, Toyota Estima and Nissan 300 ZX in his father's name were sold by his father. The BMW in Richard's name was sold by Richard. He did not know whether those cars were sold after 22-299-95 was instituted.

A month after the death of the deceased, family purchased a RM500,000 condominium — Horizon Towers, Tanjong Bungah. In 1994, his family purchased a luxury apartment in Singapore. His family has one other luxury apartment in Pulau Tikus, Georgetown. After the death of the deceased, he had not purchased any luxury cars. Prior to the death of the deceased, his family had not purchased any property.

To settle the US taxes, he saw it fit to sell the Benson land. Prior to the petition to the US court, Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat were not informed of the US taxes. The cause papers notified Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat of the US taxes. He did not seek the assistance of the other beneficiaries to pay the US taxes.

He was aware of the proposed sale of Pykett Avenue to Dragon & Phoenix Sdn Bhd for about RM16m. He was involved in the negotiations. He was also involved in the negotiations on the joint venture development of Pykett Avenue. He tried to sell Pykett Avenue to one Alex Tan of South Johore Oil Mills. After he was served with the injunction, he was trying to get offers from prospective buyers. But Howard denied he was dealing with the estates's assets. There was no intention to enter into an agreement. It was not true that he took RM500,000 from one Alex Tan. The funeral arrangements were mainly handled by his mother. The funeral expenses were those stated in PB1(136).

row.entry: You (are) not providing the receipts and original documents complying with the consent order dated 8 April 1996, as you, the person who drafted the 1992 wills, (is) aware that if you disclose the documents you will expose yourself and the first and second defendants to the penalty in (the) 1992 wills — that anyone not complying with the direction on funeral expenses would be cut off from the deceased's will?.

p.text: He did not know whether a number of telephone calls [see PB4(11-126)] were made to Thailand. 'Yes, the Thai manager called upon the first defendant at Pykett Avenue. Yes, a few months ago he called upon the first defendant at Pykett Avenue. I don't know if the Thai manager handed any documents to the first or second defendant. He did not hand any documents to me.' Howard agreed that US taxes could be paid by the post. He admitted that most of the calls from Pykett Avenue to the States were made by him.

Mr Yeoh thus commenced his cross-examination of Howard. 'Do you agree that your grandfather was frugal, careful with money and tight fisted?' Howard's reply and his testimony under Mr Yeoh's cross- examination may be paraphrased as follows.

He would not say that the deceased was tight fisted. The deceased was not careless; he was normal. At times, the deceased was extravagant on cars, food and on travel. The deceased was very strict but he was not very careful with his finances. The deceased was a disciplined person with his schedule. He was set in his ways. He would not say that the deceased was careful with his finances and assets. The deceased would purchase anything he desire. The deceased sold the Teluk Bahang land below value.

In June or July 1992, on the instructions of the deceased, he (Howard) requested a copy of the agreement on the sale of the Teluk Bahang land from Messrs Nik Saghir. He did not know why the deceased instructed him so.
Asked to explain why Hamid testified that he or Richard propositioned him 'to do something' about the 1990 wills, if it was not true, Howard replied:

After the sale (Teluk Bahang land) to the buyer obtained by Hamid felled through, Hamid blamed Richard and I as the cause of him being out of the deceased's favour. He (Hamid) was upset over his (financial) loss …. He (Hamid) is giving false evidence and taking back on me and the first and second defendants.

Howard continued: He was not aware that someone from Pykett Avenue called Hamid for copies of the 1990 wills, in July 1992, and that Hamid left copies of the 1990 wills at Pykett Avenue. Before 1 August 1992, the deceased never requested nor instructed him to prepare or type any documents for the deceased. He did not know why he was asked to type the 1992 wills. Howard agreed, as the originals of the 1990 wills in court had no amendments, that the originals of the 1990 wills were not shown to him on 1 August 1992. Howard said copies must have been amended. He made no copies of the 1990 wills. Howard maintained he obtained copies of the 1990 wills from the deceased and not Hamid.

Handwritten amendments to the 1990 wills were made to all three 1990 wills. Those amendments were: (i) Howard substituting Khaw Teik Lim as a trustee, (ii) the variation of 5 years to 30 years, (iii) the reduction of Teik Hock's interests from 4% to 2% and that 2% to Howard, the reduction of Teik Ghim's interests from 4% to 2% and that 2% to Richard, (iv) Teik Chye replacing Cheng Bok as a trustee in event of Cheng Bok's death, and (v) Howard replacing Cheng Poon in the event of Cheng Poon's death.

He did not ask the deceased, although he was close to the deceased, he wanted to amend the 1990 wills. He was not used to question the decisions of the deceased. Howard agreed that the impact of the amendments, although the amendments were not extensive, was immense.

The deceased's documents were in the deceased's safe. He (Howard) had never taken and he had not seen his father or brother taking any of the deceased's documents. The deceased's documents are still in the safe. The receiver and manager took some documents. He did not know whether the deceased was careful with his documents. He did not know where the amended copies of the 1990 wills were kept.

After the death of the deceased, the first to third defendants had the keys to the deceased's safe. He did not search for a copy of the 1990 wills. He did not look into his grandfather's possessions. Richard found, after he moved into the deceased's room, handwritten wills of the deceased (ID8A, ID8B and ID8C — not signed, not attested and not propounded by any of the parties).

Howard denied that he was never asked to change the 1990 wills. Howard denied that there were never copies of the 1990 wills with the deceased's amendments. Howard denied any truth in Beng Tatt's account that he (Howard) took the safe keys and removed an envelope from the safe on 1 August 1992. But admitting he was speculating, Howard said, Say Bee and Beng Tatt had been paid, by his uncles, to give false evidence.
Howard denied he typed the 1992 wills without the deceased's instructions, using the 1990 wills as precedents. The deceased did not want the 1990 wills, Howard said.
About a week after the deceased's death, Lim read the 1992 wills to his father,, Cheng Liat and himself. He was not sure of Cheng Bok. He was not aware who had prior possession of the 1992 wills.

On 3 August 1992, he and his parents accompanied the deceased to LWE Hospital, as the deceased had asked so. Howard denied he was present to prompt or remind the deceased of what the deceased had to say to Dr Tan. Throughout the entire consultation, he was silent. Howard denied he and his parents prompted Dr Tan to certify that the deceased was of sound mind. Howard said, deceased wanted to consult Dr Tan.

The other two wills were not prepared as he was watching the execution of the 1992 Thai will. He was not in a hurry to complete the other two wills. Howard denied he was keeping his eye on the deceased by watching the proceedings. Howard said, he was curious. He had never seen wills being executed before. He was curious as to how it would be done. It was not true he was there because of his stake or because he was the sole author of the 1992 wills. He did not prepare the second 1992 Thai will. He was only aware of the second Thai will when Cheng Bok came to Pykett Avenue with the second 1990 Thai will alleging it was forged. Howard denied he was the author of the 1992 wills.

Howard admitted that he had not received large sums, before June 1992, from the deceased. He was receiving RM50 per week. Whilst in the States, he was receiving US$1,500 per month. Other than that, he had not received any other sums from the deceased. Before June 1992, he had never received any monies from the deceased to buy a car.

row.entry: How (would) you explain all these large sums in June 1992?
He had cash only in June 1992, the proceeds from the Batu Ferringhi land.
How (would) you account for your uncles not receiving a cent from the Batu Ferringhi (land) sale?

p.text: On 1 September 1995, the first to third defendants were granted probate of the Thai estate. No property in Thailand had been sold. No dealings had been entered into.

row.entry: What reasons can you give for Dr Gafoor's testimony?
Dr Gafoor was introduced by Hamid Merican. They are very close friends as well as business associates. Hamid Merican, I�believe, prompted Dr Gafoor to lie. I have no factual basis for what I say.

p.text: In re-examination, Howard clarified as follows. He endorsed the cheque for RM225,000 [PB1(326)] as it was given to him for his endorsement. He never received the RM225,000. During cross-examination he said he was happy that his name was in the 1990 wills as a trustee. What he meant to say was that he was happy his name was in the amended 1990 wills as a trustee.

When he received US$43,000 from the Malaysian and Thai estates, the US estate had liabilities but no funds. Only in April and May 1995 were monies received from the sale of the Benson land and condominium. He did not ask his uncles to contribute towards the payment of the US taxes as they did not have that money. The sale of the condominium was not sufficient to meet the US taxes. That property was mortgaged; about US$30,000 was outstanding. US$43,000 would be repaid to the Thai and Malaysian estates.

He had no intention of residing in the States. In August 1992, when he got to know that he would be a trustee of the estate, he abandoned his plans to emigrate to the States. He consulted Le Beau on his status as a trustee in the States, his re-entry rights and his ability to carry out his duties as a trustee in the States. His mother did not consult the estate's accountant on her taxes in the States as she had no income nor properties in the States. The Mrs Khaw in the accountant's bill was Mrs Khaw Bian Cheng. She had properties in the States.

John Khoo advised him not to pay the RM866,000 (and RM826,000) Cheng Liat and Cheng Bok had only photocopies of the documents supporting their claims and if those claims were paid out, he and the other trustees could be held personally liable. Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat showed him PB2(5). He was not shown DB1(A)(97-102). But he is agreeable to the payments of RM866,000 and RM826,000 to his uncles.

Le Beau informed him of the notices objecting to his petition for administration. The negotiation with Alex Tan took place in March or April of 1995. Because of the injunction of 23 May 1995, those negotiations ceased shortly thereafter. In May 1995, he was never in a position to sell Pykett Avenue because of two existing caveats.

His mother only handled the 'Kong Teik' ceremony that was held seven weeks after the death of the deceased. His mother did not handle the funeral expenses in Singapore. He did not have any documents on the 'Kong Teik' expenses. In December 1995, the receiver and manager took possession of all documents relating to the estate. He was mistaken when he said he saw the Thai manager, just a few months ago, at Pykett Avenue. He saw him in Phuket.

The originals of the 1990 wills were not the documents the deceased amended. He did not see the deceased amending copies of the 1990 wills. The amendments to the 1990 wills had immense impact, because of the five years moratorium to the 30 years moratorium.

Cheng Hum, 66, testified in examination-in-chief as follows. He is the eldest son of the deceased. His parents sent him, when he was an infant, to his grandparents. He lived for 24 years with his grandparents. When he was 24, he was sent to Australia to further his studies. He was there for three years.

Upon return, he met Liang Imm and her husband. Liang Imm who was living with their grandparents refused to allow him to live with them. She asked him to live with their father. Liang Imm lived with his grandparents until they passed away. His other brothers and younger sister lived with his parents 'until they gave up'. Cheng Poon never left Pykett Avenue.

He lived with his parents for five years. In 1961, when he got married, he moved to 7 Brown Road, a house belonging to his father-in-law. In 1973, he moved to the present house that the deceased gave him as a wedding present. The deceased did not give a house to his brothers as a wedding present as he (the deceased) did not accept their marriages. His brothers married without his father's knowledge. They just brought their wives home. In his case, the deceased arranged his marriage and hosted a lavish dinner.

After return from Australia, he worked as a supervisor in a rubber estate — Merchiston Estate — near Taiping, until 1975, when the deceased sold the estate. Thereafter, he held no regular job. Once, he applied to the OCBC, Penang for a post. When that was discovered by the deceased, the deceased told the Manager not to employ him. The deceased said that he (the deceased) not want his eldest son to work for anyone.

His relationship with his parents was close. There were no ill feelings between him and his father. In the 1960's, he had no quarrels with the deceased. After Cheng Poon's marriage in 1963, his relationship with his parents deteriorated. Cheng Poon was constantly insinuating to the deceased that he (Cheng Poon) was a more capable son. He did not rebut Cheng Poon, as his parents would only listen to Cheng Poon. His relationship with his parents, up to 1988, did not improve. Each day, nevertheless, he was in his parents' house for lunch. The deceased insisted he should have lunch at Pykett Avenue. During lunch, Cheng Poon and Cheng Liat were also in the house.

His relationship with the deceased did not improve after 1980. It got a bit worse. It was all due to Cheng Poon's instigation and influence over the deceased. Cheng Poon was saying that he (Cheng Hum) had no son to carry on the family name. Cheng Poon was also saying that he (Cheng Poon) was good in business while he (Cheng Hum) was not. He did not defend himself.

He inherited a ⅓ undivided share of certain lands behind the Kek Lok Si temple from his paternal grandmother. The deceased owned the balance�⅔. In 1988, the deceased forced him, at Cheng Poon's instigation, to sell his ⅓ share in some of those lands. He had no reason to sell. The deceased threatened, unless he sold some of those lands, to disown him. Because of that threat, he could not protest. Hamid arranged the sale. He sold his ⅓�share concurrently with the deceased's sale of his ⅔ share. His share of the sale proceeds was RM330,000. The deceased commanded him, at Cheng Poon's instigation, to give RM130,000 to Cheng Liat and Cheng Poon. It was supposed to be a commission. He could not refuse. Cheng Liat and Hamid took RM80,000 while Cheng Poon took RM14,000. He only received RM200,000. He issued a cheque for RM80,000 [DB2(A)(12)] to Cheng Liat and handed that cheque to Cheng Liat and Hamid. He could not find the cheque to Cheng Poon.

The deceased also forced him, at Cheng Poon's instigation, to sell three pieces of lands in Bukit Tengah, Butterworth, lands the deceased had given him. He had no reason to sell those lands. He was not in need of money. He protested but the deceased threatened to disown him. Cheng Poon told the deceased to ask him to sell those lands. Thereupon, the deceased called and asked him (Cheng Hum) to sell those lands or he (the deceased) would kick him out of the house. Hamid arranged the sale. That sale was aborted. He had received the deposit and had paid a commission of RM70,000, on the deceased's instructions, to Hamid. The purchaser filed proceedings for the return of the full deposit. He had to return the full deposit. He had to fork out even the commission paid to Hamid as Hamid did not refund the commission. He asked the deceased for financial assistance, but the deceased refused to help him because of Cheng Poon's influence. In 1994, he sold the Bukit Tengah lands.

Sometime in 1990, the deceased wanted to sell the remaining lands behind the Kek Lok Si temple. Cheng Poon was instigating the deceased to instruct him to sell the remaining lots behind the Kek Lok Si temple. That time, he refused as the price offered was half the market value. Hamid was advising the deceased on the proposed sale. Similarly, he was threatened that he would be disowned. He told his father that he would not sell. The deceased told him not to come to Pykett Avenue anymore. Thereafter, he stopped going to Pykett Avenue for lunch. He also stopped his visits. He wanted to continue his visits, but he was afraid that Cheng Poon would continue his instigations and once more he would be forced to sell his lands. He was receiving a monthly allowance of RM1,000 from the deceased. After he stopped his visits to Pykett Avenue, his allowance was terminated at Cheng Poon's instigation.

In 1990, Cheng Liat was banned from Pykett Avenue. The deceased told him that Cheng Liat was poisoning his drinking water. By then, 1990, only Cheng Bok and Liang Imm were visiting the deceased. Liang Imm told him that she found difficulty visiting the deceased. She said that Cheng Poon would not allow her visits for various reasons.

His father's health, even before his mother passed away, was not good. After his mother's death, his father was suffering from depression, insomnia, of the stomach, heart problems and prostate cancer. Prior to 1988, before he was asked not to come to Pykett Avenue, he visited the deceased whenever he (the deceased) was hospitalised. He did not make similar visits, after 1990, as he was not told that the deceased was hospitalised. After 1990, he only visited his father once at Pykett Avenue. After that visit, someone from the office telephoned and told him not to visit the deceased anymore. He did not believe that his father had stopped his visits. He believed Cheng Poon was behind those instructions. He was not informed that his father was hospitalised in Singapore in 1993. He was only informed of his death.

He had no knowledge of the 1990 and 1992 wills. After Cheng Bok filed these proceedings, he got to know of those wills. He did not believe his father would leave him only RM20,000. The deceased, a kind and loving father, was not vindictive. The deceased would have been fair. The deceased would not leave him much less than his brothers. He believed, because of his experience with Cheng Poon, that it was all due to Cheng Poon's instigation.

He knew Hamid well. His father depended on Hamid for advice on the sale of properties. Hamid was close to Cheng Poon and Cheng Liat. Hamid was close to the son who was having the upper hand. Cheng Liat held the upper for a short six months in 1990. Then, Hamid was closer to Cheng Liat than Cheng Poon. After that six months, Cheng Poon was ascendant; Cheng Liat was always quarreling with a Thai girl, his father's favourite. He was present when that was happening.

He knew nothing of his brothers' trip to Singapore in 1990 with the deceased. His brothers were arranging the distribution of his father's assets to his (Cheng Hum) detriment. Cheng Hum believed it was a case of 'less men more share'. Cheng Hum did not agree with Cheng Bok's reasons for his exclusion from the 1990 wills. 'Cheng Bok gave those reasons with an ulterior purpose.'

Referring to DB1(A)(1-5), Cheng Hum alleged that only Cheng Poon could have instigated those letters. On his own, his father could not have authorized those letters. The deceased was not a man who would even attempt to take back what he had given. He gave those lands to him. The deceased was a man of his word.

He only inherited the Ayer Itam lands from his grandmother. Liang Imm inherited the bulk of her (grandmother) properties. During his father's lifetime, he inherited from his father, (i) seven rent control houses at Dato' Kramat Road, (ii) the Bukit Tengah land, and, (iii) his present house — 38�Lebuh Raya Scott — a small double storey detached house. He did not ask for those properties. The deceased gave him those properties out of his love for him. His father was giving a lot of money to Cheng Poon. Cheng Liat and Cheng Bok did not get any land from the deceased. He is supporting himself with the rent received from those seven shophouses, the interests from the sale proceeds of the Bukit Tengah land and with the help of his daughter.

The deceased made a will in 1986. That was his father's last will. Referring to DB2(A)(5-8), Cheng Hum said that his father instructed him not to inform Cheng Poon of the 1986 will. The deceased did not inform him why he was appointed in place of Cheng Liat. The deceased instructed him not to tell Cheng Poon as the deceased was afraid Cheng Poon would ask him (the deceased) to delete him as a trustee.

Cheng Hum beseeched the court to declare the 1986 will as the last will of the deceased, 'as my father had made so many wills over the years I am lost as to which will is valid'. Cheng Hum said that he did not think that the 1990 will is valid as Goh Eng Kee had passed away and the other witness (Hamid) was a bad influence.
His father and mother were inseparable. Everything his father did, he consulted his wife. His mother had a great influence on his father, his fathers's wills.

Cheng Hum considered himself as his father's favourite son until the deceased was poisoned against him. In 1988, after his mother's death, the deceased confided to him that he (the deceased) was afraid his brothers would throw his (the deceased) wishes into the sea.

Under cross-examination by Mr Khoo, Cheng Hum testified as follows. His father did not get along with his grandmother, as Ooi Geen Peen could not get along with her. His mother and grandmother were squabbling. His father sided his own wife.
He and Liang Imm inherited properties from their grandmother. Cheng Poon, Cheng Liat, Cheng Been and Liang Imm inherited a Penang Hill house from their grandmother.

Cheng Hum disagreed with Hamid's testimony that his father did not leave him any properties as he had no male issue. The deceased said that he did not mind. Grace is not his natural issue. He did not know that his father did not give him any inheritance because he had no natural issue. Cheng Hum agreed that his father believed in Hokkien traditions. He preferred daughters to sons. 'Liang Imm is the richest amongst us.' However, Cheng Hum also agreed that Liang Imm is rich because she inherited from their grandmother and not their father. 'To a certain extent, my father was biased towards small issue.'

Cheng Hum agreed that although he was a supervisor in the rubber estate, he was in Penang most of the time. He disagreed that his father was angry with him because the estate and newly planted trees under his care were razed. He disagreed that his father was angry with his wife because she refused to attend to the ancestral tablets. 'When Cheng Poon was not doing That duty, it was my wife who carried out that task.'
Cheng Poon instigated his father to force him to sell the Kek Lok Si lands as Cheng Poon wanted a ⅓ share of the sale proceeds.

In 1990, sometimes, father was normal and sometimes he was not. When he was not, he would be starring blankly and not know what he was doing. 'Fifty percent of the time, he was normal and 50% of the time he was abnormal.' 'During lunch he ate quietly. After lunch, would lie on the sofa, without talking.'
When he and his father sold their Ayer Itam lands, his father did not pay a commission. His father refused to help him return the deposit on the Bukit Tengah land sale as Cheng Poon had stopped him.

In 1990, the deceased was giving money to Cheng Poon and his family. Cheng Hum said, he had no 'former knowledge' that the deceased was giving money to Cheng Poon. The 1990 wills were invalid as his father, could not understand, he could read, the contents. The deceased was not his usual self as he was not his own man. To everything he asked, the deceased referred him to Cheng Poon or Hamid. The deceased could not recognized him. The deceased called him Cheng Poon.
In 1990, the deceased was not well. In 1990, he only spent an hour a day, during lunch, with the deceased. The lunches were always quiet affairs.
The deceased was not sound when he made the will dated 1 February 1989 — DB1(B)(6). 'My mother was like my father's walking stick. When she died in 1988, he collapsed.'

When the 1989 and 1990 wills were made, he and Cheng Imm had inherited assets whilst his brothers had none. The deceased forced him to pay the RM130,000 commission. He needed that money; he would not have paid if he was not forced by his father.
Cheng Bok never had the upper hand; he relied on Cheng Liat for information. He (Cheng Hum) was not called for the reading of the 1992 wills. The deceased was careful with money.

Under Mr Koh's cross-examination, Cheng Hum testified as follows. He was living with his grandparents at 46A Northam Road. His parents moved to Pykett Avenue. He remained with his grandparents. Liang Imm inherited the bulk of his grandmother's estate [see DB2(A)(1)].

The deceased was strict. The deceased expected obedience. When the deceased wanted to sell the Ayer Itam lands, he believed the deceased expected that he (Cheng Hum) would follow suit. He believed the deceased also expected that his wish to sell the Bukit Tengah land would be obeyed. He (Cheng Hum) would be disowned if he disobeyed. The deceased insisted that he should have lunch at Pykett Avenue. He decided, when he stood firm and refused to sell the remaining Ayer Itam lands, not to have any more lunches at Pykett Avenue. The deceased's letters to him, claiming his properties, were instigated by Cheng Poon to pressurise him into concurring with the sale of the Kek Lok Si lands.

His father was a quite man. He would not talk unnecessarily. He would command and he would not explain his decision. Later, Cheng Poon could influence his father and even made decisions for him (the deceased).

row.entry: I put it to you that up till the day the deceased died, nobody could question your father.
Cheng Poon could question my father. After 1990, I was not aware of what was happening in Pykett Avenue. Before, I heard Cheng Poon questioning our father.

p.text: Cheng Hum alleged that his brothers could get the upper hand more easily if they enlisted Hamid's help. 'When his mother was alive, when she was ill or not well, she would not allow my father to travel.' Cheng Hum maintained that he paid RM14,000 to Cheng Poon. Hamid, helping his father to sell lands to earn commissions, a reason to instigate his father into selling his lands. Although he knew that the deceased was not well, he made no powers to have the deceased medically examined.

Re-examined, Cheng Hum clarified that his parents did not object to his adoption of Grace. Grace was provided in the 1986 and 1987 wills. His brothers, in 1989 and 1990, had an inherited property — the Penang Hill house. Cheng Bok inherited a � share of two houses in Dato Keramat Road from their grandfather.

emph.emph: The testimony of the other witnesses

p.text: Lim Bok Eng, 56, affirmed as follows. She is a director of Glashaus. Cheng Poon is her husband; Richard, Howard and Gim Chuan are her children. From 1962 to 1983/1984, she was staying at Pykett Avenue. She moved out in 1983/1984 as she could not get along with her mother-in-law. She lived for ten months in Houston, Texas. When she returned to Penang, she set up a glass workshop at 72J Lorong Birch, Georgetown.

In 1988, she received the deceased's message to go to Pykett Avenue. There, the deceased told her to visit Ooi Peen Geen at the Specialists Centre. After Ooi Geen Peen passed away, she made daily visits to Pykett Avenue; the deceased asked her to sell some of his wife's jewellery. The deceased asked her to move back to Pykett Avenue, to take care of the house and Cheng Been. She agreed if she could bring along her workshop. The deceased agreed. Sometime in 1991 or after the deceased was discharged from LWE Hospital, she moved back to Pykett Avenue.

In 1993, she, husband and Richard accompanied the deceased for treatment at Singapore. She was taking care of him. The estate paid the total expenses in Singapore. She paid the rental — S$4,600 per month — for the apartment in Singapore. The medical bills were paid by the estate. She advanced S$5,000 — the taxi fare to and fro to visit the deceased, their meals and the bird's nest for the deceased.

She was with the deceased when he was in China and the States at the end of 1992. The condition of the deceased worsen in the afternoon of 8�April 1993. The deceased did not ask to see anyone. She asked the deceased if he wanted to see anyone, especially those relatives in Singapore, but he said, 'No'. She asked the deceased whether he wanted to see 'Cheng Bok'. The deceased did not even care to reply.

Before the death of the deceased, when the Thai manager was visiting the deceased, she heard the deceased instructing the Thai manager to go to Singapore with money. The Thai manager came to Singapore, either on the 10th or 11th of April, after the deceased passed away, with the equivalent of RM14,000. She kept the RM14,000. She deducted S$9,600 she had advanced and used the balance for transportation and for their expenditure in Singapore.

She discussed the funeral arrangements with Cheng Bok and other relatives. Her husband did not participate. Cheng Poon asked her to refer to Cheng Bok who he said was his elder brother. Cheng Bok wanted a Chinese style coffin. She paid for the coffin, the mourning clothes, joss papers and offerings. She paid all expenses. She did not claim for any reimbursement. She could not remember whether there was a discussion to bring the body back to Penang.

On 3 August 1992, at the request of the deceased, she accompanied the deceased to LWE Hospital. She did not know who made the arrangements. She was not told beforehand of the purpose. She was in the consultation room when the deceased spoke to Dr Tan Chee Kuan.

Cheng Poon and Richard purchased a condominium in Horizon Towers after the deceased passed away. The purchase (over RM420,000) was financed by a 90% loan secured by Cheng Poon's fixed deposit of RM150,000. She and her husband paid a 10% deposit. Monthly instalments were paid from their account. Richard was lending his name. Cheng Poon and Richard also purchased another condominium — Villa Indah, Pulau Tikus — for RM410,000, financed by a loan of RM287,000 secured by their fixed deposit of RM100,000.
She had workers working for Glashaus. The employees of the estate did not work for Glashaus. Glashaus never paid rent when the deceased was alive.

Referring to PB1(114), Bok Eng testified that she won RM556,700 in the 4-digit lottery. She won on the number 3275. Her partner fell down. A fall is 275. He fell on the third floor. She added three in front. All Glashaus workers bought the same number.
The deceased never spoke to her on the Teluk Bahang land or Pykett Avenue. She and Cheng Poon paid the instalments for the Estima after the deceased passed away.

Under Mr Khoo's cross-examination, Bok Eng testified as follows. She is a Singaporean and a permanent resident of Malaysia. She was 18�when she married Cheng Poon. She left Pykett Avenue as her mother-in-law was not treating her like a daughter. It was not true that she had worked in a cabaret.

row.entry: I don't know when DB1(C)(47) was written. But when my mother-in-law was alive, the deceased listened completely to his wife. He would comply with his wife's wishes, especially when she was old and sick. But my father-in-law did ask me to go back to Pykett Avenue even before my mother-in-law's death.

p.text: Two days before her mother-in-law's death, the deceased asked her to move back to Pykett Avenue. She did not move back immediately as she had to apply to move Glashaus from Lorong Birch to Pykett Avenue. She had to apply for three phase power.

She was solely in charge of 'Kong Teik' ceremony during her mother-in-law's funeral; Cheng Bok took charge of the other arrangements. Bok Eng denied she invited herself to Pykett Avenue, in August 1992, after the deceased was senile.

row.entry: I put it to you that PB2(35) — the tenancy agreement between Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd and Glashaus — was a sham agreement to seek protection under the rent control act?
This agreement was not signed by me.
You entered into PB2 (35) to avoid being evicted from Pykett Avenue?

p.text: Except when he sold the Batu Ferringhi land, the deceased had never given her large sums. The deceased gave her a large sum to pay the brokers. Bok Eng disagreed she took the RM225,000 in cheque PB1(325) but she agreed only she could receive the RM225,000 in cheque PB1(325).
In early April 1993, whilst the deceased was treated in Singapore, she came back to Penang with Cheng Poon for a few days.

row.entry: Do you agree that you came back and went to the BBMB Pulau Tikus?

p.text: But Bok Eng could not remember whether she was at the BBMB on 9�April 1993. She said that she could not remember anything about a sum of RM140,000 being taken from the deceased's account at BBMB Pulau Tikus on 9 April 1993. She admitted that a sum of RM140,000 was credited into her joint account with Cheng Poon. She disagreed that she and Cheng Poon 'came back to Penang to clean out the deceased's account'. Asked whether her family took at least RM2.7m from the deceased, she said that she was not sure of the figures. She said that she has about RM130,000 in all her accounts in Malaysia and Singapore. She did not know the nett worth of her family; in 1995, the two condominiums in Penang were sold with a loss of thousands. She agreed that everything her family has, except her lottery winnings, Glashaus and apartment in Singapore, came from the deceased. She denied her family 'stashed' away RM2.7m. She denied her family sold the condominiums and luxury cars as they foresaw recovery actions. She said her family only has: (i) the Teluk Bahang land, (ii) the cars belonging to her sons, (iii) her condominium in Singapore (iv) her company, Glashaus, and (v) money in the bank. She has a little jewellery.

She denied that she and her husband, between April 1992 to June 1993, were siphoning large sums of money from the deceased and from the estate. She did not see her husband signing the cheque for RM140,000 but she heard that the RM140,000 was from the deceased's account.

row.entry: I put it to you that on 9 April 1993 the deceased was already in a coma?'
I was not in Singapore on 9 April 1993.
I put it to you that you and your husband operate the deceased's account when the deceased was in a coma?

p.text: She did not know the current value of the Teluk Bahang land. She could not remember whether she called Say Bee on 12 July 1992 to accompany the deceased to LWE Hospital. The deceased was shaking and shivering; she panicked and she might have called anyone. She witnessed the deceased having seizures, but she was not sure whether it was a stroke. Sometimes the deceased answered when called, sometimes he was quiet. And so, she did not know whether the deceased was in a confused state or not. She did not agree that the deceased was confused for some time. She heard others saying that the deceased said that he saw persons walking in the pictures and on the ceiling. After discharge from LWE Hospital, the deceased had no loss of memory. It was not true that the deceased's memory was failing him in 1992.

At 6.30pm on 1 August 1992, she was in the kitchen. At 7pm, she saw Howard. The family had their meal together. She knew nothing of the preparation of a will on 1 August 1992. She agreed that she accompanied the deceased to consult Dr Tan for the first time on 3 August 1992. She denied that she accompanied the deceased, knowing a will would be signed, to ensure that a certificate would be issued. At 4pm she was downstairs when the 1992 wills were being signed. Her father-in-law told her to prepare tea. The deceased told her that Lim would be coming. She assumed that wills would be signed. Her family might have known of the execution of wills but she was not.

Her family and the deceased departed for Singapore on 8 March 1993. On 9 March 1993, the deceased was admitted to the hospital whence he stayed, except for four days at the rented apartment in Singapore, until he died. Whilst the deceased was in the hospital in Singapore, Say Bee slept each night in the deceased's room. Say Bee had a helper.

row.entry: Hamid Merican testified … about two days before the deceased passed away he called Pykett Avenue over the phone, he heard your voice instructing the person receiving his telephone call not to tell where the deceased was. Do you agree?
Maybe I said so, maybe I did not.
When the deceased was in a coma and ill, why did you not inform the other children?
Before I came back to Penang, I asked him if he wanted to see his other children. When I named his children, sometimes he would shake his head and sometimes he would keep quiet.

p.text: She denied that her family did not reveal that the deceased was seriously ill as her family wanted to avoid questions being raised by other children on the deceased's will and his properties.

The Thai manager came with Baht230,000. Since no one took charge of that money, she took it towards expenditure. She disagreed she called the Thai manager, after the death of the deceased, to bring Baht230,000 for funeral expenses.

The deceased passed away in the middle of the night to 1am on 10�April 1993. The deceased, before that, was in the ICU. 'All of us were sitting in the corridor. I (am) not sure whether Cheng Bok was there. Cheng Bok never saw or spoke to his father in Singapore.' She could not recall who called Cheng Bok to the Singapore Hospital.

row.entry: I put it to you … the deceased wanted to see his children, but your family was blocking it?
That is not true. He did not ask for his children.
Cheng Bok was not consulted on funeral matters?
I did discuss with Cheng Bok on the coffin. Cheng Bok did not say that he wanted the deceased's body to be brought back immediately to Penang.

p.text: Under cross-examination by Mr Yeoh, Bok Eng testified as follows. She did not know the amount of jewellery her mother-in-law had when she passed away. A few months after the death of his wife, the deceased asked her to sell some jewellery. She sold the jewellery on three occasions. She had no idea why the deceased asked her to sell the jewellery. She carried out his instructions. She knew that her children, in 1991, were buying luxury cars. The deceased gave the money to them.

row.entry: How would you explain that the deceased was selling jewellery of his wife but giving money to buy cars?
The sale of jewellery was a few months after his wife's death. Maybe he needed the money. But the purchase of cars came later.

p.text: She accompanied the deceased to the hospital together with her husband and children at the request of the deceased.

In re-examination, Bok Eng clarified: The deceased was capable of feeding himself both before and after his stay at LWE Hospital. When Glashaus first rented premises at Pykett Avenue, there was no tenancy agreement. She started paying rent in 1994. She came back to Penang on 4 April 1993. She was in Penang until 9 April 1993. She went back to Singapore on 9 April 1993. She took Baht230,000 to reimburse her expenses. The deceased gave her a large sum of money to pay Hamid, Tan Beng Hun (DW3) and one Tan Peng Seng. Her condominium in Singapore is owned jointly with her sister.
The testimony of Nik Saghir and Ghazi bin Ishak, in chief, under cross-examination and in re-examination, may be abridged as follows.

Nik Saghir bin Mohd Noor, 63, affirmed he was introduced to the deceased by Hamid, his close friend who habitually consulted him on land matters. Towards the end of 1988, Hamid told him that the deceased wanted him to draft a will. He asked for the prior wills of the deceased. In late 1989, Hamid gave him a copy of a will dated 1 February 1989 — DB1(B)(6) — and a copy of a deed dated 2 March 1989 — DB1(74-78). He asked Hamid, when he received the will dated 1 February 1989, for the specific instructions of the deceased. Hamid said that the deceased wanted some amendments to his earlier will. He (Nik Saghir) advised a codicil. He prepared the preliminary draft of the proposed codicil. On or about 10�March 1990 (Nik Saghir admitted he was not sure), the deceased with Hamid called at his office to discuss the proposed codicil. The deceased instructed him to amend the draft codicil. They adjourned for lunch at the Hilton Hotel; there, he met Cheng Poon and Cheng Bok (Nik Saghir was not sure of Cheng Liat).

Present during the discussion of the proposed codicil in his chambers were the deceased and Hamid (Nik Saghir was not sure of Lim). The deceased's children were not present. His only comment to the deceased, with regard to the 1989 deed, was that it seemed to favour one son; Cheng Poon would have a greater say. He could not recall the reaction of the deceased; but when he said to the deceased that he had ignored the interest of his daughter, the deceased said he had given enough property to her. The deceased instructed him to replace Richard with Cheng Bok as a trustee in the will dated 1 February 1989 but not to disturb the beneficial interests in the will of 1 February 1989.

He prepared the codicil strictly as instructed by the deceased. The codicil was signed at the E & O Hotel, Penang in the middle of March 1990. Present were Lim and himself. They subscribed as witnesses. The children and Hamid were outside.

Prior to execution, a minor amendment requested by the deceased was made to the codicil. He left it to Lim to type the required amendment. Lim returned with the amended codicil. Only one copy of the codicil was signed by the deceased. He wanted a copy but the deceased insisted he would keep the signed codicil.

He prepared the agreement dated 21 July 1991 on the sale of Lot 678 South West District, Penang. Hamid secured the purchaser. The deposit was paid directly to the deceased. On or about 13 July 1992, he received the deceased's letter dated 30 June 1992 [D1(23)] terminating the sale agreement dated 29 July 1991. He also received a similar letter dated 30 June 1992 from Cheng Poon. The sale was terminated as the purchaser defaulted on the balance. He notified the purchaser's solicitors accordingly. The purchaser was trying to obtain a loan. That was the reason, he believed, why the agreement was terminated a year after the execution of the agreement in spite of the three months' completion period. The deceased telephoned him, about but not more than a month prior to his receipt of D1(23); the deceased wanted to terminate the agreement dated 29 July 1991. The deceased enquired if he (Nik Saghir) had received the balance purchase price. When he replied in the negative, the deceased said that he was terminating the agreement.

He recalled that the number of years before the shares in Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd could be transferred was reduced at the requests of the deceased's children. There is a note on his file that his partner, Ismail bin Ibrahim, instructed a copy of the sales agreement dated 29 July 1991 to be forwarded to the deceased. Hamid gave instructions on the sale agreement dated 29 July 1991. He believed that Hamid saw him three times on the codicil. On the last occasion, Hamid came with the deceased.

Ghazi bin Ishak, 53, affirmed that he witnessed the execution of the 1990 wills on 24 October 1990. He did not prepare the 1990 wills. He was given to understand that Hamid prepared the 1990 wills. His role was to attest the signature of the deceased.

Hamid brought a draft will, about ten days before execution, for his perusal. After perusal, he returned the draft will to Hamid. He might have commented on the draft and made some amendments. Later, Hamid and the deceased came to his office with the original copies of the wills he was to witness. The deceased intimated to him that he wished to sign his will and wanted him and Hamid as witnesses.

He requested the deceased to read the will, to initial each page he read, and then to sign the will. The deceased read each page of the will. The deceased did not require any amendment. The deceased signed the will; he and Hamid signed after the deceased. They were the only persons present. He gave the executed wills to the deceased. Copies of the executed wills were not given to him. He could not recall whether there were any duplicate copies of any of those three wills.

After 24 October 1990, deceased did not see him again on the 24�October 1990 wills. He could remember those wills, even though seeing it for the first time in years, as the deceased was a good friend and those wills were the only wills of the deceased he witnessed. The 1990 wills were the wills he witnessed on 24 October 1990.

Ghazi Ishak was positive that the deceased read the 1990 wills. 'Dato'�Khaw was a very careful man. He was a man requiring all things to be done properly. He was a meticulous man. I did not mix with the deceased socially, but from my dealings with the deceased, that was the impression I had of the deceased.'

He did not read the 1990 wills to the deceased as the deceased spoke and read good English. The deceased only spoke to him after he had read and executed his wills. They spoke of other things. The deceased spoke in his usual manner.

Dr Tan Chee Khuan's full testimony may be paraphrased as follows. He was familiar with the deceased. On 16 March 1990, the deceased came to his clinic with his lawyer, one Lim, Cheng Liat and Hamid. The deceased wanted to make some changes to his will and wanted him to assess if he (the deceased) was of sound mind. The deceased told him of the proposed changes: (i) Teik Ewe (Richard) as a trustee and appoint Cheng Bok instead, (ii) the appointment of his grandsons, Teik Ewe and others, as trustees in the event of the death of his sons who were trustees, and (iii) a term of ten years in which his properties and house could not be sold. He asked the deceased for his reasons. The deceased replied that Teik Ewe was in the States while Cheng Bok was back from Johor Bahru. The deceased said, he wanted Cheng Bok back as a trustee, for convenience and in fairness to Cheng Bok who had reconciled with him. Dr Tan Chee Khuan testified that the deceased, on 16 March 1990, was of sound disposing mind.

The deceased also saw him on 24 October 1990. He came with his clerk. He could not remember anyone else, but Lim was not present. The deceased wanted to change one of the trustees — the removal of Cheng Liat and the appointment of Teik Lim and Teik Ewe (Richard). The deceased said he was not happy with Cheng Liat for recently misappropriating RM14,000 in the United Kingdom and for lying. The deceased told him that he came to see him as he felt that there could be challenges to his will if it was changed and he wanted him to certify that he was of sound mind. Dr Tan testified that the deceased, on 24 October 1990, was of sound mind.

They talked of other things as well, including the future of Cheng Been who is suffering from chronic schizophrenia. The deceased asked if there is a new breakthrough in treatment for Cheng Been. They discussed a new drug — Leporex. The deceased gave his written consent for the new drug to be administered. They had a long discussion and exchanged views. The deceased, a friend, also talked about his (Dr Tan) father-in-law.

Then Dr Tan corrected his testimony — the discussion on Laponex took place on 24 July 1992; on 24 October 1990, they discussed treatment for Cheng Been in the United Kingdom; he advised it would not be helpful. On 24 October 1990, the deceased was healthy. The deceased wanted a penile prosthesis. They had a long discussion on that possibility. He took the deceased who was serious about the penile prosthesis to the surgeon. Hearing the surgeon's advice on the anaesthetic risk, the deceased decided against the penile prosthesis.

PB1(167) was his written opinion that the mental condition of the deceased prior to 3 August 1992 was unpredictable. The doctor explained that the deceased, on 12 July 1992, was admitted for a brain infarct — damage to the brain by a stroke or a lack of blood flow or oxygen to the brain — and he formed his opinion basing on the report of Dr Francis that the deceased was mentally unpredictable and x-ray report. In Dr Tan's opinion, it was possible that the deceased had a memory disturbance — a lapse of memory. Brain infarct can cause senility and deterioration of the brain and mind. Sometimes a patient can die of a brain infarct. The brain infarct was serious, but by 17 July 1992 the deceased had recovered. But his recovery in that five days was no indicator that the damage to the brain was slight; it was a physical and not mental recovery. It might not have been a full mental recovery.

In July 1992, he did not see the deceased. He saw the deceased on 3�August 1992. The deceased came with (I think) Cheng Poon for a certification that he was mentally sound to change his will. One of Cheng Poon's sons (pointing to Howard) was present. They were constantly by the deceased's side. The deceased wanted Richard, Cheng Bok, Cheng Poon as governing trustee and Howard as his trustees. He asked for the reason. The deceased said Teik Lim was overseas. It was a short conversation. The deceased spoke to him personally. The deceased was not prompted. He spoke on his own volition. The deceased consulted him on five separate occasions. Cheng Poon, at least on two occasions, was present.

In Dr Tan's opinion, basing on the mental condition of the deceased on 3 August 1992, it was possible that the mental condition of the deceased could fluctuate from day to day. He spoke to the deceased on all five occasions. On each occasion, he was assessing his (the deceased) mental condition. From his assessment, it was entirely probable, although the deceased was mentally sound on 3 August 1992, that the deceased prior to 3 August 1992 might have had mental lapses and mental fluctuations. The mental condition of the deceased would fluctuate from hour to hour.

The visit on 3 August 1992 was the shortest. He could not recall any small talk. The deceased was rather weak. He remembered that the deceased was quite happy. On the fifth visit — 27 January 1993 — the deceased was unhappy. As for the other visits, the deceased was always looking happy. He believed the deceased's clerk arranged all five visits.

Under cross-examination by Mr Koh, Dr Tan said that the deceased saw him for his certification on 16 March 1990, 24 October 1990, 24 July 1992, 3 August 1992 and 27 January 1993. On all five occasions, he found the deceased to be mentally fit and of a sound disposing mind. Dr Tan explained that he used the expression 'sound disposing mind' as the deceased was aware of what he was saying to him and of what he was saying to the deceased.

On 24 July 1992, the deceased came to his clinic with Cheng Poon. The deceased wanted to transfer properties to Cheng Liat, Cheng Poon and Cheng Bok but not Cheng Hum. He asked the deceased what would be given to Cheng Hum. The deceased replied that Cheng Hum was too rich and Cheng Hum had already inherited a lot of property from his (Cheng Hum) grandmother. He spoke to the deceased about the new drug — Laponex.

On 27 January 1993, the deceased came to his clinic with his (the deceased) and a broker, one Ah Tan. The deceased was angry that Cheng Bok wanted to control his property and had accused him of being senile as he (the deceased) purchased six cars within a year. The deceased was unhappy that Cheng Bok mortgaged a house he had given him. He said Cheng Bok was ungrateful. The deceased said he spent RM28,000 for Cheng Bok's first wife's cancer treatment and had to support Cheng Bok's second wife and Cheng Bok's third wife.

The deceased said that he purchased six cars for his pleasure and for the use of his family. The deceased listed those cars: (i) Rolls-Royce, (ii)�Mercedes-Benz, (iii) BMW, (iv) Porsche, (v) Peugeot and (vi) Chrysler Alpine. The deceased remarked: 'Why could I not buy all those cars?' The deceased said the Porsche was for his grandson, the Peugeot for his sons and the rest were 'for his pleasure'.
The deceased told him, on 24 October 1990, he would not allow Cheng Liat to his home.

Dr Tan further said, 'the deceased's physical weakness was not a sign of mental deterioration'. However, he could not say whether the deceased on 24 July 1992 had fully recovered his mental faculty. The mental condition of the deceased, on 24 July 1992, 3 August 1992 and 27 January 1993, were about the same — there were no significant changes; the deceased appeared to be sound.

Under cross-examination by Mr Yeoh, Dr Tan testified that he first saw the deceased on 23 October 1987, when the deceased was warded at LWE Hospital. The deceased who was complaining of wind in his stomach and of breathlessness was also suffering from anxiety. According to his colleague who attended to the deceased, there were periods when the deceased had taken too much medication, and during those periods the deceased was talking nonsense. By the time he saw the deceased, his colleague had reduced the medication and he did witness the deceased talking nonsense.

The deceased, when he saw him on 23 October 1987, was troubled by 3 concerns; (i) his wife was very domineering — she was controlling his diet such that there was very little ruffage, (ii) the distribution of his property, his will and that some of his children would challenge his mental capacity, and (iii) his son Cheng Been. On 24 October 1987, they spoke of the same subjects. The deceased said that he would instruct Goh Eng Kee to prepare his will and that he (Dr Tan) could certify to his mental capacity. But the deceased never came with Goh Eng Kee.

The deceased did not inform him that he had executed wills prior to 24 October 1987. The deceased did not ask him to certify he was of sound disposing mind when he executed the codicil to the will dated 6 December 1986 [DB2A(8)] and the will dated 27 December 1987 [DB1(B)(3-5)].

Dr Tan explained that a person talking nonsense is disorientated and in a confusional state. Maybe, the deceased was disoriented because he was taking too much sedatives or suffering withdrawal symptoms when those sedatives were suddenly stopped — according to his colleague's notes, the deceased was taking sedatives for one year prior to 1987. He prescribed drugs to stabilise the deceased, that is, to help the deceased to relax and to sleep. Previously, the deceased was on too many drugs.

His social conversation assisted him in his assessment of the deceased. 'Sound disposing mind' is an accepted medical expression that a person has a satisfactory testamentary capacity. To assess if a person is of sound disposing mind, he would determine first if that person is orientated to time, place and person. He would check if he is labouring under any delusions or false belief. He would ask questions on what he wants or intends, the wills and changes and for his reasons. On each of the deceased's five visits (1990-93), he issued a certificate deposing to the mental stability of the deceased for the day of the certificate.

In October 1990, when the deceased consulted him on the penile prosthesis, the deceased came with a young lady. The deceased told him that that young lady was his companion looking after his physical needs.

row.entry: Doctor, it not occur to you that the deceased aged 85 asking for a penile prosthesis might not be in control of his senses?.

He was in control. Before his wife passed away, was inhibited. After his wife passed away he gave me an impression that he wanted to enjoy and reclaim his youth. When he saw me in 1990 he expressed to me his woe about his physical instability.

p.text: In re-examination, Tan related that his assessment was sufficient for him to issue his five certificates. He said he was not told that the deceased was showing signs of senile decay, but if told he would have looked for those symptoms. The certificates he issued were good for the day but it was possible that the mental state of the deceased would not be stable even for that day. Not all Parkinson's patients suffer mental deterioration. Altogether, he issued five certificates, but he could not find the 16 March 1990 certificate.

In further examination-in-chief, Dr Tan revealed that the deceased, according to a note dated 22 July 1992, had Parkinson's disease and that the consent to administer Leporex was given by Cheng Poon. Under Mr�Koh's further cross-examination, Tan clarified that he was not saying that a patient with Parkinson's disease would not have the mental capacity to make a will.
The court asked the following question: 'What impression did you have as you were speaking to the the deceased'. The doctor answered: 'He was talking normally, like a normal person.'

The other doctor, Dr Francis Tan, testified that he saw the deceased on 12 July 1992. The deceased was referred to him with a history of seizures — jerking movements of the arms and legs lasting a few minutes — at 3am, 5am, 7am and 9.30am. There were two or three possible causes; (i) a stroke, a mind stroke in the brain,(ii) the medication that the deceased had been taking, and, (iii) a variety of problems with his blood chemistry. A brain scan showed a lacuna infarct (a mild stroke) on the left side of the brain. The deceased had regained consciousness and was able to talk when he first saw the deceased. However, at the hospital, there were periods when the deceased was slightly confused. The deceased appeared very alert in the morning of 13 July 1992; he could get up and was even trying to do some knee squats. There were no reports of any seizures during the night of 12 July 1992 to the morning of 13 July 1992. However, the deceased was a little confused at 6pm. A similar pattern was noticed on 14 July 1992 — the deceased appeared to be better, talking reasonably and lucidly, in the morning, but a little confused in the latter half of the day. On 15 July 1992, the deceased was rambling and for no apparent reason was repeatedly doing something with his hands. However, that disappeared on 16 July 1992 — the the deceased was more his usual self and was showing interest by reading the newspapers. On 17 July 1992, the deceased was discharged at his own request.

Initially, on the first, second, maybe the third day, particularly at night when he would show some confusion or restlessness, the deceased was restrained with cotton bandages, on his hands and (maybe) his knees, to prevent him from hurting himself. The deceased had some hallucinations. The brain infarct could affect the memory of the deceased. There were times, over the first three days, when the deceased was more alert than other times. That fluctuation, after the first three days, appeared to have diminished — he was no longer rambling or confused as when he was admitted.

Given the right circumstances, the doctor testified, there could be a recurrence of the deceased's fluctuating condition. He did not diagnose Parkinson's disease. Parkinson's disease was noted on the referral note to him; he merely noted it on his file. The repetitive hand movements were not so typical of Parkinson's disease. He said, if the deceased was suffering from a recent stroke and Parkinson's disease, and the deceased was old, it was likely that the deceased's memory and mental process would have been affected. According to the GP's note to him, the deceased had been taking calcium supplements, vitamins, sleeping pills, and medicine for Parkinson's disease, his blood pressure, constipation and indigestion. The combined effect of that medication could cause the confusion. The doctor opined that it was likely that that set of medication if taken after discharge would cause hallucination and confusion to the deceased.

The deceased had a history of prostate enlargement. There was a mild impairment of his kidney function, but that impairment would not contribute much to his mental deterioration as it could be corrected with treatment.

Under cross-examination by Mr Koh, Dr Francis testified that he did not observe the seizures. He could not say whether the deceased, on 12�July 1992, was capable or incapable of signing a cheque. He did not test the ability of the deceased to sign a cheque. But the deceased was a sick man. Considering the medical condition of the deceased, he would be surprised if the deceased had the ability on 12 February 1992 to sign a cheque. Dr Francis Tan opined that the deceased was physically and mentally incapable of drawing a cheque on 12 July 1992.

Dr Francis explained that the deceased could not have fully recovered on 3 August 1992. But there was improvement on the condition he was admitted. He would not say that the deceased's condition on 17 July 1992 was such that he did know he was giving special bonuses to his employees.

On 22 July 1992, the condition of the deceased was stable. On 27 July 1992, the deceased appeared to be the same; the deceased consulted him on his old problems and his indigestion. The deceased was clear and lucid. As far as he could remember, the deceased could understand what he spoke to him. Given the deceased's age, the deceased recovered well.

Under cross-examination by Mr Yeoh, Dr Francis testified that a lacuna infarct is a small infarct occurring deep inside the brain tissue caused by obstruction to the blood supply. An infarct is the death of an area of tissue caused by blockage of blood. Due to age and the degenerative process, there was a narrowing of the deceased's blood vessels. There was insufficient blood supply to the deceased's brain — the ventricular system.

He did not record the description of the deceased's hallucinations. 'Generally, examples of hallucination would be seeing persons or objects in the room, something like that. There may also be auditory hallucinations'. If the conditions were right, it was possible that the same set of medication prior to admission would cause the hallucination and confusion to the deceased.

The deceased's prostate problem was detected at Gleneagles Hospital in January 1991; a prostate removal operation was performed at Gleneagles Hospital on 30 January 1991. The deceased's gall bladder was removed by another hospital.

He could not say for how long the deceased had been taking sleeping tablets. In general, sleeping tablets taken over a long period would have a cumulative effect, particularly on the nervous system. Patients taking sleeping tablets over a long period would develop forgetfulness, disturbance of sleep pattern, palpitations and anxiety; a person's thinking might be impaired. Dr Francis Tan agreed that the taking of sleeping tablets would be particularly hazardous to someone as old as the deceased.

row.entry: What are the tests to determine if a person is of sound disposing mind?.
There is no set formula. It is up to the examiners. These covers general questions, retentiveness, the ability to recall.

p.text: In re-examination, Dr Francis testified that it does not necessarily mean that a person with the ability to sign a document has all his mental faculties functioning.
