If the deceased was not responding to greetings, not able to carry light joss-sticks and starring blankly at his newspapers, it was a sign of Parkinson's disease. Starring blankly at the newspaper is indicative of mild dementia. Senility refers to getting old whilst dementia refers to memory, comprehension and insight. Dementia, old age, process and sleeping pills would hasten memory loss. However, memory loss is inevitable as one becomes old. A senile confused person might be able to sign cheques if he is not paralysed. However he would not know if the deceased knew what he was signing. The deceased was suffering from conditions and diseases that made him vulnerable to recurrences of symptoms of confusion, memory loss, maybe hallucinations and mental impairment. The stroke could make the dementia worse. That was a possibility.

On 22 July 1992 and 27 July 1992, he saw the deceased for not more than ten minutes. He enquired from the deceased of his health, how he was feeling and the symptoms he was having. The deceased answered him.

Lim Cheng Chuan's testimony may be paraphrased, again it must be in extenso, as follows. He is an Advocate & Solicitor. He was introduced to the deceased in 1989. He is acquainted with Beng Imm and Cheng Liat. He met Cheng Liat in 1954.

The deceased, a man of few words, wanted things his way. The deceased wanted a provision in the 1989 deed on the absolute use of the trust funds. Cheng Poon also asked to be given that absolute use. He explained to the deceased that the purpose of the trust would be defeated if Cheng Poon was given that power; nonetheless, the deceased insisted on the provisions in the 1989 deed. The public listed shares stated in the 1989 deed were transferred to the deceased and Cheng Poon as trustees for the Khaw Bian Cheng Trust Fund. However, the deceased instructed that the transfer of the lands stated in the 1989 deed to be held back.

Sometimes towards the end of 1989, Cheng Liat informed him that the deceased wanted to speak to him. In Cheng Liat's presence, the deceased informed him that Cheng Liat had complained that the 1989 deed favoured Cheng Poon and he (the deceased) wanted to revoke the 1989 deed. He advised the deceased that the 1989 deed was like a gift and could not be taken back, and that he the deceased) could exercise cl 2 — the deceased disposing off the assets and crediting himself with the sale proceeds — and nullify the entire 1989 deed. The deceased accepted his advice.

Sometime in 1990, the deceased informed him that he wanted Nik Saghir to prepare a fresh will. The deceased asked him to explain his intention to Nik Saghir. He accompanied the deceased to Kuala Lumpur. Hamid was also present. Nik Saghir advised a codicil rather than a fresh will. There was no discussion of the 1989 deed. Sometime later, they (the deceased, Nik Saghir and himself) met at the E & O Hotel. Nik Saghir read the codicil to the deceased. The deceased wanted some amendments. Nik Saghir amended the codicil. His office typed the amended codicil. The deceased signed the amended codicil. The signed codicil was handed to the deceased. He did not make nor did he take a copy of the codicil.

The deceased informed him that he had sold the Batu Ferringhi land and wanted to provide for his three sons. He prepared DB1A(97) and DB1A(100), deeds of settlement that the deceased executed at Pykett Avenue on 24 July 1992. He attested the signature of the deceased. While Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat were each given a document — DB1A(97) and DB1A(100) — Cheng Poon he was given to understand, was given cash.

The deceased instructed and he prepared the Power of Attorney ('PA') dated 24 July 1992 — DB1A(104). The deceased was troubled by prospective buyers who wanted to buy Lot 716 Section 10, Georgetown and the deceased said Cheng Poon would handle the sale. Shortly after discharge from LWE Hospital, the deceased instructed and he prepared the PA dated 3 August 1992 — DB1A(107). The deceased said he was lucky he had a mild stroke but he could be bedridden by a further stroke; the deceased wanted Cheng Poon to manage his affairs.

He knew the deceased had a piece of land at Teluk Bahang. The deceased instructed him to prepare the memorandum of discharge — PB1(290). Shortly after discharge from LWE Hospital, the deceased instructed him to prepare a transfer of the Teluk Bahang land to Cheng Poon. He prepared and attested the transfer dated 3 August 1992 — DB1F(92).

In the morning, on 3 August 1992, he received a telephone call (he believed it was from Beng Tatt) requesting him to be at Pykett Avenue to witness the execution of the deceased's wills. He arrived at Pykett Avenue at 4pm. Beng Tatt saw him to the upstairs hall. There, he met the deceased and Howard. Soon after he arrived, Dr Gafoor whom he had not met before arrived. The deceased said Dr Gafoor was his doctor.

On the table were two bundles of wills. He explained to Dr Gafoor that he would be a witness as well. He asked Dr Gafoor for his opinion on the mental health of the deceased. But the deceased informed them that he had been examined by Dr Tan and that he was certified fit to sign a will. The deceased showed them a certificate — DB1A(166).

Reading the wills and discovering that five trustees were named, he advised the deceased that only four trustees could be named. The deceased instructed Howard to delete Teik Lim as a trustee and to retype the wills. Howard took all the wills to his room.

Whilst waiting for the wills to be retyped, he took out the PA — DB1A(107) — and transfer — he had prepared and handed it to the deceased for his signature; the deceased signed both PA and transfer. The deceased instructed Beng Tatt to call Cheng Poon who was downstairs to sign the transfer. Beng Tatt called Cheng Poon who came upstairs and signed the transfer.

After that PA and transfer were signed by the deceased and Cheng Poon, Howard brought in the 1992 Thai will. The deceased read and signed the 1992 Thai will in their (Lim and Dr Gafoor) presence. Cheng Poon was not around. Beng Tatt was downstairs. He and Dr Gafoor subscribed the 1992 Thai will in the presence of each other and in the presence of the deceased.

When Howard brought in the 1992 Thai will, it was held together with a paper clip. After he read and explained the 1992 Thai will to the deceased, Howard stapled the 1992 Thai will. It was signed after it was stapled. He personally dated the 1992 Thai will. He dated it wrongly, July instead of August. He made the correction — deleting July and writing August. The deceased, Dr Gafoor and himself counter-signed the correction.

He and Dr Gafoor did not have their rubber stamps with them. It was agreed that he should take possession of the 1992 Thai will and the deceased would arrange for Beng Tatt to collect the wills from him and take it to Dr Gafoor for his rubber stamp. The deceased wanted his witnesses' rubber stamps to be affixed onto his wills.

After the 1992 Thai will was executed and subscribed, Howard brought in the Malaysian or US will. He read and explained the second will to the deceased. The deceased read and signed the second will. When the deceased was signing the second will, he and Dr Gafoor were present. They subscribed in the presence of each other and the deceased. The second will was held together with a paper clip. Howard stapled that will before it was signed. Similarly, it was also agreed that he should take possession of the second will and the second will would be rubber stamped in manner agreed for the 1992 Thai will. He personally dated, correctly that time, the second will.

After the second will was executed and subscribed, Howard brought in the third will. Similarly, it was held together with a paper clip but stapled before it was signed. The deceased executed the third will in their presence. Similarly, he and Dr Gafoor subscribed in the presence of each other and the deceased. He and the deceased read the third will before it was signed. Howard was around; he was moving in and out of the hall. He did not see Richard. Cheng Poon was not around when any of those three wills were signed.

After execution, (the deceased, Lim and Dr Gafoor) signed on each page of the three wills. He believed the deceased flipped each page of the wills himself. After the deceased had signed a page, he immediately passed that page to Dr Gafoor for signature and then to him for signature. That was done before the next page was signed by the deceased and subscribers. The whole bundle, after the execution of a page, was passed to the next signatory. He placed all three executed wills in an envelope that he took with him to his office.

A week later, Beng Tatt called at his office. He handed the three wills to Beng Tatt. He instructed Beng Tatt to take it to Dr Gafoor for his rubber stamp. A week or two later, Beng Tatt returned to him all three wills with Dr Gafoor's rubber stamp. He placed it in an envelope, sealed and deposited the envelope in his office safe. After the death of the deceased, Cheng Poon, Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat asked him to take out the wills and read it to them. The 1992 wills, until then, were always in his safe.

Sometime around 3 August 1992, he visited the deceased. He had with him RPGT Forms 1 and 2 and a written election for RPGT exemption. The deceased signed Form 1 and the election whilst Cheng Poon signed Form 2.

After 3 August 1992, only contact with Beng Tatt was that one occasion when Beng Tatt came to his office to take the 1992 wills. After 3 August 1992, he never gave any documents to Beng Tatt or anyone else for the signature of the deceased or Dr Gafoor; he personally handed the agreement on the sale of Lot 44 Section 3, Bandar Jelutong — DB1C(74) — to the deceased. DB1C(74) was executed on 2 December 1992.

At Pykett Avenue, he opened the sealed envelope and read the (1992) wills to Cheng Poon, Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat. They instructed Beng Tatt to make photostat copies. They returned the originals to him. He returned to his office with the three (1992) wills. A week or two later, Cheng Poon came to his office. Cheng Poon wanted John Khoo as the executors' solicitor. Cheng Poon asked for the 1992 wills. He affixed his rubber stamp and handed the three (1992) wills to Cheng Poon. He returned the death certificate of the deceased to Cheng Poon. Thereafter, the (1992) wills were never in his possession.

He received the deceased's written instructions — DB1A(1) and DB1A(2) — and wrote the letters — DB1A(4) and DB1A(5) — to Cheng Hum. As instructed, he lodged a private caveat [DB1A(9)] against Cheng Hum's property. He advised the deceased that he had a weak case against Cheng Hum. However, the deceased insisted on the caveat and he files a writ to support the caveat.

The deceased, as he knew of him, was in full control of his mental faculties. He was a quiet man. When he asked him a question, he would directly reply, with few other words. He did not find him forgetful. The deceased after he was discharged from LWE Hospital was alert but his movements were slow. Prior to 3 August 1992, he accompanied the deceased when he consulted Dr Tan.

About a month after Cheng Poon took away the (1992) wills, Cheng Bok came to his office, alone and unannounced. Cheng Bok alleged that the 1992 wills were forgeries. He told Cheng Bok that it was not true. He denied the alleged forgery. He was surprised at Cheng Bok's allegation. That was the only time he saw Cheng Bok at his office.

Shown D11 (a photostat of the second 1992 Thai will), Lim said he could not remember having witnessed D11. 'I have never seen the original'. 'We only executed three wills. This is not a copy of one of them.' 'I never had D11 … or any copy ever in my possession.' Lim testified that he did not open a file for the three 1992) wills. He opened a file for the estate of Khaw Bian Cheng. When he handed over the 1992 wills, he also handed his office files relating to the Estate of Khaw Bian Cheng to Cheng Poon.

The sale of Lot 44 was not completed but the total purchase price was paid to Messrs Ismail Khoo & Associates before the death of the deceased. The purchaser is waiting for the transfer to be completed.

Lim Cheng Chuan, under cross-examination by Mr Khoo, affirmed as follows. He did not know the deceased or family well. His chief clerk, who is his brother-in-law, had a key to his office safe. The other lawyers in his firm did not have access to his safe.

The deceased had not been to his office. When the deceased first consulted him, it was at Pykett Avenue. Cheng Poon was present. On a few occasions, on matters related to his father's affairs, Cheng Poon had been to his office. Sometimes, the deceased passed documents to Cheng Poon to be handed to him. Cheng Poon was the only person, other than Beng Tatt, who handed the deceased's documents to him. Sometimes, his office would telephone Beng Tatt for documents. His chief clerk could receive documents for his attention.

Lim denied that someone other than the deceased instructed the 1989 deed. About a week after the execution of the 1989 deed, the shares were transferred and the deceased instructed him not to proceed with the land transfer. Cheng Liat's complaint was after the transfer of shares.

Between early 1990 to July 1992, the deceased did not use his legal services. Only one copy of the codicil was signed at E & O Hotel. After discharge from LWE Hospital, the deceased called him by telephone to his house. He prepared both 24 July 1992 settlements.
On 3 August 92, shortly after he arrived, Dr Gafoor arrived. After escorting Dr Gafoor upstairs, Beng Tatt was in his office downstairs.

He read the 1992 wills. When he read the provision on the appointment of five trustees he stopped reading and advised the deceased to make the correction to four trustees. He did not read the rest of the document as it was not necessary.

He read aloud the 1992 wills to the deceased. He also explained some of the provisions of the wills. The deceased went through every page. The deceased instructed Howard to delete Teik Lim as a trustee. Howard prepared the 1992 wills. The 1992 wills were printed at Pykett Avenue. With him, the deceased did not discuss the making a will. 'On hindsight, I should have been more careful (as I was witnessing) a will prepared by a beneficiary. I agree that I exposed myself to an attack on my propriety. However, I maintain that there was nothing irregular.'

Lim agreed that Dr Gafoor should have heard him reading aloud the 1992 wills and should have seen the deceased signing the transfer of the Teluk Bahang and PA. He affirmed that D11 was not one of the wills signed on 3 August 1992. He said he had no knowledge of D11 — 'The signatures on ID11 purportedly mine (are) not mine'.

Lim testified that he affirmed in an affidavit in 22-271-94 [see DB1A(269)] — that his signatures were on D11 — as he thought those signature were his. 'It was similar to my signature, so I said it was my signature.'

row.entry: I put it to you that (D11) has your signature.
No. I don't know who prepared (D11). I did not lodge a report on the forgery of my signature on (D11).
I put it to you that you have knowledge of (D11) and you attested (D11).

p.text: Lim agreed that some pages of the 1992 Thai will bore no signatures of the deceased, Dr Gafoor or himself. 'I am sure each and every page was signed by all three. D2B could have been tampered while it was not in my possession.'

He did not instruct Beng Tatt to take loose documents to Dr Gafoor for signature. About a week after the death of the deceased, he read the (1992) wills to Cheng Liat, Cheng Bok and Cheng Poon. He did not give a copy of the 1992 wills to the other children. But Lim also confirmed his firm forwarded copies of the 1992 Thai will, letters dated 15 April 1993 and 15 April 1993, to Cheng Bok and Liang Imm.

He handed his file to Cheng Poon who wanted to show it to John Khoo. He took no action to recover his file. He did not know who prepared D11. He agreed that the 1992 Thai will was tampered. After execution, the 1992 wills were in his possession until it was handed to Beng Tatt for Dr Gafoor's rubber stamp. He did not send D11 to any of the parties.

Under cross-examination by Mr Yeoh, Lim affirmed that he met the deceased on several occasions. The deceased always gave him personal instructions, when they were alone and sometimes when Cheng Poon was around. The deceased was not forgetful. 'Each time I met him, he was clear and lucid and he could answer my questions.' He (Lim) never took instructions from Cheng Poon. Not once did Cheng Poon instruct him on his father's assets.

The 1989 deed was prepared on the instructions of the deceased. However, Poon intervened and asked to be given the same power of absolute use. Cheng Poon said his brothers would disturb and obstruct his every action if he was not given absolute power. Clause 5 was incorporated to accommodate Cheng Poon.

The deceased who agreed that the 1989 deed was not fair to Cheng Liat, wanted to revoke the 1989 deed. In early 1990, the deceased said he wanted to change his will but did not specify the will concerned. He was at E & O Hotel to witness the codicil.

He prepared the two settlements dated 24 July 1992 solely on the instructions of the deceased. Cheng Poon did not instruct him. A similar settlement was not given to Cheng Hum or other children as the deceased said he wanted to give a million each to Cheng Liat, Cheng Bok and Cheng Poon from the sale of the Batu Ferringhi land; that million was reduced to RM866,000. The deceased wanted to give cash to Cheng Poon.

When the PA dated 24 July 1992 was signed, he knew that the deceased was just discharged from LWE Hospital. Cheng Poon did not instruct him on the PA. On 24 July 1992, he was instructed to prepare the PA dated 3 August 1992. The deceased did not explain why he had given a limited and then a general PA. Cheng Poon did not instruct him on the transfer of the Teluk Bahang land. The deceased did not give his reason for the transfer of the Teluk Bahang land.

He did not consider it odd or strange that the deceased instructed him on twoseparate PAs, one transfer, two settlements and executed three wills within 24 July 1992 to 3 August 1992. 'The deceased wanted to settle his earthly affairs. He was a sick man.'

He did not receive any instructions on the preparation of the 1992 wills. He merely attested the signature of the deceased. He had no doubts on the deceased's mental ability but he asked for Dr Gafoor's opinion as he was a doctor. Before Dr Gafoor could respond, the deceased produced Dr Tan's certificate.

After the deceased signed a page, he had to rest his hand. They used the time to sign that page. It would be difficult for the deceased to continually sign an entire document. The deceased needed to rest his hand or his hand would tremble. On 3 August 1992, the deceased was physically weak.

The (1992) wills were in his office safe for about a week before it was handed to Beng Tatt. Before that, he was waiting for Beng Tatt. There was no urgency to have the rubber stamps. Lim could not explain why his rubber stamp was not affixed on the 1992 wills before it was handed to Beng Tatt.

Cheng Poon asked for the 1992 wills a few days after it was read. He kept the 1992 wills as the deceased had asked him, immediately after the execution of the 1992 wills, to keep the (1992) wills. He read the 1992 wills to whoever was present at Pykett Avenue. It did not occur to him to call the other beneficiaries, although he knew who they were.
In 1990, he accompanied the deceased to see Dr Tan. He could not remember the conversation.

The deceased said he wanted to sell his (Ayer Itam) land as he needed the money. Because Cheng Hum had refused to accept the proposal in DB1A(4), the deceased instructed him, as leverage, to issue DB1A(5). Cheng Poon did not instruct him on DB1A(4) but he believed Cheng Poon was present when the deceased instructed him. He was aware that Cheng Hum was not inclined to sell the Ayer Itam land. Cheng Poon said he had a buyer for one of the Ayer Itam lands.

The deceased was strict with his children but he was not mean or hard on them. The deceased loved his children but was tight fisted. He agreed that DB1(A)(2) — the instructions of the deceased to caveat and to claim Cheng Hum's house — was out of character. He would not know if Cheng Poon had instigated the deceased to send the letters DB1(A)(1-2). He did not assist Cheng Poon to get the better of his brothers. He did not disclose the existence of the 1989 deed to Cheng Liat. He disagreed that Cheng Poon and his sons were instrumental in formulating the 1989 deed. He did not know why the deceased did not inform Cheng Liat of the 1989 deed. He agreed that Cheng Liat told of the 1989 deed would have alerted the deceased earlier of the purport of the 1989 deed. To achieve the termination of the 1989 deed, it did not occur to him to advice the beneficiaries of the 1989 deed to renounce their interests. He did not allow Cheng Poon to instruct him on behalf of his father. He denied Cheng Poon instructed him from the time of the 1989 deed to the last document he prepared. He maintained that he gave his entire file to Cheng Poon as Cheng Poon wanted to show it to John Khoo. He denied Cheng Poon instructed him to keep the 1992 wills.

row.entry: But at the E & O Hotel were you not given a copy of the codicil? How (would) you explain that the three wills were entrusted to you?
The deceased wanted me to keep the wills.

p.text: Agreeing that his testimony was diametrically opposed to Dr Gafoor's, Lim maintained that his testimony was what had actually happened. He said that Dr Gafoor and Beng Tatt's testimony was not true.
The deceased's action against his eldest son and his caveat against his eldest son's house were out of character. Against his advice, the deceased insisted on the caveat.

He was positive that he sent a copy of the 1992 Thai will and not a copy of the second Thai will to the beneficiaries. He said he did not have a copy of D11. Shown the original of D11, Lim agreed the second 1992 Thai will had his signature and rubber stamp. He agreed that the second 1992 Thai will was the original of D11 and that D11 had his signature.

row.entry: Then can you explain how this fourth will dated 3 August 1992 came about?

The first Thai will had an error in the date, but I corrected it. Dato Khaw was not happy and he arranged for the second Thai will to be typed, ie 2D. The contents were the same as the first Thai will — DB2B. A date was fixed for me and Dr Gafoor to be present. I went a few days after 3 August 1992. Dr Gafoor did not turn up. We waited and yet he did not turn up. Dato signed 2D and he asked me to sign. I signed and he said he would wait for Dr Gafoor to sign as a witness. 2D was there when I reached the deceased's house. I did not prepare 2D. 2D was kept by the deceased. I now say I cannot remember whether I had given ID2D to Cheng Bok. I now say that 2D is genuine.

p.text: In re-examination, Lim Cheng Chuan explained that when he discovered, while testifying on 20 March 1997, that two pages of the 1992 Thai will did not have his signature, he hastily concluded that those two pages must have been tampered. He said he had no 'personal knowledge that it was tampered'.

row.entry: Could (there) be any other explanation for the signature not being on those 2 pp?
Perhaps the deceased flipped more than 1p.

p.text: The instructions to him, except on the singular occasion when Cheng Poon interceded, were solely from the deceased. He forgot about the second Thai will (D2D). When he arrived at Pykett Avenue, he was not aware that Howard prepared the wills. He was only aware when Howard took the wills for amendment. The file (LA/854) he gave Cheng Poon had the trustees as his clients; Cheng Poon was one of the executors.

Dr Gafoor testified that he was called by telephone, in the afternoon, on 3 August 1992, to Pykett Avenue. He thought his medical attention was required. From 1990 to 1992, the deceased was his patient. At the upstairs hall, Lim whom he had never seen before told him that he was to witness the execution of the deceased's wills. Also present were the deceased, Richard, and Beng Tatt by the side of the deceased. He did not see Howard. There were papers on the table. They (the deceased, Lim and Dr�Gafoor) signed those papers. Then further papers 'came' that they (the deceased, Lim and Dr Gafoor) signed. There were a number of trips, three Dr�Gafoor believed, in which loose sheets were taken out from a room. He could not recollect the person who brought those loose sheets. 'It was not attached together or stapled together.' The wills were not read to the deceased. On 12 August 1992 and 14 September 1992, Beng Tatt brought him loose documents for signature. Those loose sheets bore the signature of the deceased and Lim. There were many loose sheets. 'It was a thick bundle.' On both occasions, he signed those documents in the absence of the deceased and Lim. On both occasions, Beng Tatt told him that the previous documents had mistakes and amendments were required. At that time, he did not think it was irregular. Dr Gafoor said, he would not have signed those documents if he knew it was irregular. On both occasions, he also affixed his rubber stamp on those documents. Dr Gafoor affirmed that Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat came to see him and that he related the events of 3 August 1992, 12 August 1992 and 14 September 1992 to them. Dr Gafoor said that he saw the deceased and Lim for the last time on 3 August 1992.

Under cross-examination by Mr Koh, Dr Gafoor testified that Cheng Poon was also present on 3 August 1992. Beng Tatt was present all the time. He did not have his rubber stamp at that time. Later, were sent to him for signature and rubber stamp. On 3 August 1992, he did not think there was anything wrong with documents in loose sheet form. Sometime in 1994, Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat came to see him; he told Cheng Bok that the documents were in loose sheets. 'Before 1994, it did not bother me. I was asked to sign and I signed.' Dr Gafoor disagreed that Lim had read the wills to the deceased. 'The deceased read it himself.' Dr Gafoor disagreed that Cheng Poon was only there for a short while. 'He was there throughout the signing of the wills.'

Under cross-examination by Mr Yeoh, Dr Gafoor said that Lim asked him, as soon as he reached Pykett Avenue, to witness the execution of the deceased's wills. He did not inform the deceased that he was asked to witness his wills. When he saw the deceased, he greeted the deceased and he returned his greeting.
No one read the wills to the deceased. The deceased held the wills and look at it. He did not read aloud. The deceased asked no questions. No one said anything to him..

In re-examination, Dr Gafoor said that nothing was said by the person bringing in the loose sheets for signature. He could not remember the particular loose sheets signed in his clinic. 'The deceased did not look at all the loose sheets. He looked only for a short duration'.

When he was recalled, Dr Gafoor testified that Athe deceased only signed a will. 'I did not see any other documents being signed by any other person.' 'Maybe there was some other event that I did not witness'.

Teoh Eng Chye, 42, the Deputy Branch Manager of the BBMB, Pulau Tikus Branch testified that PB1(144-157) were statements on the bank account of Bok Eng, Cheng Poon and the deceased. PB1(290-323) were documents relating to the overdraft of the deceased secured by a charge of Pegangan 676 and 678, Mukim 2, Daerah Barat Daya, Pulau Pinang (Teluk Bahang land). PB1(324-336) were copies of cheques drawn on the deceased's account 1540021212. The deceased had three accounts: (i)�two normal current accounts; and (ii) juara gold account. The overdraft was granted to account 1540006019. PB1(323) and PB1(324) showed that a sum of RM866,000 and RM197,000 were drawn out from the deceased's current account 1540021212 and credited to the joint account of Cheng Poon and Bok Eng. PB1(325-336) were monies drawn from the deceased's account and credited to the persons named in the cheques.
Under cross-examination by Mr Koh, Teoh testified that his branch granted an overdraft facility of RM1.5m to the deceased. Before it was redeemed, there were attempts to sell the Teluk Bahang land.
My branch corresponded with M/s Nik Saghir acting for... I cannot remember … as the loan by that time was getting bad.

In my branch, when a customer draws an unusually large amount in favour of a third party, we usually communicate with the drawer to ascertain the genuineness of the cheques. Looking at PB1(325) I would say that the drawee saw the manager. The cheque has the signature, approving the payment out, of the manager. The cheque PB1(325) was paid to the persons named. No one else received the amount.

Chew Cheng Leong, 32, the manager of Arthur Andersen & Co ('AA') Pusat Bandar Damansara, Kuala Lumpur, testified that for the period January to December 1996, he was entrusted by the receiver and manager of the estate of the deceased to take charge of the administration of the estate of the deceased, to assist in determining the value of the estate, its incoming and out goings, and to preserve the assets.

He visited Pykett Avenue, where the books and records of the estate were kept. The occupants of Pykett Avenue handed over those books and records. AA has most of the documents. Cheng Poon and Bok Eng have not surrendered the personal valuables of the deceased and Ooi Geen Peen to AA. When he was at Pykett Avenue, he was confined to the office.

Based on Cheng Poon's account, AA prepared PB4(1-4); most of the expenses for the period 1 January 1993 to 4 October 1993 were not supported by documents. Despite several requests, Douglas Newman and Cheng Poon have not supplied the documents supporting the expenses of the US and Thai estates.

The estate has 43 properties listed in the 1992 wills. Solely, jointly or beneficially, the Malaysian estate has 40 other properties listed in P19. Despite several requests, the titles to the landed properties in Thailand have not been delivered to the receiver and manager or AA. The first to defendants refused to deliver vacant possession of Pykett Avenue. They denied that the receiver and manager had a right to possession of Pykett Avenue. He had access to the Malaysian accounts. He had never seen the probate granted in Thailand.
In October 1996, the receiver and manager instructed AA to abandon all attempts to take possession of the Thai and US properties.

The first to third defendants have not handed over the correspondence from the Thai manager. By and large, the correspondence from the US or Thailand to the estate and received by the first to third defendants and or their solicitors, after the appointment of the receiver and manager, were not handed to the receiver and manager or to AA. The receiver and manager received the rentals and dividends for the period after December 1995. The receiver and manager or AA have not received other monies of the Malaysian, US or Thai estates. He was not aware that the deceased had expensive antiques or paintings.

Under cross-examination by Mr Koh, Chew Cheng Leong testified that AA took steps to take over the administration of the US assets. On AA's instructions, Messrs Ong & Kandiah corresponded with Douglas Newman. Their correspondence were not responded within good time. The Thai manager, Tamarak Chintaphorn, furnished part of the Thai accounts. 'I would say, yes, the cooperation was not forthcoming. I agree that after I had the meeting with Tamarak and after I proposed the site visit, the defendants left it to my firm to take steps to take possession of the Thai assets.'

The issue of the inventory of the personal belongings of the deceased — jewellery, antiques and paintings — was raised many months after the appointment of the receiver and manager. At about the time that AA was appointed, AA raised the issue of the possession of Pykett Avenue with the first to third defendants. AA conducted an inquiry into the US assets, but those assets have not been ascertained.

Under cross-examination by Mr Foo, Chew Cheng Leong testified that he wrote in early 1996 for details of the US assets. Raymond Ooi & Co, directed him to Douglas Newman. A list of the US assets has not been received.

Under cross-examination by Mr Yeoh, Chew Cheng Leong testified that the deceased had 32 properties, in part or in whole, in Penang, which were not listed in any of the wills of the deceased. AA had not inquired into the personal valuables of the deceased. AA failed to obtain delivery of the personal effects and valuables of the deceased from Cheng Poon.

In re-examination, Chew Cheng Leong testified that AA could not get a complete picture of the estate. It was difficult getting the information on the assets in Penang, Thailand and US. AA received partial cooperation. The Thai manager only gave an income and expenditure account for one month.

Under further cross-examination by Mr Koh, Chew Cheng Leong testified that AA applied to the first to third defendants for details of the personal valuables of the deceased. Cheng Bok informed AA that the deceased left valuables. In further re-examination, Chew Cheng Leong reaffirmed that the details of the personal valuables of the deceased were not given to AA.

In answer to the court, Chew Cheng Leong said, AA has no reason to suspect or indeed has discovered any other properties of the deceased in Thailand or US. that are not already disclosed to the receiver and manager, AA or to the plaintiffs.

Yeoh Keat Chye, a weight lifting instructor, testified that from 1988 he was 'the deceased's driver and night security'. He said, he is still employed by the estate. 'I report each day to Cheng Poon.'

The deceased was a man of authority and few words. Beng Tatt handed him DB1(B)(9). The deceased said to him that Cheng Liat was not allowed into the house. Normally, he would drive the deceased to the Thai and Indonesian Consulates, watch shops, temples and on Sundays to restaurants. He testified

Sometimes, the deceased engaged in conversation with me. Normally, Teoh Say Bee would be around. Sometimes, the deceased would point out to us his properties as we drove passed. At the temple, Say Bee lit the joss-sticks for the deceased. Usually, the deceased would give his directions. One road I was instructed not to pass was Victoria Green Road, where Cheng Liat stayed.
There was no difference in the deceased, prior to admission and after discharge from LWE Hospital. The deceased 'looked all right even when he went to Singapore in March 1993.'
He spoke when he left for Singapore. The deceased told me that if anyone would look for him to tell them that he is in Singapore receiving treatment.

On 15 August 1995, he met Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat. They spoke to him about the Batu Ferringhi land. 'Cheng Bok related a few things for me to convey to Cheng Poon. He reported the matters spoken to him in D1A(341).'
Under cross-examination by Mr Khoo, Yeoh Keat Chye testified that Cheng Poon 'introduced him to work for the deceased'.

Cheng Poon is not a partner of Super Gym. 'I do not know why Cheng Poon's photograph is hanging in Super Gym.' 'Presently in the daytime, I don't work. At night I work in the Super Gym and as a bouncer at Party Box Discotheque.'

He never worked for Bok Eng. 'Presently, once a month, I drive Cheng Been to LWE Hospital. I still have a room at Pykett Avenue.' His contact with the deceased was less than Say Bee's. Once, he was detained for four nights by the police for a 'brawl'.

It took him 13 days to lodge his report — D1A(341) — as he was waiting for Cheng Poon's instructions. He agreed that he would not have lodged that report if Cheng Poon had not instructed him. He disagreed that Cheng Poon dictated his report.

Under cross-examination by Mr Yeoh, Yeoh Keat Chye testified that Say Bee, not the deceased, called him to the deceased's room. Cheng Poon was not around. He knew, after receiving 1(B)(17) that the deceased did not like Cheng Liat. Once, after receiving DB1(B)(9), the deceased instructed him not to pass Victoria Green Road. In re-examination, Yeoh Keat Chye said that his room in Pykett Avenue was formerly a shed.

Tan Beng Hin, 62, a former health inspector of the MPPP and a pensioner, testified that Beng Imm married his wife's cousin-in-law, one Dr Edwin Yip. 'My wife is Lim Poh Suan. Edwin Yip is my wife's brother's (Lim Eng Chye) brother-in-law. Edwin's sister married my wife's brother.'

In 1991, he and his brother, Tan Beng Seng, were involved in the sale of Batu Ferringhi. 'The others were Hamid Merican, Cheng Poon, and a friend of my brother. The deceased gave him 10% of the total sale proceeds to be shared by all five. He received � of the 10%. DB1(E)(127) was his receipt. Cheng Poon received � to be shared with Hamid Merican. His brother and his friend received � of the 10%. He received his � of the 10% by or before 18 June 1992. It was paid in cash. Bok Eng arranged the payment to him and to the others.

A few days before the deceased was admitted to LWE Hospital, he stayed with the deceased at the Shangri-La Hotel, Kuala Lumpur. In November 1992, he accompanied the deceased to Taiwan and to the States. On that trip, the deceased was quiet. At the States, the deceased said that his land was on a slope and only the rich would want land on a slope. On that trip were Cheng Poon and wife, himself and wife, Teik Ewe and the deceased. The deceased needed some assistance to dress himself. The deceased ordered soft food suitable for him. The deceased was wearing dentures. He was not wearing braces. At times, he changed his orders for his food. He was at the funeral at Singapore. Cheng Poon was not in charge of the funeral.

Under cross-examination by Mr Khoo, Tan Beng Hin said he was not a licensed estate agent. On the trip from Arizona to Port Worth, Texas, the deceased could not control his bowels and soiled the pampers he was wearing. He cleaned the deceased.
Under cross-examination by Mr Yeoh, Tan Beng Hin said he did not know who determined the 10% commission and he did not know that a 10% commission was above the norm. Tan Beng Hin was not re-examined.

Cho Choo Meng, 42, a chartered accountant and a director of Price Waterhouse, Penang, testified that Howard instructed him, by letter dated 4 April 1997 from Messrs Murad & Foo, to prepare and determine the accounts of the deceased's estate in the States. He enlisted the assistance of Price Waterhouse of Phoenix, Arizona, who since has produced a report dated 29 April 1997 on the accounts. He perused that report and prepared his summary (D37) the US accounts. From what he could elicit from the bundles of documents in court, D37 is a true and accurate summary.
The total taxes in the States were US$91,821.89 and US$6,667.84. The professional fees amounted to US$56,807.34 and US$13,224.75. The estate was in deficit — US$48,697.51.

Isdakom Kasemsri, 47, an Attorney at Law of 79 Sukhabhidan Road 3, Bangkok, testified that in general, under the Thai Land Code, only Thai nationals or Thai companies can own lands in Thailand. Non-Thais holding lands before 1 December 1954, the effective date of the Thai Land Code, are entitled to their lands without restrictions. But those lands, after 1 December 1954, cannot be inherited by non-Thai beneficiaries. The Thai Land Code provides that such non-Thai beneficiaries shall dispose of those lands within a year as prescribed by the Director General of the Land Department, and in default, the Director General is empowered to dispose off the land, by private or auction sale, within the next two years. In practice, the one year usually commences from the day the beneficiaries become entitled to the property, is, according to the Civil Code, upon the grant of administration to administrators.

A company incorporated in Thailand but owned by non-Thais cannot own lands in Thailand. If it is 51% foreign owned, it will be considered a foreign company. If Thai ownership becomes less than 51%, the company would be deemed a foreign company and its lands would be subject to sale.

The Director General, if he has knowledge that the deceased's beneficiaries are non-Thais, may enforce the provisions of the Thai Land Code and compel the sale of the lands of the deceased in Thailand. In his opinion, even if a will is contested, he would advise the trustees named in the contested will to apply for administration. He agreed, if the Director General had not issued a notice, that the deceased's lands are safe. He agreed, since four years have passed since the death of the deceased, that there was no urgency to apply for administration. In 1993, with the beneficiaries all being non-Thais, he would advise an application for administration, even though there was no impending notice of sale by the Director General.

Prateep Pattana-Amora, a lawyer practising in Hadyai and residing at 573 Supasarurang San Road, District of Hadyai, Songkla, Thailand testified that Enon-Thais may only own lands as provided under ss 85-88 of the Thai Land Code. A non-Thai is entitled to inherit under each category of use provided in s 87. A person permitted to inherit is not compel to sell the land. However, if a non-Thai inherits more than the permitted acreage, he must sell the excess, because of the limits in s 87, under s 1732 of the Civil and Commercial Code. There is no time prescribed for the disposition of the excess land. Section 94 applies only to lands acquired unlawfully and not to inherited lands; an acquisition by a non-Thai exceeding s 87 is not an unlawful acquisition.

On 30 April 1997, at the Commercial Office, Trang, Thailand, he conducted a search of Khaw Bian Cheng Nararong, Wife, Relation & Friends Ltd. It was listed in the Trang Province as a Thai company. There is no time limit for the distribution of the deceased's shares in Khaw Bian Cheng Nararong, Wife, Relations & Friends Ltd. On 30 April 1997, he conducted a search of the deceased's 147 lands in Trang Thailand (see PB1(59-64). Thirty-five properties had been sold — nine belonging to Bian Cheng Naranong Pte Ltd and 26 to the deceased. Lot 114 was charged and then discharged on 18 April 1997. Lot 114 is still in the name of the company. Those 36 (35 and 1) dealings were those in his summary DB2(B). He obtained duplicates of those 36 dealings from the Kantang Land Office — DB2(B)(1-430).

The charge of Lot 114 was created under the company's seal. Based on his knowledge and experience, the value of one rai of commercial land in Trang, during 1990 to 1993, was Baht25m. One acre is equivalent to 2.5rai. Vacant commercial land in Trang was worth Baht25m for one rai. One Chintapol Thammasak's signature signed for the vendor in almost all the agreements of sale. None of the PAs used to effect the transfer were certified by the Thai Embassy, Thai Consulate or Notary Public. All sales were lower than the market price. Each building lot was worth Baht1.5m.

row.entry: I suggest... land transactions are routinely registered in Thailand based on PAs which may not have been executed in Thailand although they purport to have been executed in Thailand. I�suggest... the Land Registering Authority would register the documents without investigating and therefore short cuts would be taken to overcome the inconvenience of PAs. being executed in Thailand.
At the time when the PA was signed, the witnesses must be present. It must be certified by the Embassy.

p.text: He tendered, inter alia, copies of documents — D40(1-6) — relating to a meeting at Pykett Avenue on 12 July 1996, of Bian Cheng Naranong Ltd attended by Cheng Poon Naranong, Richard Khaw Naranong, Howard Khaw Naranong to mortgage Lot 114 to the Thai Commercial Bank, Trang Branch for Baht1m and an agreement dated 28 August 1996 — D40(14-15).
Mr Koh delivered a long commentary on the law relating to wills, the Law relating to gifts and advancements as well as on the evidence.

Mr Koh confirmed: (i) that Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard endorsed the consolidation/joint trial of all the actions herein save on their right to challenge Cheng Bok's locus standi in the recovery action, and (ii) that the outcome of this trial would determine the fate of 32-159-93. However, he said, 'should this court not find in favour (of the 1992 wills), a separate petition for letters of administration or probate would have to be presented'.
He continued:

The declaration that the deceased died intestate is not available as the court would have to investigate other wills which might exist and the beneficiaries to those wills have not been cited. If this court should find against both the 1990 and 1992 wills, all parties would be free to propound other wills in separate proceedings; Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard, could bring fresh proceedings propounding another will.

Want of proper execution, fraud and undue influence in the execution of the 1992 wills were alleged. The testamentary capacity of the deceased was challenged. Cheng Hum and Grace made similar allegations. However, the formal validity of the 1992 wills was not challenged; it was only alleged that the 1992 wills were executed in loose sheet form.

Section 5
of the Wills Act 1959, in pari materia with
s 9
of English Wills Act 1837, leans towards upholding and not striking down the 1992 wills because of formal defects. The bare execution of a will, where the testator is shown to be rational, is sufficient to prove the will.

Where there is a proper attestation clause, the general proposition is that due execution is presumed even if the attesting witnesses have no recollection of having witnessed the will. 'That of course is a rebuttable presumption.'

Where a testator had read a will, in the absence of fraud, there is a strong presumption that the testator knew and approved of the will. That presumption can only be set aside by the clearest of evidence. That Dr�Gafoor was entirely an 'outsider' was strong evidence of the absence of fraud and 'clandestinity'. At most, the benefit to the person preparing the will is only a circumstance for some suspicion. Vague suspicion must not be freely indulged. 'Suspicion to invalidate a will must be that grave as to override all other evidence propounding the will.'

Every person is presumed sane until proved otherwise. The deceased was sane and must be presumed sane. The deceased conducted his life as a sane man and his acts were consistent with a composed mind. His testamentary capacity was certified by Dr Tan. 'The court should look at the procedural acts and conduct of the deceased; not the opinion of occasional witnesses.' Dr Tan supported the case on the testamentary capacity of the deceased. His five certificates could not be doubted. That the deceased possessed Dr Tan's certificates evinced a sound and logical mind and a sense of responsibility. The changes to the ensuing wills/codicils of the deceased were consistent with the change/s related to Dr Tan. The visits to Dr Tan showed that the deceased understood he was giving property to one or more objects of his regard and his concern. The deceased could recollect the claims of his children. He could recall his executors. He know whom he wanted as executors. He gave reasons for the changes of executors. He could recall a prior discussion. The provisions of the 1992 wills were corroborated by the matters related to the doctor on 24 July 1992 and 3 August 1992. The deceased, if not of a sound disposing mind, could not have had his conversations with Dr Tan and Dr Tan could not have known of the changes to the wills/codicils if the deceased had not related it to him. 'The deceased had a full grasp of his assets and legatees … The visit of 3 August 1992 was not orchestrated by the first to third defendants.' The last visit 27 January 1993 confirmed that the deceased remained of sound mind.

If there was intention to defraud, an independent witness — Dr Gafoor — would not have been a witness; an 'outsider' would not have been invited instead to witness the 1992 wills. It was not shown that the deceased in the ordinary affairs of life was under the control and or dominance of Cheng Poon, Richard or Howard. 'These are no facts to arouse any suspicion in this case.'

Parkinson's disease was not diagnosed. Dr Tan made it clear that one who suffers from Parkinson's disease is not necessarily incapable of making a will. 'The deceased recovered … from whatever he was suffering.' The follow-up visits (22 July 1992 and 27 July 1992) showed that the deceased was clear and lucid and was in control of his faculties. The doctors did not support the case that the deceased did not have a sound disposing mind. The evidence is preponderantly in support of a sound disposing mind.

Medical evidence on the testamentary capacity of the deceased cannot be expected to be in absolute terms; the deceased was an elderly man who had suffered a stroke. The doctors' evidence, on actual examination and observation, outweighed all hypothetical comments. Greater weight must be given to observed facts than to opinions based on facts observed by others.

Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat, seeking to enforce the 24 July 1992 deeds, admitted to the sound mind of the deceased. It was not reasonably explained why the deceased after January 1992 was not of sound mind. There was no case of an unstable mind at any given period of time. There was no sufficient evidence that the deceased was not of a sound disposing mind.

Whatever evidence adduced did not support a case of fraud in the making of the 1992 wills. The 1990 wills/codicil were not to rectify fraud in the making of the 1989 deed. 'If there was fraud, why (would) Poon be given greater powers in the 1990 codicil. Fraud was not made out.'

The deceased could not have been deceived into signing a (1989) deed. The deceased knew he had signed a (1989) deed as he implemented the 1989 deed — the transfer of assets to the trustees named in the 1989 deed — within a week of its execution. A will was made on 1 February 1989; it was unlikely that the deceased could have intended another will in that same year. Surely, the deceased intended the 1989 deed.

The provisions of the 1989 deed might have angered the deceased. But that anger, nonetheless, was not evidence that Cheng Poon deceived the deceased. The provisions of the 1989 deed should not be automatically attributed to Cheng Poon's fraud. The deceased could have been angry because Cheng Poon was getting an unfair share and not because Cheng Poon had deceived him.

The allegation that Cheng Poon attempted to secure for himself, by the 1989 deed, all the properties of the deceased was unfounded. To do that, Cheng Poon would have to secure the transfer of the properties not listed in the 1989 deed. And that would not be easy, as the deceased would not even transfer the five properties listed in the 1989 deed.

Both Say Bee and Beng Tatt did not testify that they summoned the attesting witnesses on Cheng Poon or Bok Eng's instructions. On 3 August 1992, the deceased informed the doctor of his wish to make a fresh will. All that supported that the 1992 wills were made voluntarily.

The deceased, who was of sound mind, could not have been forced into signing the 1992 wills. Say Bee testified that the deceased told him in the morning of 3 August 1992 that he would be going to the Penang Hill house. Therefore, deceased was able to give instructions on 3 August 1992. Dr Gafoor testified that the deceased greeted him. Dr Gafoor confirmed the deceased read the 1992 wills. That was clear evidence of the sound mind of the deceased. Dr Gafoor did not testify that the deceased on 3 August 1992 appeared not to be of sound mind. The 1992 and 1990 wills were not that different to have induced fraud.

Sound mind is the basis upon which all is to be judged. Once that issue is determined, truthful witnesses could be separated from the untruthful witnesses. Beng Tatt testified that the deceased asked him to stay. Dr Gafoor also said that he heard the deceased asking Beng Tatt to stay. Say Bee said the deceased asked him to go to the Penang Hill bungalow. All those acts were consistent with a sound mind. There was overwhelming evidence of a sound mind while there was no evidence to the contrary.

The legal requirements on the 1992 wills were met. The deceased signed the 1992 will in the presence of two witnesses. Section 5 did not require the papers constituting the 1992 wills to be bound. On 3 August 1992, there were valid sets of wills.
If the deceased was of sound mind, it was not probable that Beng Tatt was truthful on Howard taking the safe keys and Howard opening the safe.

Admittedly, Lim Cheng Chuan who denied the existence of a second 1992 Thai will was forced to admit that his signature was on the second 1992 Thai will. But Lim Cheng Chuan explained why there were two Thai wills — there was a mistake in the date, on the cover and on the end page. 'It was a plausible explanation.' Lim Cheng Chuan is a solicitor. It might have been awkward for him to readily admit that the second 1992 Thai will was signed without the joint presence of the witnesses. 'That would be the explanation that I would put.'

Lim Cheng Chuan denied D11 and 2D. He denied because he was embarrassed. I concede, with regard to D2D, that the evidence was that 2D was sent to Dr Gafoor for signature but not in the presence of the deceased and Lim Cheng Chuan. D2A — D2C remained intact. It suffered not the same defect. I concede 2D does not meet the requirement of s 5.

Dr Gafoor was not reliable on the events of 3 August 1992 — he said that Richard was present but Richard proved he was in Kuala Lumpur. The second 1992 Thai, not the 1992 wills, was sent to Dr Gafoor for signature. Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard could not prove by direct evidence that the 1992 wills were not substituted; however, taking all the circumstances into account, the court should not conclude that the 1992 wills were substituted.

In content, the second 1992 Thai will was not different from the first 1992 Thai will. There was no evidence that whatever document was signed by the deceased after 3 August 1992 was forced out of the deceased. In September 1992, when loose sheets were said to have been signed, Howard was not in the country. The evidence did not point to Richard or Cheng Poon as the makers of the second 1992 Thai will. There was no evidence that the deceased was made to sign any document after 3 August 1992. There was no evidence that the 1992 wills had been tampered. There was nothing wrong in Howard preparing the 1992 wills. It was probable that the deceased would ask Howard, his favourite grandson, to prepare his wills.

There need not be a finding that the pages of the 1992 wills were substituted. If the deceased was of sound mind and in control, then the events on 1 August 1992 as related by Beng Tatt must be false, as the deceased would not have arranged for the execution of (the 1992) wills fraudulently prepared and without his approval. 'In other words, he did instruct the preparation of the 1992 wills. Beng Tatt's account of the safe keys could not be true. Beng Tatt's evidence must be received with caution.'

If Lim Cheng Chuan's version is accepted, loose sheets were not signed after 3 August 1992, the evidence was entirely in favour of the execution of the 1992 wills, even if Dr Gafoor could not identify the particular pages of the wills.

Further documents were sent to Dr Gafoor for signature. Lim Cheng Chuan admitted that he sent the second 1992 Thai will to Dr Gafoor for signature. On those two admitted facts, the plaintiff built their case.

Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard had to prove on a balance of probabilities that the deceased executed the 1992 wills. The court need not infer that the 1992 wills were substituted, as Lim Cheng Chuan explained that he sent the second 1992 Thai will to Dr Gafoor and that the second 1992 Thai will was the document signed after 3 August 1992.

There was some evidence, if accepted, that may cast a doubt sufficient for the court to find that the 1992 wills had not been proved. However, it does not follow, just because the 1992 wills were not proved, that fraud was proved. Fraud must be proved beyond a reasonable doubt and not by default. Lim Cheng Chuan's evidence was beyond the first to third defendant's control. He was a witness of the court and not of the party who summoned him. As inexcusable as Lim Cheng Chuan's conduct might have been, the first to third defendants should not be made to suffer on his account. The 1992 wills were not orchestrated and the events after 3 August 1992 could not be approached with suspicion. Beng Tatt's version of the events on 1 August 1992 was a made-up story.

Since the wills 1992 was regularly executed, the events after 3 August 1992 should not arouse suspicion. Lim Cheng Chuan was the deceased's solicitor. He might have been hiding the fact that he was party to the second 1992 Thai will. He might have been foolish to have disavowed the second 1992 Thai will. He was trying to protect his reputation. He was not protecting the first to third defendants. Other than Lim Cheng Chuan's evidence and the fact that Lim Cheng Chuan reversed his stand on the second 1992 Thai will, there was no other evidence to view the 1992 wills with suspicion. The 1992 wills were sent to Dr Gafoor for his rubber stamp and not signature. The second 1992 Thai will was sent to Dr�Gafoor for his rubber stamp and signature. Dr Gafoor was not lying but his recall of events was weak. The second 1992 Thai will was executed after 3 August 1992 although dated 3 August 1992. That the provisions of the first and second 1992 Thai wills were identical supported Lim Cheng Chuan's explanation. The second 1992 Thai will was not for interpolation. It was only to tidy up.

On the 'inter vivos payments and gifts', Mr Koh submitted that a transaction, where a father purchases property or transfers property to his child, does not create a resulting trust; it is an advancement or gift to the child. The burden is on the other party to rebut the presumption of advancement or gift. The presumption is not rebutted even though the grantor retains the possession and benefits of the gift during his lifetime. A donor's acts and declaration subsequent to the transaction are not admissible in favour of the donor against the donee. The Teluk Bahang land was a gift — for love and affection. That presumption had not been rebutted. The deceased could have inserted in the transfer form that Cheng Poon was holding on trust. 'Undue influence' is to prevent victimisation but not to save donors from folly. The plaintiffs must prove that Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard were in an actual position to dominate. In the case of a father and son, there is no presumption of undue influence. The fact that the donor is old or weak does not raise a presumption of fraud.

On date of death, the deceased had only RM14,000 cash. But that was the nett cash position — Richard testified that the deceased had more than RM250,000 ready cash (Citibank Deposit less Citibank Overdraft leaving RM134,000 and the RM140,000 withdrawn by Cheng Poon). Cheng Poon and Richard could not be accountable for the payments to Howard and Gim Chuan who are not parties in the recovery action. Richard did not receive any unusual amounts. All dispositions were gifts. Any circumstantial evidence must be consistent with undue influence. The burden of setting aside the gifts rest with the parties who alleged otherwise.

Notwithstanding a dominant position, it must be established that that person used his position to obtain an unfair advantage. Dominion and use of that domination must be proved. The relationship of father and son is not a relationship of active confidence. Without proof of actual undue influence or a relationship of active confidence, the plaintiffs must fail in the recovery action. Undue influence must be judged against the actual state of mind of the deceased. The conversations with the doctors disproved senility. The evidence on senility was inconsistent with the indisputable evidence. Reliance on the 24 July 1992 deed was inconsistent with senility. In June 1992, the deceased spoke to Nik Saghir. The deceased could not be senile. Say Bee testified that the deceased spoke to him in April 1992. In June/July 1992, Hamid advised the deceased not to redeem the Teluk Bahang land. The deceased said he had no monies to pay his sons. He asked Hamid to convey his message to Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat. In July 1992, Hamid was with the deceased in Kuala Lumpur. Hamid did not say that the deceased was senile. In November 1992, the deceased signed the proposed development plans. All that refuted senility.

After the death of his wife, the deceased was more liberal with money. The deceased was fair but he had a right to give unequally to his children. If the deceased was of a sound disposing mind, then the rationale for his acts need not be established. The law would not question his gifts, even though capricious. The deceased might have been less than logical, but he was not unsound. There was no evidence, actual or presumed, of any undue influence in any of the gifts. If the deceased was not senile on 3�August 1992, the transfer of the Teluk Bahang land was good. The reasons offered by the donees for the gifts were not relevant. The reasons could be an excuse to ask for the money. The excuse might have been disbelieved but the deceased made the gifts nonetheless.

A gift per se is no ground to infer undue influence. The case was one of senility and not undue influence. The gift must be so large or the transaction so improvident as not to be reasonably accounted for on the ground of friendship, relationship or ordinary motives. There was no evidence of an improvident or large gift. There must be evidence of a relationship under which the deceased generally repose trust and confidence in the first to third defendants. There was no real evidence and the plaintiffs resorted to wild allegations. There being no case of fraud, senility or undue influence, Cheng Poon needed not answer to the accusations. The plaintiffs reported to the police that the deceased was senile from January 1992. However, they changed their mind and further alleged fraud and undue influence. Their change of mind was against the bona fides of their cause. The charge of undue influence and fraud was trumped up.

On the failure of Cheng Poon to give his version, Mr Koh tendered the case of Mcqueen v Great Western Railway Co
(1875) QBD 569
. He said that an adverse inference should not be drawn against Cheng Poon for not testifying as that inference would be against the evidence in general.
Supplementing Mr Koh's submission, Mr Foo submitted on: (i) fraud and the execution of the 1992 wills, (ii) the credibility of Howard, and, (iii) the US estate.
On fraud, he said, there were three periods to be considered: (a) 1989, (b) 1 August 1992 to 3 August 92, (c) 3 August 1992 to 14 September 1992.

There was no truth that Cheng Poon forged the 1989 deed. The deceased instructed the 1989 deed. It was not proved that Cheng Poon instructed its preparation. The deceased insisted on cl 5 and the deceased had knowledge of Cheng Poon's request for sole use. There was no proof of the true intent of the 1989 deed or the 'wrong information' given by Cheng Poon. The deceased being acquainted with wills knew that the 1989 deed was a trust deed. The deceased's properties were more than the five listed in the 1989 deed; therefore, by the 1989 deed, Cheng Poon could not 'swallow' the whole estate. There was nothing wrong in Cheng Poon's request for sole use. Each son desired their father's property. 'It was up to the father.'

To prove fraud in the making of the 1989 deed, the plaintiffs relied on 'circumstantial' facts. It must be asked if those 'circumstantial facts', if proved, were sufficient evidential material to infer fraud. It was a vile attempt to relate the 1990 codicil to the 1989 deed. If Cheng Poon cheated, why was Cheng Poon not punished but appointed the governing trustee, Mr Foo asked. 'There was nothing wrong with the 1989 deed, there should not be any suspicion of wrongdoing by Cheng Poon.' The deceased could have consulted Nik Saghir, Lim and Hamid because he was not clear as on the effect of cl 5.

Cheng Bok testified that he discussed the 1989 deed in Singapore. Yet Cheng Bok testified that he was not aware of the 1989 deed until after the death of his father. On the 1990 codicil, there were discrepancies between the evidence of Hamid and Nik Saghir. The plaintiffs willfully presented a false case. Mr Foo further commented that the plaintiffs' stand on Lim was ambivalent; cast as a villain in the 1992 wills, Lim was allegedly deceived in the 1989 deed.

'The difficulty with the 1992 wills is which wills were executed.' There was no fraud in the preparation of the 1992 wills. Beng Tatt's evidence that he had the sole key to the safe was incredible. If the deceased was not senile, then Beng Tatt's testimony that the deceased was senile would be totally discredited.

Howard testified that the deceased gave him amended copies of the 1990 wills. Beng Tatt's version was that Howard took the 1990 wills from the safe. However, the evidence showed the desire of the deceased to change his wills. To change his wills, deceased must have the 1990 wills; there was no need for Howard to force open the safe. Howard's version that the deceased handed him the amended 1990 wills was consistent with the desire of the deceased to change his wills.

Howard testified that he prepared the 1992 wills on 2 August 1992 — a Sunday. Beng Tatt testified, most conveniently, that he saw Patricia Lim on 3 August 1992 — a Monday — as Beng Tatt would not have witnessed what he said he saw on a Sunday. Patricia Lim should have been called by the plaintiffs. 'If there was fraud in the preparation of the 1992 wills, why would the 1990 wills be left so easily for Cheng Bok to retrieve from the deceased's room?' 'If the deceased was not senile, then everything that occurred on 3 August 1992 occurred as the deceased wanted it so.

On 3 August 1992, the deceased was not senile; he would have rejected the 1992 wills if they were 'Howard's wills' and not his wills. On the contrary, executing the 1992 wills, the deceased showed that he knew and approved of the 1992 wills.

Hamid's testimony that he handed a copy of the 1990 wills to Pykett Avenue could not be believed. It was an after thought to support the allegation of fraud. If Cheng Poon, Richard or Howard had forced their intention on the deceased, they would have been exposed to Dr Tan and Dr Gafoor. What took place on 3 August 1992 showed that the deceased approved of the events of 1 August 1992 to 3 August 1992. 'Otherwise, could not have the conclusion — the 1992 wills.'

On 3 August 1992, the deceased signed the 1992 wills in the presence of two witnesses. Lim's testimony, though faulted on the second 1992 Thai will, should not be rejected out of hand. The second 1992 Thai will did not affect the integrity of the 1992 wills. Dr Gafoor might have been an honest witness, but his recollection was defective and his evidence was influenced perhaps unwittingly by the allegation of fraud. Dr Gafoor admitted he was not curious. Therefore, he was not an observant witness — he was wrong on Richard and he did not see Howard.
The senility of the deceased was a false case. Beng Tatt lied that the deceased was senile. His evidence must be scrutinised for its consistency with the senility of the deceased.

Mr Foo conceded, 'we have difficulty with Lim Cheng Chuan, whether he was a credible witness'. The fact that both witnesses to the 1992 wills were not reliable should not affect the validity of the 1992 wills if other evidence pointed to the 1992 wills as the last will of the deceased.
On Howard's credibility, Mr Foo submitted that his credibility should be evaluated after a consideration of all evidence. 'Poor demeanour should detract from the truth of the evidence,' he said.

On the US estate, Howard appointed Douglas Newman as his attorney to conduct the affairs of the estate in Arizona. Le Beau was the attorney at law for Howard as trustee. Howard presented the petition to preserve the US assets — see DB1(F)(30). Newman was not Howard's alter ego — 'Newman was Howard's nothing'. Newman was the Special Administrator of the US estate. Even without Howard's consent, the US courts could appoint Newman. Newman was not acting under Howard's directions. Newman was interested in the estate as a creditor — for fees due to him from the estate.

On the allegation that Howard sold the US assets to lay his hands on the money, the accounts — D37 — answered it comprehensively. The sale of the Benson land was sanctioned by the US courts. Howard did evade the issue of the RM225,000. Even though Howard might have been evasive, his evidence was borne out by other evidence. Howard denied that he wanted to ensure his position as a trustee. His denial was consistent with the desire of the deceased to appoint Howard as a trustee. Howard left on 5 August 1997. He did not know of the second Thai will. Who prepared the second 1992 Thai wills is still a mystery. It would appear that the deceased or Lim prepared the second Thai will. Either way, it would not affect the first to third defendants. 'Howard's demeanor might not be good but he was telling the truth.'

Cheng Poon did not answer his accusers as their accusations were not proved. There was no need for Cheng Poon to answer to the 'gifts, transfers and other payments'. The deceased was winding up his earthly affairs.
Mr Yeoh's submission, with regard to the 1990 wills (his submission on the 1992 wills could be gathered from the transcript of the proceedings), may be summarised as follows:

Both the 1990 and 1992 wills were not valid wills. There was no burden on Cheng Hum or Grace to prove that the wills (1990 or 1992) were invalid. Where unsoundness of mind is alleged, the burden of proof rests upon those who set up the will. The burden of proving undue influence or fraud is on the party who alleges it.

The deceased was not of good health or memory and had a poor understanding of his wills when he executed the 1990 wills. In 1990, the deceased, who was 85, suffering from poor health, memory loss and senile dementia aggravated by the loss of his wife, could not have had the mental capacity to execute the 1990 wills. The deceased's health had never been good. He suffered from assorted ailments. He was on heavy medication. In July 1992, the deceased suffered a series of seizures stemming from a mild stroke. His medical condition reflected his advanced age and the degenerative process. His mental state was as bad as his bodily state.

As early as October 1987, the deceased was under Dr Tan's psychiatric care. There were periods in 1987 when the deceased was disorientated and in a confused state. According to Dr Tan, for a year prior to 1987, the deceased had been taking too much medication. Dr Francis Tan explained the effect of prolonged use of sedatives. The conclusion to be drawn is that prolonged use of sleeping pills would give rise to anxiety, confusion, hallucinations, memory loss and mental, given the age of the deceased. The lacuna infarct, progressive intellectual loss, age and the medication over the years must have reduced the mental capacity of the deceased to the extent that the 1990 wills were not wills of the deceased.

Whether the deceased had the mental capacity must be answered. The burden on the plaintiffs to prove that the deceased had the capacity to make the 1990 wills had not been discharged. The deceased and his wife were inseparable. Her passing and the effect on the mental capacity of the deceased could not be dismissed.

Dr Tan's certificates did not settle the controversy on the testamentary capacity of the deceased when he executed the 1990 wills. Those certificates, in the absence of supporting clinical findings, were bare certificates. Dr�Tan did not display the skill of an ordinary competent psychiatrist. The alleged conversations between the deceased and Dr Tan must be doubted. Interested parties accompanied the deceased on each of those visits and conveyed to the doctor the information attributed to the deceased and or to prompt the deceased. 'Not one of those five visits were serious sessions — more social chit-chat. Those visits were not professional visits.'

Dr Tan said that the deceased wanted a penile prosthesis. How could the deceased, a disciplined no-nonsense person who cared for his image, have asked for a penile prosthesis? If he did, then he was out of his mind. The doctor testified that the deceased, on 24 October 1990, expressed his unhappiness over Cheng Liat. Cheng Liat testified that Cheng Poon planted it into the deceased's mind. Therefore, Cheng Poon could have conveyed the information recorded by Dr Tan on 24 October 1990. On 24�July 1992, the deceased was himself assailed with all sorts of ailments and could not have discussed the new drug, Laponex. Cheng Poon gave the consent for Laponex to be administered to Cheng Been and Cheng Poon would have had those conversations with the doctor. The following minutes were found in the clinical notes for the visit on 24 October 1990: 'Patient's will in Penang (Malaysia) Thailand and USA will all be altered accordingly'. However, in October 1990, the deceased was yet not having separate wills for his overseas properties and could not have told the doctor of separate wills.

It must be asked if those certificates were orchestrated by those who would profit from those certificates and ensuing wills. Was this a case of making as many wills as possible and saving the best for last, as the situation demands? Those certificates could safely be disregarded — Dr�Tan admitted that the mental condition of the deceased could fluctuate even on the day of the certificate. Because of the poor examination and poor records, the court should not and could not rely on Dr Tan's certificates, and also as the doctor himself was non-committal — he said the deceased's mental condition out of his office could be unpredictable. Senile dementia could be seen from: (i) the deceased had no recollection of the 1989 deed, and, (ii) Cheng Hum was ordered out of the house because Cheng Hum refused to sell the balance Ayer Itam lands. The doctor's evidence must be scrutinised critically.
In the case of an old and infirmed testator, it is necessary for a doctor to be present and for that doctor to be satisfied as to the testamentary capacity of the testator.

Undue influence fitted in with the state of health of the deceased. Undue influence was constituted by: (i) Cheng Poon's influence, (ii)�Hamid Merican's influence, and (iii) first and second plaintiffs's influence. The deceased's trust in Hamid and Cheng Poon's influence were the principal reasons for the 1990 wills. The 1990 wills were procured by the importunity of Cheng Poon and Hamid. The role of Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat were limited to the meetings in Singapore. After the death of Ooi Geen Peen, the deceased felled prey to Cheng Poon's manipulations. Cheng Hum was the favourite son. Cheng Poon was given more because of his manipulations.

The influence of Hamid and Cheng Poon were complementary. Cheng Poon worked his way into a position of influence with his parents even before the death of Ooi Geen Peen. Cheng Poon was running Cheng Hum down. Cheng Poon postured himself as the better son and got to strengthen his influence over the deceased.

Cheng Poon's influence, as late as 1987, was kept at bay; the provisions of the 1987 will essentially reflected the provisions of the 1986 will. In the 1987 will, the deceased directed his trustees to ban Bok Eng from Pykett Avenue. However, that provision and the financial provisions for Cheng Hum and Grace were not found in the 1989 will. That was Cheng Poon's doing and influence. In the absence of Cheng Poon from the witness stand, all adverse inferences must be drawn against Cheng Poon.

Cheng Poon could get the deceased to sign the 1989 deed even without the deceased knowing the contents of the 1989 deed. Cheng Liat had to wait for Cheng Poon to be away before he could speak to the deceased about the 1989 deed. The deceased signed the 1989 deed without knowing the nature and effect of the 1989 deed. If indeed the deceased had instructed the 1989 deed, then how could he have been shocked by the provisions of the 1989 deed? Why would the deceased asked for a second opinion, and why would the deceased want to terminate a deed he instructed? If indeed the deceased instructed the 1989 deed, then it was inconsistent with his anger at Cheng Poon. Therefore, the deceased could not have instructed the 1989 deed. The deceased did not and could not have instructed Lim on any of the deeds/documents that Lim prepared. The 1989 deed was someone else's deed. If the 1989 deed was the deed of the deceased, then the deceased's memory in 1989 had deteriorated as he could not even remember his own deed made just about within the year before.

The two trips to Singapore in 1989 were not holiday trips. It was the stage for the three brothers to come to their agreement to share the estate. Since the deceased was not aware of his sons' arguments or quarrels, then those two trips to Singapore were not arranged by the deceased. Hamid initiated all meetings in Singapore. Hamid was a monetary opportunist. Otherwise why would Hamid give evidence partial to three sons. The trip to Nik Saghir's office was also planned by Hamid. It was a follow up to the trips to Singapore. The meeting at Nik Saghir's office was not to seek legal advise on the 1989 deed but to get the deceased to sign a will reflecting the agreement of the three sons reached in Singapore. Everything about the 1989 codicil was unclear. The state of mind of the deceased and his intention in March 1989 could not be known.

Cheng Poon could direct the deceased to force Cheng Hum to sell the Bukit Tengah lands. That was the extent of Cheng Poon's influence. Cheng Bok, Cheng Hum and Cheng Liat all agreed that Cheng Poon had a menacing influence over the deceased. Cheng Hum and Cheng Liat's ejection from Pykett was all due to Cheng Poon's doing.

'In 1989, if the deceased intended a will, did he get to do it or had events simply overtaken him. There was no will after all the meetings in Singapore and Kuala Lumpur. It would appear that the deceased was taken for a ride.' The will was signed in October 1990. 'Why was there that delay? Were the brothers waiting for the right moment to strike — to obtain a will in their favour?' 'The circumstances leading to the 1990 wills was a void. Unlike the 1990 codicil, the 1990 wills were born rather quietly. The 1990 wills was the product of an uneasy and unholy alliance that Hamid concluded.' The 1990 wills were procured by the importunity of Hamid, whether jointly or severally with Cheng Poon, Cheng Liat and Cheng Bok.

Given the suspicious circumstances, there must be strong proof of the intention to execute the 1990 wills. There was undue influence in the making of the 1990 wills. The deceased did not know nor approved of the 1990 wills. The plaintiffs failed to prove the mental capacity of the deceased, and if they did, then they failed to prove that the deceased knew and approved of the contents of the 1990 wills.
