The deceased could not know and could not have approved of the 1990 will: (1) Ghazi Ishak did not prepare the 1990 wills, 2) the deceased did not personally instruct Ghazi Ishak to prepare the 1990 wills, (3)�Ghazi Ishak did not explain the 1990 wills to the deceased, (4) the deceased did not question nor discuss the provisions of the 1990 wills, (5) Ghazi Ishak did not say whether the deceased was reading silently or loudly, and (6)�Ghazi Ishak assumed that the deceased must have read the 1990 wills.

Ghazi Ishak's testimony fell short of saying that the deceased understood the provisions of the 1990 wills. His impression was based on his previous dealings. Given the medical history of the deceased, mere reading is not enough. There was sufficient suspicious circumstances rebutting a presumption of knowledge of the contents of the will by mere execution. Why did Hamid testify that Ghazi Ishak read and explained the 1990 wills to the deceased when it was not true? Ghazi Ishak testified that he only saw the deceased on 24 October 1990, but Hamid said that the deceased gave his instruction to Ghazi at Ghazi's office prior to 24 October 1992. There were material differences in the testimony of Hamid and Ghazi Ishak with regard to the preparation of the 1990 wills.

The deceased who was careful and meticulous required all things to be properly done. The following should be asked: (1) what were the instructions given, if at all, to Hamid, (2) why was it necessary for the deceased to instruct the preparation of 1990 wills, some seven months after the execution of the 1990 codicil, (3) why did the deceased instruct a property broker and not a lawyer to prepare the 1990 wills, (4) why was the civil engineer who assisted in the preparation of the 1990 wills not called, (5) why would the deceased go through the trouble of getting medical certificates and then had his wills prepared by lay persons without the assistance of lawyers, and (6) why would the deceased, a careful and meticulous man, had no questions to ask Ghazi Ishak but proceeded meekly to execute his 1990 wills.

The 1990 wills were made in pursuance of the three sons' agreement in Singapore, an agreement without the knowledge or consent of the deceased. Since the deceased was not aware of the three sons' agreement, at which point of time was the deceased informed that the 1990 wills were in accord with the three sons' agreement in Singapore? Ghazi Ishak's testimony that he did not read, prepared, discussed nor explained the 1990 wills to the deceased showed that the deceased did and could not have known of the provisions of the 1990 wills. No evidence was led to show that the deceased intended the 1990 wills. Evidence must be led that the deceased knew he was executing three wills. There could not be any presumption that the deceased knew he was signing three wills merely because his signature appeared on three wills.

Inquiries touching the validity of a testamentary disposition are matters touching the conscience of the court. In the absence of evidence of the intention of the deceased, and in the light of the three sons agreement in Singapore, it would appear that the 1990 wills were the wills of the three sons.

There were circumstances arousing suspicion: (i) the 1990 wills reflected the three sons' agreement, (ii) 24 October 1990, Cheng Poon was with the deceased at Dr Tan's clinic, and (iii) clinical notes that the deceased's wills in Penang, Thailand and USA will be amended accordingly.

Although Hamid was not a beneficiary under the 1990 wills, the onus was on him to substantiate the truth and honesty of the transaction, bearing in mind that he was in Singapore when the brothers reached their agreement and he was also instrumental in framing the 1990 wills. The three 1990 wills was a radical departure from the previous practice of only one will. This departure must be examined.

Allegedly, Cheng Hum was bypassed because Cheng Hum had inherited properties. The deceased could not have said so. The deceased enjoyed a close relationship with Cheng Hum until the dispute in 1990. The deceased could not have provided a paltry RM20,000 to Cheng Hum. It was Hamid's doing in pursuance of the agreement between the three sons. Why would Hamid prepare the 1990 wills? There must be something for him. Hamid had been able to move with the tide, and always harvested where it was bountiful.

Hamid gave a loan of RM500,000 for the purchase of a Rolls Royce. That evidence was fabricated. Then he said he was not personally aware if his loan of RM500,000 was used to purchase the Rolls Royce. Cheng Poon paid the RM512,000 cheque to Hamid, and Hamid received that cheque in their grand scheme to dissipate the monies of the deceased. Hamid was in the thick of things concerning the three sons. Hamid must be cautiously received. His credibility is in doubt. He was a shark as much as the first to third defendants.

The deceased could not have told Cheng Bok of the 1990 wills. Everything said in court about the 1990 wills being the wills of the deceased could not have happened. Cheng Liat denied that Cheng Poon and Hamid influenced the deceased in signing the 1990 wills. That denial was baseless — the agreement in Singapore and the meetings at Nik Saghir's office and at E & O Hotel. Cheng Poon must have known of the 1990 wills — Cheng Poon was at the clinic on 24 October 1990. The denial was inconsistent with the known facts and also inconsistent with his allegation that Cheng Poon and his sons were instrumental in procuring the 1989 deed and the 1992 wills.

Cheng Hum as first born held the place of pride in the family. He was deserving of a rightful share of his father's properties. Yet under the 1990 wills, Cheng Hum got less than his nephews and nieces. He got nothing near that of his lessers. Cheng Hum displayed no malice to his brothers. There was only truth in his evidence, recounting his entanglements with the deceased and over the sale of his share of the Ayer Itam land and the Bukit Tengah land, no doubt instigated by Cheng Poon. Things fall apart when the centre — Ooi Geen Peen — could not hold. The deceased fell victim to his children. When things were falling apart, the only son who seemed to be riding the crest was Cheng Poon.

None of the 1986, 1987, 1989 wills designated a governing trustee. The 1990 wills designated Cheng Poon as governing trustee. It showed that Cheng Poon's influence had matured. In the 1990 Thai will, Cheng Poon got an extra 10% for being faithful and filial. Why was Cheng Poon given that extra 10% must be asked. Why was Cheng Poon described as faithful and designated governing trustee must also be asked and explained. Cheng Liat testified that he called Cheng Poon a wicked son. Yet within a year, the deceased called Cheng Poon a faithful son. Cheng Poon inserted the provisions into the 1990 wills.

The fact that Cheng Liat and Cheng Bok profited equally from Cheng Poon's fraud documents did not detract from the fraud of Cheng Poon. Cheng Poon was found out on the 1989 deed. He had to tread cautiously. He was therefore even handed to Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat. But Cheng Poon had his eye on the deceased's bounty. The three sons discarded Cheng Hum but on the evidence the deceased could not have done so.

Howard said the deceased did not want the 1990 will (see 420N). On the basis that the 1990 will had not complied with the formal requirements, then the deceased would have no wills. The deceased's declaration was a sufficient revocation of the 1990 wills.

With or without the collaboration of the first and second plaintiff, the first defendant had so prejudiced the mind of the deceased against Cheng Hum, that Cheng Hum who had by any other account was a natural object of the deceased's bounty or affection, was excluded.

It was the fraud of the first defendant that forced out the fourth defendant from the house and from intercourse with his father. It is the fraud of the first and second plaintiffs as well with Hamid's assistance to realise for themselves an equal distribution of the deceased's property in pursuance of their agreement in Singapore to the exclusion of Cheng Hum. Cheng Poon had remained silent. He was the central player and all allegations against him remained unrebutted. These allegations are serious allegations, and yet they remained unanswered. They cannot better their evidence by not calling evidence. That would be a dangerous precedent for those with unclean hands.
The court must find intestacy, if it finds that the 1990 and 1992 had not been proved.

text.emph: Mr Khoo Boo Lai and other counsel

p.text: Mr Khoo delivered the main submission for all the plaintiffs; his submission as well as that of other counsel and the respective replies could be garnered from the transcript of the proceedings.

emph.emph: The peadings and the evidence, and hearsay

p.text:
Pleadings serve to give fair notice of the case which has to be met, so an opponent would not be taken by surprise [ Spedding v Fitzpatrick
(1888) 38 Ch D 414
], and to define the issues on which the court will have to adjudicate in order to determine the matters in dispute between the parties (36 Halsbury's Laws of England (4th Ed) para 4). Matters which if not expressly stated might take the opposite party by surprise or would raise issues of fact not arising out of the preceding pleadings must be specifically pleaded [
O 10
r 8(1)
of the Rules of High Court 1980]. No evidence of such matters can, as a rule, be given at the trial if they were not expressly pleaded (English Supreme Court Practice 1995 para 18/8/2), for 'to condemn a party on a ground of which no fair notice has been given may be as great a denial of justice as to condemn him on a ground on which his evidence has been improperly excluded [ Esso Petroleum Co Ltd v Southport Corp
[1955] 3 All ER 864 at p 869
, per Lord Normand].

'[A] case must be decided on issues raised by the pleadings which bind the parties. If other issues are desired to be raised or come to light during the trial they must be pleaded by way of amendment' (per Buttrose J in Kiaw Aik Hang Co Ltd v Tan Tien Choy
[1964] MLJ 99 at p 101
). If a case was decided on an issue not raised in the pleadings,, 'the judgment must be set aside': The Chartered Bank v Yong Chan
[1974] 1 MLJ 157 at p 159
[see also Anjalai Ammal & Anor v Abdul Kareem
[1969] 1 MLJ 22
]. A party who at the trial radically departs from his case as pleaded is likely to fail: Waghorn v George Wimpey & Co Ltd
[1970] 1 All ER 474
. And so in Amos William Dawe v Development & Commercial Bank (Ltd) Bhd
[1981] 1 MLJ 230
, where the appellant had not sought to amend his defence, the Federal Court held that the appellant's affidavit which raised issues of fact not averred to in the pleadings but which also flatly contradicted his own pleadings could not be considered.

There was also evidence — out of court statements — that could not be relied on testimonially as proof of the facts asserted. Where oral evidence is adduced,
s 60(1)
of the Evidence Act 1950, the codification of the common law hearsay rule, requires that it shall be direct:
if it refers to a fact which could be seen, it must be the evidence of a witness who says he saw that fact;
if it refers to a fact which could be heard, it must be the evidence of a witness who says he heard that fact;
if it refers to a fact which could be perceived by any other sense or in any other manner, it must be the evidence of a witness who says he perceived that fact by that sense or in that manner;
if it refers to an opinion or to the grounds on which the opinion is held, it must be the evidence of the person who holds the opinion on those grounds.

Still, '[e]vidence of a statement made to a witness by a person who is not himself called as a witness may or may not be hearsay. It is hearsay and inadmissible when the object of the evidence is to establish the truth of what is contained in the statement. It is not hearsay and is admissible when it is proposed to establish by the evidence, not the truth of the statement but the fact that it was made': Subramaniam v Public Prosecutor
[1956] 1 WLR 965 at p 970
. '… A question of hearsay only arises when the words spoken are relied on "testimonially", ie as establishing some fact narrated by the words': Leith McDonald Ratten v The Queen
[1972] AC 378
, per Lord Wilberforce at p 387. Why a statement is introduced is the deciding factor. It is hearsay if it is proposed to admit an out-of-court assertion as truth of the facts but not when it is to prove the fact that the statement was made. Indeed, illustrations (b) and (c) on the meaning of 'fact' (see s 3 of the Evidence Act) designate both spoken words and that heard as facts, and a witness testifying on spoken words (a fact) he heard, would be giving direct evidence of the words spoken although not of the facts asserted.

emph.emph: Presumption arising from a party not going into the witness box

p.text: Cheng Bok, Cheng Liat and Cheng Hum leveled distinct charges against Cheng Poon from the witness-box and led evidence in support. They called witnesses who testified on numerous facts in dispute (paraphrased hereinbefore) which Cheng Poon had knowledge of the whole circumstances to give evidence to contradict or to deny. But Cheng Poon did not give evidence nor subject himself to cross-examination, although he heard, since he was in court throughout the trial (almost), all that was said or made out against him.

That maxim has been codified;
s 114(g)
of the Evidence Act 1950 provides that the court may presume 'that evidence which could be and is not produced would if produced be unfavourable to the person who withholds it'. An adverse inference may be drawn if reason for the absence of important material witnesses is not given [ Guthrie Sdn Bhd v Trans-Malaysian Leasing Corp Bhd
[1991] 1 MLJ 33
]. However, a presumption under s 114 is not mandatory but discretionary [ Synn Lee & Co Ltd v Bank of China
[1962] MLJ 395
]. 'An adverse inference can only be drawn if there is withholding or suppression of material facts and not merely on account of failure to obtain evidence' [ Munusamy v PP
[1987] 1 MLJ 492
, per Mohd Azmi SCJ]. But even then, '(a) presumption may be adopted if consistent with the proved facts' [ CEC v Comptroller of Income Tax
[1971] 2 MLJ 43
, per Winslow J]. His Lordship explained (at p 58):

In the case under reference [ Ramoo v Gan Soo Swee & Anor
[1971] 1 MLJ 235
(PC)], two police officers saw the lights changing quickly. It was accordingly incumbent upon the defendant taxi driver to deny this state of affairs. He did not give this evidence and accordingly there was no denial. The presumption was accordingly drawn because it was consistent with the proved facts. Now had the plaintiff given no evidence that the lights were green as the taxi approached the junction, and had the police officers not given any evidence as to the changing lights, it would seem that the failure of the defendant to give evidence would have justified no such presumption because the evidence on this point would have been nil on both sides.

This is very far from being the case in the current appeal before me in the sense that a number of witnesses have in fact given evidence that the properties were owned by the two sons. If it was the comptroller's contention that the properties were not in fact owned by the two sons, he should have led some evidence as to this so as to create a conflict of evidence or to rebut the appellant's case. The clear documentary evidence coupled with the evidence of the solicitors concerned — matters which the board never mentioned once in the course of its lengthy judgment — makes it clear that the properties were owned by the two sons. The appellant never owned the properties at all.

With regard to the presumption arising from a party not going into the witness box and the presumption arising from not calling witnesses acquainted with facts and keeping the adversary out of possession of evidence, Sarkar on Evidence (4th Ed) pp 1547-1548 provides the following exposition on s 114(g) of the Indian Evidence Act, which is in pari materia with the Malaysian provision:

Presumptions are necessarily made against parties who having a knowledge of the facts in dispute will not subject themselves to examination, when a prima facie case is made against them, and when by their own evidence, they might have answered it [ Nawab Syed v Amanee
19 WR 149
PC at pp 150-151 … Under such circumstances, it is impossible to overlook the significance attaching to the refusal of the respondents and their son Jot Singh to enter the witness-box. It raises a presumption against them [ Durga v Mathura
15 CWN 717, 721-722; 10 IC 963 PC]

It is the bounden duty of a party personally knowing the whole circumstances to give evidence and to submit to cross-examination. Non-appearance as a witness would be the strongest possible circumstance to discredit the truth of his case [ Gurbakhsh v Gurdial
1927 AIR PC 230
; 32 CWN 119]. (In this case, the question was whether a woman had given birth to a posthumous son to inherit her husband's property. She avoided a challenge to undergo medical examination on her husband's death to find out advanced pregnancy and disappeared into a foreign State whence she emerged after a long time with a male child. She was present in court during the progress of the suit but did not go to the witness box). A prima facie case is made out when the plaintiff makes a distinct charge against the defendant from the witness-box and leads evidence in support. The fact that the defendant does not come himself nor calls any witness to contradict the evidence shows that the facts alleged cannot be denied. What was prima facie against the defendant becomes conclusive by failure to deny [ Pranballav v Tulsibala
(1958) 713
; 63 CWN 258].

In the adversarial system of trials, a litigant has the absolute right to conduct his case as he sees fit. Nevertheless, for Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard, the failure of Cheng Poon to testify or offer himself for cross-examination, which was not a valuable contribution to their cause, would be a recurring theme when considering the evidence.

The following survey on the law relating to wills [and much was extracted from Chapter 13 of Williams, Mortimer and Sunnucks on Executors, Administrators and Probate ; Chapter 33 of Tristram and Coote's Probate Practice (28th Ed) and Vols 17 and 50 of the Halsbury's Laws of England (4th Ed)] should find room in this grounds.

A 'will' means 'a declaration intended to have legal effect of the intentions of a testator with respect to his property or other matters which he desires to be carried into effect after his death and includes a testament, a codicil and an appointment by will or by writing in the nature of a will in exercise of a power and also a disposition by will or testament of the guardianship, custody and tuition of any child' (
s 2
of the Wills Act 1959).

Other than privileged wills, the requisites for the formal validity of a will are: (i) it must be in writing, (ii) it must be signed 'by the testator or by some other person in his presence and by his direction, and, (iii) such signature shall be made or acknowledged by the testator as the signature to his will in the presence of two or more witnesses present at the same time, and such witnesses shall subscribe the will in the presence of the testator' (
s 5
of the Wills Act 1959).

The requisite for the substantial as distinct from the formal validity of a will is that the testator's mind must go with his testamentary act. It is necessary for the validity of a will that the testator should be of sound mind, memory and understanding — words which have consistently been held to mean sound disposing mind. It is essential that the testator should know and approve of its contents [ Hastilow v Stobie
(1865) LR 1
P & D 64; Guardhouse v Blackburn
(1866) LR 1
P & D 109]. Unless suspicion attaches to the document, the testator's execution is sufficient evidence of his knowledge and approval [ Guardhouse v Blackburn
]. Unless there is a question of fraud, the fact that a will has been read over to or by a capable testator, or the contents brought to his knowledge in some other way, is as a rule conclusive evidence that he knew and approved of the contents [ Guardhouse Blackburn ; Atter v Atkinson
(1869) LR 1
P & D 665 at p 670]. That latter presumption may be rebutted [ Garnett-Botfield v Garnett-Botfield
[1901] P 335
] but only by the clearest of evidence [ Gregson v Taylor & Ors
[1917] P 256
]. If knowledge and approval are clearly established at the time of giving instructions for a will, or drafting it, very little evidence of the position at the time of execution is required [ Re Wallace & Ors, Solicitor of the Duchy of Cornwall v Batten
[1952] 2 TLR 925
].

There are a number of ways in which a testator's mind may not go with his testamentary act. He may lack, or be deemed to lack testamentary capacity; he may not know and approve of the contents of the will; he may be deceived into making it by fraud or constrained to make it by force, threats or other forms of undue influence. Another person may forge a will and propound it as that of the deceased. Wherever any of the above matters are proved, the document purporting to be executed by the deceased has no validity and cannot be admitted to probate (Williams, Mortimer and Sunnucks on Executors, Administrators and Probate at p 158).

In Banks v Goodfellow
(1870) LR 5 QB 549
, Cockburn CJ said:

It is essential … that a testator shall understand the nature of his act and its effects; shall understand the extent of the property of which he is disposing; shall be able to comprehend and appreciate the claims to which he ought to give effect, and there shall with a view to the latter object, be no disorder of the mind that shall poison his affection, pervert his sense of right, or prevent the exercise of his natural faculties, that no insane delusion shall influence his will in disposing of his property and bring about a disposal of it which, if his mind had been sound, would not have been made.

'The law does not call for a perfectly balanced mind, nor is a will to be pronounced against merely because the testator was moved by capricious, frivolous or even bad motives. A testator may disinherit his children to gratify his spite or benefit charity to gratify his pride but the court must nevertheless uphold his will' (Mortimer, Williams and Sunnuck at p 159).

'In broad terms it may be said that there are two grounds on which a person may be held to lack testamentary capacity: (i) that his mind has never developed sufficiently; and (ii) that his mind has become impaired, temporarily or permanently … There are two groups of causes of mental impairment. (1) Organic (physical) causes which impair the operation of the brain, (2) Functional disorders, ie mental illness without established physical causes … faculties principally affected by organic causes are consciousness, memory, attention, concentration, calculation and the ability to appreciate the significance of events and recall them … functional disorders refer to morbid changes in mood or of thinking … The most common causes of testamentary incapacity are; (i) physical injury, (ii)�physical illness, (iii) abuse of alcohol or drugs, (iv) dementia, and, (v)�functional mental illness, eg Schizophrenia' (Mortimer, Williams and Sunnuck at pp 161 to 166).
Halsbury's Laws of England (4th Ed) Vol 17 para 898 thus enunciated a sound disposing mind:

In order to be of sound disposing mind, a testator must not only be able to understand that he is by his will giving his property to one or more objects of his regard, but he must also have capacity to comprehend and to recollect the extent of his property and the nature of the claims of others whom by his will he is excluding from participation in that property … It is essential that no disorder of the mind should poison his affections, pervert his sense of right or prevent the exercise of his natural faculties, that no delusion should influence his will in disposing of his property and bring about a disposal of it which, if the mind had been sound, would not have been made.

The degree of capacity which must be retained by the old was discussed in Den v Vancleve
2 Southard at p 660:

By the terms 'a sound disposing mind and memory', it has not been understood that the testator must possess these qualities of mind in the highest degree; otherwise, very few would make testaments at all; neither has it been understood that he must possess them in as great a degree as he may have formerly done, for even this would disable most men in the decline of life; the mind may be in some degree debilitated, the memory may have become in some degree enfeebled, and yet there may be enough left clearly to discern and discreetly to judge, of all things and all those circumstances which enter into the nature of rational, fair, and just testament. But if they have so far failed as that these cannot be discerned and judged of, then he cannot be said to be of sound disposing mind and memory.
The question to be determined in probate cases is seldom what form of mental illness afflicts the testator, but whether its degree is such as to remove testamentary capacity.

In Mudway v Croft
(1843) 3 Curt 671 at p 676
, Sir HJ Fust said:

… it has frequently been attempted to furnish some general rules which might serve as guides to court of law in the investigation and decision of cases of (alleged unsoundness of mind) but all endeavours to do so have failed … It is absolutely and essentially necessary to look to the peculiar circumstances of each individual case; and to judge from the whole character of the person whose mental capacity is the subject of enquiry, what was the state and condition of mind of that individual; not only with respect to the immediate times at which a will is executed, but at the intermediate stages of his life.

Those propounding the will must satisfy the court that the testator was of sound disposing mind [per Lord Brougham in Waring v Waring
(1848) 6 Moo PCC 341
; see also Udham Singh v Indar Kaur
[1971] 2 MLJ 263
; Dr�Shanmuganathan v Periasamy s/o Sithambaram Pillai
[1997] 3 MLJ 61
]. Sanity is presumed until the contrary is shown: Burrows v Burrows
(1827) 1 Hag Ecc 109
. Where the will is rational on the face of it and is shown to be duly executed and no other evidence is offered, the court will pronounce for it presuming that the testator was mentally competent [ Symes v Green
(1859) 1 Sw & Tr 401
; Sutton v Sadler
(1857) 3 CBNS 87 at p 98
]. Testator is entitled to be capricious or improvident [ Bird v Luckie
(1850) 8 Hare 301 at p 306
] and slight evidence of mental incapacity will not disturb the presumption of mental capacity [ Sutton v Sadler
].

It has therefore been said that the burden of proving unsoundness of mind lies with those who allege it [ Dew v Clark and Clark
(1826) 2 Add 79
; Wheeler and Batsford v Alderson
(1831) 3 Hag Ecc 574
). But when the whole evidence is before the court, the decision must be against the validity of the will, unless it is affirmatively established that the deceased was of sound mind when he executed it [ Symes v Green
; Sutton v Sadler
; Smith v Tebbitt
(1867) LR 1
P & D 354 at p 398; see Harmes v Hinkson
(1946) 90 SJ 515
(PC)]. The burden of proof may shift from one party to another in the course of a case [ Waring v Waring
(1848) 6 Moo PC 341
]. Where grave suspicion of incapacity arises in the case of those propounding the will, they must dispel that suspicion by proving testamentary capacity [Ibid at p 356]. Thus where it is admitted by those propounding the will that the deceased suffered from serious mental illness at a period before the will [ Bannatyne v Bannatyne
(1852) 2 Rob Eccl 472
], or where its terms are incoherent, irrational or strange [ Austen v Graham
(1854) 8 Moo PCC 493
], a presumption is raised against it, though not a conclusive one (Mortimer, Williams and Sunnuck at p 169).

A party who puts forward a document as being the true last will of the deceased must established that the testator knew and approved of its contents at the time when he executed it [ Barry v Butlin
(1838) 2 Moo PC 480
; Guardhouse v Blackburn
at p 116]. In ordinary circumstances, the burden of proof is discharged by proof of testamentary capacity and of due execution, from which knowledge and approval by the testator of the contents of his will are assumed [ Barry v Butlin
at p 484]. The burden of proving due execution is upon the person setting up the will. 'The evidence of one of the attesting witnesses, if he deposes to the due execution, is sufficient' [17 Halsbury's Law of England (4th Ed) para 892]. There is a presumption of due execution where there is a proper attestation clause, though the witnesses have no recollection of having witnessed the will [ Woodhouse v Balfour
(1887) 13 PD 2
; Re Webb, the deceased; Smith v Johnston & Ors
[1964] 2 All ER 91
], but this presumption may be rebutted by the witnesses [17 Halsbury's Laws of England (4th Ed) para 893] or otherwise [ Re Parslow, Parslow v Parslow
(1959) The Times, 3 December — evidence that the attestation was forged].

Knowledge and approval, and it takes any form provided it is strong enough to satisfy the court, must be affirmatively proved by those propounding the will if those who oppose it, by cross-examination or otherwise, succeed in meeting the prima facie case raised by proof of execution [ Cleare v Cleare
(1869) LR 1
P & D 655 at p 658].

In Re R the deceased
, Willmer J said:

The conclusion which I draw from these authorities [ Davis v Mayhew
[1927] P 264
; Low v Guthrie
[1909] AC 278
] to which I have referred is that, when it is a question of knowledge and approval of the contents of a will the circumstances which are held to excite the suspicions of the court must be circumstances attending, or at least relevant to, the preparation and execution of the will itself.

Surrounding circumstances not attending or relevant to the preparation and execution of the will may well be relevant to other issues such as testamentary capacity or undue influence. Conduct of the beneficiaries may amount to fraud [ Fulton v Andrew
at p 448]; but the court must not address itself solely on the question of fraud and decide the case on whether or not those opposing the will have made out a case of fraud [ Tyrrell v Painton & Anor
[1894] P 151
]. The vital and essential issue in cases of this kind is whether those propounding the will have discharged the burden of showing the righteousness of the transaction and that the paper propounded expresses the true will of the deceased [ Finny v Govett
(1908) 25 TLR 186
(CA)].

Sir JP Wilde in Hall v Hall
(1868) LR 1
P & D 481 at p 482 defined undue influence as follows:
Pressure of whatever character... if so exercised as to overpower the volition without convincing the judgment.

Viscount Haldane in Craig v Lamoureux
[1920] AC 349 at p 357
explained it as follows:

… Undue influence, in order to render a will void, must be an influence which can justly be described by a person looking at the matter judicially to have caused the execution of a paper pretending to express a testator's mind, but which does not express his mind, but something else which he did not really mean.

There is a difference between undue influence as understood in probate and in equity. In equity, persons standing in certain relationships to others are liable to have undue influence presumed against them in relationship to certain transactions. In probate, undue influence cannot be presumed [ Parfitt v Lawless
(1872) LR 2
P & D 462 at p 468]; 'there must be coercion … it is only when the will of the person who becomes a testator is coerced into doing that which he does not desire to do, that it is undue influence' [ Wingrove v Wingrove
(1885) 11 PD 81 at p 82
].

Those alleging undue influence must prove it. It is not sufficient to show the circumstances attending the execution are consistent with its having been procured by undue influence. It must be shown that they are inconsistent with any other hypothesis [ Boyse v Rossborough
at p 51]. Even if the power to overbear the will of the testator is admitted, it must be shown that such power was exercised, and that the circumstances of the execution are inconsistent with any other view but undue influence [ Craig v Lamoureux
[1920] AC 349
]. Nevertheless in many cases in which the court has not been satisfied that there was undue influence, and even in cases where undue influence has been positively disproved, the court has pronounced against the will propounded because the circumstances have excited its suspicion and vigilance, and it has not been satisfied as to the righteousness of the transaction [ Barry v Butlin
(1838) 2 Moo PC 480
; Fulton v Andrew
(1875) LR 7 HL 448
; Re Hartley, Hartley v Fuld (Fuld intervening)(No 3)
[1965] 3 All ER 776
]

Fraud unlike undue influence does not involve any degree of coercion. A false representation about the character of an individual, made to the testator for the purpose of inducing him to revoke a bequest made in favour of that individual, or to exclude the person so calumniated from any benefit in his will is a strong instance of fraud [ Allen v M'Pherson
(1847) 1 HL Cas 191
at p 207
].

emph.emph: The formal validity of the 1992 wills

p.text:
Section 134
of the Evidence Act 1950 provides that 'no particular number of witnesses shall in any case be required for the proof of any fact'. This means that the testimony of a single witness, if believed, is sufficient to establish any fact.

In the case of wills, an instrument required by law to be attested and subscribed by two or more witnesses, 'it shall not be used as evidence until one attesting witness at least has been called for the purpose of proving its execution, if there is an attesting witness alive and subject to the process of the court and capable of giving evidence' (
s 68
of the Evidence Act 1950). '…The evidence of one of the attesting witnesses, if he deposes to due execution, is sufficient' (17 Halsbury's Laws of England (4th Ed) para 892). This means that the evidence of one of the attesting witnesses, if believed, is sufficient to prove due execution.

In the case of the 1992 wills, there was a proper attestation clause and 'one attesting witness at least' who deposed to due execution on 3 August 1992. That would have been sufficient ordinarily to prove due execution. That would have been sufficient, even in this extraordinary situation where the second attesting witness deposed to the contrary, to prove due execution if Lim's evidence is believed. The tricky question is whether Lim could be believed.

According to Howard, he prepared the 1992 wills — one set each of the 1992 Malaysian, Thai and US wills. Then, there could only have been a set of each of the Malaysian, Thai and US (1992) wills. Except that Cheng Hum produced, confounding the latter assumption, a second Thai will dated 3 August 1992 (D2D) apparently bearing the signatures of the deceased, Lim and Dr Gafoor, a second Thai will that should not exist at all if it was true that the 1992 wills were the only wills executed on 3�August 1992. Adding to the intrigue, the provisions of the second Thai will were identical to the provisions of the 1992 Thai will, except that the second Thai will was not a replica of the 1992 Thai will; identical provisions were not identically positioned in the two documents — cl 2 for example was found in p 1 of the 1992 Thai will but in p 2 of the second Thai will, the pagination was printed on the top half of one but the bottom half of the other. It means that the second Thai will could not have been prepared nor printed on the one occasion as the 1992 Thai will.

Both Howard and Lim denied that they prepared the second Thai will. Howard said he had no knowledge of the second Thai will when he left Penang for the US on 5 August 1992. Lim firmly maintained, even when a copy of the second Thai will (then ID11) was before him, that he did not attest and he had not seen the second Thai will. Plainly, the execution of loose sheets after 3 August 1992 was vehemently denied.

row.entry: I put it to you … what you testified about Lim Cheng Chuan coming on 26 August 1992 with loose sheets for the deceased's signature is a lie.

p.text: But Lim admitted, when the second Thai will (D2D) was before him, that his signature was on the second Thai will. Lim explained that the 1992 Thai will (D2B) had mistakes, that the second Thai will was to rectify the mistakes in the 1992 Thai will, and that he forwarded through Beng Tatt the second Thai will to Dr Gafoor for Dr Gafoor's signature and rubber stamp.

There was agreement therefore, albeit impliedly, that the second Thai will was prepared after the execution of the 1992 Thai will, and that the 1992 Thai will was the template for the second Thai will. Indeed, without the 1992 Thai will as template or precedent and save for a highly unlikely coincidence, the content of the second Thai will could not have been identical with the 1992 Thai will. Whoever prepared the second Thai will must have had the 1992 Thai will, or, the computer file in Howard's laptop computer.

Lim testified that he took possession of the 1992 wills immediately after it was executed, that he handed the 1992 wills to Beng Tatt and instructed Beng Tatt to obtain Dr Gafoor's rubber stamp, that he kept the 1992 wills in his office safe and that he only removed the 1992 wills from his safe after the death of the deceased. It means that Lim had possession of the 1992 wills at the material time. As observed in the foregoing, whoever prepared the second Thai will must have had the 1992 wills or the computer file from Howard's laptop computer. That would only have been Lim, Howard or Richard; Richard said he had access to Howard's laptop computer. However, all three denied that they prepared the second Thai will. Howard said he deleted the computer file after he printed the 1992 wills and Richard said he had no knowledge whatsoever of the preparation or execution of wills. Lim said, 'the second Thai will was there when I reached the deceased's house'. Nonetheless, the second Thai will was the irrefutable testament, despite the chorus of denials, that one, at least, was not speaking the truth.

The following evidence and the deductions that could be drawn come to mind. After 5 August 1992, Howard was not in the country. Richard could have prepared the second Thai will, except that Howard said that he deleted the computer file after he printed the 1992 wills. Lim said he handed the second Thai will to Beng Tatt. Lim had possession of the 1992 wills — the template for a second Thai will — at the material time. Only Lim was directly linked to the second Thai will. Evidently, the evidence was pointing to Lim as the maker of the second Thai will.

Mr Foo contended that the deceased could have prepared the second Thai will. With respect, the deceased could have, if only he had the template — the 1992 wills from Lim, or Howard's computer file from Howard — he never had; Howard testified that he deleted the computer file after he printed the 1992 wills and Lim said that the 1992 wills were constantly with him. The maker of the second Thai will could only have been from the side propounding and or supporting the 1992 wills; and after 3 August 1992, Lim was the only one with the template and the only one directly linked to the second Thai will.

Lim's demeanour in the witness box also left much too much to be desired. Under examination-in-chief and when referred to a copy of the second Thai will (D11), Lim testified that the second Thai will and or copy was never in his possession. 'I have never seen the original of the (second Thai will)', Lim said. Under cross-examination by Mr Khoo, Lim testified that he had no knowledge whatsoever of D11. Still under cross- examination by Mr Khoo, Lim denied that his signature was on the copy of the second Thai will or that he attested the second Thai will. So clearly up to that point, Lim repudiated all knowledge of the second Thai will. Then Lim made a dramatic turnabout; cross-examined by Mr Yeoh and when the second Thai will before him, Lim conceded like a bolt out of the blue that D11 was a copy of the second Thai will and that his signature was on the second Thai will and on D11.

What was the explanation for that volte face? Lim said he forgot about the second Thai will. Perhaps. But that could not explain why Lim's memory was enkindled by the second Thai will but not by an identical copy, as if an original or copy rather than the text that mattered, when he was shown an identical copy of the second Thai will? Further to his admission that his signature was on both the second Thai will and D11, Lim related that: (i) the 1992 Thai will had mistakes, (ii) the deceased was not happy with the mistakes and the deceased arranged for a second Thai will to be typed, (iii) a date was fixed for Dr Gafoor and him to witness the execution of the second Thai will, (iv) Dr Gafoor did not turn up on the appointed date, (v) the deceased signed the second 1992 Thai will in his presence, and, (vi) the deceased kept the second Thai will. But in rendering that testimony, (i) to (vi), Lim was materially changing his testimony. Gone was his testimony that the deceased did not sign any other documents (meaning wills) after 3 August 1992. Gone was his testimony that all wills were executed at Pykett Avenue on 3 August 1992. Gone too was his testimony that he never handed any documents to Beng Tatt for Dr�Gafoor's signature. Then, it was that the deceased signed a will after 3�August 1992 and that he attested a will of the deceased (second 1992 Thai will) without the presence of a second attesting witness.

Lim explained that he had forgotten about the second Thai will. As said, perhaps. It should be said though that the second Thai will was not sprung upon Lim. Lim affirmed in his affidavit dated 10 February 1995 (enclosure 20 in 22-271-94) he could not remember anything about the second Thai will. Therefore, Lim was alerted in 1995 of the possible existence of a second Thai will, and Lim had time enough to mull, to reflect and to do some real soul-searching on a second Thai will long, long before he entered the witness box. And Lim was a witness who could recollect the nits and minutiae of all the happenings he said he witnessed at Pykett Avenue on 3 August 1992, even though his professed role was limited to the attestation of wills that Howard prepared. Then could it be, given that Lim was endowed with some capacity for recollection, that Lim's memory of the second 1992 Thai will, if even dormant, was so dead that it could not be enkindled even by an identical copy? And if Lim's memory was in such deep recess that an identical document (D11) could not jump start it to life, then how could the second Thai will mend Lim's memory any better? Then how could it be explained that the production of the second Thai will could bring Lim's memory to life where an identical copy had utterly failed before? Lim attested the second Thai will. He said a date was fixed for Dr Gafoor to attest the second Thai will. He attested the second Thai will after 3 August 1992. Given that active role, it was just not probable that Lim could have forgotten the second Thai will he was so vehemently denying from the witness box. It could be said only that Lim was stonewalling, and stonewalling he was, until he was overwhelmed by the probably unexpected production of the second Thai will, when further denials would be futile, into owning up to his knowledge and to his active role in the second Thai will.

It was remarked in the foregoing that Lim abandoned his prior testimony — the deceased did not sign any documents (meaning wills) after 3 August 1992 and all wills were executed at Pykett Avenue on 3 August 1992 — after he was confronted by the second Thai will. But Lim did not just abandoned his prior testimony; he turned his testimony around. Where he testified that all wills were executed on 3 August 1992, meaning that no wills were executed after 3 August 1992, he then testified that the deceased executed a second Thai will after 3 August 1992 without the joint presence of witnesses and that he attested that will after 3 August 1992. Where he denied all knowledge of a second Thai will, he then rendered a saturated account of the second Thai will. Evidently, Lim could invert his testimony with ease but without any scruples whatsoever.

Mr Koh submitted that the first to third defendants should not suffer on account of Lim's demeanour. With respect, it should have been said just as well that the first to third defendants should not profit either. Through Lim, the first to third defendants sought to prove due execution of the wills they propounded. If Lim is believed, due execution is proved. If Lim is disbelieved, it only stands to reason that due execution might not be proved (might not for the time being until Dr Gafoor's testimony has been considered).

All along, it was the plaintiffs' case (and adopted by the fourth and fifth defendants) that the 1992 wills were reconstructed by the first to third defendants whilst it was the first to third defendants' case that the deceased only executed the 1992 wills and no other wills on 3 August 1992 and that the 1992 wills were not reconstructed wills. The plaintiffs adduced evidence that the deceased executed wills in loose sheet form, that further loose sheets were signed and subscribed after 3 August 1992, and that Dr�Gafoor subscribed those further loose sheets without the joint presence of the deceased and Lim. Need it be said that the integrity of the 1992 wills, if Dr Gafoor is believed, could be irreparably damaged, the execution of further loose sheets after 3 August 1992, quite apart from the question of formal validity, would not weaken the case that the 'wills' executed on 3�August 1992 were reconstructed and would also put the identity of the 'wills' executed on 3 August 1992 into serious doubt. Put bluntly, a second Thai will — clear-cut evidence that the deceased executed more wills than was pleaded by the first to third defendants — could not enhance the prospects of the 1992 wills. But put away, the allegation that the 1992 wills were reconstructed would be hard-pressed to prove. Given the importance of the second Thai will, it could be asked if Lim's denial in the witness box was to screen out crucial evidence or to conceal the fact that the second Thai will was not executed in accordance with the legal requisites. Be that as it may, it was crystal clear that Lim was not a credible witness. Even Mr Foo reluctantly admitted that he had difficulty with Lim's credibility. Lim testified that the 1992 wills were the only wills executed and that he had no knowledge whatsoever of the second Thai will. Doing so, he nailed his colours to the mast. He was contradicted by the second Thai will. He was hesitant and diffident when the second Thai will was produced before him. He said he had forgotten about the second Thai will but his admission of a fourth will (second Thai will) and his explanation for the existence of the second Thai will were not pleaded. In truth, Lim's credibility had gone to rack and ruin the moment the second Thai will was produced. He was forced to backpedal, to extricate himself from his erstwhile denials of the second Thai will. And what about the explanation for the second Thai will — a mistake in the date, on the cover and on the end page. Mr Koh contended that it was a plausible explanation. With respect, it was not a plausible explanation: a corrected cover need not be resigned by the deceased or Dr Gafoor, and the end page was already corrected and countered-signed by the deceased and Dr Gafoor. In any event, from Lim's account, some effort was taken to secure the second Thai will to rectify the mistakes in the 1992 Thai will. Then, why was the second Thai will not propounded? Instead, inexplicably, the 1992 Thai will with the mistakes was propounded.

Section 134 follows the maxim, testimonia ponderanda sunt non numeranda , that testimony is to be weighed and not counted. ' … more regard is to be paid to the character of the evidence adduced in support of case than to the number merely of the witness who gave it; for the evidence of two respectable and credible witnesses is of more value than of a dozen witnesses of notoriously abandoned and profligate character' ( Trayner's Latin Maxims at p 599). ' …. the court is concerned with the quality and not quantity of evidence' [ Sarkar at p 1958]. The weight to be attributed to evidence, testibus non testimoniis credendum est , 'depends upon the character and credibility of a witness more than upon the probability or improbability of his statements. The value of the evidence given is to commensurate with the honesty and truthfulness of the witness; evidence as to an improbable fact spoken to by a witness above all suspicion deserves and receives more weight than the evidence of a doubtful or incredible witness regarding a fact itself very probable' ( Trayner's Latin Maxims at p 599).

Mr Foo submitted that the integrity of the 1992 wills, even in spite of the second Thai will, was intact. However, the second Thai will was the irrefutable proof that the deceased executed more 'wills' than was pleaded by the first to third defendants. It was revealing proof that Lim was not adverse to his attestation of wills without the presence of a joint attesting witness. It was also revealing proof that Lim was not adverse to his attestation of a will not correctly dated — the second Thai will executed after 3 August 1992 was dated 3 August 1992.

But it was far worse than not exhibiting the skill of an ordinary competent solicitor. Knowing that the deceased had signed the second Thai will without the joint presence of two attesting witnesses, he attested that the deceased signed the second Thai will in the presence of two witnesses. To say the least, that was highly irregular. Knowing that the second Thai will was executed after 3 August 1992, he dated it as 3 August 1992. That was deceitful. Sadly, Lim, a senior lawyer called for the purpose of proving due execution could not be believed on his assertion that the 1992 wills were intact. Clearly, due execution was not proved.

Dr Gafoor testified that loose documents were forwarded to him on two separate occasions for his signature. His testimony that he signed loose documents after the 3 August 1992 was not challenged. On every material aspect, he was corroborated by Beng Tatt. Indeed, his entire testimony, so it turned out, was authenticated by the second Thai will. Indeed, there was no reason to doubt Dr Gafoor, a witness who was consistent throughout his testimony. The only possible blip was his evidence, as was the case with Beng Tatt's evidence, that Richard was at Pykett Avenue on 3 August 1992. But that did not make him an unreliable witness, as the overall veracity and integrity of his evidence was not at all adversely affected.

Section 5
of the Wills Act 1959, in pari materia with
s 9
of English Wills Act 1837, leans towards upholding and not striking down the 1992 wills because of formal defects. In the instant case, it was not a case of mere formal defects. Section 5 was not respected. Section 5 was desecrated. In more ways than one, the 1992 wills cannot be admitted to probate; clearly, due execution was disproved.
It is necessary, on the subject of the 'gifts', to turn back a few years, to 1988.

By all accounts, the deceased and his wife were devoted to each other. The loss of his wife in 1988, when he was 82 and well in his climacteric years, down in the dumps some witnesses said, would have been extremely hard for the deceased. However, after a short period of grief, the deceased was his old self. Things were looking up. He was on the rebound. The year 1991 was a tranquil year at Pykett Avenue. Cheng Liat and Cheng Hum were not calling, but Liang Imm and Cheng Bok even if not visiting enough were at least visiting. Already, it could be observed, that the life of the deceased, beginning from the date of death of his wife, was becoming more and more focused and more and more centered around Cheng Poon and his family. Where he had the daily company of three sons (Cheng Hum, Cheng Poon and Cheng Liat, during meal time at least), he would only have, beginning 1991, Cheng Poon and family. In July 1992, at 86, the deceased suffered a stroke. By then, old and decrepit of body, his spirit blighted by a recent stroke, and in the final flush of his life, the deceased would have been totally dependent on Cheng Poon, his ever present son, and on Cheng Poon's family for all his daily needs and daily care.

In June 1992, the deceased received approximately RM6.3m from the sale of the Batu Ferringhi land. By July 1992, all that money was gone, in the main to Cheng Poon and his family. The plaintiffs pleaded that the first to third defendants misappropriated RM6.4m. Cheng Poon and his sons pleaded that those monies (and cars) were gifts from the deceased. The plaintiffs impugned the good faith of all those purported gifts. They impugned as well the transfer of the Teluk Bahang land.
It is necessary, to settle that controversy, to understand the law applicable to gifts.

'As between persons dealing on a footing of complete equality, there is no presumption against good faith. So, ordinarily a person who challenges the validity of a transaction on the ground of fraud, undue influence and charges his opponent with bad faith has the burden of proof. There is an exception to this rule where a fiduciary or confidential relationship subsists between the contracting parties, eg guardian and ward, and cestui que trust, parent and child, physician and patient, preceptor and disciple, etc. The rule applies to parents, executors, administrators, trustees, etc who take any benefit in respect of any property entrusted to their care. Where on account of such relationship one of them is in a position to exert undue influence or 'dominion' over the other and takes any benefit from him, the burden of proving good faith of the transaction is thrown upon the dominant party, ie the party who is in a position of active confidence. A person standing in a fiduciary relation to another has a duty to protect the interest given to his care and the court watches with jealousy all transactions between such persons so that the protector may not use his influence or the confidence to his advantage. When the party complaining show such relation, the law presumes everything against the transaction and the onus is cast upon the person holding the position of confidence or trust to show that the transaction is perfectly fair and reasonable, that no advantage has been taken of his position and that no information which should have been communicated has been withheld' ( Sarkar on Evidence (14th Ed) p 1463).

Accordingly, 111 of the
Evidence Act 1950
provides:

Where there is a question as to the good faith of a transaction between parties, one of whom stands to the other in a position of active confidence, the burden of proving the good faith of the transaction is on the party who is in a position of active confidence.

The principle on which the court acts in relieving against transactions on the ground of inequality of footing between the parties is not confined to cases where a fiduciary relation can be shown to exist, but extends to all the varieties of relations in which dominion may be exercised by one man over another, and applies to every case where influence is acquired and abused, or where confidence is reposed and betrayed [ Huguenin v Baseley
14 Ves 273 at p 286
; Kerr p 182]. If it is established that the defendant was in a position to dominate his will and that the transaction was unconscionable, the burden of proof of absence of undue influence rests upon the defendant [ Ballo v Parasam
1972 AIR HP 33
].

The jurisdiction of the court to relieve undue influence is as wide and as flexible as the exigency of the case, and even exercisable without any proof of dominance of the will of a party to a transaction.

In National Westminster Bank plc v Morgan
[1985] 1 All ER 821 at p�831
, Lord Scarman said:

… There is no precisely defined law setting limits to the equitable jurisdiction of a court to relieve against undue influence. This is the world of doctrine, not of neat and tidy rules. The courts of equity have developed a body of learning enabling relief to be granted where the law has to treat the transaction as unimpeachable unless it can be held to have been procured by undue influence. It is the unimpeachability at law of a disadvantageous transaction which is the starting point from which the court advances to consider whether the transaction is the product merely of one's folly or of the undue influence exercised by another. A court in the exercise of this equitable jurisdiction is a court of conscience. Definition is a poor instrument when used to determine whether a transaction is or is not unconscionable: this is a question which depends on the particular facts of the case.

In Tengku Abdullah ibni Sultan Abu Bakar & Ors v Mohd Latiff bin Shah Mohd & Ors and other appeals
[1996] 2 MLJ 265 at pp 310
, 314-315, Gopal Sri Ram JCA said:

Undue influence, like all other equitable doctrine, is an extremely flexible concept. Subject to policy considerations, the categories in which it may operate are therefore not closed. For this reason, it is important to apply the doctrine, as housed in
s 16
of the Contracts Act 1950, to varying fact patterns in a flexible manner. This is to be done by interpreting s 16 in a broad and liberal fashion. Being a remedial provision — in the sense that it is designed to relieve obligations — it should, in our judgment, be given a liberal interpretation. Even in cases which are not stricto sensu contractual in nature, the section may be resorted to by analogy. Another reason for adopting this approach to interpretation lies in the absence of any intention on the part of Parliament to alter the doctrine or to deprive it of flexibility it has acquired through historical development … [T]he proof of dominance of the will of a party to a transaction — be it a gift, … by the other party to the transaction is not a sine qua non of the doctrine of undue influence. The doctrine applies with equal force where, from the proved or admitted facts, there is shown a relationship of confidence and an abuse of that confidence by the person in whom it was reposed.

Whereas the Evidence Act places the burden of proving the good faith of the transaction on the party in a position of active confidence, the
Contracts Act 1950
prescribes the context in which a contract is said to be induced by 'undue influence'. The relevant provisions of the
Contracts Act 1950
read:

(1) All agreements are contracts if they are made by the free consent of parties competent to contract, for a lawful consideration and with a lawful object, and are not hereby expressly declared to be void.
13 Two or more persons are said to consent when they agree upon the same thing in the same sense.
14 Consent is said to be free when it is not caused by —
(a) coercion, as defined in section 15;
(b) undue influence, as defined in section 16;
(c) fraud, as defined in section 17;
(d) misrepresentation, as defined in section 18; or
(e) mistake, subject to sections 21, 22 and 23.
Consent is said to be so caused when it would not have been given but for the existence of such coercion, undue influence, fraud, misrepresentation, or mistake.

15 'Coercion' is the committing, or threatening to commit any act forbidden by the Penal Code, or the unlawful detaining or threatening to detain, any property, to the prejudice of any person whatever, with the intention of causing any person to enter into an agreement.

(1) A contract is said to be induced by 'undue influence' where the relations subsisting between the parties are such that one of the parties is in a position to dominate the will of the other and uses that position to obtain an unfair advantage over the other.
(2) In particular and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing principle, a person is deemed to be in a position to dominate the will of another —
(a) where he holds a real or apparent authority over the other, or where he stands in a fiduciary relation to the other; or
(b) where he makes a contract with a person whose mental capacity is temporarily or permanently affected by reason of age, illness, or mental or bodily distress.

(a) Where a person who is in a position to dominate the will of another, enters into a contract with him, and the transaction appears, on the face of it or on the evidence adduced, to be unconscionable, the burden of proving that the contract was not induced by undue influence shall lie upon the person in a position to dominate the will of the other.

(b) Nothing in this subsection shall affect
s 111
of the Evidence Act 1950.

17 'Fraud' includes any of the following acts committed by a party to a contract, or with his connivance, or by his agent, with intent to deceive another party thereto or his agent, or to induce him to enter into the contract:
(a) the suggestion, as to a fact, of that which is not true by one who does not believe it to be true;
(b) the active concealment of a fact by one having knowledge of belief of the fact;
(c) a promise made without any intention of performing it;
(d) any other act fitted to deceive; and
(e) any such act or omission as the law specially declares to be fraudulent.
(1) When consent to an agreement is caused by coercion, fraud, or misrepresentation, the agreement is a contract voidable at the option of the party whose consent was so caused.

(2) A party to a contract, whose consent was caused by fraud or misrepresentation, may, if he thinks fit, insist that the contract shall be performed, and that he shall be put in the position in which he would have been if the representations made had been true.

20 When consent to an agreement is caused by undue influence, the agreement is a contract voidable at the option of the party whose consent was so caused. Any such contract may be set aside either absolutely or, if the party who was entitled to avoid it has received any benefit thereunder, upon such terms and conditions as to the court may seem just.

Section 16(3)(b) provides that 'nothing in this subsection shall affect s�111 of the
Evidence Act 1950
'. However, there is a difference between
s 111
of the Evidence Act and s 16(3) of the Contracts Act. Under s 111, whenever the good faith of a transaction between persons, one of whom stands to the other in a position of active confidence is in question, there is a presumption against the deed and the burden of proving good faith is on the person who holds the position. But under s 16(3), the burden of proving good faith is thrown on the person who holds the position only when the transaction appears on the face of it, or on the evidence adduced to be unconscionable' ( Sarkar at p 1464; see also Datuk Jagindar Singh & Ors v Tara Rajaratnam
[1983] 2 MLJ 196 at p 205
). However, with regard to s 16(2) of the Indian Contract Act, in the case of gifts or settlements where the donee or the settlee is shown to have been a person in real or apparent authority or in a fiduciary relationship to the donor or settlor's mental capacity was temporarily or permanently affected by reason of age, illness or mental or bodily distress, the onus is upon the donee or settlee to prove that the gift or settlement was not brought about by undue influence (see Venkataramier v Krishnammal
52 Mad LJ 20; AIR 1927 Mad 259).

'The words "active confidence" should, in order that the law may be really protective, receive a wider interpretation [ Benoy v Santi
40 CWN 45; 62 CLJ A99]. (Active confidence) may be presumed to exist as a natural consequence of the condition of the parties, though it be not actually proved that the one habitually acted as if under the dominion of the other. There are many relations of common occurrence in life from which the court presumes confidence put in the general course of affairs and influence exerted in the particular transaction complained of [ Smith v Kay
(1859) 7 HL Cas 750
]. Persons may therefore not only be proved by direct evidence of conduct, but presumed by reason of standing in any of these suspected relations, as they be called, to a position of commanding influence over those from whom they take a benefit. In either case, they are called upon to rebut the presumption that the particular benefit was procured by the exertion of that influence and was not given with due freedom and deliberation. They must take upon themselves the whole proof that the thing is righteous. A stringent rule of evidence is imposed as safeguards against evasion of the substantive law ( Pollock on Contract p�581)' ( Sarkar at pp 1467-1468).

Undue influence is inferred from the special relationship between the parties, quite apart from proof of fraud or unfair advantage. The doctrine of undue influence and its scope were considered in Allcard v Skinner
(1887) 36 Ch D 145
. Lindley LJ observed at p 183:
As no court has ever attempted to define fraud, so no court has ever attempted to define undue influence, which includes one of its many varieties�….
Lindley LJ thus explained the doctrine of undue influence (at pp 182-183):

The principle must be examined. What then is the principle? Is it, that is right and expedient to save persons from the consequences of their own folly? Or is it that it is right and expedient to save them from being victimised by other person? In my opinion, the doctrine of undue influence is founded upon the second of those two principles. Courts of Equity have never set aside gifts on the ground of folly, imprudence, or want of foresight on the part of donors. The courts have always repudiated any such jurisdiction. Huguenin v Baseley
14 Ves 273
is itself a clear authority to this effect. It would obviously be to encourage folly, recklessness, extravagance and vice if persons could get back property which they foolishly made away with … On the other hand, to protect people from being forced, tricked or misled in any way by others into parting with their property is one of the most legitimate objects of all laws.
Cotton LJ classified the gifts that could be set aside:

These decisions may be divided into two classes — first, where the court has been satisfied that the gift was the result of influence expressly used by the donee for the purpose; second, where the relations between the donor or donee have at or shortly before the execution of the gift been such as to raise a presumption that the donee had influence over the donor … The first class of cases may be considered as depending on the principle that no one shall be allowed to retain any benefit arising from his own fraud or wrongful act. In the second class of cases, the court interferes, not on the ground that any wrongful act has in fact been committed by the donee, but on the ground of public policy, and to prevent the relations which existed between the parties and the influence arising therefrom from being abused.
Pollock's Indian Contract Act (7th Ed) p 92 says:

It is impossible to find plain and clear-cut categories for transactions which are often obscure and complicated, and sometimes purposely made so. Practically the most important thing to bear in mind is that persons in authority, or holding confidential employments such as that of a spiritual, medical, or legal adviser, are called on to act with good faith and more than good faith in the matter of accepting any benefit (beyond ordinary professional remuneration for professional work done) from those who are under their authority or guidance. In fact, their honourable prudent course is to insist on the other party taking independent advice.

The special relationship of confidence between parent (or person in loco parentis) and child is statutorily recognized [see illustration (a) in s 111]. But special relationship is not confined to the illustrations in s 111. It extends to all varieties of relations in which dominion may be exercised by one over another and applies to every case where influence is acquired and abused. Undue influence is not possible without a special relationship of confidence between parties, where one reposes trust and the other retains the influence. By the same token, influence is possible where there exists that special relationship; accordingly, the party holding the position of confidence, and it could be a child over his parent, must dispel bad faith in the pecuniary transaction.

In Carpenter v Heriot
(1759) 1 Eden 338
, Lord Landgale MR observed:

Nobody has ever asserted that there cannot be a pecuniary transaction between a parent and a child, the child being of full age; but everybody will affirm in this court that if there is a pecuniary transaction between parent and child, just after the child attains the age of 21 years, and prior to what may be called a complete 'emancipation' without any benefit moving to the child, the presumption is that an undue influence has been exercised to procure that liability on the part of the child …

Perhaps, the sentiment of the courts on undue influence is best expressed in Tate v Williamson
(1866) 2 Ch App 55
, where Lord Chelmsford LC said at pp 60-61:

The jurisdiction exercised by courts of equity over the dealings of persons standing in certain fiduciary relations has always been regarded as one of a most salutary description … the courts have always been careful not to fetter this useful jurisdiction by defining the exact limits of its exercise. Whenever two persons stand in such a relation that, while it continues, confidence is necessarily reposed by one, and the influence which naturally grows out of that confidence is possessed by the other, and this confidence is abused or the influence is exerted to obtain an advantage at the expense of the confiding party, the person so availing himself of his position will not be permitted to retain the advantage, although the transaction would not have been impeached if no such confidential relation had existed.

The importance of bringing home to the mind of the donor the consequences of his gift, to rebut a presumption of undue influence arising upon proof of the existence of a relationship between the parties, was particularly stressed by Lord Hailsham LC in Inche Noriah v Shaik Allie bin Omar
[1929] AC 127 at p 136
; 1 MC 79:

In the present case, their Lordships do not doubt that Mr Aitken acted in good faith; but he seems to have received a good deal of his information from the respondent; he was not made aware of the material fact that the property which was being given away constituted practically the whole estate of the donor, and he certainly does not seem to have brought home to her mind the consequences to herself of what she was doing, or the fact that she could more prudently, and equally effectively, have benefited the donee without undue risk to herself by retaining the property in her own possession during her life and bestowing it upon him by her will. In their Lordships'view, the facts proved by the respondent are not sufficient to rebut the presumption of undue influence which is raised by the relationship proved to have been in existence between the parties ….

A more recent illustration is Lim Kim Hua v Ho Chui Lan & Anor
[1995] 3 MLJ 165
, where Steve Shim J held there was a special relationship between a grandmother (plaintiff/transferor) and her granddaughter (defendant/transferee) as the plaintiff, old, illiterate and with poor memory, was living with the defendant who provided her food and accommodation, as the plaintiff entrusted the management of her shophouse (the subject of the transfer) to the defendant and as the plaintiff was dependent on the defendant in both her physical and financial needs, that undue influence could reasonably be inferred from those factors unless the defendant could show that she had not abused her position and that the transfer was not brought about by undue influence. The learned judge went on to say (at pp 173-174):

… She must show, by strict proof, that the plaintiff, at the time of executing the said transfer, had fully understood, not just the nature of the transfer but its full significance and effect: see Zamet & Ors v Hyman & Anor
[1961] 3 All ER 933
; [1961] 1 WLR 1442
. I do not think that the first defendant has done so. She has merely allege that the plaintiff wanted to effect the said transfer in a hurry and that the contents therein were read and explained to her. In my view, this would not be sufficient to rebut undue influence. As Lord Eldon said in Huguenin v Baseley
[1803–13] All ER 1 at p 3
:

'The question is not whether she knew what she was doing, had done or proposed to do, but how the intention was produced; whether all that care and providence was placed round her, as against who advised her, which, from their situation and relation with respect to her they were bound to exert on her behalf.'

In the instant case, the defendant has not adduced evidence to show that all care and providence had been taken by her that the plaintiff was put in possession of all material facts and information so as to enable her to decide fairly, fully and freely what she wanted to do with her property. The plaintiff placed in the position she was in relation to the defendant, must be in full view and complete appreciation of what she was doing. In my view, the defendant should, in the circumstances of this case, not only have drawn the plaintiff's attention to the provisions of the 1983 will but also to the consequential effect or effects upon the execution of the memorandum of transfer. By keeping silent, she had actively concealed the material facts and thus committed dishonesty against the plaintiff.

Unlike the rest of the 'monetary gifts' where the alleged transactions were said to have been strictly between 'donor' and 'donees', the 'gift' of the Teluk Bahang was said to have taken place in the presence of several witnesses.

To recapitulate, Lim testified that the deceased instructed him, shortly after the deceased was discharged from LWE Hospital, to prepare a Memorandum of Discharge [PB1(290)] and a Memorandum of Transfer [DB1F(92)] of the Teluk Bahang land in favour of Cheng Poon. According to Lim, he received, in the morning of 3 August 1992, a telephone call requesting him to be at Pykett Avenue to witness the execution of the deceased's wills. Whilst waiting for the 1992 wills to be retyped, he took out the PA [DB1A(197)] and Memorandum of Transfer ('transfer') [DB1F(92)] he prepared and presented those instruments to the deceased for his signature. Lim testified that the deceased executed both the PA and transfer and then instructed Beng Tatt to call Cheng Poon who was then downstairs to execute the transfer. Beng Tatt called Cheng Poon who came upstairs and signed the transfer. After the execution of the PA and transfer, Howard brought out the 1992 Thai will for execution, Lim added.

However, Lim was not supported by any of the persons present at Pykett Avenue on 3 August 1992. Dr Gafoor who was seated next to the deceased and Lim when the PA and transfer were said to have been executed and would have seen the execution of the PA and transfer testified that the deceased only executed documents relating to wills and not of any other instrument. Beng Tatt who was standing next to the deceased testified that the deceased only executed documents relating to wills and that the deceased did not execute a PA or transfer on 3 August 1992. Howard, who testified that he saw his father signing some documents, did not say that his father was signing a transfer. And most pertinently, Cheng Poon who would profit if the transfer is validated but would lose out if the transfer is invalidated and therefore would have defended the gift of the Teluk Bahang land, if it was indeed a gift, did not testify, when he had personal knowledge to affirm, that the transfer was a gift as pleaded. The only evidence supporting a 'gift' was the statements in the transfer attested by Lim, and Lim's testimony. But Lim's testimony on the gift of the Teluk Bahang land was not at all assuring.

Lim testified that he was asked on 3 August 1992 to witness the execution of the deceased's wills. Then, the purpose of his visit to Pykett Avenue on 3 August 1992 was to witness the execution of wills; Lim did not say that he was asked to bring the transfer or PA. Nonetheless, he had with him, the transfer and PA he prepared. Perhaps, with regard to the transfer and PA, Lim was prescient. As said, Lim knew of the squabbles between the brothers. He knew that Cheng Poon in 1989 had attempted to gain control of some of the assets of the deceased. He knew, with regard to the sale proceeds received from the Batu Ferringhi land, that Cheng Poon received cash (RM866,000) whilst Cheng Liat and Cheng Bok received, whereas it was patently unfair to them, pieces of paper (24 July 1992 deeds). An apple of discord was growing. Conflict was brewing. It was just a matter of boiling over. Lim should have been sagacious. So, why did it not strike Lim at all that Cheng Liat and Cheng Bok would find issue with the transfer? And was it not convenient, with witnesses around, to explain the transfer, for the benefit of the witnesses around if not for the deceased who might already have been acquainted? And, if the deceased acknowledged the transfer, would not Dr Gafoor depose to the good faith of the transaction? Evidently, as providence had it, Lim had Dr Gafoor, if he wanted him, as a supporting witness to vouch for the good faith of the transfer. Yet Dr Gafoor was spurned; instead, Lim shoved the transfer and PA to a man who recently suffered a stroke, without so much as a spurious reading of the transfer or a cursory explanation of the effect of that transaction. In the upshot, there was no evidence at all that the deceased understood that he was signing a transfer of the Teluk Bahang land to Cheng Poon. The deceased in the position he was in relation to Cheng Poon and his family ought to have been in full view of what he was doing. But there was no evidence at all that care and providence had been taken by Cheng Poon to ensure that the deceased was put in possession of all material facts and information so as to enable the deceased to decide freely what he wanted to do with the Teluk Bahang land. In the circumstances of this case, Cheng Poon, not Lim, should have drawn the deceased's attention to the effect of the execution of the transfer. By keeping silent, Cheng Poon had actively concealed the material facts and thus committed dishonesty against his siblings if not against the deceased. There was no evidence as to how the intention of the deceased to transfer the Teluk Bahang land was formed; whether care and providence were placed round the deceased, as against those who advised him, which, from their situation and relation with respect to him they were bound to exert on his behalf. Even Lim admitted that the deceased did not give any reason for the said transfer.
