There was no evidence to rebut the inference that Cheng Poon's testimony if given would have been unfavourable to the asserted gift of the Teluk Bahang land. And Cheng Poon would not even deny Hamid's testimony that he (Cheng Poon) instructed Hamid to transfer the Teluk Bahang land to himself.

In the final analysis, the gift of the Teluk Bahang land was totally reliant on a discredited witness who testified, whereas all others present at the same time and place said nothing of the sort, that the deceased executed a transfer at Pykett Avenue on 3 August 1992.
The plaintiffs pleaded that Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard, between March to July 1992, misappropriated RM6.4m from the deceased.
The following payments were made to the following persons.

Richard, and Bok Eng readily admitted, in their testimony or through their counsel, that the above payments were indeed received by Cheng Poon, Richard, Howard Bok Eng or Gim Chuan; but Howard asserted that he returned his cheque for RM225,000 to the deceased. Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard pleaded that those monies received were gifts from the deceased. But as the trial unfolded, a gift was not the only 'justification'.

Both Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat testified that their mother had promised to give to each of them (Cheng Bok, Cheng Poon and Cheng Liat) 15% of the sale proceeds that would be received from the sale of her Batu Ferringhi land. That sale was concluded. Hamid testified that he calculated for the deceased that 15%; Hamid made it out to be RM866,000. Therefore, that RM866,000 to Cheng Poon could be justified as Cheng Poon's 15% (not disputed by Cheng Bok, Cheng Poon and Cheng Liat). However, the reasons for the other payments were not that straightforward nor the 'gifts' pleaded.

In 1991, the Batu Ferringhi land was sold for RM7,501,032. Hamid testified that Tan Beng Seng of Tan Seng Brothers secured the purchaser and that he received a 2% seller's commission. Tan Beng Hin testified that he and his brother (Tan Beng Seng), Hamid, Cheng Poon, and a friend of his brother were 'involved' in the sale of the Batu Ferringhi land. Tan Beng Hin testified that the deceased gave him 10% of the total sale proceeds to be shared by all five; he received in cash � of the 10% before 18 June 1992, Cheng Poon received � of the 10% to be shared with Hamid Merican, his brother received � of the 10%. Tan Beng Hin said that Bok Eng arranged the payment to him and to the others. It would appear that a sum of RM750,000 was paid as a sales commission to brokers; it was not a gift to the recipients. Tan Beng Hin denied all knowledge that a 10% sales commission was above the norm. Bok Eng testified that the deceased gave her a large sum to be paid to the brokers. She did not specify the amount. Bok Eng disagreed that she took the RM225,000 in exh PB1(325). Nonetheless, she agreed that only she could receive the RM225,000 in exh PB1(325). Pertinently, Bok Eng did not say that the monies her family received were gifts from the deceased.

Richard who admitted that his family received, between June and July 1992, a total of RM2.7m explained that RM512,063.70 was to settle the overdraft owing by the deceased and his father to the BBMB, Georgetown. He explained that Howard purchased a Mercedes SL with the RM350,000 given him by the deceased and that his father withdrew RM140,000 from the deceased's account, a day before the deceased died. Richard said that that RM140,000 had been accounted for; the balance (RM38,274), said, had been paid into the trustees' account. So Richard indirectly deposed that the deceased gave RM350,000 to Howard. Again, pertinently, Richard did not say that the RM121,567.35 credited to him was a gift from the deceased. In fact, Richard did not offer any explanation, reason, excuse or rationalization, and none could be deduced from the evidence, for the RM70,000, credited to him.

Howard, who admitted that he 'received' RM352,000 from the deceased, testified cryptically that 'a significant part was for his schooling fund and that the rest was for a car … (and) that the schooling fund, so long as he could finish his education, was not for any specific period'. He said that he endorsed a cheque for RM225,000, that sum was paid to Tan Beng Hin; Howard said that the deceased, after he endorsed the cheque, took the cheque from him. He said that he did not instruct the payments in his favour. Each time he needed money, he approached the deceased. The deceased approved and instructed all payments to him. Beginning June 1992, he was receiving large sums from the deceased. He received all sums stated in PB1(326-333). Between 17 June 1992 to 29 June 1992, he received cheques totaling RM576,000 from the deceased; but he did not receive the said RM225,000. Before then, he was only receiving RM50 a week.

Both Bok Eng and Howard each denied having received a sum of RM225,000. However, the relevant crossed cheques [PB1(325/326)] in favour of Bok Eng and Howard could only have been credited, most reasonably, to Bok Eng and Howard or to their order. Even Bok Eng admitted that only she could receive that RM225,000 in exh PB1(325). Howard said that the deceased took that cheque from him after he endorsed that cheque [PB1(325)].

But the bank did not agree with Howard. Teoh Seng Chye, the Deputy Branch Manager of the drawer bank, DBBMB Pulau Tikus branch, testified that two sums of RM866,000 and RM197,000 were credited into the joint account of Cheng Poon and Bok Eng and that the cheques for RM225,000 [PB1(352/326)] were credited to Bok Eng and Howard, the payees of those crossed cheques. Teoh Seng Chye who was testifying from incontestable records was not challenged. Undoubtedly, both Bok Eng and Howard received the RM225,000 they denied receiving.

Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard pleaded that the monies they received were gifts. But pleadings are not evidence. The only evidence of a 'gift', and it came from Richard and Howard, was that the deceased gave RM350,000 to Howard for a 'so long as he would finish his education schooling fund and for a car'. Other than that, Richard's explanation for the payment of the RM512,063.70 could not be true, as the cheque in favour of Cheng Poon (D35-A) was credited to Hamid's account in repayment of Cheng Poon's debt to Hamid; the redemption sum of the Teluk Bahang land was RM1,436,781.57 and not RM512,063.70. Bok Eng and Howard's denials that they received the two sums of RM225,000 were disproved. There was absolutely no evidence that the deceased gave RM139,000 to Gim Chuan. There was absolutely no evidence that the deceased gave RM197,000, RM225,000 or RM512,063.70 to Cheng Poon.

Accordingly, the absence of any evidence, not even a bare assertion, the payments: (a) RM197,000, RM225,000, RM512,063.70 to Cheng Poon, (b) RM139,000 to Gim Chuan, and (c) RM121,567.35 to Richard, were not gifts. Accordingly, as the denials were disproved, the payments: (c) RM225,000 to Howard, and, (d) RM225,000 to Bok Eng, were indeed received by Bok Eng and Howard who failed to offer any reason or justification.

That leaves the RM352,000 that Howard said was given to him for his schooling fund and for a car. Both Richard and Howard testified that the deceased only gave them RM50 a week. Whilst Richard was overseas, the deceased gave him US1,000. When Richard returned to Penang, the deceased gave him RM50 a week. Whilst Howard was overseas, the deceased gave him US$1,500 a month. Both admitted that the deceased before June 1992 had never given them any other monies. Howard admitted that the deceased before June 1992 had never given him any money to buy a car.

Evidently, the deceased was not one who would allow his grandchildren, even those with him and therefore in the lap of luxury, to be spoilt by his wealth. The moment Richard and Howard returned to Penang, he discontinued their overseas allowance and put them back on the local meager weekly allowance RM50), even though Richard and Howard were grown men by then. He was also not one who would mollycoddle or pander to his children. When he gave RM14,000 to Cheng Bok, he took in return three houses in Kulim. He gave a fixed monthly allowance (RM1,400, according to Beng Tatt) to Cheng Hum, Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat, though he shouldered as well their education/other expenses — RM1,000 to Cheng Hum, RM1,000 to Cheng Liat and RM5,000 to Cheng Bok. To Cheng Poon, the son under his aegis, gave an occasional RM1,000 to RM3,000. Bok Eng and Gim Chuan each received RM50 a week. Sally Khaw, Cheng Liat's first wife was given �200 a year. Yes, the deceased had riches and wealth, but he was also prudent and restrained in his ways. Indeed, a large brood as a millstone, the deceased had no choice but to be prudent and restrained, even though it was never a case of pinch and scrape, in his spending. He was not one who would play ducks and drakes with his money. He had far too good a head on his shoulders. As Beng Tatt said, 'the deceased was not easy or free with his money. He was concerned about his cash flow'. Neither was the deceased easy on his children's profligate ways, as he was angry, according to Richard, that Cheng Bok had charged the house he had given Cheng Bok. He was careful with money, to the extent that he maintained a record, who else accountable only to himself would do so, of his ancestral worship expenses.

The deceased was also one who could not afford to waste or throw away his money. He was rich, property wise, but he was not rolling in hard cash. From 1987, at least, he was constantly dogged by cash flow problems. He had to sell (a portion of Holding 10, 11(1) and 12, Mukim 14 NE District Ayer Itam) borrow (RM1.5m from the BBMB) to keep the pot boiling. Hamid testified that the deceased needed the money. The deceased even forced Cheng Hum to sell the remaining Ayer Itam lands with him. The deceased could not wait for the land value to rise. According to Richard, in 1991 and 1992, the deceased was desperate for cash, to travel, to spend and primarily to settle his overdraft, and the deceased instructed brokers to sell his properties, including the Teluk Bahang land. Teoh Seng Chye testified that the overdraft account in 1991 was turning bad. Evidently, the deceased was going through a thin time. Then in 1991, as if god-sent, the Batu Ferringhi land was sold. Reasonably, the balance sales proceeds bringing deliverance but only payable in June 1992 would have been eagerly awaited. Reasonably, the deceased could not play ducks and drakes, and neither was it his nature, with the balance sales proceeds from the Batu Ferringhi land.

Then what was the reason for that orgy of handouts in June 1992 when the sales proceeds from the Batu Ferringhi land all but dissipated in the space of a few short days? The following exchange is both telling and pertinent.

row.entry: How (would) you explain all these large sums in June 1992?
He had cash only in June 1992, the proceeds from the Batu Ferringhi land.

p.text: Was that a plausible or reasonable explanation for that orgy of handouts in June 1992? He who had never given more than RM50 a week to Bok Eng, Richard, Howard and Gim Chuan, was suddenly handing out hundreds of thousands of ringgit to them. He who had never given more than an occasional RM1,000 to RM3,000 to Cheng Poon, was suddenly handing out close to RM2m to Cheng Poon. He who had not done so before was dishing out money like water, like it was going out of fashion, like there was no tomorrow, all seemingly without any care that it was totally improvident. It was certainly improvident, nay, beneath improvident, as the deceased in December 1992, when he was yet not aware that he was having cancer and therefore would not be emptying his pockets, had less than RM10,000 — money that would not even tide himself let alone children and grandchildren over. It was just midsummer madness. Richard testified that the deceased intended just before he died to travel to Europe and purchase the latest Mercedes 600 SEL. Sadly, if that was true, the deceased was not even aware that his money was no longer in his hands.

Is it to be believed that the deceased suddenly abandoned his life long commitment to his children and grandchildren when he received the balance sales proceeds in June 1992? Is it to be believed that the deceased who needed the money (Hamid's testimony), who was desperate for cash to spend and to travel (Richard's testimony) and who quarreled bitterly with his eldest son (Cheng Hum's testimony) because his eldest son would not yield to his demand for the sale of the Ayer Itam lands to raise needed cash, would give it all away within the space of a few short days in June 1992? And is it to be believed that the deceased upon receipt of the balance sales proceeds was suddenly seized only by concern for Cheng Poon and his family to the extent that he divested his entire purse and even put himself in a highly disadvantageous position? Or as there a systematic exploitation of an old and sickly man at death's door? Were those around him lining their pockets?

As the saying goes, 'the proof of the pudding is in the eating'. There is no point in looking for any direct proof of any undue influence, for there is none, as the 'donor', a case of 'dead men tell no tales', is not around, and the 'donees', even if they exerted undue influence, did not and surely were not expected to say so. The indirect evidence, the facts and circumstances of the case was the litmus test. To recall Lord Scarmand, National Westminster Bank plc v Morgan
[1985] 1 All ER 821
at 831:

… it is the unimpeachability at law of a disadvantageous transaction which is the starting point from which the court advances to consider whether the transaction is the product merely of one's folly or of the undue influence exercised by another. A court in the exercise of this equitable jurisdiction is a court of conscience. Definition is a poor instrument when used to determine whether a transaction is or is not unconscionable: this is a question which depends on the particular facts of the case.

And the facts of this case were not edifying. They were shocking. In June 1992, the balance sale proceeds payable in June 1992 was received. In May/June 1992, Howard returned home from the States. Perhaps that was a coincidence. On 17 June 1992, Cheng Poon received RM197,000, RM866,000 and RM512,063.70; Bok Eng received RM225,000 and Howard received RM225,000. Perhaps that was a one off splurge. A day later, on 18 July 1992, Cheng Poon received RM225,000 and Howard received RM39,000 and RM182,000. Perhaps that was a sequel to the one off splurge. Eight days later, on 26 June 1992, Howard received RM31,000 and Gim Chuan received RM31,000. Perhaps that was a sequel to a sequel. But that was not the end. Three days later, on 29 June 1992, Howard received RM100,000 while Gim Chuan received RM100,000. In June/July 1992, Richard received RM121,567.35. On or about 3 July 1992, Cheng Poon instructed the early settlement of the loan outstanding (RM282,547.62) on the Rolls-Royce that Richard said the deceased gave to Cheng Poon. RM1,436,781.57 was paid to redeem the Teluk Bahang land that Lim said was given to Cheng Poon. RM750,000 was paid to 'brokers'. And so, inevitably, the coffers were emptied.

All in all, Cheng Poon and his family 'picked up' a total of RM4,573,960.51 [cash of RM2,854,631.32, RM282,547.62 for the redemption of the Rolls-Royce, RM1,436,781.57 for the redemption of the Teluk Bahang land], a veritable lion's share, or about 72% of the approximately RM6.3m received in June/July 1992 (see p 9 of the bundle of all agreed facts). Speaking of a lion's share, practically nothing was received by the other siblings. Obviously, the rhetorical question is whether Cheng Poon and his family could have had their incredible run of good fortune within the space of a few short days in June/July 1992, when they were receiving and receiving, whilst the deceased was just showering and showering tranche upon tranche on them.

It has already been said that the asserted gifts were not proved as gifts at all. Cheng Poon and family could not have had that incredible run of good fortune to the total exclusion of all others. Yes, the deceased had a soft spot for Cheng Poon. That was evident from the fact that Cheng Poon had more shares in the Thai corporate and a large provision in almost every pre-1990 will. But that is not to say that the deceased only cared for Cheng Poon. The deceased cared for all his children. It was just a matter of degree. He would not have forgotten or left the rest of his children to the elements. He amply demonstrated that in the case of Cheng Been, his luckless schizophrenic son, for whom he set up a special trust to ensure surely that Cheng Been would be financially supported even after him. The deceased did not just put bread on the table. He showed compassion to. According to Dr Tan, the deceased enquired on a breakthrough in the treatment for Cheng Been, sought his advice on medical treatment for Cheng Been in the United Kingdom and discussed the new drug that would be administered to Cheng Been. So, even as he was wrapped up with his own testamentary capacity, the deceased had not forgotten his hapless schizophrenic son. That was the measure of the deceased. The deceased had all his children (except Liang Imm), able or disabled, under his wings. In all pre-1990 wills, deceased provided for all his children and grandchildren. His sons (including Cheng Been) and eight of his grandchildren were given shares in the Thai corporate. All his sons received monthly allowances. He gave allowances to most of his grandchildren. He educated Cheng Bok and Cheng Poon's children. He also educated Grace. He gave an allowance to Bok Eng. He paid the expenses of Cheng Bok's wives. He gave money to Cheng Bok to marry a third time. He purchased a factory and installed Cheng Liat as the manager. He purchased a rubber estate and installed Cheng Hum as the estate supervisor. He gave properties to all his sons. Except for Liang Imm, apparently none was not provided for in one way or another. To the deceased, it could be said even that taking care of his children and grandchildren was his mission in life. It was probably second nature too. So why should a large sum of money in June/July 1992, even though some RM6.3m, as if the deceased was a mendicant who had never tasted money, change a habit of a life time? Indeed, there was no reason after all the years and then in the final flush to change at all.

As said, the deceased had a soft spot for Cheng Poon. Reasonably, a gift here and a gift there to Cheng Poon or his family would have been entirely plausible. After all, the deceased could not be expected to be equal to all his children. But it was not the character of the man to hand out tranche upon tranche to the point of total exhaustion of all that could be given to only one son. It was not the character of the man to be totally partial to one son, as he was reasonably even handed with all his sons. He gave allowances to the sons who were not gainfully employed (Cheng Hum and Cheng Poon) but not to the sons with a livelihood (Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat). But when Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat retired, he gave them monthly allowances just as well. To each son, he gave properties. Really, the deceased looked after all, and unless he had taken leave of his senses or was subjected to pressure, he would not have been as partial to Cheng Poon and his family as it would appear he was in June 1992. Hamid, Beng Tatt, Cheng Bok, and Cheng Liat all testified that the deceased agreed to carry out the wishes of his wife in giving Cheng Bok, Cheng Poon and Cheng Liat each 15% of the sales proceeds of the Batu Ferringhi land. The deceased was a man of his word. Then why would he not give to Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat their share of the sales proceeds of the land he inherited from his wife? In June 1992, there was more than enough to settle the RM866,000 to all three sons. There was no question of it not being enough. It was only not enough only because everything in the main went into the pockets of Cheng Poon and his family. But surely, being a man of his word, the deceased would have given to Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat their due, would he not, and being a man of prudence, the deceased would have save on the interests paid to Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat from July 1992 to April 1993, would he not, than lavishing it on some wishy-washy, how else to be described, 'so long as he would finish his education' schooling fund and for a car.

Mr Koh submitted that the reasons offered by the donees were not relevant. He contended that the reasons could be an excuse to ask for money, and that the excuse might have been disbelieved. He further contended that a gift per se is no ground to infer undue influence, unless that gift is so large or the transaction so improvident as not to be reasonably accounted for on the ground of friendship, relationship or ordinary motives. He added that there was no evidence of an improvident or large gift.

With respect, if the reason for a gift is not relevant, then how could the good faith of a transaction be judged? By just blindly accepting the donee's ipse dixit assertion, even if the 'donor' is not around to give his version? And if the reason for a gift is not relevant, then how would donors be protected from being forced, tricked or misled in any way by others into parting with their property? Surely, an alleged gift must be proved, and only if a gift is proved will the law not question the rationale no matter how capricious for the gift.

To get back on track, the only reason given for any of the monetary 'gifts' was that the deceased gave RM352,000 to Howard for his schooling fund and for a car. Other than Howard, none of the other 'donees' claimed that they received gifts from the deceased. not Cheng Poon, not Bok Eng, not Richard and Not Gim Chuan. Howard admitted that the deceased never gave him any money before June 1992 to buy a car. Howard admitted that the deceased only gave him RM50 a week. Then, it was entirely inconceivable that the deceased who controlled his spending and run a tight ship, relatively speaking, would have given Howard RM352,000 for a 'so long as he would finish his education' schooling fund and for a car.

Beyond any question, deceased was worth many millions, many times over. A gift of RM352,000, in the light of his many millions, would not be so large or so improvident as would not be reasonably accounted for on the ground of his love for a grandchild. But it would be wrong to judge that RM352,000 in isolation, as that transaction was but one link in the chain of transactions that shackled the deceased so that he only had RM10,000 at the end of 1992 and RM14,000 on the day he died, the final link being Cheng Poon's withdrawal RM140,000) a day before the deceased died when the deceased was in a coma, a final link that told its own tale, forcefully as well as graphically, that Cheng Poon, Bok Eng, Richard and Howard were taking and taking all that they could lay their hands on. Richard testified that that RM140,000 had been accounted for. But that was not pleaded. A gift was all that was pleaded.

With regard to the cars, Cheng Poon did not testify that the deceased gave him the Rolls-Royce and a Mercedes Benz 380 SEL. Only Richard said that the deceased gave those two cars to Cheng Poon. Richard also testified that Cheng Poon purchased the Ladybird and a Nissan sports car, and that Cheng Poon purchased the Ladybird with his own funds. But Richard did not testify that the deceased had gave him the BMW (BCU 8). Accordingly, except for the Rolls-Royce, Mercedes Benz 380 and Porsche, there was no evidence at all of a gift of any of the deceased's cars to Cheng Poon and his family.

However, the evidence was not consistent with a gift of the Rolls-Royce and Mercedes Benz 380 to Cheng Poon. It was only consistent with those cars being held by Cheng Poon for the deceased. The evidence clearly showed that the deceased registered his cars in the names of others. Hamid testified, and he was not challenged, that the deceased had several cars in the names of Cheng Poon and Richard and that the deceased told him that Cheng Poon and Richard were holding the cars for Cheng Bok, Cheng Liat and Cheng Poon. On the same point, Beng Tatt who testified that the deceased registered his cars in Cheng Poon and Richard's names was also not challenged. Dr Tan testified, whilst he was cross-examined by Mr Koh, that the deceased said to him (on 27 January 1993) that he (the deceased) purchased six cars — Rolls-Royce, Mercedes-Benz, BMW, Porsche, Peugeot and Chrysler Alpine — for his pleasure and for the use of his family, but that the Porsche was for his grandson, the Peugeot for his sons and the rest were 'for his pleasure'. Richard testified that sometime in early 1992, the deceased purchased a Rolls-Royce but registered it in his father's name. Richard also testified that in 1990/1991, the deceased purchased a BMW (BCU 8) but registered it in his name. Further, according to Richard, after the purchase of the Rolls-Royce, the deceased asked Cheng Poon to transfer a Mercedes 380 SEL to Cheng Poon, and the deceased also asked Cheng Poon to transfer a Mercedes Benz 280 purchased in 1988/1989 to Cheng Bok. According to Richard, the deceased had a passion for cars and always had 'a string of cars'. 'The deceased would have, at the very least, three cars at any point in time.' 'The deceased always had a beautiful sedan and other cars for His daily use.' Perhaps the Porsche, because Dr Tan said that the deceased said to him that the Porsche was for his grandson, was a gift to Richard. But where are those other cars of the deceased at any point in time?

The facts and circumstances showed that the coffers of the deceased were empty because it was broken into and that the cars (other than the Porsche) were expropriated. It had been proved, even if the plaintiffs had the burden of proving undue influence, that the facts and circumstances attending the gifts were entirely consistent with undue influence but entirely inconsistent with any other hypothesis.

Furthermore, and it was not the father and son relationship per se, undue influence could be presumed. The deceased, at death's door, totally dependent, and in that sense beholden, to Cheng Poon and his family. From the evidence adduced, there existed that close confidential relationship where Cheng Poon and his family were persons with great influence and pull over the life of the deceased and in a commanding position to exert undue influence or 'dominion' over the deceased; the deceased and Cheng Poon, with regard to the gifts, were not persons dealing on a footing of equality.

Mr Kok submitted that the monetary gifts to Cheng Poon and his family were advancement from a father to his child. With respect, that was not the big picture. As said, the proof of the pudding is in the eating. The proved or admitted facts showed that the relationship between the donor and donee at or shortly before the execution of the gifts had been such as to raise a presumption that the donee had great influence over the donor — a natural consequence of the condition of the parties. Cheng Poon and his family took substantial benefits and unusual amounts from the deceased and the burden of proving good faith of the transactions was upon him and his family, the party in a position of active confidence. Indeed, to a very high degree of probability, those transactions could not have been if Cheng Poon and his family had not been able to dominate the will of the deceased and had not used their position to obtain an advantage. The gifts were so large and so improvident as not to be reasonably accounted for on the ground of the relationship between the deceased and Cheng Poon and his family. In particular, the monetary transactions appeared on the face of it to be wholly unconscionable. In either case, whether under
s 111
of the Evidence Act or s 16(3) of the Contracts Act, Cheng Poon and his family — who stood in such a relationship that while its continued confidence was necessarily reposed by the deceased and influence possessed by Cheng Poon and his family — were called upon to act with good faith and they had the burden of proving that the gifts were not brought about by undue influence. And they who had the burden of proof of absence of undue influence failed to show that the transactions were fair and reasonable, that no advantage had been taken of his position and that no information which should have been communicated had been withheld. They failed to dispel bad faith. Undue influence, that proved as well as presumed, was not rebutted. Strangely enough, Tan Beng Hin's evidence revealed that Cheng Poon, who had a duty to protect the deceased, even partook of, while his wife was paying out, and it could be ripping off, an unconscionable 10% sales commission (RM750,00) from the deceased. A son taking a commission from his father! Sadly, every imaginable pretext was used to draw off the deceased's money, whilst the deceased was in a coma, and until there was none at all. How could it not be said that the proved or admitted facts showed a relationship of confidence and an abuse of that confidence?

emph.emph: The substantial validity of the 1992 wills

p.text: Strictly speaking, since formal execution was not proved and also disproved, need it be said on the balance of probabilities, it should not be necessary to delve into the substantial validity of the 1992 wills. Nonetheless, it was still desirable to do so, as it substantiated the absence of all good faith in the transactions in 1992.

Howard testified that the deceased made corrections to the 1990 wills, handed him (Howard) corrected 1990 wills and told him (Howard) to type fresh wills following his (the deceased) corrections. Howard said he did not know why he was asked to prepare the 1992 wills. According to Howard, the following amendments were made to all 1990 wills: (i)�Howard substituting Khaw Teik Lim as a trustee, (ii) the variation of five years to 30 years, (iii) the reduction of Teik Hock's interests from 4% to 2% and that 2% to Howard, the reduction of Teik Ghim's interests from 4% to 2% and that 2% to Richard, (iv) Chye replacing Cheng Bok as a trustee in event of Cheng Bok's death, and (v) Howard replacing Cheng Poon in the event of Cheng Poon's death.
However, those five amendments that Howard listed were not the entire changes to the 1990 wills.

The 1992 Thai will made two major changes to the 1990 Thai will; (i)�whereas Cheng Poon (governing trustee), Cheng Bok, Richard and Teik Lim were the trustees, it then appointed Cheng Poon (governing trustee), Cheng Bok, Richard and Howard as the trustees, and, (ii) whereas it was silent, it then provided that Richard shall be the governing trustee in the event of the death of Cheng Poon and that Howard shall be the governing trustee in the event of the death of Richard.

The 1992 US will made three major changes to the 1990 US will; (i)�whereas Cheng Poon (governing trustee), Cheng Bok, Richard and Teik Lim were the trustees, it then appointed Cheng Poon (governing trustee), Cheng Bok, and Howard as the trustees, (ii) whereas it was silent, it then provided that Richard shall be the governing trustee in the event of the death of Cheng Poon and that Howard shall be the governing trustee in the event of the death of Richard, and, (iii) Poon's beneficial interests was increased from ⅓ to 40%, whilst Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat's respective interest was reduced to 30% from ⅓.

The 1992 Malaysian will made seven major changes to the 1990 Malaysian will; (i) whereas Cheng Poon (governing trustee), Cheng Bok, Richard and Teik Lim were the trustees, it then appointed Cheng Poon (governing trustee), Cheng Bok, Richard and Howard as the trustees, (ii)�whereas it was silent, it provided that Richard shall be the governing trustee in the event of the death of Cheng Poon and that Howard shall be the governing trustee in the event of the death of Richard, (iii) with regard to Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd, the beneficial interests of Cheng Poon was increased from 15% to 16%, of Richard from 3% to 6%, of Howard from 3% to 6% whilst the beneficial interests of Cheng Liat was reduced from 15% to 14% and of Teik Hock/Teik Gim from 4% to 1%, (iv) whereas it provided that Pykett Avenue could not be sold within five years from the date of death of the deceased, it was then silent, (v) whereas it provided that Pykett Avenue shall be maintained for five years, it was then silent, (vi) Cheng Poon's beneficial interest was increased from 30% to 40% whilst Cheng Liat's ⅓ beneficial interest was reduced to a 30% life interest which the trustees 'shall be at liberty to dispose of the said 30% in any manner as they deem fit', and, (vii) Cheng Poon's interests to the residue of the estate was increased from ⅓ to 40% whilst Cheng Bok's interest was reduced from ⅓ to 30% and whilst Cheng Liat's ⅓ beneficial interest in the residue of the estate was reduced to a 30% life interest which the trustees 'shall be at liberty to dispose of the said 30% in any manner as they deem fit'.

With respect to Mr Koh who contended that there was not much difference between the 1990 and 1992 wills, even Howard could see that the impact of the 1992 wills was immense. Both the 1990 and 1992 wills had Cheng Poon as the governing trustee. The 1990 wills provided 'that all decisions of the trustees shall be with the written consent of at least three trustees one of whom shall be Cheng Poon'. It means that any decision of the trustees must have the written consent of Cheng Poon. But Cheng Poon even as governing trustee and with Richard's support would not control the estate, as all 'decisions shall be with the consent of at least three trustees'. Likewise, Cheng Bok and Teik Lim would not control the estate. Therefore, under the 1990 wills, there was a fine balance between Cheng Bok and Cheng Poon, even though Cheng Poon who could not be outvoted by the other trustees had a personal edge.
Clauses 5, 6 and 7 of the 1990 Malaysian will read as follows:

5 Notwithstanding cl 4 of this my said will, I hereby direct that my shares in Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd shall not be transferred to the beneficiaries referred to in cl 4 until after five (5) years of my death and in the meantime such shares shall be registered in the names of my trustees who shall hold the shares upon trust to transfer them to my said beneficiaries after five years of my death provided that:

(a) after my death and for the period of five (5) years of my death my trustees shall not dispose of or otherwise deal with the fixed asset of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd. held in the property known as Lot�951, TS 13, Georgetown, North East District, Penang together with the building erected thereon bearing assessment No 20, Pykett Avenue, 10400 Penang;

(b) after my death and for the period of five (5) years of my death my trustees shall have the right to dispose of or otherwise deal with any other asset or property of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd if such a disposal or dealing is in their opinion beneficial to the interests of my said beneficiaries referred to in cl 4 of this my said will and or for the purpose of paying for the expenses, and other charges incurred or payable by the said company;

(c) in the event after my death and for the period of five (5) years there is insufficient funds in Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd to pay for expenses, taxes and other charges incurred and payable by the said company, I authorize my trustees to borrow funds from the general income of my estate in order to loan the same to the company to enable the company to pay its dues without fail.

6 After my death and for the period of five (5) years of my death my trustees shall continue to maintain in good state of repair my house at No 20, Pykett Avenue, 10400 Penang. My trustees shall continue to employ the staff of my said house such as the cook, the servant, the clerk, gardener, the guard and the driver and my trustees shall continue to pay their salary and benefit-in-kind at the same rate and amount as they were receiving immediately prior to my death. I authorize my trustees to utilise funds from the general income of my estate in order to pay for the maintenance of my said house and its yard in good state of repair and to pay the salaries and benefit-in-kind of the house staff as well as for other miscellaneous expenses payable and incurred in respect of my said house.

7 After my death and for the period of five (5) years of my death at least one of my trustees shall take up full-time residence in my house at No�20, Pykett Avenue, 10400 Penang in the capacity of caretaker. The trustee who resides in the said house shall vacate the residence if there is an offer to purchase my said house and property after the period of five (5) years. The said trustee residing in my said house shall forthwith surrender and deliver vacant possession of my said house to the Trustees.
However, under the 1992 wills, 'all decisions shall be with the written consent of all trustees (or a majority) of the trustees'.
Clauses 5, 6 and 7 of the 1992 Malaysian will read as follows.

5 Notwithstanding cl 4 of this my said will, I hereby direct that my shares in Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd shall not be transferred to the beneficiaries referred to in the said cl 4 until after thirty (30) years of my death and in the meantime such shares shall be registered in the names of my trustees who shall hold the shares upon trust to transfer them to my said beneficiaries after thirty (30) years of my death, provided that:

(a) after my death my trustees shall have the right to dispose of or otherwise deal with any asset or property of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd if such disposal or dealing is in their opinion beneficial to the interest of my said beneficiaries referred to in cl 4 of this my said will and/or for the purpose of paying for The expenses, taxes and other charges incurred or payable by the said company;

(b) in the event after my death and for the period of thirty (30) years of my death there is insufficient funds in Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd to pay for expenses, taxes and other charges incurred and payable by the said company, I authorize my trustees to borrow funds from the general income of my estate in order to loan the same to the company to pay its dues without fail.

6 After my death my trustees shall continue to maintain in good state of repair my house at No 20, Pykett Avenue, 10400 Penang. My trustees as they see fit shall continue to employ the staff of my said house such as the cook, the servant, the clerk, gardener, the guard and the driver and my trustees shall continue to pay their salary and benefit-in-kind at the same rate and amount as they were receiving immediately prior to my death. I authorize my trustees to utilise funds form the general income of my estate in order to pay for the maintenance of my said house and its yard in good state of repair and to pay the salaries and benefit-in-kind of the house staff as well as for other miscellaneous expenses payable and incurred in respect of my said house.

7 After my death at least one of my trustees shall take up full-time residence in my house at No 20, Pykett Avenue, 10400 Penang in the capacity of caretaker. The trustee who resides in the said house shall vacate the residence if there is an offer to purchase my said house and property. The said trustee residing in my said house shall forthwith surrender and deliver vacant possession of my said house to the trustees.

Since three of the four trustees were Cheng Poon and his sons, it means that Cheng Poon and his sons would control the estate in Malaysia, Thailand and the US whilst Cheng Bok, who would always be outvoted, should it come to that, would be making up the numbers. Cheng Bok would be a frigid trustee. Real control would vest with Cheng Poon and his sons. The delicate balance so astutely formulated under the 1990 wills was totally discarded.

Also, under the 1990 Malaysian will, and for a period of five years, (i)�the trustees could not sell Pykett Avenue or any other property of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd [see 5(a) and 5(b)], (ii) Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd, a company without business and merely holding Pykett Avenue would be financially supported by the estate [see 5(c)], (iii) Pykett Avenue with the estate's support would be maintained in a good state of repair (see 6), (iv)�the employees of the deceased would be retained (see 6), and (v) one trustee at least would reside at Pykett Avenue. Reading cll 5, 6 and 7 of the 1990 Malaysian will as a whole, and all three clauses were geared towards the period five years after the death of the deceased, the deceased clearly intended that Pykett Avenue shall be retained for five years after his death. During those five years, Pykett Avenue could not be sold whilst the shares of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd could not be distributed; reasonably, at the end of five years and because Pykett Avenue could not be sold, the beneficiaries of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd would be transferred shares of a company with a valuable asset — Pykett Avenue. Clearly, all those three clauses were designed to retain and maintain Pykett Avenue until the appointed date (five years), so that the shares to be transferred to the beneficiaries on the appointed date would enjoy the intrinsic value of Pykett Avenue.

However, under the 1992 Malaysian will, and because cl 5(a) of the 1990 Malaysian will was discarded, the sale of Pykett Avenue could be effected even prior to the appointed date (30 years) for the transfer of the shares to the beneficiaries. Indeed, cl 5(a) of the 1992 Malaysian will expressly provided that the trustees 'shall have the right to dispose of or otherwise deal with any asset or property of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd'. There arose the incongruity between cll 5, 6 and 7 of the 1992 Malaysian will.

Clause 5(a) of the 1992 Malaysian will provided that the shares of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd, 'shall not be transferred to the beneficiaries … until after thirty (30) years of (the) death of the deceased' and that 'in the meantime such shares shall be registered in the names of the trustees'. Since there was no restriction on the sale of Pykett Avenue, then there was no reason, unlike the 1990 Malaysian will, to prohibit the transfer of the shares for 30 years. Alternatively, since Pykett Avenue could be sold at any given time, it was only reasonable, was it not, so that the beneficiaries would enjoy the intrinsic value of Pykett Avenue, that the transfer of the shares should be effected immediately upon the sale of Pykett Avenue and not some 30 years after the death of the deceased. Moreover, since Pykett Avenue could be sold at any given time, there was reason only to support Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd. until the sale of Pykett Avenue and not for 30�years. The intent of cl 5(c) of the 1990 Malaysian will [cl 5(b) of the 1992 Malaysian will is in similar terms], reading cll 5, 6 and 7 of the 1990 Malaysian will as a whole, was to maintain Pykett Avenue until the distribution of the shares of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd. Reasonably, there was no reason, in the absence of a restriction in the 1992 Malaysian will on the sale of Pykett Avenue for 30 years, to support Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd for 30 years.

But things do not exist in vacuum. As said, under the 1992 wills, Cheng Poon and his sons would control the Malaysian, Thai and US estates. Clause 5 of the 1992 Malaysian will provided that the shares of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd until transfer to the beneficiaries shall be registered in the names of the trustees. It means that Cheng Poon and his sons would also control Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd until the year 2023.

Clause 5(b) of the 1992 Malaysian will authorized the trustees 'in the event … and for the period of thirty (30) years … there is insufficient funds in Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd to pay for the expenses, taxes and other charges incurred and payable by the said company' to borrow funds from the general income of the estate and 'loan the same to the company to pay its dues without fail'. Clause 6 of the 1992 Malaysian will authorized the trustees to borrow from the general income of the estate 'to pay for the maintenance of (Pykett Avenue) and its yard in good state of repair and to pay the salaries and benefit-in-kind of the house staff as well as for other miscellaneous expenses payable and incurred in respect of (Pykett Avenue)'. Unlike the 1990 Malaysian will, there was no specified period in the 1992 Malaysian will for the maintenance of Pykett Avenue and for the retention of the staff of Pykett Avenue. Clause 7 of the 1992 Malaysian will provided that 'at least one of the trustees shall take up full-time residence at Pykett Avenue in the capacity of caretaker' and that that trustee 'shall vacate Pykett Avenue if there is an offer to purchase Pykett Avenue'. Unlike the 1990 Malaysian will, the 1992 Malaysian will did not specify the period of residence of the trustee at Pykett Avenue.

It all means that Cheng Poon and his sons, in total control of the estate and Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd could: (i) sell Pykett Avenue as and when they dictate, or, (ii) reside at Pykett Avenue — with the house and retinue of attendants maintained at the costs of the estate — until the year 2023. In the case of the sale of Pykett Avenue, they would control the sales proceeds until 2023, or, in the event that Pykett Avenue is not sold, then for a period of 30 years, they could 'utilise funds from the general income of the) estate … to pay for the maintenance of (the) house and its yard in good state of repair and … the salaries and benefit-in-kind of the house staff as well as for other miscellaneous expenses payable and incurred in respect of the said house' (see cl 6). Either case, by the year 2023, considering what Cheng Poon and his sons could pull off in the space of a few days in June 1992, would there be anything worth the while for any of the beneficiaries to have their shares in the company or would there be anything left in the estate after 30 years' borrowings from Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd? Well, probably not for Liang Imm, Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat who are in their sixties and would probably not be around in 2023. Probably, Cheng Poon would also not be around to account to the beneficiaries.

Clauses 5, 6 and 7 of the 1992 Malaysian will serve exclusively to benefit Cheng Poon and his two sons. In control of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd, they could deal with the company and its assets (Pykett Avenue or the sale proceeds) as they please. They could 'borrow funds from the general income of (the) estate in order to loan the same to the company to pay its dues without fail' for 30 years. There is no restriction on the trustees borrowing from the estate, even after the sale of Pykett Avenue. For 30 years, the estate would have to sustain Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd. The company could drain, or could be the vehicle to drain the estate. But who would benefit? Cheng Poon and his sons occupy Pykett Avenue. Their stay at Pykett Avenue would be supported by the estate for 30 years. Richard is the Managing Director of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd, and he was taking a monthly salary of RM14,000 even though the company had no business and was merely holding Pykett Avenue and even though a salary of RM2,500 could not reasonably commensurate with the work and responsibility. The other beneficiaries of Khaw Ban Cheng Sdn Bhd, despite their overwhelming majority interest would be out in the cold. They would have to wait until the year 2023 for their shares. By then, Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd could have totally drained the estate of all assets and Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd could have nothing at all. And Richard's proclivity was not undocumented. By letter dated 28 December 1995 [PB3(1)], Richard as Managing Director of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd. applied to the receiver and manager for a RM190,000 advance. As a director of the Thai company, and there was no evidence that he was doing any real work, he was taking, Richard admitted he was taking without lawful authority, a monthly salary of Baht40,000.

Without any restriction on the sale of Pykett Avenue, and because for 30 years the trustees could borrow from the estate [either under cll 5(b) or 6], cll 5, 6 and 7 of the 1992 Malaysian will could only benefit Cheng Poon and his two sons. Only they would be comfortably ensconced for the next 30 years which could probably be the rest of Cheng Poon's life. As said, the deceased cared for all his children. In 1989, when Cheng Liat complained about the inequity of the 1989 deed, the deceased consulted a number of solicitors and held a number of meetings to verify that complaint. The deceased was angry, when it was confirmed that Cheng Poon would control a number of his properties. Surely, the deceased would be angrier still if Cheng Poon and his sons would have absolute control of all his properties, and if Cheng Poon and his sons, meanwhile, would derive all benefit whilst the other beneficiaries would have to wait, for 30 years, for their beneficial interest or what would be left then to be distributed to them. When Cheng Bok, Cheng Poon and Cheng Liat pleaded to the deceased that they were in their sixties and that the retention of Pykett Avenue for 10 years would be too long, the deceased reduced it to 5 years, a fact confirmed by Nik Saghir and a fact reflected in the 1990 Malaysian will.

Then, how could it be that the 1992 Malaysianwill provided that the shares shall be transferred after 30 years, one generation (who amongst the Cheng generation would be alive in 2023?) and subjecting the next generation, save Richard and Howard, to a guessing game [because of cll 5(b) and 6] for 30 years. The deceased, if he was the author of the 1992 wills, not have played such a diabolical trick on his beneficiaries.

Mr Koh submitted that the benefit to the person preparing the will is only a circumstance for some suspicion. 'Suspicion to invalidate a will must be that grave as to override all other evidence propounding the will,' he said. 'These are no facts to arouse any suspicion in this case.'

Except that Mr Koh totally forgot that the benefit to the person preparing the 1992 wills and to his nuclear family was so absolute and so complete, whilst the interests of the other beneficiaries were so subservient to the dominion and authority of the person preparing the 1992 wills and to his nuclear family that it could not not be asked if the person preparing the 1992 wills was the author of the 1992 wills. Cheng Bok asked that of Cheng Poon. According to Cheng Bok, Cheng Poon said to him that his (Cheng Poon) sons forged the 1992 wills. Of course, what Cheng Bok testified what Cheng Poon said was not evidence that Richard and Howard forged or authored the 1992 wills. But what Cheng Bok testified that Cheng Poon said was evidence of what Cheng Bok heard from Cheng Poon, evidence of a statement that Cheng Poon sphinx-like throughout the trial did not deny. It could only be presumed that it could not be denied. Again strangely enough, the pleadings supported the case that Howard and or Richard could have authored the 1992 wills. Howard said that he followed the amendments of the deceased. Richard denied all knowledge of the preparation and or execution of the 1992 wills. Bok Eng said she had no knowledge that Howard was preparing the 1992 wills. However, that was not how they pleaded their case. Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard pleaded that the deceased having lost trust in the rest of his family only permitted them (and they meant themselves) and Bok Eng to be party in the preparation of the 1992 wills. That being their pleaded case, then Richard and Bok Eng's denials of knowledge of the preparation of the 1992 wills, since it was not pleaded and since it was a radical departure from their pleaded case, could not be considered. Rather, the evidence was that Bok Eng knew of the execution of the 1992 wills, as Beng Tatt testified that Bok Eng told him in the morning of 3 August 1992, that 'they have made arrangements for Lim and Dr Gafoor's presence in the house and that an appointment has been made with one Dr Tan'. And what part Cheng Poon, Richard and Bok Eng played in the preparation of the 1992 wills was not explained nor clarified.

A further circumstance for suspicion, grave suspicion, was the proximity between the stroke, the 24 July 1992 deeds, the two PAs to Cheng Poon, the transfer and the execution of the 1992 wills, and the trips to China and the US.

On 12 July 1992, the deceased suffered a stroke. On 17 July 1992, the deceased was discharged from the hospital. On 24 July 1992, the deceased executed the 24 July 1992 deeds in favour of Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat, granted a limited PA to Cheng Poon. On 3 August 1992, the deceased 'executed' a general PA to Cheng Poon, 'executed' a transfer of the Teluk Bahang land to Cheng Poon, and 'executed' the 1992 wills. Therefore, just about two weeks after discharge from hospital, unholy haste some would say, the deceased executed' two 24 July 1992 deeds, two (2) Powers of Attorney and 1992 wills — seven instruments in all. Mr Koh contended that the deceased was settling his earthly affairs. That might have been if only the events of June 1992 could be disregard. However, and taking into account the events of June 1992 and the fact that the 1992 wills were altogether slanted towards Cheng Poon and his sons, the indelible impression was that all was done double time to seize control of the estate before the impending death of the deceased, a death forewarned by the stroke, rather than that the deceased was hurriedly settling his earthly affairs. Was it not obvious that the two PAs gave Cheng Poon all control whilst the deceased, struck down by further strokes or not, was alive and that the 1992 wills would give Cheng Poon and his sons all control if the deceased was dead? It was (almost), some would say, a master stroke.

A further unsettling fact was the trips to China and the US. The deceased was 87, well passed the average age, when he suffered a stroke. Surely, rest would have been the prescription. Yet, soon after the stroke but after the execution of the 1992 wills and the two PAs, Cheng Poon, and Bok Eng took the deceased on two long trips to China and to Taiwan and the US, as if those long excursions would not further weaken the deceased, and or, as if the deceased, since they were already in control, would not die fast enough.

There might have been another reason. Cheng Bok testified that he was informed each time he telephoned Pykett Avenue that the deceased was holidaying in Kuala Lumpur, and that Beng Tatt and Say Bee told him that Cheng Poon had instructed them not to inform him that the deceased was in Singapore. Hamid testified that two days before the deceased passed away he telephoned Pykett Avenue and he heard Bok Eng's voice in the background telling Cheng Poon not to inform him (Hamid) of the whereabouts of the deceased. All other children were not informed that the deceased was hospitalised in Singapore. Only when the deceased was in a coma in the intensive care unit, did Cheng Bok get to know of his father's condition. The other children got to know of their father's death.

Bok Eng testified that the deceased did not want to see the other children. Perhaps, the deceased was unhappy with Cheng Liat and or Cheng Hum. Perhaps, as Richard related, the deceased was unhappy with Cheng Bok who was always asking for money — Richard forgot that his family took almost all his money and the deceased, following his reasoning, would have been much more unhappy with his family. But why would the deceased at death's door not want to see Liang Imm, his only surviving daughter who visited him regularly, who never burdened him financially and who apparently held his affection? — in both 1990 and 1992 wills the deceased provided Liang Imm a greater beneficial share in Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd than the other children (including Cheng Poon) and grandchidren. And what plausible reason was there to explain why the deceased would not want to see the grandchildren he supported through the years for the last time? Bok Eng's explanation was just not plausible. She was also contradicted by Yeoh Keat Chye (DW2), a witness summoned by her family, who testified:
He spoke when he left for Singapore. The deceased told me that if anyone would look for him to tell them that he is in Singapore receiving treatment.
The following exchange is also pertinent:

row.entry: Hamid Merican testified … about two days before the deceased passed away, he called No 20 Pykett Avenue over the phone, heard your voice instructing the person receiving his telephone call not to tell where the deceased was. Do you agree?
Maybe I said so, maybe I did not.

p.text: It was a smug and haughty reply that did not erase but decidedly reinforced suspicion that the other children were kept away from the deceased. And Bok Eng would not have known of the last wishes of the deceased in the last days of his life, as she and Cheng Poon were in Penang (from 4 April 1993 to 9 April 1993) and with Cheng Poon busily cleaning out the last sen from the deceased's banking account. And now the two trips arranged by Cheng Poon to China and to the US (Beng Tatt's testimony that Cheng Poon arranged those trips was not challenged), within August 1992 to November 1992, could fit into a scheme of things. Consider the following. With the deceased in China and the US, the other siblings would not be able to reach the deceased, not learn of the 1992 wills and therefore could not lodge any protest (as was the case of the 1989 deed) against the 1992 wills. As it was, the 1992 wills were not disclosed to the other children until after the death of the deceased. From March 1993, to his other children, the deceased was hospitalised and there remained for six weeks until the day he died. Therefore, for a substantial period between 3 August 1992 until 10 April 1993 (the day the deceased died), the deceased was person a non communicado , a circumstance that did the 1992 wills no harm and suited the interests of Cheng Poon and his sons as well.

Sim Bee had one son — Joo Chie. Joo Chie had one son — the deceased. It would appear, if the alleged gifts and 1992 wills were transactions of good faith, that the deceased had only one son — Cheng Poon — and three lesser sons. But the deceased had not forgotten that he had more than one son, for even as he was dying and although his sons were not visiting him at Mount Elizabeth Hospital, he confided to Say Bee — his loyal servant of 50 years who remained steadfastly by his side throughout his stay at Mount Elizabeth Hospital — that the Teluk Bahang land was for Cheng Bok, Poon and Cheng Liat. Quite clearly, the deceased had not forgotten his other sons. He would not have abdicated all to one son.

The 1992 wills have the following untypical features. In each case, the attestation clause is the only text on a fresh page. That would have been handy in the reconstruction of the wills. The page with the attestation clause, in both the 1992 Thai and US wills, was not paginated. That should not be if the page with the attestation clause was printed after the preceding pages (Howard testified that he used Wordstar — a computer software this court is familiar with — in the preparation of the 1992 wills). In the case of the 1992 Thai will, none of the 6 pages in the first Schedule listing the Thai properties were paginated. Again, unless intentionally suppressed, the pagination of Those 6pp would have been automatically printed if those 6pp were printed after the preceding pages. In the case 1992 Thai will, cl 2 begins in p 2 and although there is sufficient space in p 1 to accommodate cl 2 (for a comparison, see second Thai will). If cl 2 is on p 1, then p 8 will have space to accommodate the attestation clause (for comparison, see second Thai will). Those features that dismembered the structure of the 1992 Thai and US wills are not inconsistent with a reconstruction. That is not to say though that there could not have been a legitimate explanation. It was just that nothing was explained.
The plaintiffs alleged that the 1992 wills were reconstructed. Howard did not give an explanation for the untypical and therefore questionable features of the 1992 wills he prepared.

The incredulous contention that the deceased was not senile and that therefore the gifts and 1992 wills were transactions of good faith, as if a non senile person could not be coerced or influenced, could not be accepted. It was so very clear, that Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard, by the device of the so-called gifts and 1992 wills, were salting away and securing their own nest in preparation of the impending death of the deceased.

emph.emph: The substantial validity of the 1990 wills

p.text: All parties agreed that the deceased executed the 1990 wills in the presence of Hamid and Ghazi Ishak, the attesting witnesses, on 24 October 1990. Only Cheng Hum and Grace disputed the substantial validity of the 1990 wills.

Cheng Hum and Grace contended that the deceased did not know nor approve of the contents of the 1990 wills. Mr Yeoh submitted that the certificates of Dr Tan could not be relied on, that the 1990 wills were not read to the deceased or brought to his knowledge in some other way and that the deceased was constrained by undue influence.

The witnesses who testified on the circumstances attending the preparation and execution of the 1990 wills were Hamid and Ghazi Ishak. The witness who specifically testified on testamentary capacity was Dr�Tan. However, there was no direct evidence that the deceased lacked the testamentary capacity when he executed the 1990 wills. Ruefully, the case of intestacy was particularly plagued by a paucity of evidence.

Mr Yeoh portrayed Hamid as a bete noire . He lambasted Dr Tan and his certificates. But he did not quarrel, and the others did not, with the testimony of Nik Saghir and Ghazi Ishak. According to Nik Saghir, in 1989 and in 1990, the deceased consulted him on his wills, and that he (Nik Saghir) advised the codicil executed at E & O Hotel Penang in March 1990. Nik Saghir also testified that the deceased enquired in June 1992 about the completion of the sale of the Teluk Bahang land. Ghazi Ishak testified that he had a conversation with the deceased on 24 October 1990 and that the deceased spoke in his usual manner. Clearly, the evidence of two impeccable witnesses supported the case on the sound disposing mind of the deceased.

Say Bee and Beng Tatt were also witnesses of truth. Mr Yeoh who did not quarrel with their testimony only found issue with Say Bee with regard to his evidence that the deceased was senile at about the end of 1991 but not at about the time of the execution of the 1990 wills as could suit the case that the deceased died intestate. Mr Yeoh also did not challenge Beng Tatt who testified — 'I believe … from February 1992 the deceased was not aware of what he was paying out … mostly he would stare at me' — that the memory of the deceased was only bad in 1992.

In their respective submissions, both Mr Koh and Mr Foo attacked the credibility of Say Bee and Beng Tatt and questioned their entire testimony. They submitted that the certificates of Dr Tan refuted senility and that therefore Say Bee and Beng Tatt who testified affirmatively on senility were not reliable witnesses whose entire testimony could not be relied on.

Apparently, Mr Yeoh, Mr Koh and Mr Foo all seemed to have equated senility with testamentary incapacity. But senility is infirmity resulting from deterioration of mind and body experienced in old age ( Black's Law Dictionary (6th Ed)) while testamentary incapacity is something else altogether. A testator may not possess those qualities of the mind in the highest or in his former degree. His mind may be debilitated and his memory may be enfeebled. But yet, there may be enough left to discern and to judge of all things and all those circumstances which enter into the nature of rational, fair and just testament. It is only when 'they have so far failed as that these cannot be discerned and judged of, (that) he cannot be said to be of sound disposing mind and memory' [ Den v Vancleve
]. It means that senility, a (common) cause of mental impairment, cannot be automatically equated with testamentary incapacity.

In the instant case, there was no evidence that the infirmity of mind and body experienced by the deceased, although some degree of senility given his age could not be denied, had perverted his sense of right, prevented the exercise of his natural faculties or so deluded his mind when he executed the 1990 wills that if he was of sound mind he would not have made it. There was no evidence that the feebleness of mind and body incidental to old age and poor health had so impaired the intellectual faculties of the deceased that he lacked the testamentary capacity to contract on 24 October 1990. Say Bee and Beng Tatt's testimony that the deceased was senile from 1992, or for that matter from 1990, was not the cogent evidence of testamentary incapacity.

Dr Tan's five certificates deposed that the deceased, on the five occasions that he examined him, was of sound disposing mind. But Dr�Tan's certificates did not depose that the deceased was not suffering from any infirmity resulting from deterioration of mind and body experienced in old age. Accordingly, Dr Tan's certificates did not disprove Say Bee and Beng Tatt's testimony that the deceased was senile. Say Bee and Beng Tatt did not depose that the deceased lacked the testamentary capacity. There was no contradiction between Dr Tan's certificates deposing to sound disposing mind and Say Bee/Beng Tatt's testimony that the deceased was senile.

Richard produced receipts showing that he was in Kuala Lumpur on 3 August 1992. Mr Koh contended that Beng Tatt who testified that Richard was in Pykett Avenue on 3 August 1992 at about the time of the execution of the 1992 wills was therefore not a reliable witness. Maybe, Beng Tatt was wrong with regard to that (minor) aspect of his testimony. Nevertheless, Beng Tatt was right on the dot with regard to the rest of his testimony and on all critical issues. He was dead on about the 1989 deed, about the meeting at E & O Hotel, about Howard bringing out documents for signature on 3 August 1992, Lim taking possession of the documents signed on 3 August 1992, Lim handing him documents after 3 August 1992 for the signatures of the deceased and Dr Gafoor, the execution after 3 August 1992 of documents relating to wills by the deceased and Dr�Gafoor, the execution after 3 August 1992 of documents relating to wills without the joint presence of the attesting witnesses, all large payments to Cheng Poon and his family, the Malaysian accounts of the deceased, about Glashaus Sdn Bhd, the instructions of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd to Tan Chiew Hun to secure a purchaser for Pykett Avenue at the price of RM16,215,760, the RM866,000 promised to three sons, the interests paid to Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat, the redemption of the Teluk Bahang land, the monthly maintenance to the sons and grandchildren, the termination of the monthly maintenance to Cheng Hum, Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat, Cheng Liat being barred from Pykett Avenue, about the RM140,000 taken by Cheng Poon, the offer for the Benson land, and practically about everything else. Given that preponderant accuracy in his testimony, Beng Tatt could only come across as a reliable witness, even though he could have been wrong about Richard being in Pykett Avenue on 3 August 1992. After all, one swallow does not make a summer. And surely, Beng Tatt, as is the case of any witness, was not expected to give perfect evidence.

Both Say Bee and Beng Tatt were exhaustively examined. Both emerged with their credibility intact. In any event, why would they not speak as a matter of factly? Howard accused Say Bee and Beng Tatt of having been suborned by his uncles. But both deserved better. Say Bee had served the deceased for 50 years. That was not the hallmark of a man of fleeting loyalties and shifting allegiance. All day and night, Say Bee cared for the deceased at LWE Hospital and Mount Elizabeth Hospital. That was devotion beyond the call of duty. Beng Tatt was also a trusted employee of long standing. Reasonably, both would not betray the memory of the man they gave yeoman service. And anyway, Cheng Bok who had no money for his (third) marriage and Cheng Liat who was an undischarged bankrupt from 1990 to 1997 would not have had the money to buy witnesses. Even Howard who said that Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat did not have the money to help pay the taxes of the US estate recognized that his uncles were not financially sound. In contradistinction, Cheng Poon and his family were Mr Moneybags. Surely, if Say Bee and/or Beng Tatt would sell their soul for gold, it would have been logical for them to be on Cheng Poon's side. Cheng Poon was near and Cheng Poon and his family were already in de facto control of the estate. After all, Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat at best could only promise while Cheng Poon could be much more tangible. It was not unnoticed that Say Bee and Beng Tatt remained in court, quite unlike witnesses who had perjured and would have made themselves scarce, throughout the rest of the proceedings as if in vigil. Nay, Say Bee and Beng Tatt were just two respectable and credible witnesses. There was no reason for them to take sides. As Beng Tatt tersely answered Mr Koh who suggested that he (Beng Tatt) had prepared himself to lie in court: 'Personally, I have nothing against the first to third defendants. They have treated me well. Richard has also invited me to work for Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd. There is no reason for me to lie in court. I was summoned … I am here to tell the truth.'

Likewise, Say Bee and Beng Tatt's testimony would only support the case of testamentary capacity. According to Say Bee, in 1991, the deceased was still replying his letters. However, by the end of that year (1991) the deceased was forgetful and could not express himself. From January 1992, the deceased was not registering the letters read to him nor instructing his replies, although sometimes he would ask what was read to him. Even on 3 August 1992, the deceased was able to understand questions put to him, as he said 'curry and bread', a totally judicious answer, when Say Bee asked what he wanted to eat. According to Beng Tatt, it was only from February 1992 that the deceased was not able understand the reason for the cheque he was signing; before that, the deceased would ask the reason for each payment. In 1990, the deceased was able to instruct Beng Tatt to prepare the letter barring Cheng Liat from Pykett Avenue — DB1(B)(9). In July 1992, the deceased was able to instruct Beng Tatt to pay interests to Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat and to pay RM40 for a Justice of the Peace tie he ordered.

Truly, not one of the witnesses supported testamentary incapacity. Dr Gafoor who said that the deceased was his patient between 1990 to 1992, testified that the deceased returned his greeting on 3 August 1992. He said that the deceased 'read the 1992 wills himself'. Dr Francis testified that the deceased after he regained consciousness appeared very alert and was able to talk on 13 July 1992. In the morning of 14 July 1992, the deceased was talking reasonably and lucidly. On 16 July 1992, the deceased who was rambling on 15 July 1992 was more his usual self and was showing interest by reading the newspapers. On 22 July 1992 and 27 July 1992, the deceased was clear and lucid. He was able to understand and answer Dr Francis.

Clearly, the evidence even without Hamid and Dr Tan was already overwhelmingly for sound disposing mind. But Hamid and Dr Tan's testimony could not not be believed. Perhaps Hamid was wrong about Ghazi Ishak reading the 1990 wills to the deceased on 24 October 1990. Otherwise, Hamid's testimony was totally substantiated. His account of the relationship between the deceased and his wife, the 1989 deed and the codicil, the meetings in Singapore, Kuala Lumpur and at E & O Hotel, Nik Saghir's advice, the 1990 wills, the deceased accusing Cheng Liat of poisoning him and then barring Cheng Liat from Pykett Avenue, his three visits to Pykett Avenue after July 1992, the sales proceeds payable to Cheng Bok, Cheng Poon and Cheng Liat from the sale of the Batu Ferringhi land, the RM866,000 paid to Cheng Poon and the interests paid to Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat, his telephone call to Pykett Avenue, the cars, the overdraft from the BBMB, Dr Tan's certification of sound disposing mind, the sale and aborted sale of the Ayer Itam lands and Cheng Hum's payments to Cheng Poon and Cheng Liat, the trip to London, his visit to the Benson land in Arizona, the offer from Tri-Am International Inc, and the mental stability of the deceased was corroborated by credible witnesses and or by established evidence. Never was Hamid discredited. There was no reason to disbelieve him. And according to Hamid, in June 1992 the deceased said to him that he (the deceased) had no money to pay 45% of the sales proceeds (Batu Ferringhi land) to his three sons and the deceased asked him (Hamid) to convey that to Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat. In July 1992, Hamid was with the deceased in Kuala Lumpur. That was clear evidence that the deceased had his faculties even in June 1992.

Mr Yeoh contended that the certificates deposing to the sound disposing mind of the deceased could not be relied on. He berated the good doctor for not recording his clinical findings. He contended that the medical certificates in the absence of the clinical findings had no probative value whatsoever. Thus far, Mr Yeoh was engaging in fair and legitimate criticism. Then astonishingly, Mr Yeoh contended that Dr Tan's testimony that the deceased informed him of the coming changes to his wills was a lie. He contended that the deceased never related the coming testamentary changes that Dr Tan recorded; those testamentary changes, he contended, were related by the persons who accompanied the deceased. With respect, Mr Yeoh had forgotten that it was not put to Dr Tan that the deceased never spoke of the testamentary changes that Dr Tan recorded or that Dr Tan's testimony was a lie; since Dr Tan's was not challenged, it was too late, at the stage of submissions, to put what was not challenged and therefore not in dispute into controversy. Accordingly, Dr Tan's testimony of his conversations with the deceased on all five occasions could not be denied. In any event, no interested third parties accompanied the deceased on 24�October 1990. Whatever recorded by Dr Tan Could only have been related by the deceased himself — according to Dr Tan, and it was adduced by Mr Yeoh, Lim who accompanied the deceased on 24 October 1990 remained silent throughout the medical examination. The contention that Cheng Poon or third parties related the coming testamentary changes that Dr Tan recorded and attributed to the deceased had no evidential basis whatsoever. There was not an iota of evidence for such a contention.

The absence of clinical findings was not in issue during the examination of the witness. But assuming it was, it did not put the certificates into doubt. After all, the certificates were not inconsistent with the established evidence. There was no reason to doubt the testimony of the witness. There was never any suspicion of testamentary incapacity. The deceased's desire for a penile prosthesis though lascivious was not abnormal. The occasional quirk was not insanity. Rather, in July 1992, the deceased even had the mental capacity to discuss the drug to be administered to Cheng Been. As Dr Tan said, '(the deceased) was talking normally, like a normal person'.

There was no evidential basis to accept the contention that the lacuna infarct (it was not in 1990), progressive intellectual loss, age and the medication over the years must have reduced the mental capacity of the deceased to the extent that the 1990 wills were not wills of the deceased. The disorientation and confused state was redressed in 1987. There was no evidence that the deceased was incapable of making a will in October 1990. The evidence of credible witnesses present when the deceased executed the 1990 wills and of Dr Tan (and they were not merely witnesses called into his presence for a few moments) were of considerable weight. The state of mind of the deceased, at the immediate time at which the 1990 wills were executed and at the intermediate stages of his life, was affirmatively sound and stable. There was no disorder of the mind that poisoned his affection, perverted his sense of right, prevented the exercise of his natural faculties. The deceased was old, and his mind may be in some degree debilitated, and his memory might have become in some degree enfeebled; but there was more than enough to discern and discreetly to judge, of all things and all those circumstances which enter into the nature of rational, fair, and just testament.

Mr Yeoh beseeched the court to inquire if the certificates were orchestrated by those who would profit from those certificates and from the ensuing wills. Dr Tan testified that the deceased informed him on 23�October 1987 that he (the deceased) was afraid that his children would challenge his mental capacity and he (the deceased) wanted him (Dr Tan) to certify to his mental fitness. Dr Tan was not challenged. Then, it would appear that the deceased anticipated, even as early as 1987, that his children would challenge his mental capacity, and that the deceased had prepared himself and procured the medical certificates to foil his children who would challenge his mental capacity. And those certificates could not be disregarded, even though Dr Tan admitted that the mental condition of the deceased could fluctuate even on the day of the certificate, for it must be reasonably assumed, because there was no history of any psychotic intervals, that the mental capacity of the deceased, even though assuming that it could fluctuate on the day of the certificate, would not instantly plummet to total testamentary incapacity.

In summary, the evidence could only be synthesized into the one inescapable conclusion that the deceased had testamentary capacity. Cheng Hum's testimony on the health of the deceased — not good, suffering from depression, insomnia, palpitation of the stomach, Parkinson's disease, heart problems and prostate cancer — was not the cogent evidence that the deceased lacked the testamentary capacity. Cheng Hum's testimony on the mental health of the deceased — 'starring blankly and not knowing what he was doing, 50% of the time, he was normal and 50% of the time he was abnormal, during lunch he ate quietly, after lunch, he would lie on the sofa without talking, the deceased could not understand the contents of the 1990 wills' — if it was Cheng Hum's proof of testamentary incapacity, was totally against the weight of the evidence. Despite whatever was submitted at length on the poor health, poor memory, senile dementia aggravated by the loss of wife, assorted ailments and heavy medication, it was ineluctable that the deceased had never lost his mental capacity. Witness after witness reinforced that fact that was only opposed by a bare assertion, from Cheng Hum.

The plaintiffs showed that none of the beneficiaries had a hand in the preparation of the 1990 wills.
