Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat testified that they did not know of the preparation and execution of the 1990 wills. They were not challenged. Hamid testified that the deceased was the only person who instructed him on the 1990 wills. Hamid was not challenged. And it was unchallenged evidence as well that Cheng Poon did not know of the 1990 wills until after the safe was opened.

What was the proof that Cheng Hum and Grace supplemented? Both the 1990 and 1992 wills only bequeathed token legacies to Cheng Hum. In both wills, Grace was not a beneficiary. Then, the 1990 or 1992 wills as the true last will of the deceased would leave them, and them alone, out in the cold. Reasonably and even understandably, neither the 1990 nor 1992 wills should interest Cheng Hum or Grace.

Cheng Hum pinned his misfortune and his spats with the deceased at Cheng Poon's door. The following was what Cheng Hum who considered himself the favourite son until the deceased was poisoned against him said. His relationship with his parents deteriorated after Cheng Poon's marriage in 1963. Cheng Poon was constantly insinuating to the deceased that he (Cheng Poon) was a more capable son. He did not rebut Cheng Poon, as his parents would only listen to Cheng Poon. His relationship with the deceased did not improve after 1990 It got a bit worse. It was all due to Cheng Poon's instigation and influence over the deceased. Cheng Poon was saying that he (Cheng Hum) had no son to carry on the family name. His relationship with his parents, up to 1988, did not improve. In 1988, at Cheng Poon's instigation, the deceased forced him to sell his Ayer Itam lands and to give RM130,000 to Cheng Liat and Cheng Poon. He could not refuse. At Cheng Poon's instigation, the deceased also forced him to sell three pieces of lands in Bukit Tengah, Butterworth. That sale was aborted. Because of Cheng Poon's influence, deceased refused to help him refund the deposit. Sometime in 1990, Cheng Poon instigated the deceased to instruct him to sell the remaining Ayer Itam lands. He was similarly threatened that he would be disowned. That time, he refused as the price offered was half the market value. The deceased told him not to come to Pykett Avenue anymore. Thereafter, he stopped going to Pykett Avenue and stopped visiting the deceased. He wanted to continue his visits, but he was afraid that Cheng Poon would continue his instigations and he would be forced to sell his lands once more. After he stopped visiting Pykett Avenue, his monthly allowance was terminated at the instigation of Cheng Poon. He did not believe that his father had stopped his visits. He believed that Cheng Poon was behind those instructions. He had no knowledge of the 1990 and 1992 wills. He got to know of those wills after Cheng Bok filed these proceedings. He did not believe that his father would leave him RM20,000. The deceased, a kind and loving father, was not vindictive. The deceased would have been fair and would not leave him much less than his brothers. He believed, because of his experience with Cheng Poon, it was all due to Cheng Poon's instigation. The deceased depended on Hamid for advice on the sale of properties. Hamid was close to Cheng Poon and Cheng Liat. Hamid was close to the son who was having the upper hand. Cheng Liat held the upper for a short six months in 1990. Then, Hamid was closer to Cheng Liat than Cheng Poon. After that six months, Cheng Poon was on the ascendant. He knew nothing of his brothers' trip to Singapore in 1990 with the deceased. His brothers were arranging the distribution of his father's assets to his (Cheng Hum) detriment. It was a case of 'less man more share'. He could not agree with Cheng Bok's reasons for his exclusion from the 1990 wills. 'Cheng Bok gave those reasons with an ulterior purpose.' Only Cheng Poon could have instigated the deceased's letters claiming his properties. On his own, the deceased could not have authorized those letters. The deceased was not a man who would even attempt to take back what he had given. The deceased gave those properties to him. The deceased was a man of his word. Those letters were instigated by Cheng Poon to pressurise him into concurring with the sale of the Ayer Itam land. Cheng Poon could influence the deceased. Cheng Poon even made decisions for the deceased. His brothers could get the upper hand more easily if they enlisted Hamid's help.

It was not undiscerned that Cheng Hum's testimony was more of a ventilation of his anger for his disadvantageous position than of any real complaint of any undue influence in the making of the 1990 wills. He blamed Cheng Poon for the deterioration beginning 1963 of his relationship with his father. He said that his relationship did not improve but rather got worse because of Cheng Poon's instigation and influence. He said that Cheng Poon was saying that he (Cheng Hum) had no son to carry on the family name. He said his relationship with his parents, up to 1988, did not improve. Next, he blamed Cheng Poon for the sale of his Ayer Itam lands, the RM130,000 paid to Cheng Liat and Cheng Poon, the sale of his lands in Bukit Tengah, Butterworth, the attempts to force him to sell his remaining Ayer Itam lands, the threats to disown him, the attempts to claim back the properties given him, the termination of his monthly allowance and the instruction barring him from Pykett Avenue. He said that his father would not leave him RM20,000 but would have been fair and not leave him much less than his brothers. He believed it was all due to Cheng Poon's instigation. Cheng Poon could influence the deceased and even made decisions for the deceased, he said. Blame was pinned all round. Surprisingly, Cheng Hum uttered not a word that the 1990 wills were procured by undue influence.

Mr Yeoh exhorted that Cheng Poon's influence over the deceased and the deceased's trust in Hamid were the principal reasons for the 1990 wills and that the 1990 wills were not wills of the deceased but were procured by the importunity of Cheng Poon and Hamid. He asserted that the deceased fell prey to Cheng Poon's manipulations after the death of Ooi Geen Peen.

The gravamen for that hypothesis was the alleged importunity of Cheng Poon and Hamid. As said, those alleging undue influence must prove it. But there was no evidence that undue influence had been exercised in relation to the 1990 wills. There was no evidence that the other brothers, either jointly and or severally, had obtained Hamid's help in procuring the 1990 wills. There was no evidence that importunity, be that of Cheng Poon and or Hamid, had been visited and or inflicted upon the deceased into making the 1990 wills, or that Cheng Poon was involved in the preparation of the 1990 wills. There was no evidence, and it was also not shown, that Cheng Poon's influence over his father had been exercised in relation to the 1990 wills. Hamid testified that only the deceased instructed him to prepare the 1990 wills and that none of the sons knew of the 1990 wills. Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat testified that they had no knowledge whatsoever of the preparation and execution of the 1990 wills. And there was no evidence that Cheng Poon and Hamid had banded together and exerted their respective influence on the deceased. True, Cheng Poon did not refute Cheng Hum's allegations. Yet, all that could be reasonably inferred was that Cheng Hum's allegation that Cheng Poon was the cause of his rift with the deceased could not be denied. But that adverse inference, even meaning that Cheng Poon out-maneuvered Cheng Hum, could not extend, unrestrained, to an inference that the 1990 wills were not wills of the deceased.

In truth, all that Cheng Hum had related were circumstances — Cheng Poon's influence over the deceased, the deceased's trust in Hamid — that might not have served his interests. But that were not the only circumstances attending the execution of the 1990 wills. The entire circumstances attending the execution of the 1990 wills were not consistent with them having been procured by undue influence. Cheng Poon might have worked himself into a position of great influence. Cheng Poon, Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat might have agreed to an equal distribution of their father's estate. Yet, the pertinent issue was what the deceased intended and whether the 1990 wills expressed the mind of the deceased and not what the beneficiaries wished and even legitimately strived for.

Cheng Hum and Grace challenged the righteousness of the 1990 wills. Cheng Hum testified that the deceased would not only have left him RM20,000. However, Hamid testified that the deceased informed him that Cheng Hum was bypassed as he (the deceased) and Lim Swee Eam had given substantial properties to Cheng Hum and that Cheng Hum had no issue. Dr Tan testified that he asked of the deceased what would be given to Cheng Hum and that the deceased replied that Cheng Hum who had already inherited a lot of properties from Lim Swee Eam. Sadly for Cheng Hum, it would appear that the deceased had not forgotten Cheng Hum. He was just set on leaving his eldest son without issue out of his will to correct the imbalance he perceived. And the latter deduction was not inconsistent with Cheng Hum's admission that his relationship with the father deteriorated in 1963 and thereafter only got worse. That is not to say though that the 1990 wills would achieve parity amongst the sons. After all, as Mr Koh rightly submitted, the deceased was entitled to treat his children unequally. The deceased had a penchant for changing his wills. The numerous 'wills' prior to the 1990 wills attested to that predilection. Therefore, the execution of the 1990 wills, just seven months after the 1990 codicil, was not a departure from past predilection. The deceased had declared his intention to leave out Cheng Hum. Therefore, the token provisions to Cheng Hum did not arouse suspicion.

Mr Yeoh pointed out that the deceased did not personally instruct Ghazi Ishak to prepare the 1990 wills and Ghazi Ishak did not explain the 1990 wills to the deceased and that there were differences in the testimony of Hamid and Ghazi Ishak — Hamid testify that Ghazi Ishak read and explained the 1990 wills to the deceased whilst Ghazi Ishak testified that he did not do so; Hamid testified that the deceased gave instructions to Ghazi Ishak prior to 24 October 1990 whilst Ghazi Ishak testified that he only saw the deceased on 24 October 1990. Nevertheless, the preparation of the 1990 wills by a lay person and the difference in the testimony of Hamid and Ghazi Ishak did not compromise the integrity of the 1990 wills. It was unchallenged evidence that the deceased discussed the 1990 wills with Hamid on several occasions and that Ghazi asked the deceased to read the 1990 wills. It was unchallenged evidence as well that the deceased read through the 1990 wills before he set his hand. There was no evidence that the deceased was under the influence of the persons benefiting from his will or that he was not a free agent. Besides, there was no plausible reason for Hamid who was not shown to be tendentious to procure a will solely against Cheng Hum.

There were no circumstances attending or surrounding, or relevant to, the preparation and execution of the will itself that excited the court. Preparation of a will by a lay person is not a circumstance for suspicion. Why the deceased would pick a lay person to prepare his will after going through the trouble of getting a certificate could only be answered speculatively. The civil engineer who assisted Hamid was not a necessary witness to unfold the entire circumstances regarding the preparation and execution of the wills, his absence from the witness-box was not material. The 1990 wills was a departure from the past only with regard to form — it was partitioned into three separate documents. With regard to substance, the 1990 wills was not a radical departure. Ghazi Ishak explained why he did not explain the 1990 wills to the deceased. The deceased who was fluent in the language of the document and had experience with formal deeds and instruments, must reasonably be assumed, when he set his hand, to have read and accepted the provisions of the 1990 wills. It could not be suspected, merely because the deceased did not question nor discuss the document, that he was not aware of the provisions of the 1990 wills, as he had discussed the draft wills and was priorly asked to read each page of the 1990 wills. Indeed, there was no doubt that the deceased had read through the documents. Whether it was read loudly or silently was not of any consequence in the circumstances of the case. There was no material evidence that mere reading, even given the (sketchy) medical history of the deceased, was not enough. Admittedly, there was some inconsistency between the evidence of Hamid and Ghazi Ishak. But even witnesses from the same side are not expected to give replica evidence, and the inconsistency in the instant case was not anything that material and that substantial as could cast doubt on knowledge of the document. There were no circumstances that rebutted the presumption of knowledge by execution.

With respect, all that was so assiduously submitted on Cheng Poon's manipulation and his so-called menacing influence, on the 1986, 1987 and 1989 wills, on the 1989 deed and 1990 codicil, on the meetings in Singapore, on the agreement of the brothers to exclude Cheng Hum, was irrelevant. For even if all that Mr Yeoh submitted were true, it was water under the bridge. If there were any undue influence, menacing influence or manipulation, it was purged by the 1990 wills — the 1990 wills was the break from the past. The fact of the matter was that the 1990 wills were prepared and executed without the knowledge of the children. The fact that the 1990 wills were born quietly, without fanfare and without the knowledge of the beneficiaries and that therefore the deceased could not have been influenced by his beneficiaries only reinforced belief that the 1990 wills was the deed of the deceased. All that was said about the meetings in Singapore, if at all true, could only apply to the 1990 codicil. Undoubtedly, Cheng Poon had influence, in 1990. But that solitary fact was too little for any inference or deduction that Cheng Poon had manipulated the deceased into making the 1990 wills, particularly as there was no evidence that connected Cheng Poon to the 1990 wills.

At any rate, the evidence was that the deceased intended the 1990 wills. Hamid testified that the deceased requested him to prepare the 1990 wills and that the deceased discussed the draft 1990 wills with him on many occasions. Dr Tan testified that the deceased informed of the coming testamentary changes on 24 October 1990. Later in the same day, the deceased attended before Ghazi Ishak and executed the 1990 wills. It was so very clear that the deceased knew and approved of the wills he was executing on 24 October 1990. That conclusion was irresistible and ineluctable.

The circumstances attending the execution of the 1990 wills, as far as could be judged, were not consistent with them having been procured by undue influence. The deceased was not deceived into making them by fraud or constrained to make them by force, threats or other forms of undue influence. The court is satisfied that there was no undue influence and that there were no circumstances that should excite its suspicion and vigilance. There was no question of fraud, and the fact that the 1990 wills were read by the capable the deceased was conclusive evidence that he knew and approved of the contents, and that presumption had not been rebutted.
Moving on, the next pressing issue is whether Cheng Poon and Richard, as the executors and trustees in the true last will of the deceased, be removed as executors and trustees of the estate.

There is no power contained in the 1990 wills to remove any named executor and trustee. There is 'power to revoke a grant of probate or letters of administration … by
s 34
of the Probate and Administration Act 1959 … for any sufficient cause' [ Re Khoo Boo Gong decd
; Khoo Teng Seong v Teoh Chooi Ghim & Ors
[1981] 2 MLJ 68
, per Chang Min Tat FJ]. There is no definition of what is sufficient cause. However, at p 69, Chang Min Tat FJ expressed the view of the Federal Court that if in the words of Jeune, President, In the Goods of William Loveday
[1900] P 154 at p�156
'the real object which the court must always keep in view is the due and proper administration of the estate and the interests of the parties beneficially entitled thereto', then the test of what is sufficient cause, and his Lordship added that it is strictly an objective test, is the due and proper administration of the estate and the interests of the beneficiaries.

Following Re Khoo Boo Gong , Haidar J (as he then was) enunciated, in Jigarlal Kantilal Doshi & Ors v Damayanti Kantilal Doshi & Ors
[1995] 3 AMR 2590
, that 'the court, in the exercise of its power under s 34 … to dispossess a trustee or executor who is willing to act, will be induced to do so only when a strong case is made out [as it] is not for the court to say in whom the trust for the administration of the property shall be reposed'.

There is no direct statutory provision on the power of the court to remove a person named as executor in a will who is willing to act, before the grant of probate. There are only provisions on the appointment of new trustees either in substitution or in addition to existing trustees who are not willing to act or are unfit or incapable.

Section 40(1)
of the Trustee Act 1949 empowers the persons specified in sub-ss (a) and (b) to 'appoint one or more other persons … to be a trustee or trustees in the place of the trustee so the deceased, remaining out of Malaysia, desiring to be discharged, refusing, or unfit or being incapable, or being a minor', whilst
s 45(1)
of the Trustee Act 1949 empowers the court under the stated circumstances to 'make an order appointing a new trustee or new trustees [but not an executor or administrator —
see s 45(3)
of the Trustee Act 1949] either in substitution for or in addition to existing trustees, or although there is no existing trustee'.

In the Estate of Lum Yoon Kow decd, Lum Hor Choong v Hew Lye Heong & Lam Cheok Tong
[1936] MLJ 136
, in an application to remove a trustee and to appoint new trustees, Whitley J, observing that the appointment and removal of trustees were not specifically included amongst the matters which may be determined under s 68 of the Civil Procedure Code, held that the words 'the determination of any question arising in the administration of the estate or trust' comprised in the general cl (g) was wide enough to include the appointment and removal of trustees.

A similar judicial devise, the giving of a wide interpretation, was also employed in Rachael Mei Ling Ong & Anor v Dato' Bruno Henry Almeida (as the executor for the estate of Ong Soon Hoe, deceased)
[1998] 6 MLJ 258
, in an application to have the defendant removed and/or substituted as the executor/trustee before the grant of probate, where Kamalanathan Ratnam�JC (as he then was) held that O 80
r 2(3)(e)
of the Rules of the High Court 1980 is wide enough to give the court the general power to remove or substitute an executor or trustee from such capacity.

The closest direct provision on the power of the court to remove any person named as executor in any will before the grant of probate is
s 40
of the Probate and Administration Act 1959 which reads:

The Court shall have the power to summon any person named as executor in any will to prove or renounce probate of the will and do such other things concerning any will as the High Court in England could do.

The recourse in general to English Law is provided in
s 3(1)
of the Civil Law Act 1956 which reads:
Save so far as other provisions has been made or may hereafter be made by any written law in force in Malaysia, the Court shall —
(a) in West Malaysia or any part thereof, apply the common law of England and the rules of equity as administered in England on the 7th day of April 1956;

Provided always that the said common law, of equity and statutes of general application shall be applied so far as the circumstances of the States of Malaysia and their respective inhabitants permit and subject to such qualifications as local circumstances render necessary.

In England, courts undoubtedly have that jurisdiction to remove an executor or trustee before the grant of probate. In Re Chetwynd's Settlement, Scarisbrick v Nevinson
[1902] 1 Ch 692
, Farwell J held that in an action to administer a trust, the court has inherent jurisdiction to discharge a trustee whilst in Re Bridgman
29 LJ Ch 844
, it was held that an application to remove a trustee on the ground of vexatious conduct must be made by bill. 'Where there is no dispute of fact, the court in the exercise of its statutory power to appoint new trustees ( s 41 of the
English Trustee Act 1925
which is in pari materia with s 45 of the Malaysian Trustee Act) may order the removal of a trustee against his will in proceedings begun by originating summons ( Re Henderson, Henderson v Henderson
[1940] Ch 764
, 3 All ER 295; Re A Solicitor
[1952] 1 All ER 133
, where a solicitor was removed from the trusteeship of the clients' account). Where there is a dispute of fact, the proper course is to invoke the court's inherent jurisdiction over trustees in an action begun by writ …' [48 Halsbury's Law of England (4th Ed) para 784].
That being the undoubted position, the local jurisdiction has similar inherent jurisdiction to remove a trustee.
Halsbury's Law of England (4th Ed) Vol 48 para 783 imparts the following commentary on the removal of a trustee by the court:

The court will remove a trustee, including the trustee of a foreign settlement, where he refuses to execute the trust [ Palairet v Carew
(1863) 32 Beav 564
; Luke v South Kensington Hotel Co
(1879) 11 Ch D 121
] or has mismanaged the trust [ Ex Parte Phelps
(1742) 9 Mod Rep 357
; Ex Parte Reynolds
(1800) 5 Ves 707
; Peatfield v Benn
(1853) 17 Beav 522
] or has disqualified himself by his circumstances or conduct from continuing to hold the office [ Millard v Eyre
(1793) 2 Ves 94
] or may perhaps do so if his continuance in office would be likely to be detrimental to the trust owing to his being out of sympathy with its objects [ A-G v Hardy
(1851) 1 Sim NS 338
at p 357
] and with the beneficiaries. A trustee will not, however, be removed against his will on account of a pecuniary embarrassment which has ceased to exist and which does not appear to have imperiled the interests of the beneficiaries [ Re Bridgman
(1860) 8 WR 598
].

Story's Equitable Jurisprudence , s 1289 has the following commentary which was cited with approval by the Privy Council in Letterstedt (now Vicomtesse Montmort) v Broers & Anor
(1884) 9 AC 371
:

… it is not indeed every mistake or neglect of duty or inaccuracy of conduct of trustees, which will induce Courts of Equity to adopt such a course. But the acts or omissions must be such as to endanger the trust property to shew a want of honesty, or a want of proper capacity to execute the duties, or a want of reasonable fidelity.

In Yusof bin Ahmad & Ors v Hongkong Bank (Singapore) Ltd & Ors
[1990] 2 MLJ 326
, Chan Sek Keong J (as he then was) held that a trustee who failed to comply with the directions of the testator may be removed by the court even if no harm has been done to the beneficiaries or to the trust. 'Friction or hostility between trustees and the immediate possessor or the trust estate is not of itself a reason for the removal of the trustees' [ Letterstedt v Broers & Anor
at p 389, per Lord Blackburn]. However, where the acrimonious relationship between parties was compounded by the failure of the trustees to properly discharge their duties in the interests of the estate or beneficiaries, the court held that there was 'sufficient cause' to revoke the probate [ Jigalal Kantilal Doshi & Ors v Damayanti Kantilal Doshi & Ors
].

Much was said by the plaintiffs' witnesses against Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard. But much was also said by Richard and Howard that did not reflect well on their conduct as executors and trustees. There ought to be no complaints from Cheng Poon's side if only Richard and Howard's testimony is considered. First, it should be said that Cheng Poon and Richard were not accountable for Howard's conduct. But there was a oligarchy in Pykett Avenue, Howard's conduct as an executor and trustee could not but also reflect on Cheng Poon and Richard, and Howard's conduct, though he is not a trustee under the 1990 wills could not be regarded.

It should not be lost that Cheng Poon, Richard or Howard, either jointly and severally, were administering the estate (in Thailand and the US) or petitioning for probate of the estate (in Malaysia). Richard was and is the Managing Director of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd and the Thai company. In all their acts and deeds, with regard to the estate, Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd and the Thai company, they were dealing with estate property and they had to account to the estate and the beneficiaries. They were in de facto control of the entire estate. All three conducted themselves as the (majority) executors and trustees of the deceased. Richard and Howard petitioned and were granted probate of the Thai estate whilst Howard petitioned and was granted probate of the US estate. Cheng Poon and Richard were the only directors of Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd. Richard is also the Managing Director of the Thai company. They were the only persons with actual knowledge of the affairs of the estate and with a fiduciary duty to inform the other beneficiaries. Against that backdrop, their conduct should be judged.

Lest it is not obvious, 'it is the first duty of an accounting party, [including a trustee] … to be constantly ready with his accounts [ Pearse v Green
(1819) 1 Jac & W 135
, per Plumer MR]. He must not only keep proper accounts, and allow a cestui que trust to inspect them, he must also, on demand, give a cestue que trust information and explanations as to the investment of and the dealings with the trust property [ Springett v Dashwood
(1860) 2 Giff 521
]. Some cases apparently lay down that the trustees must, prima facie actually render an account to each cestui que trust, and that it is not enough merely to make an offer to him, or his accountant, or some other person, to inspect and take copies' ( Equity and the Law of Trusts (4th Ed) by Philip H Pettir, p 492).

With regard to the Thai estate and Thai company, Richard showed he was totally inept, said on the basis it was not intended, as an executor and trustee, as he had not the faintest idea of his duties. He admitted that he could not provide the Thai accounts as at the date of death of the deceased. He admitted that he did not know he had to provide such an account. He admitted that for the past four years he had not shown the accounts of the Thai company to any of the plaintiffs.

Richard also showed he was dishonest. He admitted that from April 1996, as Managing Director of the Thai company, he was receiving an unauthorized monthly salary of Baht40,000. He admitted that he knew he had to have the approval of the company. He admitted that he had not informed the plaintiffs of that Baht40,000 salary.

There were other transgressions, and it could either have been ineptness or dishonesty, as well. Richard said that it was not true that the deceased had a lot of money in Thailand but he would not furnish any account. Richard revealed that he took charge of the Thai company after the resignation of the Thai manager and that the rentals from Thai properties was about Baht150,000 per month. Nevertheless, he has not rendered an account of the rentals received. Richard related that Cheng Poon, Howard, himself, his sister, Cheng Liat and the Thai manager are the present directors of the Thai company. But he admitted that there was no meeting to appoint his sister and Howard as additional directors. He admitted that his father appointed his sister and Howard as additional directors. He admitted that he did not inform the other beneficiaries of the appointment of the additional directors. He admitted that he did not inform the beneficiaries of the tenancy agreement between Khaw Bian Cheng Sdn Bhd and Glashaus Sdn Bhd a company in which his mother is a director.

With regard to the petition for probate in Thailand, perhaps Richard and Howard had valid reason, because of Thai inheritance laws and because a petition for probate could be in the estate's interests, to prosecute their petition for probate despite Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat's objections. Richard agreed that the plaintiffs applied, in 22-271-94, to restrain his application for probate in Thailand. But he admitted that the first to third defendants had not disclosed, in 22- 271-94, that they were yet proceeding with the petition for probate in Thailand. He admitted that he did not inform the other beneficiaries of the proceedings in the Thai courts as he and the other beneficiaries were not on speaking terms. He admitted that he did not see it fit, at any time, to inform the Thai courts of the plaintiffs' actions in Malaysia or to disclose to the Malaysian courts of the petition in Thailand. Surely, that could not have been the conduct of an impartial executor and trustee?

Richard also showed he was not of truthful character. He testified that the deceased disliked jewellery and never wore rings or watches. 'His passion was cars.' The latter was said in answer to questions on the watches of the deceased. He was contradicted by his witness (Yeoh Keat Chye) who testified that he would normally drive the deceased to watch shops. Richard testified that his family disposed off their cars, even though after the recovery action (22-299-95) was filed, to raise money but not to avoid the recovery action. But he did not explain why funds were so urgently needed to be raised by the sale of their cars when his family had millions in their pockets. On the other hand, the overpowering impression from Richard's testimony was that the cars were sold to avoid the recovery action. Richard agreed that he sold the BMW after he received Cheng Bok's letter, inter alia, enquiring whether the BMW was the property of the estate. It was improbable that that sale of the BMW 735 was not a reaction to Cheng Bok's letter. Richard said that the Toyota Estima purchased in 1991 was sold in 1994 as his family could not afford the instalments. Even that was improbable, as the Toyota Estima purchased on instalments terms in 1991 would have little unpaid in 1994 and Richard's family with their millions were well able to settle the remaining instalments and/or redeem the car. Richard did not offer any reason for the sale of the Rolls- Royce, Mercedes Benz 380, the Ladybird, Peugeot, Chrysler Alpine and such other cars there were. He said that notices were sent to the plaintiffs of the meetings in Thailand but also said that he had not held any meetings in Thailand. When he was asked, 'so, your family did as it pleased', he offered no answer. He testified that none of the 146/147 lands of the Thai estate had been sold, charged or pledged. It turned out that the estate had 131/132 lands; 15 had been sold; one had been charged by Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard on or about 12 July 1996.

Howard conducted the affairs of the US estate through proxies. At the expense of the estate, he retained the services of an attorney (Douglas Newman) and an accountant (Gary Hockman) to assist him. He said that he sold the Benson land and the Racquet Club condominium in Arizona, with the approval of the US courts, to pay US taxes. But he had no respect whatsoever for Malaysian courts. On 25 May 1995, he was served with an injunction restraining him from selling the properties of the estate. Yet, he concluded the sale of Racquet Club condominium. For that, he was found in contempt of court by Hamid J. He would not render any account of the US$237,000, approximately, being the sum received from the sale of the Benson land and Racquet Club condominium and from the Malaysian and Thai estates, any of the plaintiffs. It was only produced in the course of the trial by DW8. Before he was formally appointed by the courts in the respective jurisdictions, he received Cheng Bok and Cheng Liat's notice of withdrawal of consent to his appointment as the legal representative of the US estate and Cheng Bok's notice of withdrawal of consent to his application for probate in Thailand. Yet, he proceeded with both petitions. The following exchange should be highlighted:

row.entry: The excuse in the States was to pay taxes. What is the excuse for the petition, despite the protests of the plaintiffs, to proceed in Thailand?

p.text: He applied to the US courts for administration of Ooi Geen Peen's estate in the US. On 10 May 1995, he was appointed the administrator of Ooi Geen Peen. He did not inform the other beneficiaries. He did not inform the plaintiffs of any of the proceedings in Thailand.

Howard was less than genuine in the witness box. He was totally abandoned. On a flimsy ground — 'After the sale (Teluk Bahang land) to the buyer obtained by Hamid felled through, Hamid blamed Richard and�I as the cause of him being out of the deceased's favour. He (Hamid) was upset over his (financial) loss …' — he accused Hamid of having given false evidence to take it back on his family. Knowing there was no factual basis, he accused Hamid and Dr Gafoor of having conspired to fabricate their evidence — Howard: 'Dr Gafoor was introduced by Hamid Merican. They are very close friends as well as business associates. Hamid Merican, I believe, Dr Gafoor to lie. I have no factual basis for what I say'. Knowing it was not true, since he was party to the resolution on 12 July 1996 authorising the charge of one of the Thai properties, he testified that none of the Thai properties had been sold and that no dealing had been entered into. And as said, he intemperately accused Say Bee and Beng Tatt of having been suborned by his uncles.

It was so clear that Richard and Howard run the Thai and US estates as their fiefdoms. The beneficiaries were not informed. The beneficiaries were not given accounts. The beneficiaries were ignored. Objections were of no consequence. The receiver and manager received little co-operation and was pushed from lawyer to lawyer. Court orders were disobeyed. A�clandestine petition (Estate of Ooi Geen Peen) for probate was made without the knowledge of the other beneficiaries. Salaries were taken without lawful authority. Additional family members (Howard and Gim Chuan) were appointed without lawful meetings. A large sum (the rental from Thai properties) remains unaccounted for. And that is only going by the account of Richard and Howard from the witness box.

On the basis that more than RM40,000 was spent on the funeral of the deceased, Mr Khoo submitted that the beneficial interests of Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard under the 1990 or 1992 wills should be forfeited.
Clause 3 of the 1990 Malaysian will reads as follows:

I direct my trustees to spend not more than Malaysian Ringgit Forty Thousand (RM40,000) for my funeral which should conform to Chinese custom such as using Chinese coffin of hard wood and the performance of 'Choo Soon' and 'Kong Teik' ceremonies.
Clause 12 of the 1990 Malaysia will read as follows:

All persons mentioned in this will shall act in accordance with my order as stated in this will. Anyone neglecting to act accordingly shall have his rights in this will forfeited from receiving his share of the estate, and his portion of his entitlement shall revert to the estate.
An identical provision is found in both the 1990 Thai and US wills.

However, the plaintiffs did not plead that the beneficial interests of Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard should be forfeited for their failure to comply with the direction of the deceased on the total expenses of his (the deceased) funeral. It only transpired in the course of the trial (during the examination of Beng Tatt) that an additional sum of about RM14,000 could have been spent by the Thai estate on the funeral expenses. But even if it was true that Cheng Poon, Richard and or Howard had expended more than RM40,000 on the funeral, the plaintiffs never sought to amend their pleadings. Accordingly, there was never any notice to the other party that the plaintiffs would be seeking an order on that ground. And even if the pleadings had been amended, it was not satisfactorily proved that a sum of more RM40,000 was spent on the funeral. Other than the accounting entry that was disputed by Howard, there was no other evidence that more than RM40,000 could have been spent on the funeral. Surely, with a singular accounting entry, and even that disputed, and whereas the order of a forfeiture would be draconian, the court should be slow in acting on a solitary bit of disputed evidence and in ordering any forfeiture.
There is a prayer for exemplary damages, and Mr Khoo submitted that this is a proper case for the award of exemplary damages; he proposed RM5m.

Generally damages are directed to the compensation of the plaintiff for the harm done; exceptionally, a plaintiff may look also to the punishment of the defendant. Such damages are variously called punitive damages, vindictive damages, exemplary damages, even retributory damages. They can only apply where the conduct of the defendant merits punishment, which is only considered to be so where his conduct is wanton, as where it discloses fraud, malice, violence, cruelty, insolence or the like, or, as is sometimes put, where he acts in contumelious disregard of the plaintiff's rights. The torts where exemplary damages are most likely to feature are those which affect the person, rather than those which affect property, since outside personal injury, the former require intentional, even malicious, conduct on the part of the tortfeasor. Beyond this, however, the courts have allowed exemplary damages in torts which affect property, where there has been a wanton intentional interference by the defendant ( Mayne & McGregor on Damages (12th Ed) paras 207-208; see also McGregor on Damages para 406).

Lord Devlin in Rookes v Barnard & Ors
[1964] AC 1129 at p 1226
restricted the award of exemplary damages to situations where they are 'oppressive, arbitrary or unconstitutional actions by servants of the government' or where 'the defendant's conduct has been calculated by him to make a profit for himself which may well exceed the compensation payable to the plaintiff' and where statute expressly authorized it [see also Cheng Hang Guan & Ors v Perumahan Farlim (Penang) Sdn Bhd & Ors
[1993] 3 MLJ 352
].

In the instant case, there was no evidence that Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard's conduct was calculated to make a profit for themselves which would exceed restitution. The restitution of the cars/sale proceeds and 'monetary gifts' would adequately compensate the estate. That Cheng Poon and Richard would not be executors and trustees itself would be some form of punishment. The executors and trustees of the estate would not be estopped, should they uncover any so far unrevealed torts against the estate whilst it was under the management of Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard, from bringing a suit on behalf of the estate. Still, there was wanton disregard of the rights of beneficiaries [see Ooi York Choo v Lim Song Foundry
[1963] MLJ 87
, where the court awarded exemplary for the defendant's wanton disregard of the plaintiff's rights over her land] that cannot be condoned. That all beneficiaries (save for Cheng Hum and Grace who had their own agenda) were united in their cause was genuine demonstration of their utter dissatisfaction with their so-called trustees. It is imperative that the first to third defendants be punished to express the court's abhorrence at their shabby and deplorable treatment of beneficiaries in whose name they assumed the character of trustees. Having regard to the facts and circumstances of the case and to the substantial worth of the estate, an award of RM500,000 as exemplary damages which would not cripple Cheng Poon, Richard and Howard would be just and adequate.

In the premises of all that has been said, the court pronounces for the force and validity of the last will and testament dated 24 October 1990 of Khaw Bian Cheng, the deceased in this action and pronounces against the force and validity of the alleged last will and testament dated 3 August 1992 of the said Khaw Bian Cheng (for an order for and against a will and the grant of probate to the trustees, see 32 Atkin's Court Form s (2nd Ed, 1996 Issue) Form 125).

that Cheng Poon do pay the sum of RM934,063.70 (being RM197,000, RM512,063.70 and RM225,000) the estate;

that Cheng Poon do execute a good and registrable memorandum of transfer of lands known as Holding Nos 6767 and 678, Mukim 2, Daerah Barat Daya, Penang (Teluk Bahang land) in favour of the executors and trustees of the estate and do deliver the said duly executed memorandum of transfer together with the document of title to the executors and trustees within 30 days from the date hereof, failing which, the learned senior assistant registrar do execute the said memorandum of transfer and the Registrar of Titles do cancel the present title and issue a new title;

that all monetary awards hereinbefore shall carry interests at the rate of 8% per annum from the date of filing of the respective claims (save that the award of exemplary damages shall carry interests from 1�June 1998) till date of satisfaction.
